description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management and prepare for the Agile Foundation examination accredited by BCS.

We start with a downloadable introduction to the services which outlines the contents of the syllabus.
descriptionMD:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management and prepare for the Agile Foundation examination accredited by BCS.

We start with a downloadable introduction to the services which outlines the contents of the syllabus.
name: Agile Project Management Concepts
subtitle: Agile Foundation

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management and prepare for the Agile Foundation examination accredited by BCS.

We start with a downloadable introduction to the services which outlines the contents of the syllabus.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.111 --> 00:00:05.052
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.052 --> 00:00:08.900
Welcome everyone to
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

3
00:00:08.900 --> 00:00:11.240
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:11.240 --> 00:00:12.270
Today, we'll be with Mrs.

5
00:00:12.270 --> 00:00:16.850
Joe Peacock, taking a look at different
methodologies associated with Agile.

6
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:19.720
And I'm super excited because this is
something that I've always wanted to

7
00:00:19.720 --> 00:00:22.190
learn, so thank you so
much for joining us Joe.

8
00:00:22.190 --> 00:00:25.120
Could you take a moment to tell us
a little bit about who should be watching

9
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:28.480
this show, if we're gonna be
attaching a certification to this.

10
00:00:28.480 --> 00:00:30.330
Are we studying for
a particular certification?

11
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:31.820
Things like that.

12
00:00:31.820 --> 00:00:33.340
>> Sure.
Well, thanks Cherokee,

13
00:00:33.340 --> 00:00:35.760
it's great to be with you this week.

14
00:00:35.760 --> 00:00:38.920
So, what we're gonna be looking
at in this particular series is,

15
00:00:38.920 --> 00:00:42.350
as Cherokee said,
Agile Project Management.

16
00:00:42.350 --> 00:00:46.370
We're going to look at the basics
of Agile Project Management.

17
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:49.350
Agile actually encompasses
quite a few methodologies.

18
00:00:49.350 --> 00:00:53.835
So we're going to be looking at each of
those methodologies in turn and very,

19
00:00:53.835 --> 00:00:54.732
very briefly.

20
00:00:54.732 --> 00:00:56.953
This is just a concept series.

21
00:00:56.953 --> 00:01:00.948
We're going to be looking at the
difference between the Agile methodology,

22
00:01:00.948 --> 00:01:04.464
and the Traditional Waterfall
approaches to project management.

23
00:01:04.464 --> 00:01:07.511
Such as Prince two and PMI.

24
00:01:07.511 --> 00:01:10.260
And we're going to be
preparing if you want to,

25
00:01:10.260 --> 00:01:14.700
we're gonna be preparing for
the Agile Foundation Certification.

26
00:01:14.700 --> 00:01:17.620
But obviously that's if you want to,
and if you just want to

27
00:01:17.620 --> 00:01:21.860
gain some experience in Agile Project
Management, learn a little bit about it.

28
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:25.553
Understand what it is that your
organizations doing, or maybe prepare for

29
00:01:25.553 --> 00:01:28.484
that really important job
interview that you got lined up,

30
00:01:28.484 --> 00:01:30.494
then this is definitely the place to be.

31
00:01:30.494 --> 00:01:31.902
>> Perfect, thank you so much Joe.

32
00:01:31.902 --> 00:01:35.109
I'm super excited to get started on
the series, and good luck to you, and

33
00:01:35.109 --> 00:01:36.060
let's get started.

34
00:01:36.060 --> 00:01:41.957
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: This episode answers the question "what is Agile" and explores the differences between the Agile approach to project management and traditional waterfall approaches such as Prince2 and PMP.
episodes.title: What is Agile?
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:04.101
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.101 --> 00:00:05.913
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.913 --> 00:00:08.661
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.661 --> 00:00:11.094
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.094 --> 00:00:15.720
>> Welcome, everyone, to your
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

7
00:00:15.720 --> 00:00:17.740
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.740 --> 00:00:21.262
In this episode we'll be taking a look
at a very important question, and

9
00:00:21.262 --> 00:00:22.834
that is, well, what is Agile?

10
00:00:22.834 --> 00:00:24.394
And of course, we have Mrs.

11
00:00:24.394 --> 00:00:27.580
Jo Peacock in studios today
to help answer that question.

12
00:00:27.580 --> 00:00:29.040
How are you doing today, Jo?

13
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:30.660
>> I'm absolutely fine,
thank you, Cherokee.

14
00:00:30.660 --> 00:00:31.340
How are you?

15
00:00:31.340 --> 00:00:31.970
>> I''m doing great.

16
00:00:31.970 --> 00:00:33.910
I'm super excited to be
in studios with you.

17
00:00:33.910 --> 00:00:35.560
It's been a while since
I've seen you last.

18
00:00:35.560 --> 00:00:37.490
>> It has.
>> Since the show started.

19
00:00:37.490 --> 00:00:40.388
Brand new series,
really cool topic, Agile.

20
00:00:40.388 --> 00:00:43.416
I do have some background
in project management, but

21
00:00:43.416 --> 00:00:47.895
I'm really hoping that you can expand
that, and show me the Agile way of life.

22
00:00:47.895 --> 00:00:52.560
>> [LAUGH] Right, okay, well in Agile
we like to do things on an incremental

23
00:00:52.560 --> 00:00:57.070
basis and we like sort of short
deliveries and quick deliveries as well.

24
00:00:57.070 --> 00:01:02.130
So we're gonna try and deliver this
particular class in an Agile way.

25
00:01:02.130 --> 00:01:03.200
>> Perfect, yeah.

26
00:01:03.200 --> 00:01:04.530
>> That's exactly what we do here.

27
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:05.445
>> So where are we gonna start?

28
00:01:05.445 --> 00:01:09.310
>> Well, we're gonna start with just
really understanding a little bit about

29
00:01:09.310 --> 00:01:11.195
Agile, where Agile came from.

30
00:01:11.195 --> 00:01:13.830
>> And a bit of a history lesson?

31
00:01:13.830 --> 00:01:15.980
>> Exactly,
that's exactly what it's going to be.

32
00:01:15.980 --> 00:01:20.480
And certainly if you're studying for
your Agile Foundation Certification,

33
00:01:20.480 --> 00:01:23.930
then you will need to have this
little bit of a history lesson.

34
00:01:23.930 --> 00:01:26.590
So yeah, we're gonna take
you back in time, Cherokee,

35
00:01:26.590 --> 00:01:31.650
and it's gonna be back in time by quite
a long way as well, about 18 years now.

36
00:01:31.650 --> 00:01:36.618
So we're gonna just take a brief look at
where Agile came from and then we're gonna

37
00:01:36.618 --> 00:01:40.938
move into the concept of just what Agile
is and why is it so different from

38
00:01:40.938 --> 00:01:45.783
the traditional waterfall approaches
that you mentioned earlier on, right?

39
00:01:45.783 --> 00:01:47.745
Take a look at this slide
in front of you now.

40
00:01:47.745 --> 00:01:51.695
You'll see that actually
Agile's been around since 2001.

41
00:01:51.695 --> 00:01:53.395
And prior to 2001,

42
00:01:53.395 --> 00:01:57.715
we had sort of the traditional waterfall
approaches to project management.

43
00:01:57.715 --> 00:02:00.805
But you see, the problem was as far
as the organization is concerned,

44
00:02:00.805 --> 00:02:02.494
as far as the business is concerned,

45
00:02:02.494 --> 00:02:07.180
traditional waterfall approaches didn't
deliver anything quick enough for them.

46
00:02:07.180 --> 00:02:08.160
You know what it's like.

47
00:02:08.160 --> 00:02:13.520
We're in the 21st century now, and
when somebody wants a solution or

48
00:02:13.520 --> 00:02:18.180
they want an answer to a problem that they
have, they generally want it yesterday.

49
00:02:18.180 --> 00:02:22.100
The other thing that happens is
that in a day to day environment,

50
00:02:22.100 --> 00:02:26.990
you'll find that I mean, let's face it,
products are updated on a frequent basis.

51
00:02:26.990 --> 00:02:29.200
How often do you get
yourself a new cellphone?

52
00:02:29.200 --> 00:02:31.920
>> I know, right, and actually,
I find it odd that that word there,

53
00:02:31.920 --> 00:02:34.655
evolve is pretty significant.

54
00:02:34.655 --> 00:02:38.671
Or I guess it's just ironic in this
situation, because even looking at I see

55
00:02:38.671 --> 00:02:41.639
it's stemming from software
development practices.

56
00:02:41.639 --> 00:02:46.595
And I don't know if you work in any
capacity dealing with software development

57
00:02:46.595 --> 00:02:47.740
or for a company.

58
00:02:47.740 --> 00:02:52.640
Here at ITProTV, we certainly do,
and the project that you

59
00:02:52.640 --> 00:02:56.170
might start on may look a little bit
different by the time you finish,

60
00:02:56.170 --> 00:02:59.660
which in the past, when you talk
about traditional project management,

61
00:02:59.660 --> 00:03:03.870
you stick and
adhere to that scope really tightly.

62
00:03:03.870 --> 00:03:06.890
But that's not the case here,
is it, so much, Jo?

63
00:03:06.890 --> 00:03:07.770
>> It's not.

64
00:03:07.770 --> 00:03:10.450
And the other thing about,
you mention sticking to the scope,

65
00:03:10.450 --> 00:03:12.620
but how long does
a traditional project take?

66
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:16.060
It can take six months,
maybe if it's a very small project.

67
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:17.570
It could take two years.

68
00:03:17.570 --> 00:03:21.390
And what happens is that the customer,
the business or whoever it is that's

69
00:03:21.390 --> 00:03:25.670
asking for that deliverable,
has asked for it probably six months ago.

70
00:03:25.670 --> 00:03:30.590
They defined the scope, and then as you
said, that scope is then cast in stone.

71
00:03:30.590 --> 00:03:31.930
But then they hear nothing.

72
00:03:31.930 --> 00:03:35.220
And maybe there is a little bit of
communication throughout the project, but

73
00:03:35.220 --> 00:03:37.770
they hear nothing for two years.

74
00:03:37.770 --> 00:03:41.470
And then two years later all of a sudden
this new product has been delivered.

75
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:44.950
The problem with that is that by
the time it's delivered sometimes,

76
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:46.710
in a traditional waterfall approach,

77
00:03:46.710 --> 00:03:51.250
by the time that's delivered it's out
of date and things have moved on.

78
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:55.310
And so way back in 2001, as it says
on the screen in front of you right

79
00:03:55.310 --> 00:04:00.750
now, software developers and

80
00:04:00.750 --> 00:04:05.340
the project management sort of
gurus at the time got together and

81
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:10.340
they created a manifesto for
Agile software development.

82
00:04:10.340 --> 00:04:13.530
And we're gonna look at
that in another episode.

83
00:04:13.530 --> 00:04:17.530
But basically they acknowledged that
traditional waterfall approaches,

84
00:04:17.530 --> 00:04:23.440
whilst they had their place,
they weren't particularly, well, agile.

85
00:04:23.440 --> 00:04:25.050
In other words, they couldn't be changed.

86
00:04:25.050 --> 00:04:28.080
And so what happened was they
were subject to scope creep.

87
00:04:28.080 --> 00:04:32.550
And in these traditional waterfall
approaches, you're finding that

88
00:04:32.550 --> 00:04:37.170
the scope was cast in stone but
then people wanted to make changes.

89
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:41.640
And there was no defined way,
should I say,

90
00:04:41.640 --> 00:04:46.870
of incorporating those changes into
the project without a big upheaval.

91
00:04:46.870 --> 00:04:51.917
So Agile was born, and
the Agile manifesto was created,

92
00:04:51.917 --> 00:04:55.191
as we said there, back in 2001.

93
00:04:55.191 --> 00:04:57.645
And it was by industry experts.

94
00:04:57.645 --> 00:05:01.250
The idea of Agile is that we focus,
that bottom bullet point,

95
00:05:01.250 --> 00:05:05.835
focuses on delivery through evolution and
iteration of requirements.

96
00:05:05.835 --> 00:05:08.285
And it's about adaptive planning.

97
00:05:08.285 --> 00:05:11.970
It's about acknowledging
that things change.

98
00:05:11.970 --> 00:05:16.500
And in a project environment we
cannot afford to be too rigid.

99
00:05:16.500 --> 00:05:19.990
What we're here to do
as a service provider,

100
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:24.660
as a business unit within an organization,
is to deliver value.

101
00:05:24.660 --> 00:05:26.350
That's what we're here to do.

102
00:05:26.350 --> 00:05:28.370
And let's be honest about this.

103
00:05:28.370 --> 00:05:33.360
If your organization doesn't perceive
value in anything that you do,

104
00:05:33.360 --> 00:05:35.670
they're gonna find somebody else to do it.

105
00:05:35.670 --> 00:05:39.500
And this is what was happening is that
a lot of organizations way back then and

106
00:05:39.500 --> 00:05:44.790
even now were outsourcing a lot of
their development purely because

107
00:05:44.790 --> 00:05:49.950
development teams that were adopting
waterfall approaches were seen to be

108
00:05:49.950 --> 00:05:53.080
too cumbersome, too bureaucratic.

109
00:05:53.080 --> 00:05:54.890
And so we needed something.

110
00:05:54.890 --> 00:05:58.450
And we needed something that was going
to allow us to respond to the needs of

111
00:05:58.450 --> 00:05:59.350
the organization.

112
00:06:00.382 --> 00:06:04.610
What you've got to understand is
that Agile is not a single approach.

113
00:06:04.610 --> 00:06:08.590
In fact, there are lots of
methodologies within Agile and

114
00:06:08.590 --> 00:06:10.470
we're going to look at
those in the next slide.

115
00:06:10.470 --> 00:06:14.770
But we're going to go a little bit more
in-depth into each one of those as we move

116
00:06:14.770 --> 00:06:16.640
through next episodes.

117
00:06:17.780 --> 00:06:19.500
Agile is not a single approach.

118
00:06:19.500 --> 00:06:23.340
Agile is more of a mindset.

119
00:06:23.340 --> 00:06:28.250
It's a way of introducing
a project in a iterative way.

120
00:06:28.250 --> 00:06:31.350
It's a group of methodologies
that encompasses many.

121
00:06:31.350 --> 00:06:35.240
But it's all about having a pragmatic
mindset and it says there,

122
00:06:35.240 --> 00:06:38.600
a flexible approach, pragmatic, realistic.

123
00:06:38.600 --> 00:06:41.840
Realistically acknowledging
that things are gonna change.

124
00:06:41.840 --> 00:06:46.630
And not trying to cast everything in stone
and say this is the way it's going to be

125
00:06:46.630 --> 00:06:51.465
right at the very start of a project, and
they're carrying on down that road without

126
00:06:51.465 --> 00:06:56.505
even acknowledging that the path that
you've chosen might need to change.

127
00:06:56.505 --> 00:06:59.355
But without even acknowledging
that actually what we want to

128
00:06:59.355 --> 00:07:01.575
achieve is completely different.

129
00:07:01.575 --> 00:07:03.900
You see, the business changes.

130
00:07:03.900 --> 00:07:09.110
And in a traditional waterfall project, it
doesn't really allow for too much change.

131
00:07:09.110 --> 00:07:10.443
And if the business changes,

132
00:07:10.443 --> 00:07:13.919
then surely we've got to change to be
aligned with the needs of the business.

133
00:07:13.919 --> 00:07:14.970
>> Right.

134
00:07:14.970 --> 00:07:18.510
>> And the other problem that we've
got is that technology changes,

135
00:07:18.510 --> 00:07:23.010
too, and it's not just the business but
our suppliers change on a regular basis.

136
00:07:23.010 --> 00:07:27.630
And when I say they change, what I mean
is they change what they supply us with.

137
00:07:28.790 --> 00:07:31.312
How often do you update the operating
system on your cell phone?

138
00:07:31.312 --> 00:07:32.345
>> On my cell phone?

139
00:07:32.345 --> 00:07:34.258
>> Yeah.
>> Quite often I can update.

140
00:07:34.258 --> 00:07:34.866
>> Right.

141
00:07:34.866 --> 00:07:36.730
>> I mean, I don't have to manually do it.

142
00:07:36.730 --> 00:07:40.630
I get a notification,
it's time to update and we're good to go.

143
00:07:40.630 --> 00:07:44.560
>> So let's imagine then if you were using
a traditional waterfall approach, and

144
00:07:44.560 --> 00:07:48.590
you were creating an app for a cell phone.

145
00:07:48.590 --> 00:07:49.920
>> Okay.

146
00:07:49.920 --> 00:07:53.970
>> So we'd start off with, and I'm just
gonna use something that's familiar to me,

147
00:07:53.970 --> 00:07:55.520
we start off with iOS.

148
00:07:55.520 --> 00:07:57.461
I don't know,
let's say we start off with iOS7.

149
00:07:57.461 --> 00:07:58.220
>> Okay.

150
00:07:58.220 --> 00:08:03.080
>> And we start to design
our new app based on iOS7.

151
00:08:04.380 --> 00:08:06.966
What do we do when iOS8 comes along then?

152
00:08:06.966 --> 00:08:09.310
>> I'm gonna have to go
back to the drawing board.

153
00:08:09.310 --> 00:08:11.730
>> Right, but
how much time have we wasted?

154
00:08:11.730 --> 00:08:16.540
>> Well, from the beginning of my project
to that time that that update came out.

155
00:08:16.540 --> 00:08:20.150
>> Exactly, and
then we go back to the drawing board and

156
00:08:20.150 --> 00:08:22.280
we start to do all of
the design work again.

157
00:08:22.280 --> 00:08:27.384
And we might even be halfway through
development when iOS 9 comes out.

158
00:08:27.384 --> 00:08:28.510
And then we're back again.

159
00:08:28.510 --> 00:08:29.572
>> I see your point, Jo.

160
00:08:29.572 --> 00:08:32.244
[LAUGH]
>> And so we're not saying that

161
00:08:32.244 --> 00:08:35.880
the traditional waterfall approach
to project management doesn't work.

162
00:08:35.880 --> 00:08:37.690
We're not saying that at all.

163
00:08:37.690 --> 00:08:41.620
What we're saying is that there
are times when it doesn't work, and

164
00:08:41.620 --> 00:08:43.890
there are times when
clearly it doesn't work.

165
00:08:43.890 --> 00:08:48.790
And the thing is, that your business and
your users, they expect rapid change.

166
00:08:48.790 --> 00:08:50.740
They expect rapid development.

167
00:08:50.740 --> 00:08:54.710
That's what they get in a day-to-day
environment with their cell phones,

168
00:08:54.710 --> 00:08:59.300
with their operating systems on their
laptops, they get rapid development.

169
00:08:59.300 --> 00:09:02.860
>> So we're able to meet those versions.

170
00:09:02.860 --> 00:09:06.360
Whenever that versioning starts to roll
out, we're able to approach it and

171
00:09:06.360 --> 00:09:07.353
handle it properly.

172
00:09:07.353 --> 00:09:09.760
>> Right, and
that's exactly what Agile is about.

173
00:09:09.760 --> 00:09:14.690
Agile is about accepting that we're
going to do development in increments,

174
00:09:14.690 --> 00:09:18.600
and that with each increment
we build on the last.

175
00:09:18.600 --> 00:09:21.970
And with each increment we make progress,
but

176
00:09:21.970 --> 00:09:24.310
we're not trying to do
everything all at once.

177
00:09:24.310 --> 00:09:25.080
>> Okay.

178
00:09:25.080 --> 00:09:28.450
>> That's what Agile's about, and
that's where the pragmatic bit comes in,

179
00:09:28.450 --> 00:09:32.530
is the fact that acknowledging that
you don't wanna start off right from

180
00:09:32.530 --> 00:09:35.980
the very beginning, go back to the drawing
board every time there's been a change.

181
00:09:35.980 --> 00:09:40.431
And there are so
many influences to changing a project.

182
00:09:40.431 --> 00:09:44.615
>> Right, customer needs, it doesn't
just have to focus around updates or

183
00:09:44.615 --> 00:09:47.970
environment changes, but
a lot of external factors.

184
00:09:47.970 --> 00:09:50.410
>> Right, and we can't influence them.

185
00:09:50.410 --> 00:09:52.470
And that again is down to
that pragmatic approach.

186
00:09:52.470 --> 00:09:56.653
We can't influence those external factors,
because we can turn onto the business and

187
00:09:56.653 --> 00:09:59.760
say no, you're gonna stick with
this iOS and what will happen?

188
00:09:59.760 --> 00:10:01.273
They'll be-
>> The competitor is like no,

189
00:10:01.273 --> 00:10:02.880
I'm already two steps ahead of you.

190
00:10:02.880 --> 00:10:05.190
So we're gonna go ahead
with the competitor then.

191
00:10:05.190 --> 00:10:08.950
>> Right, and the business is gonna go
somewhere else and yeah, we've lost out.

192
00:10:08.950 --> 00:10:11.450
And the next thing you know,
we're kind of, well,

193
00:10:11.450 --> 00:10:14.070
I was gonna use the word redundant,
but that's a British word.

194
00:10:14.070 --> 00:10:17.930
We're kind of surplus to requirements now,
okay?

195
00:10:17.930 --> 00:10:21.430
So the other thing about Agile is,
we mentioned the word pragmatic, and

196
00:10:21.430 --> 00:10:22.660
we've been talking about that.

197
00:10:22.660 --> 00:10:27.310
The word flexible, again, allowing for
change, that's what Agile is about,

198
00:10:27.310 --> 00:10:29.050
it's allowing for change.

199
00:10:29.050 --> 00:10:34.820
>> So we've got quite a few methodologies
that we actually consider to be Agile.

200
00:10:34.820 --> 00:10:40.280
So we've got Scrum, you've got XP,
you've got Lean, you've got Kanban.

201
00:10:40.280 --> 00:10:44.030
We're going to look at
those in more detail

202
00:10:44.030 --> 00:10:46.100
a little bit later in other episodes.

203
00:10:46.100 --> 00:10:49.170
We're just gonna be taking a quick look,
very,

204
00:10:49.170 --> 00:10:52.650
very high level to those
particular methodologies.

205
00:10:52.650 --> 00:10:56.140
So Agile is not actually
a methodology in its own right,

206
00:10:56.140 --> 00:11:00.360
it's about a mindset, and it's about
the way that we approach projects.

207
00:11:00.360 --> 00:11:01.745
And there are, we said that,

208
00:11:01.745 --> 00:11:04.880
lots of methodologies that will
approach projects in that way.

209
00:11:07.050 --> 00:11:10.290
So let's just take another look at
those two words that we just spent

210
00:11:10.290 --> 00:11:12.150
a bit of time talking about there,
Cherokee.

211
00:11:12.150 --> 00:11:17.841
This pragmatic mindset also takes
into consideration the fact that,

212
00:11:17.841 --> 00:11:19.100
you know what?

213
00:11:19.100 --> 00:11:22.360
We don't know everything right now and
we don't know the future, and

214
00:11:22.360 --> 00:11:24.370
I hate to get into cliches.

215
00:11:24.370 --> 00:11:27.880
But the only thing that you know about the
future is that the future's gonna change.

216
00:11:27.880 --> 00:11:33.020
Yeah, I know that's a cliche and I hate
to get into those, but it's so true.

217
00:11:33.020 --> 00:11:35.060
And we don't know what
our suppliers are doing.

218
00:11:35.060 --> 00:11:36.830
We don't know what our
customers are doing.

219
00:11:36.830 --> 00:11:39.100
We don't know what our
customers are learning.

220
00:11:39.100 --> 00:11:43.445
How many people are actually
watching this right now,

221
00:11:43.445 --> 00:11:46.563
not because they've been told to, but

222
00:11:46.563 --> 00:11:52.152
because they actually want to do
some personal development, right?

223
00:11:52.152 --> 00:11:53.648
>> I know I've, yeah, guilty.

224
00:11:53.648 --> 00:11:56.467
[LAUGH]
>> But there's nothing to feel guilty

225
00:11:56.467 --> 00:11:57.121
about.

226
00:11:57.121 --> 00:11:58.026
>> Yeah, right.

227
00:11:58.026 --> 00:12:01.840
>> And so every time you learn
something new, you want to apply it.

228
00:12:03.380 --> 00:12:05.761
And it's the same with people
in our business as well.

229
00:12:05.761 --> 00:12:10.495
Every time our customer learns something
new or they're exposed to something new,

230
00:12:10.495 --> 00:12:12.530
they want to apply it.

231
00:12:12.530 --> 00:12:17.970
Now I don't know about you, but I'm a bit
of a demon when it comes to new gadgets.

232
00:12:17.970 --> 00:12:20.270
So I've got to have the latest shiny toy.

233
00:12:20.270 --> 00:12:21.420
>> Yeah, you like to try things out.

234
00:12:21.420 --> 00:12:22.758
I've seen some of your toys.

235
00:12:22.758 --> 00:12:23.740
>> [LAUGH] Right.

236
00:12:23.740 --> 00:12:26.180
I've gotta have the latest shiny toy.

237
00:12:26.180 --> 00:12:32.090
But every time I see something on TV,
it's advertised, I have to have that.

238
00:12:32.090 --> 00:12:34.050
I need it in my life.

239
00:12:34.050 --> 00:12:35.870
And this is the problem with our business.

240
00:12:35.870 --> 00:12:37.630
I'm not the only one, by the way.

241
00:12:37.630 --> 00:12:43.470
I am not unique, and manufacturers and
developers will understand that.

242
00:12:43.470 --> 00:12:45.915
And we need to be ahead of the game.

243
00:12:45.915 --> 00:12:48.525
As developers ourselves,
we need to be ahead of the game.

244
00:12:48.525 --> 00:12:53.941
We need to be driving that need
rather than responding to our need.

245
00:12:53.941 --> 00:12:57.015
That's a bullet point talks about
things changing with little warning.

246
00:12:57.015 --> 00:13:03.240
If we allow that change
then to influence us, then

247
00:13:03.240 --> 00:13:08.530
we're responding to the business need, and
that's exactly what we should be doing.

248
00:13:08.530 --> 00:13:10.250
If we bury our head in the sand,

249
00:13:10.250 --> 00:13:14.060
which can be what happens with the
traditional waterfall approach, if we bury

250
00:13:14.060 --> 00:13:17.570
our head in the sand, then we're not
responding to the business needs at all.

251
00:13:17.570 --> 00:13:21.120
We're giving the business
what we want to give them.

252
00:13:21.120 --> 00:13:23.808
And giving them what we wanna give
them is not gonna keep them happy.

253
00:13:23.808 --> 00:13:30.575
And that last bullet point talks
about predicting for the future.

254
00:13:30.575 --> 00:13:35.532
How much time is spent, how much time
is wasted planning for something in

255
00:13:35.532 --> 00:13:41.530
a year's time when the environment is
gonna change completely in six months?

256
00:13:41.530 --> 00:13:44.470
Let's be honest, and
it's part of being pragmatic here.

257
00:13:44.470 --> 00:13:46.580
Your organization doesn't come to you and

258
00:13:46.580 --> 00:13:51.190
ask permission to, say,
merge with another organization, or

259
00:13:51.190 --> 00:13:55.050
to make an acquisition or maybe to
sell off part of the organization.

260
00:13:55.050 --> 00:13:58.550
They don't come to us in IT and
ask for our permission to do that.

261
00:13:58.550 --> 00:13:59.905
And quite often we don't-
>> Yeah,

262
00:13:59.905 --> 00:14:03.625
as much as I'd like to think that
they have to, that's just not.

263
00:14:03.625 --> 00:14:05.086
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right, I mean,

264
00:14:05.086 --> 00:14:08.530
we don't even get to influence
that decision a lot of the time.

265
00:14:08.530 --> 00:14:11.192
>> Right.
>> A lot of the time it's told to us,

266
00:14:11.192 --> 00:14:13.960
that's what's going to happen.

267
00:14:13.960 --> 00:14:16.100
So we have to be able
to respond to change.

268
00:14:16.100 --> 00:14:20.800
And if we don't, yet again,
the organization's gonna go elsewhere.

269
00:14:20.800 --> 00:14:23.640
So Agile is flexible.

270
00:14:23.640 --> 00:14:26.890
And Agile is about keeping
our customers happy, but

271
00:14:26.890 --> 00:14:31.090
making sure that we can deliver software,
that we can develop and

272
00:14:31.090 --> 00:14:36.315
we can deliver software
in an iterative way.

273
00:14:36.315 --> 00:14:40.865
And exactly the same with our cellphones,
with our mobile phones and

274
00:14:40.865 --> 00:14:45.445
an operating system and all of those apps
that nowadays they update themselves

275
00:14:45.445 --> 00:14:49.505
overnight and
you don't even notice that it's happening.

276
00:14:49.505 --> 00:14:51.005
That's where we want to be.

277
00:14:52.085 --> 00:14:55.790
And so we have to adapt our projects,

278
00:14:55.790 --> 00:15:00.760
adapt our delivery, and adapt our
development as the project progresses.

279
00:15:02.430 --> 00:15:06.520
What starts off as being our
deliverable is not always what

280
00:15:06.520 --> 00:15:09.840
ends up as being our deliverable
in a waterfall project.

281
00:15:09.840 --> 00:15:12.500
And in an Agile project,
we acknowledge that.

282
00:15:12.500 --> 00:15:16.040
And we actually plan to adapt,
and funnily enough,

283
00:15:16.040 --> 00:15:19.710
if you plan to change,
then it makes change a lot less painful.

284
00:15:21.220 --> 00:15:23.440
Something else that we don't
like to do in Agile, and

285
00:15:23.440 --> 00:15:26.790
I'm gonna get into this in
some of our other episodes,

286
00:15:26.790 --> 00:15:32.340
is that we do not like to spend too
much time on bureaucracy and red tape.

287
00:15:32.340 --> 00:15:35.770
And in fact, very similar to ITIL for

288
00:15:35.770 --> 00:15:39.950
service management,
we want to remove bureaucracy.

289
00:15:39.950 --> 00:15:44.140
We want to make our development
process more efficient.

290
00:15:44.140 --> 00:15:47.110
We're looking at efficient
delivery of software,

291
00:15:47.110 --> 00:15:49.720
and that's what we're doing with Agile.

292
00:15:49.720 --> 00:15:54.070
So we talk about self-organization,
we talk about

293
00:15:54.070 --> 00:15:59.710
allowing our team to manage
themselves within certain guidelines.

294
00:15:59.710 --> 00:16:03.060
Empowering people, and
we really love that word, too.

295
00:16:04.300 --> 00:16:09.004
So that's an introduction really and
little bit of history to Agile or

296
00:16:09.004 --> 00:16:13.071
where it came from and
just the differences between Agile and

297
00:16:13.071 --> 00:16:17.935
the traditional waterfall approach and
why this flexible approach is so

298
00:16:17.935 --> 00:16:20.830
relevant to business nowadays.

299
00:16:20.830 --> 00:16:25.300
In our next episode, we're actually going
to be looking at that Agile manifesto

300
00:16:25.300 --> 00:16:30.250
that was created back in 2001,
so I hope to see you back then.

301
00:16:30.250 --> 00:16:32.350
Perfect, Jo, thank you so
much for joining us today.

302
00:16:32.350 --> 00:16:36.230
And thank you for joining us as well,
but stay tuned for that next episode.

303
00:16:36.230 --> 00:16:37.641
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

304
00:16:37.641 --> 00:16:38.255
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

305
00:16:38.255 --> 00:16:40.592
>> See you next time at ITProTV.

306
00:16:40.592 --> 00:16:47.838
[MUSIC]

307
00:16:47.838 --> 00:16:50.945
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In these 2 episodes we explore the values of Agile, the 12 principles underpinning the Agile Manifesto, and also the 3 Pillars of Agile.
episodes.title: The Agile Manifesto
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.340 --> 00:00:02.928
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.928 --> 00:00:05.807
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.807 --> 00:00:08.517
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.517 --> 00:00:11.959
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.959 --> 00:00:15.254
>> Welcome, everyone, to your
Agile Project Management Concepts series,

6
00:00:15.254 --> 00:00:17.720
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.720 --> 00:00:21.140
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at the Agile manifesto.

8
00:00:21.140 --> 00:00:25.810
And of course, with us back in studios
today, we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:25.810 --> 00:00:28.200
Thank you for joining us today,
Jo, how are you doing?

10
00:00:28.200 --> 00:00:29.812
>> Absolutely great, thank you, Cherokee.

11
00:00:29.812 --> 00:00:30.980
>> Thank you.
>> How are you?

12
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:31.580
>> I'm doing great.

13
00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:33.890
I'm actually pretty excited to
take a look at this manifesto,

14
00:00:33.890 --> 00:00:36.760
because this is really where
it all started, right?

15
00:00:36.760 --> 00:00:40.460
This was the document that kind
of paved the way and outlined,

16
00:00:40.460 --> 00:00:44.130
I guess what is this,
a best practices that we'll be looking at?

17
00:00:44.130 --> 00:00:44.662
>> Right, so

18
00:00:44.662 --> 00:00:48.702
in the manifesto we're gonna look in this
particular episode at the manifesto.

19
00:00:48.702 --> 00:00:51.866
And then in the next episode we're
gonna look at the principles that

20
00:00:51.866 --> 00:00:53.690
are in the manifesto.

21
00:00:53.690 --> 00:00:58.678
This is really the, I guess,
I don't wanna call it the principles,

22
00:00:58.678 --> 00:01:00.170
because we've got the 12 principles.

23
00:01:00.170 --> 00:01:02.523
This is really our underlying theme,

24
00:01:02.523 --> 00:01:07.754
this is what underpins our job project
management, that's what our manifesto is.

25
00:01:07.754 --> 00:01:12.185
I mean, we call it a statement of values,
really, it's what we value.

26
00:01:12.185 --> 00:01:15.455
And you'll see straightaway,
and in our next episode,

27
00:01:15.455 --> 00:01:19.605
we'll spend a little bit of time looking
at the difference between waterfall

28
00:01:19.605 --> 00:01:24.250
approaches, such as PMI and
PRINCE2, and the Agile approaches.

29
00:01:24.250 --> 00:01:29.340
But really we just do things slightly
differently here in our Agile world.

30
00:01:29.340 --> 00:01:30.250
>> Okay.

31
00:01:30.250 --> 00:01:37.364
>> So we can take a look at the values
right now, and you'll see that we value.

32
00:01:37.364 --> 00:01:40.300
And that's the thing, you've got to put
the word value in front of all of these.

33
00:01:40.300 --> 00:01:45.480
We value individuals and
interactions over processes and tools.

34
00:01:45.480 --> 00:01:48.960
We value working software over
comprehensive documentation.

35
00:01:48.960 --> 00:01:51.500
And we value working together and

36
00:01:51.500 --> 00:01:57.180
collaboration over having a piece
of paper and contract negotiation.

37
00:01:57.180 --> 00:02:00.002
Now that that might be a little
bit strange to some people.

38
00:02:00.002 --> 00:02:00.514
[LAUGH]
>> I-

39
00:02:00.514 --> 00:02:01.027
>> [LAUGH]

40
00:02:01.027 --> 00:02:02.292
>> You saw my face,

41
00:02:02.292 --> 00:02:04.100
because I'm just like, what?

42
00:02:04.100 --> 00:02:07.950
Yeah, if you have a statement of work or
SLA and something binding like that.

43
00:02:07.950 --> 00:02:11.650
But it's okay, I'll trust this process and
I'll let you guide us, Jo.

44
00:02:11.650 --> 00:02:13.322
>> Keep calm, take a breath.

45
00:02:13.322 --> 00:02:14.471
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right,

46
00:02:14.471 --> 00:02:15.985
we'll be okay on this one.

47
00:02:15.985 --> 00:02:16.520
>> Okay.

48
00:02:16.520 --> 00:02:18.780
>> Think about,
back to our previous episode.

49
00:02:18.780 --> 00:02:24.150
In our previous episode we looked at
the fact that when it's cast in stone,

50
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:25.515
you can't change it.

51
00:02:25.515 --> 00:02:27.350
>> Right.
>> Right, so think about the bullet-

52
00:02:27.350 --> 00:02:29.070
>> But that's my mentality right now.

53
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:29.570
>> Right-
>> [LAUGH]

54
00:02:29.570 --> 00:02:30.690
>> But then think about a contract.

55
00:02:30.690 --> 00:02:32.680
How many times have you read the small

56
00:02:32.680 --> 00:02:33.590
print in a contract?

57
00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:36.335
>> Well.
>> That would be a never.

58
00:02:36.335 --> 00:02:36.860
>> This is a-
>> [LAUGH]

59
00:02:36.860 --> 00:02:38.839
>> We're being recorded right now,

60
00:02:38.839 --> 00:02:42.133
so I have to be honest, right?
>> All the time, yeah, all the time.

61
00:02:42.133 --> 00:02:43.280
>> Sure, sounds good.

62
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:44.580
>> Yeah, I mean,

63
00:02:44.580 --> 00:02:47.944
we don't.
We spend a lot of time arguing about

64
00:02:47.944 --> 00:02:52.680
the small print and arguing about
certain words in contracts, etc.

65
00:02:52.680 --> 00:02:54.930
All that time could be spent working, and

66
00:02:54.930 --> 00:02:59.000
let's get together working as a team.
Sometimes with contracts,

67
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:03.330
the wording in contracts, or just there
might be a specific clause in a contract

68
00:03:03.330 --> 00:03:07.380
that might really sort of cause
problems between the two of us.

69
00:03:07.380 --> 00:03:10.409
Just because I don't want it one way and
you want it another way, and

70
00:03:10.409 --> 00:03:11.805
we can't reach an agreement.

71
00:03:11.805 --> 00:03:14.660
Well, we're not going to collaborate
from that moment onwards.

72
00:03:14.660 --> 00:03:15.842
We're not gonna work together as a team.

73
00:03:15.842 --> 00:03:17.045
>> Right.

74
00:03:17.045 --> 00:03:19.426
>> And
we'll take a look at that in a second.

75
00:03:19.426 --> 00:03:22.763
And then the last one is that we
value responding to change over

76
00:03:22.763 --> 00:03:24.340
following a plan.

77
00:03:24.340 --> 00:03:27.640
Now, I'm not gonna tell you that
we don't follow plans, all right?

78
00:03:27.640 --> 00:03:30.060
Everything has to be planned out.

79
00:03:30.060 --> 00:03:35.310
But what we're saying is we respond
to changes, to request for changes.

80
00:03:35.310 --> 00:03:39.494
And to business changes over
sticking rigidly to a plan,

81
00:03:39.494 --> 00:03:44.140
we don't wanna do that, that's-
>> Especially if it's gonna cause

82
00:03:44.140 --> 00:03:48.272
a detriment to the customer,
or can I say project at stake?

83
00:03:48.272 --> 00:03:49.034
>> Yeah.
>> Okay, so

84
00:03:49.034 --> 00:03:52.330
we're still using those terms here, but-
>> It's still a project.

85
00:03:52.330 --> 00:03:53.410
>> Okay.
>> [LAUGH]

86
00:03:53.410 --> 00:03:55.411
>> I'm just making sure,

87
00:03:55.411 --> 00:03:57.919
because different vendors.

88
00:03:57.919 --> 00:04:03.695
But I guess I wouldn't be very Agile if we
had these particular ideals set in stone,

89
00:04:03.695 --> 00:04:04.695
now would it?

90
00:04:04.695 --> 00:04:07.279
>> Well think about it,
you just used the word Agile.

91
00:04:07.279 --> 00:04:08.230
>> Right.

92
00:04:08.230 --> 00:04:09.690
>> And that's exactly what it is.

93
00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:11.970
We're not talking about
an upper case Agile,

94
00:04:11.970 --> 00:04:15.130
we're talking about lower
case agile as well.

95
00:04:15.130 --> 00:04:17.660
It's an agile approach
to project management,

96
00:04:17.660 --> 00:04:20.150
which means it's flexible by it's nature.

97
00:04:20.150 --> 00:04:24.820
We're not trying to
cross all of the t's and

98
00:04:24.820 --> 00:04:28.565
dot all of the i's, and then cast
them in stone and say, that's it.

99
00:04:28.565 --> 00:04:31.755
The project looks like this and
it's never going to change.

100
00:04:31.755 --> 00:04:36.535
We've got to accept that change happens,
and we've got to be able to respond to it.

101
00:04:36.535 --> 00:04:40.785
You bury your head in the sand and just
ignore change, and it's not gonna go away.

102
00:04:40.785 --> 00:04:41.775
>> Right.

103
00:04:41.775 --> 00:04:43.585
>> So think common sense.

104
00:04:43.585 --> 00:04:48.368
I like to think that Agile, and
a lot of our methodologies as well within

105
00:04:48.368 --> 00:04:52.535
IT; in the IT arena,
It's kinda common sense written down.

106
00:04:52.535 --> 00:04:54.300
And you'll hear me say that a lot.

107
00:04:54.300 --> 00:04:57.760
Whether I'm doing consultancy or
whether I'm a student in a classroom.

108
00:04:57.760 --> 00:05:01.620
You will hear me say
the words common sense a lot.

109
00:05:01.620 --> 00:05:05.540
Now I know you can turn around and say to
me that, yeah, but Jo, you don't have any.

110
00:05:05.540 --> 00:05:09.535
[LAUGH] And I'm all right with that, but
that's why I need it written down, right?

111
00:05:09.535 --> 00:05:13.411
[LAUGH] Because we've gotta
write down what makes sense.

112
00:05:13.411 --> 00:05:17.290
And we've got to be able
to apply what makes sense.
