criteria in stories.

339
00:18:04.330 --> 00:18:11.390
But we don't want to jeopardize the
delivery and the time scale, just because

340
00:18:11.390 --> 00:18:14.740
we're producing a lot of documentation
that is just simply not read.

341
00:18:16.290 --> 00:18:20.690
So then our next value, customer
collaboration over contract negotiations.

342
00:18:20.690 --> 00:18:22.030
We already talked about this.

343
00:18:22.030 --> 00:18:25.060
The fact that we've gotta get along.

344
00:18:25.060 --> 00:18:27.776
And sometimes contracts can
prevent us from getting along.

345
00:18:27.776 --> 00:18:31.178
And sometimes contracts
can tell us that well,

346
00:18:31.178 --> 00:18:35.270
we've gotta do it this way or
we've gotta do it that way.

347
00:18:35.270 --> 00:18:37.331
And in fact, that's not
necessarily the way that we work.

348
00:18:37.331 --> 00:18:41.447
>> Yeah, instead of working with Jo's way
and my way, why don't we have an our way?

349
00:18:41.447 --> 00:18:43.296
>> Right, exactly.

350
00:18:43.296 --> 00:18:47.180
So we don't necessarily want
to pin everything down to

351
00:18:47.180 --> 00:18:51.710
a service level agreement or
to a service level target.

352
00:18:51.710 --> 00:18:56.750
Too often, service level targets
by the way are used as a weapon.

353
00:18:56.750 --> 00:18:59.096
And that's, exactly, what we don't want.

354
00:18:59.096 --> 00:19:01.703
That sort of service review
meeting where the customer and

355
00:19:01.703 --> 00:19:04.055
the service provider sits down and
says hey, look.

356
00:19:04.055 --> 00:19:07.430
Everything is green on
our nice chart here.

357
00:19:07.430 --> 00:19:10.700
It tells us that we've achieved
all of our service level targets.

358
00:19:10.700 --> 00:19:12.544
And the customer sits there and
says yeah, but

359
00:19:12.544 --> 00:19:14.530
what about that outage note last night?

360
00:19:14.530 --> 00:19:15.177
>> Right.

361
00:19:15.177 --> 00:19:21.150
>> Right, so you don't want to rely,
too heavily, on those targets.

362
00:19:21.150 --> 00:19:22.960
We want to work together.

363
00:19:22.960 --> 00:19:27.370
And that's why it tells us that
the customer should be part of our team.

364
00:19:27.370 --> 00:19:30.410
And we should be able to
work with our customer.

365
00:19:30.410 --> 00:19:34.990
And we should not allow a piece of
paper and a contract to get in the way.

366
00:19:34.990 --> 00:19:37.138
That's not saying that
we shouldn't have them.

367
00:19:37.138 --> 00:19:38.676
But nevertheless,

368
00:19:38.676 --> 00:19:44.650
they should be flexible enough to allow
the project team to work efficiently.

369
00:19:46.465 --> 00:19:49.850
We gotta make sure that whatever
documentation that we've got and whatever

370
00:19:49.850 --> 00:19:55.090
type of agreement that we have in place
that we evaluate it on a regular basis.

371
00:19:55.090 --> 00:19:58.621
And that we adjust any of
the targets sort of regularly, so

372
00:19:58.621 --> 00:20:00.937
that we know what we're delivering.

373
00:20:00.937 --> 00:20:03.200
And we know when we're
going to deliver it by and

374
00:20:03.200 --> 00:20:05.660
we know the involvement of the customer.

375
00:20:05.660 --> 00:20:09.056
But then what we have written down
in those agreements is not rigid.

376
00:20:11.340 --> 00:20:14.124
And then let's look at this, the last one,

377
00:20:14.124 --> 00:20:17.870
which is responded to change
over following a plan.

378
00:20:17.870 --> 00:20:19.400
And that's our last value statement.

379
00:20:20.440 --> 00:20:23.757
And we've already talked about this at
the beginning about embracing change.

380
00:20:23.757 --> 00:20:27.521
And the fact that the only thing that we
know about technology is that it's gonna

381
00:20:27.521 --> 00:20:29.328
be different, you know about-
>> It's always changing.

382
00:20:29.328 --> 00:20:30.884
>> Right.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

383
00:20:30.884 --> 00:20:34.036
>> Which means that even in
an Agile environment now,

384
00:20:34.036 --> 00:20:37.200
we've gotta get smarter
in an Agile environment.

385
00:20:37.200 --> 00:20:41.364
There was a time back in 2001,
and in sort of the early 2000s,

386
00:20:41.364 --> 00:20:43.989
where Agile was really, really relevant.

387
00:20:43.989 --> 00:20:48.130
And it was seen as the fast
way of delivering software.

388
00:20:48.130 --> 00:20:51.130
But now when you think about how
quickly software is developed and

389
00:20:51.130 --> 00:20:55.050
delivered, even Agile
could be too cumbersome.

390
00:20:55.050 --> 00:20:57.547
>> Yeah, and I'm still trying to
wrap my brain around all the time.

391
00:20:57.547 --> 00:21:01.161
So for someone who has worked in IT for
a very long time,

392
00:21:01.161 --> 00:21:03.920
I'm looking at the way things used to be.

393
00:21:03.920 --> 00:21:05.748
But you can't think like that anymore,

394
00:21:05.748 --> 00:21:08.073
you see Microsoft changing
their business model.

395
00:21:08.073 --> 00:21:10.980
So they're not releasing
operating systems anymore.

396
00:21:10.980 --> 00:21:15.972
They have Windows as a service and
it's on a continual rolling, changing,

397
00:21:15.972 --> 00:21:17.575
evolving schedule.

398
00:21:17.575 --> 00:21:20.849
And that's something that we have to
learn how to adjust with as well.

399
00:21:20.849 --> 00:21:25.848
>> Right, I think that on my personal
professional opinion is that I think

400
00:21:25.848 --> 00:21:29.349
the waterfall approach
to projects definitely,

401
00:21:29.349 --> 00:21:33.930
definitely has its place for
large scale implementations.

402
00:21:33.930 --> 00:21:36.850
But I wouldn't even say it's an industry,

403
00:21:36.850 --> 00:21:40.680
I just think it's a world we're moving
towards the more agile approach

404
00:21:40.680 --> 00:21:44.920
in absolutely everything that we do and
everything that we release.

405
00:21:46.570 --> 00:21:50.166
We also talk about efficiency in Agile and
we really do like that word.

406
00:21:50.166 --> 00:21:53.406
And so we'll say things like if
the software is not being used,

407
00:21:53.406 --> 00:21:55.189
why on earth have you got it there?

408
00:21:55.189 --> 00:21:57.210
And then exactly the same
with documentation.

409
00:21:57.210 --> 00:21:59.790
If you don't refer to it, why is it there?

410
00:21:59.790 --> 00:22:03.160
So remove any software
that's not being used.

411
00:22:03.160 --> 00:22:06.310
If it's not required,
then you don't need it.

412
00:22:06.310 --> 00:22:08.679
And you don't need to be programming and

413
00:22:08.679 --> 00:22:12.173
developing something that's
never ever going to be used.

414
00:22:12.173 --> 00:22:17.456
Now, I like the fact that
we accept continual change.

415
00:22:17.456 --> 00:22:21.060
So we accept change right the way
through to the project ends.

416
00:22:22.120 --> 00:22:26.110
But I also like, the next bullet
point is really important to me,

417
00:22:26.110 --> 00:22:29.543
direct observation,
which provides validated feedback.

418
00:22:29.543 --> 00:22:34.290
I can ask you a question and
I can ask you a question right now.

419
00:22:34.290 --> 00:22:36.711
And I'll say to you something, Cherokee,

420
00:22:36.711 --> 00:22:40.647
along the lines of are you understanding
all of the concepts right now?

421
00:22:40.647 --> 00:22:44.184
>> Yes, I'm just thinking of what so
that was just a rhetorical question?

422
00:22:44.184 --> 00:22:45.434
>> That's a question.

423
00:22:45.434 --> 00:22:47.436
>> A real question?
>> No, no, it's a real question,

424
00:22:47.436 --> 00:22:49.300
>> It sounds great to be able to adapt,

425
00:22:49.300 --> 00:22:53.280
but what if I'm in this continual loop
where you're just not satisfied with

426
00:22:53.280 --> 00:22:55.220
my work and you wanna keep changing.

427
00:22:55.220 --> 00:22:56.148
Am I ever gonna get a break or?

428
00:22:56.148 --> 00:22:58.415
[LAUGH]
>> A simple yes or

429
00:22:58.415 --> 00:22:59.531
no would have done right there,
are you with me?

430
00:22:59.531 --> 00:23:03.506
>> You know I couldn't be that easy,
Jo, that's a good point.

431
00:23:03.506 --> 00:23:07.601
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's just assume she said yes.

432
00:23:07.601 --> 00:23:11.180
>> [LAUGH]
>> The only way I'm really gonna truly

433
00:23:11.180 --> 00:23:16.070
find out whether Cherokee is really
understood what I'm saying is

434
00:23:16.070 --> 00:23:18.790
by seeing if she goes and applies it.

435
00:23:18.790 --> 00:23:20.530
It's the only way I'm gonna find out.

436
00:23:20.530 --> 00:23:21.880
>> Test me, right?

437
00:23:21.880 --> 00:23:23.624
>> Well, I could test you, that's one way.

438
00:23:23.624 --> 00:23:26.872
But then that's just testing
that you understand the theory.

439
00:23:26.872 --> 00:23:29.019
>> Okay, I'm thinking like
a performance-based test.

440
00:23:29.019 --> 00:23:32.842
>> Right, well, yeah,
we don't necessarily like that.

441
00:23:32.842 --> 00:23:36.418
What we want to do is we want to,
we talk about direct observation.

442
00:23:36.418 --> 00:23:39.914
The only way I'm really going to
understand whether you've understood any

443
00:23:39.914 --> 00:23:41.670
of this is to see whether you apply it.

444
00:23:41.670 --> 00:23:45.270
It's to see whether you can use it
in your day to day environment.

445
00:23:45.270 --> 00:23:50.780
And we value direct observation over
asking questions and over the testing.

446
00:23:50.780 --> 00:23:55.270
Because the testing and asking questions,
all that's going to do is that's gonna

447
00:23:55.270 --> 00:23:58.510
show me that you're able
to memorize something or

448
00:23:58.510 --> 00:24:00.310
that you're able to learn something.

449
00:24:00.310 --> 00:24:01.834
It's not gonna tell me that
you're able to apply it.

450
00:24:01.834 --> 00:24:03.261
>> Implement it, right?

451
00:24:03.261 --> 00:24:06.300
>> Right, and some of the most important
conversations happen in break rooms.

452
00:24:07.367 --> 00:24:08.064
True story.

453
00:24:08.064 --> 00:24:10.959
>> That's where we find out whether
you've really understood what we're

454
00:24:10.959 --> 00:24:12.620
talking about.

455
00:24:12.620 --> 00:24:14.460
So we like direct observation.

456
00:24:14.460 --> 00:24:16.940
I like to call it the getting
off your bum principle.

457
00:24:16.940 --> 00:24:19.090
It means get off your bum and go and see.

458
00:24:19.090 --> 00:24:23.794
Go and see what's really happening
rather than just listening to feedback.

459
00:24:23.794 --> 00:24:27.437
>> Something that I think is pretty
cool that our Dev team does is they work

460
00:24:27.437 --> 00:24:29.310
in pairs, but they share systems.

461
00:24:29.310 --> 00:24:34.240
So they have dual monitors for
each one of the collaborators.

462
00:24:34.240 --> 00:24:36.940
So that they can watch each other
doing their work to make sure that

463
00:24:36.940 --> 00:24:38.340
they are staying on track.

464
00:24:38.340 --> 00:24:41.949
I guess kind of like keeping each
other honest like we do here.

465
00:24:41.949 --> 00:24:42.611
>> Right, right.

466
00:24:42.611 --> 00:24:45.632
[LAUGH] Well you know what we're gonna
talk about this in a later episode

467
00:24:45.632 --> 00:24:46.407
funnily enough.

468
00:24:46.407 --> 00:24:48.218
We're gonna talk about
partner development.

469
00:24:48.218 --> 00:24:49.143
>> Okay, cool.

470
00:24:49.143 --> 00:24:52.932
>> So yeah, we'll expand on that, but
yeah, keeping each other in check.

471
00:24:52.932 --> 00:24:55.022
Cuz someone's gotta keep me in check.

472
00:24:55.022 --> 00:24:56.125
Someone's gotta keep an eye on her.

473
00:24:56.125 --> 00:24:58.110
>> It's hard work, but
somebody's gotta do it.

474
00:24:58.110 --> 00:25:00.474
[LAUGH]
>> Right, so and again,

475
00:25:00.474 --> 00:25:06.053
when we talk about embracing change,
that last bullet point looks irrelevant.

476
00:25:06.053 --> 00:25:09.447
Our desires and
our needs as an organization changes,

477
00:25:09.447 --> 00:25:12.060
and they change very rapidly now.

478
00:25:12.060 --> 00:25:15.200
So we need to develop
at a sustainable pace.

479
00:25:15.200 --> 00:25:18.975
We need to accept that we have
got to respond to change,

480
00:25:18.975 --> 00:25:23.340
but we've also gonna try maintain
stability at the same time.

481
00:25:23.340 --> 00:25:27.056
As a development team,
we are responsible for

482
00:25:27.056 --> 00:25:32.020
any instabilities we may cause
in our business environment.

483
00:25:32.020 --> 00:25:36.888
Because if were releasing at such a rapid
pace, that what we're doing is we're just

484
00:25:36.888 --> 00:25:39.740
causing chaos and mayhem-
>> A volatile environment.

485
00:25:39.740 --> 00:25:40.396
>> Right.

486
00:25:40.396 --> 00:25:41.924
>> And a crazy-
>> Yeah, and

487
00:25:41.924 --> 00:25:47.330
you don't build business
confidence by constant change.

488
00:25:47.330 --> 00:25:51.330
So we've got to change in a way, and
this is where it gets really tricky.

489
00:25:51.330 --> 00:25:54.670
You've gotta change in a way that
the business will embrace the change.

490
00:25:54.670 --> 00:25:58.990
But you cannot afford
to create instability.

491
00:25:58.990 --> 00:26:03.865
>> So maybe some kinda rolling
release schedule something like that.

492
00:26:03.865 --> 00:26:08.560
>> And that's exactly what we've got to do
and we'll look at that in another episode.

493
00:26:08.560 --> 00:26:12.449
We'll look at the increments and
the iterations and releases.

494
00:26:12.449 --> 00:26:17.905
And how we actually release in a way
that is acceptable for our business,

495
00:26:17.905 --> 00:26:24.000
but in a way that we can manage as well,
whilst still responding to change.

496
00:26:24.000 --> 00:26:27.640
So we talk about things like
brown bagging lunch bite

497
00:26:27.640 --> 00:26:31.520
session to get our message across.

498
00:26:31.520 --> 00:26:35.190
And to ensure that all of
the businesses engaged

499
00:26:35.190 --> 00:26:37.450
in what it is we're trying to achieve.

500
00:26:37.450 --> 00:26:39.752
>> Does that mean like a working lunch?

501
00:26:39.752 --> 00:26:40.530
>> Yep.
>> Okay.

502
00:26:40.530 --> 00:26:43.154
>> That's exactly like a working lunch,
and we've had plenty of them, right.

503
00:26:43.154 --> 00:26:45.035
>> Yeah, I actually have one today.

504
00:26:45.035 --> 00:26:47.914
>> [LAUGH] That's a hint by the way.

505
00:26:47.914 --> 00:26:50.782
I know I can tell you this.

506
00:26:50.782 --> 00:26:54.825
So the other thing that we've got to
focus on is not over engineering or

507
00:26:54.825 --> 00:26:58.059
not over egging the pudding,
as I would say in English.

508
00:26:58.059 --> 00:26:58.829
>> [LAUGH]
>> See,

509
00:26:58.829 --> 00:27:00.346
while we're talking about language.

510
00:27:00.346 --> 00:27:02.808
It's not over-engineering.

511
00:27:02.808 --> 00:27:05.070
Keep it simple, okay?

512
00:27:05.070 --> 00:27:07.737
Just because you've ticked the box,

513
00:27:07.737 --> 00:27:12.380
or you've checked the box, doesn't mean
that you're actually delivering value.

514
00:27:12.380 --> 00:27:15.110
It just means that you've
actually got to a certain point.

515
00:27:15.110 --> 00:27:19.279
But it doesn't mean that the work that
you've done so far is in any value.

516
00:27:19.279 --> 00:27:22.280
Keep it simple and deliver value.

517
00:27:22.280 --> 00:27:24.800
Prioritize the requirements and

518
00:27:24.800 --> 00:27:29.290
make sure that you don't overload
people with too much work.

519
00:27:30.330 --> 00:27:33.160
Keep it simple and
then we'll deliver value.

520
00:27:33.160 --> 00:27:35.030
>> You like to have little sayings.

521
00:27:35.030 --> 00:27:37.456
Have you ever heard of
the KISS methodology.

522
00:27:37.456 --> 00:27:38.965
>> I have, but
I didn't want to mention that here.

523
00:27:38.965 --> 00:27:41.913
[LAUGH]
>> I don't think we really can go into

524
00:27:41.913 --> 00:27:44.709
detail, but
you guys might have heard about it.

525
00:27:44.709 --> 00:27:47.228
>> Just don't look at the last S.

526
00:27:47.228 --> 00:27:48.270
You'll be fine.

527
00:27:48.270 --> 00:27:51.007
>> [LAUGH]
>> So for this particular episode,

528
00:27:51.007 --> 00:27:51.770
that's it.

529
00:27:51.770 --> 00:27:53.146
We're gonna wrap this one up.

530
00:27:53.146 --> 00:27:58.591
And in our next episode, not our last
though, we're actually going to look

531
00:27:58.591 --> 00:28:03.971
at the 12 principles that underpin
those values in the Agile Manifesto.

532
00:28:03.971 --> 00:28:06.177
>> Perfect, sounds like a plan,
Jo, thank you so much.

533
00:28:06.177 --> 00:28:08.963
And thank you for joining us,
but it is time to sign out.

534
00:28:08.963 --> 00:28:10.484
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

535
00:28:10.484 --> 00:28:11.459
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

536
00:28:11.459 --> 00:28:13.967
>> See you next time here at ITPro.TV.

537
00:28:13.967 --> 00:28:20.039
[MUSIC]

538
00:28:20.039 --> 00:28:26.225
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In these 2 episodes we explore the values of Agile, the 12 principles underpinning the Agile Manifesto, and also the 3 Pillars of Agile.
episodes.title: The Agile Manifesto Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.318
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.318 --> 00:00:07.170
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.170 --> 00:00:08.346
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.346 --> 00:00:13.652
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome, everyone, to your

5
00:00:13.652 --> 00:00:18.352
agile project management concepts series,
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.352 --> 00:00:21.538
So we're actually in a part two,
a continuation,

7
00:00:21.538 --> 00:00:24.760
where we take a look at
agile the manifesto.

8
00:00:24.760 --> 00:00:27.011
And with us today back in studios,
we have Ms.

9
00:00:27.011 --> 00:00:30.390
Jo Peacock, how's it going today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, Cherokee,

10
00:00:30.390 --> 00:00:31.730
how are you?
>> I'm good,

11
00:00:31.730 --> 00:00:36.700
we did start talking about what agile is,
the basics there.

12
00:00:36.700 --> 00:00:40.160
And we started looking at that manifesto,
but we ran out of time.

13
00:00:40.160 --> 00:00:42.790
So are we gonna be picking right
back up here in this show?

14
00:00:42.790 --> 00:00:44.350
>> Right, so in our last episode,

15
00:00:44.350 --> 00:00:48.760
we looked at the values
of the agile manifesto.

16
00:00:48.760 --> 00:00:50.660
And in this particular episode,

17
00:00:50.660 --> 00:00:56.020
we're going to be looking at the 12
principles that underpin those values.

18
00:00:56.020 --> 00:00:59.930
So these are the actual manifesto
principles themselves, and

19
00:00:59.930 --> 00:01:03.300
we're also gonna be looking at
the three pillars of agile as well.

20
00:01:03.300 --> 00:01:06.970
I know that it sounds
like a lot of jargon, and

21
00:01:06.970 --> 00:01:09.630
that's not what it
should be sounding like.

22
00:01:09.630 --> 00:01:12.670
This is, I've already said this
before in previous episodes,

23
00:01:12.670 --> 00:01:17.340
this is kind of common sense written down
when it comes to project management.

24
00:01:17.340 --> 00:01:20.810
However, what we're gonna
be doing is just expanding

25
00:01:20.810 --> 00:01:24.480
the values that we looked
at in our last episode.

26
00:01:24.480 --> 00:01:27.510
And looking at what really underpins them,
and what we should be doing for

27
00:01:27.510 --> 00:01:29.710
each and every project.

28
00:01:29.710 --> 00:01:34.421
So let's jump straight into it then,
we'll look at now, we've got principles

29
00:01:34.421 --> 00:01:38.130
one through to principle six
on the screen in front of you.

30
00:01:38.130 --> 00:01:42.280
There's a lot, there are 12, [LAUGH] so
we can't get them all on one page.

31
00:01:42.280 --> 00:01:46.470
So let's just go through these one by
one and if there are any questions,

32
00:01:46.470 --> 00:01:50.800
then-
>> I'm sure I'll throw them out there and

33
00:01:50.800 --> 00:01:55.940
ask [LAUGH].
>> Right, so I've also for you, and

34
00:01:55.940 --> 00:02:00.290
for everybody else as well, and this will
be available in the downloadable material.

35
00:02:00.290 --> 00:02:03.910
I've highlighted really what we're
concentrating on in each one of these

36
00:02:03.910 --> 00:02:05.090
principles.

37
00:02:05.090 --> 00:02:07.900
Number one, our highest priority, so

38
00:02:07.900 --> 00:02:12.610
therefore it's number one, obviously,
is to keep the customer happy.

39
00:02:12.610 --> 00:02:18.810
Through, it says early and
continuous delivery of valuable software.

40
00:02:18.810 --> 00:02:22.670
And exactly the same as I mentioned
in a previous episode when

41
00:02:22.670 --> 00:02:24.320
we looked at frequent releases.

42
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:27.950
And I asked about updating
your cellphone app, and

43
00:02:27.950 --> 00:02:30.500
how often do you update
that operating system?

44
00:02:30.500 --> 00:02:35.000
And it seems to me that it updates at
least once a month [LAUGH] nowadays.

45
00:02:35.000 --> 00:02:38.580
And that's what we're looking at,
we're looking at continuous delivery of

46
00:02:38.580 --> 00:02:42.810
software, so we're looking at
iterations of software delivery.

47
00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:45.110
Each one must add value, and

48
00:02:45.110 --> 00:02:51.340
each one must build on the improvements of
the last iteration or the last release.

49
00:02:51.340 --> 00:02:53.660
So we're looking at keeping people happy.

50
00:02:53.660 --> 00:02:56.680
The last thing that you want, and
I know that you've suffered this, and

51
00:02:56.680 --> 00:03:01.000
I've suffered this as well, is when you
download a version of the software,

52
00:03:01.000 --> 00:03:02.470
your operating system.

53
00:03:02.470 --> 00:03:04.310
And you realize that
something else isn't working

54
00:03:05.350 --> 00:03:07.710
because it's not been tested properly.

55
00:03:07.710 --> 00:03:10.545
Or because they weren't aware
of these other add-on apps

56
00:03:10.545 --> 00:03:12.015
that you had on your phone as well.

57
00:03:12.015 --> 00:03:13.865
If something doesn't work and

58
00:03:13.865 --> 00:03:17.975
you made the situation a whole lot
worse than what it was before.

59
00:03:17.975 --> 00:03:21.355
And instead of fixing problems that you
were trying to fix with the release,

60
00:03:21.355 --> 00:03:23.400
you're actually creating new ones.

61
00:03:23.400 --> 00:03:25.700
So what we want to do is make
sure that that doesn't happen.

62
00:03:25.700 --> 00:03:28.740
So we still want to have
that rapid delivery, but

63
00:03:28.740 --> 00:03:31.270
we wanna make sure that we
don't cause more problems, so

64
00:03:31.270 --> 00:03:34.020
we gotta keep people happy.
>> And that's true because even this

65
00:03:34.020 --> 00:03:37.540
morning, we were just joking about
the user interface for Snapchat.

66
00:03:37.540 --> 00:03:40.709
But you saw with their
latest update they released,

67
00:03:40.709 --> 00:03:45.474
there was a lot of pushback on that UI,
and the end users just weren't having it

68
00:03:45.474 --> 00:03:48.916
>> Snap what, what was that, [LAUGH] yeah,

69
00:03:48.916 --> 00:03:52.225
you forget-
>> Its what all the cool kids are doing,

70
00:03:52.225 --> 00:03:54.793
Jo.
>> Yeah, all right, this dinosaur here is

71
00:03:54.793 --> 00:03:58.400
just gonna have to live without that for
a little bit longer [LAUGH].

72
00:03:58.400 --> 00:04:01.750
But yeah, youre right, unfortunately,

73
00:04:01.750 --> 00:04:05.450
when theyre building operating systems
and when theyre building apps.

74
00:04:05.450 --> 00:04:09.530
One of the things that weve gotta
be very careful of is understanding

75
00:04:09.530 --> 00:04:14.512
who our customer is, and what it is they
want, and also what they use as well.

76
00:04:14.512 --> 00:04:19.540
Now, there's absolutely no way that
companies like Snapchat or Apple and

77
00:04:19.540 --> 00:04:24.630
the operating system, there's no way they
can accommodate every single app thats

78
00:04:24.630 --> 00:04:25.816
out there, no way at all.

79
00:04:25.816 --> 00:04:30.490
And there's no way people like Apple could
understand every single one of their

80
00:04:30.490 --> 00:04:34.140
billions of users and
understand how they work.

81
00:04:34.140 --> 00:04:37.000
But nevertheless,
that's what we should be striving to do.

82
00:04:37.000 --> 00:04:41.690
And so we'll take a look at some of
the techniques that we can employ

83
00:04:41.690 --> 00:04:42.950
to help us achieve that.

84
00:04:43.970 --> 00:04:46.795
So the second principle there
is about welcoming change and

85
00:04:46.795 --> 00:04:49.685
requirements, even in late development.

86
00:04:49.685 --> 00:04:54.155
We've spoken in previous episodes
about waterfall projects.

87
00:04:54.155 --> 00:04:59.056
And about how with a traditional waterfall
style project, that's great for very,

88
00:04:59.056 --> 00:05:00.860
very large implementations.

89
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:05.900
But you quite often don't see
any delivery of the solution or

90
00:05:05.900 --> 00:05:10.080
of the new software until a good
few months down the line.

91
00:05:10.080 --> 00:05:14.570
And what that means is, though,
that we don't accommodate change, and

92
00:05:14.570 --> 00:05:18.150
we have our requirements cast in stone.

93
00:05:18.150 --> 00:05:20.690
And by the time we come to
deliver them and release them,

94
00:05:20.690 --> 00:05:22.390
they're about 18 months out of date.

95
00:05:23.790 --> 00:05:27.241
We can't afford to be like that anymore,

96
00:05:27.241 --> 00:05:31.973
this was something that was great 10,
15 years ago,

97
00:05:31.973 --> 00:05:35.976
but it's not something that we can really-
>> Well,

98
00:05:35.976 --> 00:05:38.130
everyone's in a rush
to be first to market.

99
00:05:38.130 --> 00:05:40.250
First to market with this,
first to market for that.

100
00:05:40.250 --> 00:05:44.872
So looking at these timelines,
if it is just a couple of months,

101
00:05:44.872 --> 00:05:49.000
in tech, that's huge, that's a long time.
>> Well,

102
00:05:49.000 --> 00:05:53.640
it is now, but you have to understand that
when these waterfall approaches first,

103
00:05:53.640 --> 00:05:55.950
I'm not gonna say came out.

104
00:05:55.950 --> 00:06:00.689
But you have to understand that
when these waterfall approaches

105
00:06:00.689 --> 00:06:05.440
were first conceptualized,
development wasn't that rapid.

106
00:06:05.440 --> 00:06:08.564
And we weren't releasing
software every five minutes,

107
00:06:08.564 --> 00:06:11.270
cuz that's what it feels like right now.

108
00:06:11.270 --> 00:06:14.770
But then our users had
a different expectation, and

109
00:06:14.770 --> 00:06:18.760
I wouldn't say a lower expectation,
but they had a different expectation.

110
00:06:18.760 --> 00:06:22.800
Now our users expect to have a new
version of an operating system

111
00:06:22.800 --> 00:06:25.990
at least once a month,
whereas ten years ago, they didn't.

112
00:06:25.990 --> 00:06:29.985
That was something that, updating your
operating system was a huge, big upheaval,

113
00:06:29.985 --> 00:06:32.270
and it was something that
you never wanted to do.

114
00:06:32.270 --> 00:06:33.460
>> Yeah, and good point,

115
00:06:33.460 --> 00:06:36.860
because you look at something,
like I'm familiar with Six Sigma.

116
00:06:36.860 --> 00:06:40.410
And you're looking at companies,
like what started with Motorola, right?

117
00:06:40.410 --> 00:06:42.790
I wannna say, I don't remember
the exact year, but in the 80s.

118
00:06:42.790 --> 00:06:46.780
And we have seen a huge
evolution since then.

119
00:06:46.780 --> 00:06:48.380
>> Right, and so

120
00:06:48.380 --> 00:06:50.650
we've gotta make sure that
we can accommodate that.

121
00:06:50.650 --> 00:06:55.490
And this is another reason why agile,
we mentioned, was originally thought of,

122
00:06:55.490 --> 00:06:57.230
the agile manifesto came out in 2001.

123
00:06:57.230 --> 00:07:02.790
And these principles
are still relevant now, but

124
00:07:02.790 --> 00:07:06.140
we have to adapt the way
that we manage our projects.

125
00:07:06.140 --> 00:07:10.030
It's really simple, it's a simple concept,
but it makes so much sense.

126
00:07:10.030 --> 00:07:13.195
We can't afford to have
projects that last for

127
00:07:13.195 --> 00:07:16.410
two years when the business
changes every few weeks.

128
00:07:17.800 --> 00:07:19.530
And that comes into point number three,

129
00:07:19.530 --> 00:07:21.760
which is deliver working
software frequently.

130
00:07:21.760 --> 00:07:24.710
There's a couple things that I
wanna bring out on that one,

131
00:07:24.710 --> 00:07:28.490
and the first one is the word working.

132
00:07:28.490 --> 00:07:32.430
Yeah, you don't just release something,
right, and it doesn't work.

133
00:07:32.430 --> 00:07:34.510
>> And it comes down to common sense,

134
00:07:34.510 --> 00:07:37.250
you said that, but
[INAUDIBLE] here on paper.

135
00:07:37.250 --> 00:07:42.070
And we're kind of laughing and
scoffing at this, but it happens.

136
00:07:42.070 --> 00:07:47.832
Sometimes that being first to market,
they push it out a little too fast, before

137
00:07:47.832 --> 00:07:52.562
the whole working part comes about, right?
>> And that could be the thing that

138
00:07:52.562 --> 00:07:56.311
sends your customers over the edge and
sends them to somebody else, as well,

139
00:07:56.311 --> 00:07:59.024
if They've received software
that doesn't work, and

140
00:07:59.024 --> 00:08:03.050
this is the third lot of software that
they've received that doesn't work.

141
00:08:03.050 --> 00:08:05.800
Then they're gonna go somewhere else.

142
00:08:05.800 --> 00:08:10.900
I come across a lot of software
providers in my day-to-day

143
00:08:10.900 --> 00:08:15.850
environment where they have very,
very unhappy customers.

144
00:08:15.850 --> 00:08:20.505
And this is because they are really
seeing software that doesn't work,

145
00:08:20.505 --> 00:08:22.119
it's as simple as that.

146
00:08:22.119 --> 00:08:25.186
But they're releasing it because
they've got a deadline, and

147
00:08:25.186 --> 00:08:28.320
the deadline says that they've
gotta release this by next week.

148
00:08:28.320 --> 00:08:31.595
And then they've gotta have
another release two weeks later,

149
00:08:31.595 --> 00:08:34.460
because that's the sort
of release timescale.

150
00:08:34.460 --> 00:08:37.105
And so they're doing this,
even though it doesn't work.

151
00:08:37.105 --> 00:08:39.529
And we all joke about it, but

152
00:08:39.529 --> 00:08:44.584
there is that joke that happens
when software is released.

153
00:08:44.584 --> 00:08:48.373
And we look down at the sort
of the known error list, or

154
00:08:48.373 --> 00:08:50.911
rather the features list, right.

155
00:08:50.911 --> 00:08:52.856
[LAUGH] It's not an known error,
it's a feature.

156
00:08:52.856 --> 00:08:54.685
>> It's not a bug, yeah,

157
00:08:54.685 --> 00:08:59.784
it's an enhancement [LAUGH].
>> Yeah, and yeah, that doesn't work,

158
00:08:59.784 --> 00:09:05.310
so we wanna deliver working software
frequently, it's got to work.

159
00:09:05.310 --> 00:09:08.452
But it's gotta be frequent as well,
you can't wait for 18 months or

160
00:09:08.452 --> 00:09:09.581
2 years to see results.

161
00:09:09.581 --> 00:09:12.416
And the other thing is that if
you're waiting for 18 months and

162
00:09:12.416 --> 00:09:15.568
2 years to see results, your customers
have probably already started

163
00:09:15.568 --> 00:09:17.420
looking elsewhere at that point in time.

164
00:09:17.420 --> 00:09:22.608
And that comes into number four,
when I said customers have already started

165
00:09:22.608 --> 00:09:28.840
looking elsewhere at that point in time,
you've gotta work with the business.

166
00:09:28.840 --> 00:09:33.430
If you don't understand who your customer
is, and you don't understand the way that

167
00:09:33.430 --> 00:09:37.830
they work, and you don't understand
the expectations and the requirements that

168
00:09:37.830 --> 00:09:41.811
they have, then how on Earth can you
deliver something that they can use?

169
00:09:41.811 --> 00:09:46.529
You've gotta understand who your
customer is, cuz you've gotta

170
00:09:46.529 --> 00:09:50.804
give them something that they can use.
>> Business 101, right?

171
00:09:50.804 --> 00:09:51.351
>> Well,

172
00:09:51.351 --> 00:09:55.184
you'd like to think so,
but I could tell you now,

173
00:09:55.184 --> 00:10:00.038
I go into so many organizations,
and they produce a RAG chart.

174
00:10:00.038 --> 00:10:05.235
And a RAG chart is red, amber,
green, it's traffic lights.

175
00:10:05.235 --> 00:10:09.749
And they'll show it to me and they'll say,
right, this is our performance against our

176
00:10:09.749 --> 00:10:13.250
service level targets, and
all of our customers see that.

177
00:10:13.250 --> 00:10:17.492
And then I'll say to people, okay,
how many of your customers are colorblind?

178
00:10:17.492 --> 00:10:21.650
And every single person,
every time I go into an organization,

179
00:10:21.650 --> 00:10:25.733
they look at me with that,
sort of, well, I don't know.

180
00:10:25.733 --> 00:10:27.794
So why are you producing red, amber,

181
00:10:27.794 --> 00:10:31.994
green if you don't know that that's
really relevant to your customer base?

182
00:10:31.994 --> 00:10:36.591
The whole idea of that chart is to see at
a glance whether we're doing well against

183
00:10:36.591 --> 00:10:41.476
our targets, or whether we're doing badly,
and if you can't tell the difference-

184
00:10:41.476 --> 00:10:42.795
>> Yeah, if you're colorblind.

185
00:10:42.795 --> 00:10:44.340
>> Then it's not at a glance, is it,

186
00:10:44.340 --> 00:10:49.340
anymore, it's kind of, well, give me 30
minutes and I'll take a look through this.

187
00:10:50.770 --> 00:10:55.653
We don't understand our customers,
and that's why we gotta work together.

188
00:10:55.653 --> 00:10:58.959
So number five talks about
motivating individuals,

189
00:10:58.959 --> 00:11:02.197
building projects around
motivated individuals.

190
00:11:02.197 --> 00:11:05.880
And then trust them or
rather empower them to get the job done.

191
00:11:06.910 --> 00:11:11.870
Trust the people that you've got working
for you, and don't micromanage them.

192
00:11:11.870 --> 00:11:16.540
Agile is about delivering
software on a regular basis, and

193
00:11:16.540 --> 00:11:18.840
so efficiency is really important.

194
00:11:18.840 --> 00:11:21.830
It is not efficient to micromanage people,
and

195
00:11:21.830 --> 00:11:26.790
how demotivating is it if you
have to micromanage people?

196
00:11:26.790 --> 00:11:31.477
It shows that you don't trust them, and
it also means that you're fostering

197
00:11:31.477 --> 00:11:34.952
an environment where they
don't trust you as a manager.

198
00:11:34.952 --> 00:11:40.210
And so what kind of contribution
are they going to make to that project?

199
00:11:40.210 --> 00:11:45.140
They are not going to give it 100%,
you've gotta trust people,

200
00:11:45.140 --> 00:11:47.275
you've got to empower them.

201
00:11:47.275 --> 00:11:51.162
And then I love number six,
I've highlighted

202
00:11:51.162 --> 00:11:56.156
face-to-face conversation,
and I absolutely love it.

203
00:11:56.156 --> 00:12:00.988
We had a conversation a little
while ago about something that,

204
00:12:00.988 --> 00:12:03.735
it was the way I phrased something.

205
00:12:03.735 --> 00:12:05.584
And it was the way I said something, and

206
00:12:05.584 --> 00:12:09.280
we talked about the fact that you
didn't quite understand what I said.

207
00:12:09.280 --> 00:12:11.200
And there was me standing
there talking about,

208
00:12:11.200 --> 00:12:13.510
you've gotta have that conversation.

209
00:12:13.510 --> 00:12:15.657
You've gotta communicate in
the language of the audience.

210
00:12:15.657 --> 00:12:18.671
You were my audience and
you didn't understand me, so

211
00:12:18.671 --> 00:12:21.521
I was really good at that.
>> [LAUGH]

212
00:12:21.521 --> 00:12:24.315
>> Face to face conversation gives you so

213
00:12:24.315 --> 00:12:27.820
many benefits,
including the body language.

214
00:12:28.940 --> 00:12:31.003
I can see whether you're
paying attention to me.

215
00:12:31.003 --> 00:12:33.977
>> [LAUGH] Uh-oh, I'm in trouble.

216
00:12:33.977 --> 00:12:35.887
>> Yeah, right, you've been called out,

217
00:12:35.887 --> 00:12:38.680
[LAUGH] I can see whether
you're paying attention to me.

218
00:12:38.680 --> 00:12:40.100
But more importantly than that,

219
00:12:40.100 --> 00:12:43.869
I can also see whether you're
understanding what I'm saying.

220
00:12:45.680 --> 00:12:49.290
We communicate in absolutely
everything that we do, and

221
00:12:49.290 --> 00:12:54.020
if I take you to the ITIL service
management, we have a communication

222
00:12:54.020 --> 00:12:57.604
principal in ITIL that looks at the fact
that we communicate all the time.

223
00:12:57.604 --> 00:13:03.098
In the way that we dress, in the way that
we carry ourselves, in our body language,

224
00:13:03.098 --> 00:13:07.258
in the sort of comments,
maybe the under the breath comments,

225
00:13:07.258 --> 00:13:09.412
I'm telling you now.
>> [LAUGH] Or

226
00:13:09.412 --> 00:13:11.695
lack of communication.
>> Right.

227
00:13:11.695 --> 00:13:12.344
>> [LAUGH]

228
00:13:12.344 --> 00:13:13.782
>> Or the lack of engagement,

229
00:13:13.782 --> 00:13:16.166
the lack of sort of eye contact for
instance.

230
00:13:16.166 --> 00:13:18.965
We're communicating all the time,

231
00:13:18.965 --> 00:13:23.756
I can tell right now whether
you're getting what I'm saying.

232
00:13:23.756 --> 00:13:28.640
I can't tell whether you're getting
what I'm saying, I don't know.

233
00:13:28.640 --> 00:13:31.810
So I've gotta make sure that I
communicate in your language.

234
00:13:31.810 --> 00:13:39.170
But I don't have that face to face method
of communication, so I can't tell.

235
00:13:39.170 --> 00:13:42.199
Face to face communication
is more efficient,

236
00:13:42.199 --> 00:13:47.118
I can understand straight away whether
you're on the same wavelength as me,

237
00:13:47.118 --> 00:13:51.819
and I don't have to duplicate myself.
>> So I can see now, a lot of this time in

238
00:13:51.819 --> 00:13:56.054
with our development team, because,
and I keep bringing this up and

239
00:13:56.054 --> 00:14:00.523
this is what I have to relate it to,
because I'm not a developer myself.

240
00:14:00.523 --> 00:14:05.841
So I'm looking at them, and they have
a remote team that they work with closely,

241
00:14:05.841 --> 00:14:10.780
but they're not on the phone with them,
they're on a messaging service.

242
00:14:10.780 --> 00:14:15.269
So I don't know if it's Skype for
Business, or whatever platform they use,

243
00:14:15.269 --> 00:14:17.975
but they're video
chatting with each other.

244
00:14:17.975 --> 00:14:20.571
>> Yep, yeah, and we will tell you that,

245
00:14:20.571 --> 00:14:25.464
in a project environment, we want you
all in the same room, if possible.

246
00:14:25.464 --> 00:14:28.626
Now that doesn't necessarily have to
be physically all in the same room,

247
00:14:28.626 --> 00:14:30.905
that can be virtually
all in the same room.

248
00:14:30.905 --> 00:14:36.550
But you're gonna get more out
of people if they feel involved.

249
00:14:36.550 --> 00:14:39.890
You're not gonna get as much out of
people if they feel disconnected.

250
00:14:39.890 --> 00:14:42.040
And I hear people all the time say to me,
but

251
00:14:42.040 --> 00:14:46.290
I get more done when I'm working from
home, yeah, all right, you get more done.

252
00:14:46.290 --> 00:14:49.120
You get more done in between
doing the laundry, in

253

00:25:01.620 --> 00:25:05.510

00:27:52.960 --> 00:27:55.210
don't forget all of this
is downloadable for you.

483
00:27:55.210 --> 00:28:00.030
These slides just really look
at the difference between them.

484
00:28:00.030 --> 00:28:03.270
Traditional waterfall, in other words,
something like Prince 2 or PMI,

485
00:28:03.270 --> 00:28:07.000
look at bringing all of
the requirements up front.

486
00:28:08.060 --> 00:28:10.160
And all the requirements
are specified out front.

487
00:28:10.160 --> 00:28:12.243
The functional, the non-functional,

488
00:28:12.243 --> 00:28:16.810
the usability, all of those requirements
are specified, and then they are agreed.

489
00:28:16.810 --> 00:28:20.373
And this goes back to
that casting it in stone.

490
00:28:20.373 --> 00:28:26.010
And then we go and build, and
we design our documentation,

491
00:28:26.010 --> 00:28:30.665
and we design all of the specifications.

492
00:28:30.665 --> 00:28:34.345
And we have accurate designs
including all of our environment.

493
00:28:35.455 --> 00:28:40.800
And then, then we go and actually do
the build which is the implementation.

494
00:28:40.800 --> 00:28:47.070
But just think,
we've done all of this work up front, and

495
00:28:47.070 --> 00:28:51.470
we come up with our requirements, we cast
them in stone, and then we design them.

496
00:28:53.190 --> 00:28:54.720
How long does it take to do that?

497
00:28:54.720 --> 00:28:59.950
In a traditional project, that in itself
could take maybe six months depending on

498
00:28:59.950 --> 00:29:03.800
the size of the project or by which time
who's requirements have probably changed.

499
00:29:05.160 --> 00:29:08.470
So we have to think about
the scale of the project and

500
00:29:08.470 --> 00:29:12.080
think about what the project
is looking to achieve,

501
00:29:12.080 --> 00:29:15.780
before we work out whether we want to use
the traditional waterfall approach, or

502
00:29:15.780 --> 00:29:21.760
whether we want to use an agile approach.
>> So I have a little, I'm just thinking.

503
00:29:21.760 --> 00:29:25.045
So are project charters even
involved in this process?

504
00:29:25.045 --> 00:29:27.595
Have they gone by the wayside?

505
00:29:27.595 --> 00:29:29.371
[CROSSTALK] Do I have to wait for
that cliffhanger?

506
00:29:29.371 --> 00:29:31.779
>> Yeah, you're gonna have to wait and

507
00:29:31.779 --> 00:29:33.200
see on that one.

508
00:29:33.200 --> 00:29:37.321
[LAUGH] Project charter, that's
something that's terminology that we use

509
00:29:37.321 --> 00:29:39.780
specifically in a waterfall approach.

510
00:29:39.780 --> 00:29:42.962
Now were not saying that the child
hasn't gone by the wayside.

511
00:29:42.962 --> 00:29:46.580
What we're saying is that we've got
another approach to requirements

512
00:29:46.580 --> 00:29:48.872
definition, because we're not looking for

513
00:29:48.872 --> 00:29:51.540
requirements definition for
everything up front.

514
00:29:52.700 --> 00:29:54.210
And that's the difference.

515
00:29:54.210 --> 00:29:56.340
Because in a waterfall approach,

516
00:29:56.340 --> 00:30:01.915
we do the requirements definition up front
as it says at the top of that slide, GRUF.

517
00:30:01.915 --> 00:30:04.890
[LAUGH] Yeah.
>> That's a great acronym

518
00:30:04.890 --> 00:30:07.680
there [LAUGH].
>> [LAUGH] I didn't think that one up

519
00:30:07.680 --> 00:30:09.530
myself, I wish I could take credit for it.

520
00:30:09.530 --> 00:30:13.650
But we do the requirements definition
up front, and then it's cast in stone.

521
00:30:14.670 --> 00:30:18.130
And that might work for
some implementations.

522
00:30:18.130 --> 00:30:22.200
However, from an agile perspective,
yeah, it doesn't work.

523
00:30:22.200 --> 00:30:26.010
We have to be aware the requirements
are going to change.

524
00:30:26.010 --> 00:30:29.590
And what I wanted yesterday
might not be what I want today,

525
00:30:29.590 --> 00:30:31.610
because my environment's changed as well.

526
00:30:32.970 --> 00:30:34.610
And then with the traditional waterfall,

527
00:30:34.610 --> 00:30:40.485
you'll see that we will be aware
of all of our testing environment.

528
00:30:40.485 --> 00:30:44.005
And we will be implementing beta tests,

529
00:30:44.005 --> 00:30:47.335
or beta tests, as you might call them.
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

530
00:30:47.335 --> 00:30:48.570
>> See what I've got there.

531
00:30:48.570 --> 00:30:51.205
[LAUGH] We might be doing that.

532
00:30:51.205 --> 00:30:53.685
But we will do that in
a very formalized way.

533
00:30:53.685 --> 00:30:56.835
Now I'm not telling you that agile
doesn't test, because we do test.

534
00:30:58.320 --> 00:31:03.440
But a beta test, or a beta test,
could take three months just in itself.

535
00:31:03.440 --> 00:31:08.890
So we want to test, but we wanna make sure
that again that that testing is efficient.

536
00:31:08.890 --> 00:31:11.330
And the full solution
itself is implemented.

537
00:31:11.330 --> 00:31:16.180
Now when we implement something huge,
that creates a big

538
00:31:16.180 --> 00:31:20.440
impact on the environment, it creates
a big impact on our organization.

539
00:31:20.440 --> 00:31:24.720
And so therefore, the bedding-in
period for that new service and

540
00:31:24.720 --> 00:31:27.400
that new solution can be quite large.

541
00:31:27.400 --> 00:31:32.405
And that means the early life support or
DevOps period, that hand-holding

542
00:31:32.405 --> 00:31:36.900
period between the project being completed
and operations taking over support,

543
00:31:36.900 --> 00:31:41.960
that can be extended as well
in a waterfall environment.

544
00:31:41.960 --> 00:31:46.894
In an agile environment, because we
are releasing in an iterative manner, and

545
00:31:46.894 --> 00:31:50.513
then the project team are always
working with operation.

546
00:31:50.513 --> 00:31:55.238
But it means that the impact is less
severe and by severe I don't mean that in

547
00:31:55.238 --> 00:31:59.966
a negative way What I mean is that there's
just not as much being deployed at

548
00:31:59.966 --> 00:32:03.134
any one point in time.
>> Yeah, and by having the, I guess,

549
00:32:03.134 --> 00:32:07.420
the more frequent, like you were talking
about, not just once every ten years.

550
00:32:07.420 --> 00:32:11.357
It's not as invasive or
alarming if you have the smaller

551
00:32:11.357 --> 00:32:12.795
increments.
>> Scary,

552
00:32:12.795 --> 00:32:14.815
thats the word you wanna say.
>> [LAUGH]

553
00:32:14.815 --> 00:32:15.753
>> Its not as scary.

554
00:32:15.753 --> 00:32:17.067
>> Not as scary.

555
00:32:17.067 --> 00:32:18.672
>> Youve gotta understand your customer,

556
00:32:18.672 --> 00:32:20.550
and some customers just dont like change.

557
00:32:20.550 --> 00:32:24.120
Some customers like stability, if youre
working in a financial institution-

558
00:32:24.120 --> 00:32:25.604
>> Yeah, tell me about it.

559
00:32:25.604 --> 00:32:26.464
>> Right, and

560
00:32:26.464 --> 00:32:30.250
Ive done some work with
financial institutions.

561
00:32:30.250 --> 00:32:34.821
And I can tell you now that when
youre talking about clientele that

562
00:32:34.821 --> 00:32:37.717
maybe havent grown up with technology.

563
00:32:37.717 --> 00:32:40.550
Maybe because of environment or
maybe because of age.

564
00:32:40.550 --> 00:32:42.002
>> Industry requirements

565
00:32:42.002 --> 00:32:43.878
>> Right, and then all of a sudden,

566
00:32:43.878 --> 00:32:48.100
were bringing out something completely
new like contactless payment.

567
00:32:48.100 --> 00:32:50.572
And these are people that
have never even used a check,

568
00:32:50.572 --> 00:32:54.860
they've always used cash before, and now
we're talking about contactless payment.

569
00:32:54.860 --> 00:32:58.360
You can imagine that that's daunting, and
so a lot of people don't want to change.

570
00:32:58.360 --> 00:33:01.920
So the idea is with an agile approach that

571
00:33:01.920 --> 00:33:03.970
you want to make that as
painless as possible.

572
00:33:03.970 --> 00:33:08.236
So we introduce certain elements
at certain points in time.

573
00:33:08.236 --> 00:33:12.740
You see the waterfall approach also, and
I do like the fact that with the waterfall

574
00:33:12.740 --> 00:33:17.410
approach, we're able to demonstrate
that ROI, that return on investment.

575
00:33:17.410 --> 00:33:19.700
And we do that right at
the very end of the project.

576
00:33:19.700 --> 00:33:21.960
Now that's sometimes a challenge for

577
00:33:21.960 --> 00:33:25.200
an agile approach,
because when do we go and measure?

578
00:33:25.200 --> 00:33:29.183
When do we go and do benefits realization,
when do we measure?

579
00:33:29.183 --> 00:33:32.380
Because how do we know when
this solution is complete?

580
00:33:32.380 --> 00:33:35.000
And how do we then measure
the return on that investment?

581
00:33:35.000 --> 00:33:37.019
>> Especially if it's more cyclic, so

582
00:33:37.019 --> 00:33:39.604
to speak.
>> Right, and so that's a challenge, for

583
00:33:39.604 --> 00:33:40.602
an agile approach,

584
00:33:40.602 --> 00:33:43.960
it definitely is a challenge to
measure that return on investment.

585
00:33:45.160 --> 00:33:50.630
And of course, with an agile approach
as well, it can be difficult

586
00:33:50.630 --> 00:33:55.500
too to maintain service level targets and
key performance indicators.

587
00:33:55.500 --> 00:34:00.980
In a traditional waterfall approach,
the solution is implemented,

588
00:34:00.980 --> 00:34:05.780
and then we start measuring then
performance against service level targets.

589
00:34:05.780 --> 00:34:09.220
And then if we need to improve,
then we can implement improvements.

590
00:34:09.220 --> 00:34:13.250
But in an agile approach, you have to
think that we are always changing.

591
00:34:13.250 --> 00:34:14.860
So those service level targets,

592
00:34:14.860 --> 00:34:19.760
the KPIs could also be
changing with every iteration.

593
00:34:19.760 --> 00:34:24.796
So how then are we able to demonstrate
whether we have met our key

594
00:34:24.796 --> 00:34:30.412
performance indicators,
whether we are performing as we should do?

595
00:34:30.412 --> 00:34:34.140
It can be incredibly difficult
in an agile environment.

596
00:34:34.140 --> 00:34:36.920
So you can see that there are pros and
cons to both approaches.

597
00:34:36.920 --> 00:34:40.836
And we will never try to tell you
that agile is better than PRINCE2, or

598
00:34:40.836 --> 00:34:43.940
that PRINCE2 is better than agile,
for example.

599
00:34:45.210 --> 00:34:48.910
So we've looked at the underpinning
12 principles, and

600
00:34:48.910 --> 00:34:51.432
we looked at the three pillars of agile.

601
00:34:51.432 --> 00:34:55.535
And we've just looked at sort of
the pros and cons of the waterfall and

602
00:34:55.535 --> 00:34:58.560
the agile approaches
to problem management.

603
00:34:58.560 --> 00:34:59.860
And in our next episode,

604
00:34:59.860 --> 00:35:05.620
we're going to look a little bit closer at
the various methodologies that fall under

605
00:35:05.620 --> 00:35:09.440
the banner of agile project management.
>> Perfect, we're gonna be coming back

606
00:35:09.440 --> 00:35:14.190
to debunk one of the myths that you had
displayed on one of those slides there.

607
00:35:14.190 --> 00:35:16.640
Yeah, so
we'll take a look at those methodologies.

608
00:35:16.640 --> 00:35:19.770
You don't wanna miss that,
but for now, let's sign out.

609
00:35:19.770 --> 00:35:22.340
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

610
00:35:22.340 --> 00:35:25.117
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

611
00:35:25.117 --> 00:35:31.020
[MUSIC]

612
00:35:31.020 --> 00:35:34.084
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: An overview of the stages that form part of the Agile lifecycle.
episodes.title: The Agile Life Cycle
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.670 --> 00:00:04.230
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:04.230 --> 00:00:07.227
I'm your host, Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.227 --> 00:00:08.449
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.449 --> 00:00:10.500
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome

5
00:00:12.230 --> 00:00:15.870
everyone to your Agile project
management concept series.

6
00:00:15.870 --> 00:00:17.880
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.880 --> 00:00:21.740
In this episode we'll be taking a look at,
well, the Agile life cycle.

8
00:00:21.740 --> 00:00:25.310
And of course, with us today back in
studios, we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:25.310 --> 00:00:27.460
How's it going today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great.

10
00:00:27.460 --> 00:00:28.160
Thank you, Cherokee.

11
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:29.830
How are you?
>> I'm doing wonderful.

12
00:00:29.830 --> 00:00:34.980
I managed to make it through the word
life cycle without doing this.

13
00:00:34.980 --> 00:00:35.580
>> Right.

14
00:00:35.580 --> 00:00:38.555
And that's why I was stood here laughing.

15
00:00:38.555 --> 00:00:41.630
[LAUGH] I was waiting.
>> I was trying not to.

16
00:00:41.630 --> 00:00:43.060
But no.
In all seriousness,

17
00:00:43.060 --> 00:00:45.180
we're going to be looking at
starting at the beginning and

18
00:00:45.180 --> 00:00:49.060
then what to expect as we go through
this process, but it is, doing it now.

19
00:00:49.060 --> 00:00:51.770
All right, yep.
>> [LAUGH] What we are going

20
00:00:51.770 --> 00:00:53.190
to be looking at in this session.

21
00:00:53.190 --> 00:00:54.340
This is just a really,

22
00:00:54.340 --> 00:00:59.120
really brief introduction to
the life cycle of the Agile project.

23
00:00:59.120 --> 00:01:03.680
In our future episodes we're going to be
looking at each stage in more depth and

24
00:01:03.680 --> 00:01:08.190
we're going to be looking at activities
that occur within each stage of the Agile

25
00:01:08.190 --> 00:01:11.678
life cycle or now I'm gonna always
refer to it as the life cycle.

26
00:01:11.678 --> 00:01:13.049
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:01:13.049 --> 00:01:15.570
>> However at this particular episode

28
00:01:15.570 --> 00:01:20.130
we're just gonna take a really quick
overview on the life cycle itself and

29
00:01:20.130 --> 00:01:23.880
what activities there
are in the life cycle.

30
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:27.490
So, in a previous episode,
Cherokee, you mentioned that

31
00:01:27.490 --> 00:01:33.260
the life cycle of a scrum project,
or of a project the,

32
00:01:33.260 --> 00:01:37.040
an Agile type project would normally
be between sort of one to four weeks.

33
00:01:37.040 --> 00:01:40.410
And yeah, it really depends
on what's being developed

34
00:01:40.410 --> 00:01:44.840
as to how quick that release
is actually developed and

35
00:01:44.840 --> 00:01:45.960
deployed.
>> Right.

36
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:47.690
>> And what's inside each

37
00:01:47.690 --> 00:01:49.500
iteration as well.

38
00:01:49.500 --> 00:01:52.460
So let's take a look at
the life cycle itself.

39
00:01:52.460 --> 00:01:54.720
It can, as I've already said,

40
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:58.220
vary in size depending on what
it is we want to release.

41
00:01:58.220 --> 00:02:03.360
And so you'll see that we start off
with envisaging our release plan, and

42
00:02:03.360 --> 00:02:06.440
then we move into sort of
planning the iteration, and

43
00:02:06.440 --> 00:02:09.540
then actually developing that iteration.

44
00:02:09.540 --> 00:02:13.080
And during the increment itself,
then we're going to have

45
00:02:13.080 --> 00:02:17.630
standup meeting that we looked at very,
very briefly in a previous episode, and

46
00:02:17.630 --> 00:02:21.000
then we're going to have after
the face updates as well.

47
00:02:21.000 --> 00:02:24.515
And then once the iteration is
complete and it's ready for

48
00:02:24.515 --> 00:02:26.760
release then we will release.

49
00:02:26.760 --> 00:02:31.180
And then we will review and so
to make sure that it's going to deliver

50
00:02:31.180 --> 00:02:34.350
what it's suppose to
deliver to ensure that

51
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:39.580
every single story that we have put in to
that particular iteration is an iteration.

52
00:02:39.580 --> 00:02:42.290
I can't even say the word now.

53
00:02:42.290 --> 00:02:44.890
See you've got me tongue tied.
>> We know what you're talking about.

54
00:02:44.890 --> 00:02:47.683
It's because you didn't do some kind
of hand movement while you're talking.

55
00:02:47.683 --> 00:02:49.290
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I'm just not that smooth [LAUGH]

56
00:02:49.290 --> 00:02:50.720
That's all it is.

57
00:02:50.720 --> 00:02:54.490
And then of course it
doesn't just end there,

58
00:02:54.490 --> 00:02:57.560
once we've delivered the increments,
and we've done our retrospective,

59
00:02:57.560 --> 00:03:01.940
we've taken a look back to
conductor lessons learned exercise,

60
00:03:01.940 --> 00:03:05.090
then after that we're going
to plan our next iteration.

61
00:03:05.090 --> 00:03:09.230
And as you can see every single
iteration will take between one and

62
00:03:09.230 --> 00:03:13.740
four weeks depending on the scale
of what it is that we're deploying.

63
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:15.570
>> It's kind of interesting.

64
00:03:15.570 --> 00:03:18.470
I should have Rob from the Dev
team come in and explain this,

65
00:03:18.470 --> 00:03:20.370
because I know I'm going to butcher it.

66
00:03:20.370 --> 00:03:22.100
But it's pretty cool.

67
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:27.150
He explained it once to us, a way
that they help identify the length or

68
00:03:27.150 --> 00:03:30.940
duration of a particular story.

69
00:03:30.940 --> 00:03:35.240
So for instance, if we were talking about
implementing a technology or task or

70
00:03:35.240 --> 00:03:41.210
whatever then they basically huddle and
play a modified rock,

71
00:03:41.210 --> 00:03:46.350
paper, scissor game,
they all at the same time express their,

72
00:03:46.350 --> 00:03:50.945
they use little codes for
hours, or days, or whatever.

73
00:03:50.945 --> 00:03:54.915
But then they would say like,
I think it's X amount of time.

74
00:03:54.915 --> 00:03:57.775
So, that if they're too far apart,
like let's say,

75
00:03:57.775 --> 00:04:01.905
I think a test may take two hours,
and you think it may take two days,

76
00:04:01.905 --> 00:04:04.815
then that would identify an issue,
and they would need to talk about and

77
00:04:04.815 --> 00:04:09.375
say okay, well, why are our time
estimates so different here?

78
00:04:09.375 --> 00:04:11.840
So, just kind of like determining.

79
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:14.580
I'm sure other companies have
different methods or ways but

80
00:04:14.580 --> 00:04:18.720
that's just kind of like a fun little
thing that they do to help keep on track

81
00:04:18.720 --> 00:04:22.451
and keep their stories in check.
>> Yeah, we will use techniques like that

82
00:04:22.451 --> 00:04:26.370
in estimating when we actually
start estimating the amount

83
00:04:26.370 --> 00:04:30.850
of time that is going to be able to take
to develop a particular resolution to use

84
00:04:30.850 --> 00:04:34.602
a story there will be all sorts
of methods that are in use.

85
00:04:34.602 --> 00:04:39.300
We've looked in previous
episodes at team skills or

86
00:04:39.300 --> 00:04:43.210
individual skills and
showing that we've got the right spread

87
00:04:43.210 --> 00:04:46.410
of skills across the team and
that the team collaborate.

88
00:04:46.410 --> 00:04:51.020
And it could well be that in an instance
like that, we've got that disparity there,

89
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:53.130
because one person's got

90
00:04:53.130 --> 00:04:54.450
one particular set of skills.
>> Right.

91
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:56.040
>> And somebody else hasn't

92
00:04:56.040 --> 00:04:58.480
got those skills, or
they've got a different set of skills.

93
00:04:58.480 --> 00:05:03.000
And so, that's why we want
to work together as a team.

94
00:05:03.000 --> 00:05:07.720
Traditionally in a waterfall
type project we find roles and

95
00:05:07.720 --> 00:05:09.900
we'll assign tasks to roles.

96
00:05:09.900 --> 00:05:13.210
And it might not necessarily be
that level of collaboration.

97
00:05:13.210 --> 00:05:18.070
And there's certainly not that
level of flexibility that allows

98
00:05:18.070 --> 00:05:21.890
you to turn around to somebody else in
the team and say, do you know what?

99
00:05:21.890 --> 00:05:25.100
I'm working on this bit of code and
I can't look at this.

100
00:05:25.100 --> 00:05:29.190
I really can't figure it out, so
it's gonna take me five days to do

101
00:05:29.190 --> 00:05:31.650
something like this or
five days to figure it out.

102
00:05:31.650 --> 00:05:32.770
You could do it in half an hour.

103
00:05:32.770 --> 00:05:33.900
Can you do that?

104
00:05:33.900 --> 00:05:38.140
And this is why we'll talk about it more
detail in different episodes when we look

105
00:05:38.140 --> 00:05:40.960
at the activities we'll talk
about our stand-up meetings, but

106
00:05:40.960 --> 00:05:43.910
that's exactly why we had
those type of meetings.

107
00:05:43.910 --> 00:05:47.330
So that we can all get a chance to say,

108
00:05:47.330 --> 00:05:50.420
this is what I'm working on today and
I need help.

109
00:05:50.420 --> 00:05:53.400
And then someone else could say,
okay I can help you.

110
00:05:53.400 --> 00:05:55.620
So that's exactly why we would do that.

111
00:05:55.620 --> 00:05:58.590
And that's what's different to
the Agile approach as opposed to

112
00:05:58.590 --> 00:06:00.330
the waterfall approach.

113
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:05.470
I know, to the casual observer,
that there are some techniques that we're

114
00:06:05.470 --> 00:06:09.215
using in Agile project management that
may seem as though we are playing games,

115
00:06:09.215 --> 00:06:13.110
[LAUGH] like rock, paper,
scissors, or something like that.

116
00:06:13.110 --> 00:06:17.180
And it can seem as though,
it's just a bit of fun, but

117
00:06:17.180 --> 00:06:22.720
really it's whatever gets the job done and
that will enable us to work together.

118
00:06:22.720 --> 00:06:26.730
You know,
that sort of exercise builds team morale.

119
00:06:26.730 --> 00:06:32.710
It gives everybody a feeling that they're
equally important to the actual project,

120
00:06:32.710 --> 00:06:35.880
and it actually resolves an issue as well.
>> Yeah.

121
00:06:35.880 --> 00:06:37.490
>> So it does work.

122
00:06:37.490 --> 00:06:40.890
We don't have to do things
in the conventional.

123
00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:47.660
Didn't wanna use the word strict but we
don't have to be so rigid in our approach.

124
00:06:47.660 --> 00:06:49.050
>> Traditional, yeah, traditional,

125
00:06:49.050 --> 00:06:52.670
good words there.
>> Yeah we don't wanna be traditional in

126
00:06:52.670 --> 00:06:56.450
that approach, we wanna ensure that
we're getting the best out of people.

127
00:06:56.450 --> 00:07:01.090
And we have to understand that getting the
best out of people is not necessarily done

128
00:07:01.090 --> 00:07:06.020
in a conventional way or in a way where
we've got too much bureaucracy or

129
00:07:06.020 --> 00:07:08.705
it's just heavily sort of processed.

130
00:07:08.705 --> 00:07:09.985
Should we say.

131
00:07:09.985 --> 00:07:13.755
So let's take a look at each
one of these steps in sequence.

132
00:07:13.755 --> 00:07:17.645
As I've said we're gonna have
episodes where we're going to look

133
00:07:17.645 --> 00:07:20.965
very specifically at the activities
that happened with each

134
00:07:20.965 --> 00:07:23.925
one of these life cycles phases or
each one of these steps.

135
00:07:25.315 --> 00:07:29.960
So first of all, the first thing that
we do is envisioning a release plan and

136
00:07:29.960 --> 00:07:32.960
then envisioning the product backlog.

137
00:07:32.960 --> 00:07:37.260
Now, what that means is what
is it that we want to achieve?

138
00:07:37.260 --> 00:07:41.600
And that's what do we want
to achieve as a whole?

139
00:07:41.600 --> 00:07:47.275
What is the vision for this project,
bearing in mind that the vision for

140
00:07:47.275 --> 00:07:53.344
the project may not necessarily be
a complete one off delivery of a project.

141
00:07:53.344 --> 00:07:58.080
It might be ongoing,
iterative delivery of a project.

142
00:07:58.080 --> 00:08:02.860
Because were talking about iterative
delivery of functionality What I mean by

143
00:08:02.860 --> 00:08:06.738
that is, in a previous episode I
mentioned an operating system.

144
00:08:06.738 --> 00:08:10.695
And we don't just deliver an operating
system as a one-off exercise.

145
00:08:10.695 --> 00:08:14.379
When we're developing that operating
system we'll say, right, okay,

146
00:08:14.379 --> 00:08:16.490
I'm gonna develop the operating system.

147
00:08:16.490 --> 00:08:18.130
And once it's developed, then that's it.

148
00:08:18.130 --> 00:08:19.850
We're not going to touch it again.

149
00:08:19.850 --> 00:08:22.730
And it doesn't have a finite lifespan.

150
00:08:22.730 --> 00:08:27.371
What happens when we're developing an
operating system is that we develop this

151
00:08:27.371 --> 00:08:31.952
operating system and then we have another
increment of the operating system.

152
00:08:31.952 --> 00:08:33.954
And then another increment and

153
00:08:33.954 --> 00:08:38.960
then another increment as we continually
enhancing that operating system.

154
00:08:40.200 --> 00:08:46.040
So we have to understand what the
long-term vision is of the project itself.

155
00:08:46.040 --> 00:08:51.170
Is the project to deliver
a one-off product,

156
00:08:51.170 --> 00:08:55.210
or is the project to
deliver an ongoing product?

157
00:08:56.550 --> 00:08:59.730
Either way, we're still gonna use
an agile approach to deliver the product.

158
00:08:59.730 --> 00:09:03.519
So we're still going to deliver
the functionality in increments, but

159
00:09:03.519 --> 00:09:06.920
we still have to work out
what our long-term vision is.

160
00:09:06.920 --> 00:09:11.871
We also have to understand our goals, and
our constraints, and our requirements,

161
00:09:11.871 --> 00:09:14.186
and ensure that they are articulated.

162
00:09:14.186 --> 00:09:18.420
It says defined, articulated just simply
means defined and then written down.

163
00:09:19.670 --> 00:09:22.590
And then we identify who
our stakeholders are.

164
00:09:23.650 --> 00:09:25.570
And we will look at this
in another episode.

165
00:09:25.570 --> 00:09:28.950
But a stakeholder is basically
anybody that's interested,

166
00:09:28.950 --> 00:09:33.470
anyone that has an interest or
could be impacted by the project or

167
00:09:33.470 --> 00:09:37.970
the particular piece of coding, that
iteration that you're planning right now.

168
00:09:39.110 --> 00:09:41.680
So we identify who our stakeholders are.

169
00:09:41.680 --> 00:09:46.940
And when we're identifying who they are,
we've got to identify their level

170
00:09:46.940 --> 00:09:52.120
of interest, their level of
involvement in the actual project.

171
00:09:52.120 --> 00:09:56.580
Because you see, they may have
huge interest in the project, but

172
00:09:56.580 --> 00:09:58.490
they may have very little involvement.

173
00:10:00.020 --> 00:10:01.980
So we have to go and identify that.

174
00:10:01.980 --> 00:10:05.650
And then we move into
planning that iteration.

175
00:10:05.650 --> 00:10:09.749
And an iteration, which we saw in
Scrum in the previous episode,

176
00:10:09.749 --> 00:10:14.234
they call it sprint in Scrum,
it'll ask for between one to four weeks.

177
00:10:14.234 --> 00:10:18.165
It really depends on
the scope of the iteration.

178
00:10:18.165 --> 00:10:23.290
An iteration in an agile project should
not last for longer than four weeks.

179
00:10:24.450 --> 00:10:29.600
We're talking about incremental
delivery of functionality.

180
00:10:30.720 --> 00:10:33.249
But then that doesn't mean
that we sort of scrimp and

181
00:10:33.249 --> 00:10:35.610
save when it comes to
requirements definition.

182
00:10:35.610 --> 00:10:39.865
We've still got to be very precise when
it comes to defining what it is we're

183
00:10:39.865 --> 00:10:41.240
delivering.

184
00:10:41.240 --> 00:10:44.440
And we'll talk about user
stories in another episode.

185
00:10:44.440 --> 00:10:49.150
But we do have to know exactly what we're
delivering and what problem we're solving.

186
00:10:50.500 --> 00:10:55.210
Planning an iteration, as it says,
involves elaborating on the requirements,

187
00:10:55.210 --> 00:11:00.100
identifying what tasks are needed
within that iteration.

188
00:11:00.100 --> 00:11:04.950
That iteration being the sprint,
being that portion of work.

189
00:11:04.950 --> 00:11:08.460
That's what we're releasing,
is that portion of work.

190
00:11:08.460 --> 00:11:12.450
We'll talk about in another episode,
cuz this is just a taster.

191
00:11:12.450 --> 00:11:15.710
We'll talk about the relationships
between iterations and

192
00:11:15.710 --> 00:11:18.210
releases in another episode.

193
00:11:19.485 --> 00:11:23.200
But once we've decided what it
is we're going to build and

194
00:11:23.200 --> 00:11:25.880
what it is we're going to deliver,
then we start to deliver.

195
00:11:26.920 --> 00:11:29.750
This is where our development happens.

196
00:11:29.750 --> 00:11:35.540
And so every 24 hours,
we will have our standup meetings, okay?

197
00:11:35.540 --> 00:11:40.270
You might call them your Scrum meetings,
you might call them your daily standup.

198
00:11:40.270 --> 00:11:41.520
We have talked about this.

199
00:11:41.520 --> 00:11:45.710
We have a daily standup meeting
ourselves every morning,

200
00:11:45.710 --> 00:11:51.230
where we discuss exactly what everyone
within the team are going to be doing and

201
00:11:51.230 --> 00:11:54.660
exactly what we're going
to be recording for a day.

202
00:11:54.660 --> 00:11:57.473
And look at, sort of,
our schedules for that day.

203
00:11:57.473 --> 00:12:02.412
And sometimes there may be
things that might happen during

204
00:12:02.412 --> 00:12:06.700
our day where one person
might be unavailable.

205
00:12:06.700 --> 00:12:09.230
And it's at that point in time where
somebody else could say, well, look,

206
00:12:09.230 --> 00:12:09.832
I'm available.

207
00:12:09.832 --> 00:12:12.840
I can stand in, I can do this for you.

208
00:12:12.840 --> 00:12:15.547
And so this is what a standup
meeting really does.

209
00:12:15.547 --> 00:12:20.779
It allows us to identify any challenges,
to outline what

210
00:12:20.779 --> 00:12:26.889
we're going to be doing for
that day and also to identify any help.

211
00:12:26.889 --> 00:12:30.960
[LAUGH] Because sometimes we
all need a little bit of help.

212
00:12:30.960 --> 00:12:31.600
>> This is true, and

213
00:12:31.600 --> 00:12:33.780
especially if it's something
that someone's already done,

214
00:12:33.780 --> 00:12:35.750
especially if they have
that prior knowledge.

215
00:12:35.750 --> 00:12:38.945
And then they can just bring that
knowledge to the table to make your life

216
00:12:38.945 --> 00:12:42.162
a little bit easier.
>> Right, and so every 24 hours you'll

217
00:12:42.162 --> 00:12:47.076
see, and we should really have some arrows
in that graphic there, because every 24

218
00:12:47.076 --> 00:12:51.733
hours, what we're doing is we have our
standup meetings at the start of the day.

219
00:12:51.733 --> 00:12:55.039
And then we want to update
where we've got so far,

220
00:12:55.039 --> 00:12:57.736
and then we want to develop the product.

221
00:12:57.736 --> 00:13:00.745
Then we tell everybody the next
day how far we've got.

222
00:13:00.745 --> 00:13:04.970
And then we update all of our,
we call them our artifacts, but

223
00:13:04.970 --> 00:13:07.663
we want to keep all of our boards, etc.

224
00:13:07.663 --> 00:13:11.875
We wanna make sure that our backlogs
are kept updated with our progress.

225
00:13:13.690 --> 00:13:18.980
Then after we've developed, then,
well, we want to review the increment.

226
00:13:18.980 --> 00:13:21.940
And review the increment means just

227
00:13:21.940 --> 00:13:27.290
evaluating as to whether that increment
actually resolves the user story.

228
00:13:27.290 --> 00:13:30.470
Does it do what it was supposed to do?

229
00:13:30.470 --> 00:13:33.866
And then we also conduct what
we call a retrospective.

230
00:13:33.866 --> 00:13:36.419
And the retrospective is our
lessons learned exercise.

231
00:13:36.419 --> 00:13:39.582
What did we do well,
given that we've only been at this for

232
00:13:39.582 --> 00:13:42.860
maybe a week or maybe four weeks,
what did we do well?

233
00:13:42.860 --> 00:13:45.220
What did we not do so well?

234
00:13:45.220 --> 00:13:48.780
And it's at this point in time
where I expect things like

235
00:13:48.780 --> 00:13:51.110
inefficiencies to be highlighted.

236
00:13:51.110 --> 00:13:52.690
I expect people to say,
well, you know what?

237
00:13:52.690 --> 00:13:54.933
If I'd listened to Cherokee
in the first place,

238
00:13:54.933 --> 00:13:57.460
then maybe I wouldn't be in
this situation right now.

239
00:13:57.460 --> 00:14:00.120
Maybe things wouldn't have been delayed.

240
00:14:00.120 --> 00:14:05.100
And at the end of that,
then a working product is then available.

241
00:14:06.570 --> 00:14:14.820
Now, there's a word in there which is
really important, and that's the word may.

242
00:14:14.820 --> 00:14:18.600
The iteration may be
released to the customer.

243
00:14:20.448 --> 00:14:24.590
In that left-hand corner,
you'll see it says deliver increments, and

244
00:14:24.590 --> 00:14:26.820
then we've got numbers one,
two, and three.

245
00:14:26.820 --> 00:14:29.210
And then we've got the word
release underneath.

246
00:14:30.700 --> 00:14:36.055
You may choose not to release every
single increment in isolation.

247
00:14:38.125 --> 00:14:40.782
Think about this for a moment.

248
00:14:40.782 --> 00:14:45.189
How often does your operating system get

249
00:14:45.189 --> 00:14:49.810
updated on your cellphone?
>> We talked about this earlier.

250
00:14:49.810 --> 00:14:51.530
I think it's pretty frequent.

251
00:14:51.530 --> 00:14:53.450
So you said about a month.

252
00:14:53.450 --> 00:14:56.019
I'd say something similar to that,
month, month and a half,

253
00:14:56.019 --> 00:14:59.577
somewhere around there.
>> Yeah, and how happy are you with

254
00:14:59.577 --> 00:15:05.642
the frequency of those releases?
>> Well, that's relative,

255
00:15:05.642 --> 00:15:11.062
because am I happy that my information
is spread across the Internet

256
00:15:11.062 --> 00:15:15.637
because they're updating
security vulnerabilities?

257
00:15:15.637 --> 00:15:17.800
Then, yes.

258
00:15:17.800 --> 00:15:19.100
Am I inconvenienced?

259
00:15:19.100 --> 00:15:23.870
Yes, but it's not life changing.
>> There

260
00:15:23.870 --> 00:15:25.760
has to be a balance.
>> Right.

261
00:15:25.760 --> 00:15:27.090
>> There has to be, and

262
00:15:27.090 --> 00:15:31.476
this is where development teams and
project teams have to be very,

263
00:15:31.476 --> 00:15:33.921
very aware of who their customer is.

264
00:15:33.921 --> 00:15:36.430
Cuz there has to be a balance.

265
00:15:36.430 --> 00:15:41.700
If you're releasing every week,
it's gonna cause instability.

266
00:15:41.700 --> 00:15:45.507
And not just instability
within your own environment,

267
00:15:45.507 --> 00:15:49.345
it's also going to cause some very-
>> Unhappy?

268
00:15:49.345 --> 00:15:53.072
I'm thinking of the politically
correct word to say here, but

269
00:15:53.072 --> 00:15:54.780
they're gonna be unhappy.

270
00:15:54.780 --> 00:15:58.760
Customers don't want to be interrupted.
>> Loss of reputation, there we go.

271
00:15:58.760 --> 00:16:00.246
>> Right, loss of credibility,

272
00:16:00.246 --> 00:16:01.279
loss of reputation.

273
00:16:01.279 --> 00:16:05.899
Customers don't want to be
interrupted every couple of hours, or

274
00:16:05.899 --> 00:16:09.620
every couple of days, or
even maybe every week or so.

275
00:16:09.620 --> 00:16:13.900
So we have to get the balance right
between maintaining stability but

276
00:16:13.900 --> 00:16:19.086
also being responsive to changing factors
and being responsive to requirements.

277
00:16:19.086 --> 00:16:21.223
And we've got to deliver requirements.

278
00:16:21.223 --> 00:16:25.230
We've also got to deliver, you mentioned
security patches and security updates.

279
00:16:25.230 --> 00:16:27.600
We've still gotta be
able to deliver those.

280
00:16:27.600 --> 00:16:32.540
So what we may choose to do is we may
choose to bundle together increments.

281
00:16:32.540 --> 00:16:35.300
So we may choose to have
a release schedule that, say,

282
00:16:35.300 --> 00:16:38.990
releases every four weeks, or
releases every three weeks.

283
00:16:38.990 --> 00:16:42.151
But understanding that
on the odd exception,

284
00:16:42.151 --> 00:16:44.743
when there has been security issues,

285
00:16:44.743 --> 00:16:50.104
that we may need to release an increment
outside of those scheduled releases.

286
00:16:50.104 --> 00:16:53.471
And that would be our hot fixes or, yeah.

287
00:16:53.471 --> 00:16:56.577
And then just with like our features,
usually,

288
00:16:56.577 --> 00:16:59.848
then that would be on
the normal release schedule.

289
00:16:59.848 --> 00:17:04.179
But then any kind of immediate security
vulnerability would require that immediate

290
00:17:04.179 --> 00:17:06.990
attention with that hot fix.
>> Right, yeah.

291
00:17:06.990 --> 00:17:11.023
So there's no right or
wrong when it comes to when to release and

292
00:17:11.023 --> 00:17:14.675
when it comes to how many
increments to have in a release,

293
00:17:14.675 --> 00:17:19.505
other than get to know your customer and
know what your customer wants.

294
00:17:19.505 --> 00:17:25.300
The other thing that I would say to
you is you have got a major increment,

295
00:17:25.300 --> 00:17:29.280
if you have got some
major functionality that

296
00:17:29.280 --> 00:17:33.170
really is going to cause some disruption,
positive disruption,

297
00:17:33.170 --> 00:17:37.010
you'd like to hope, but is going to have
an impact in the customer environment,

298
00:17:37.010 --> 00:17:39.640
you may choose to release
that separately as well.

299
00:17:39.640 --> 00:17:43.770
You don't necessarily want it bundled
in with lots of other increments too.

300
00:17:43.770 --> 00:17:48.460
So get to know your customer and
get to know what they would prefer, and

301
00:17:48.460 --> 00:17:51.260
think also, though,
about the stability of your environment.

302
00:17:52.870 --> 00:17:56.960
But then it doesn't just stop there,
it's not just the one-off exercise.

303
00:17:56.960 --> 00:18:00.408
And this is where it talks
about iterative development,

304
00:18:00.408 --> 00:18:06.550
because you'll notice that
these wheels keep turning.

305
00:18:06.550 --> 00:18:10.240
After the iteration review and
retrospective, we go back and

306
00:18:10.240 --> 00:18:13.180
we start planning our next iteration.

307
00:18:13.180 --> 00:18:16.070
So we develop our products in increments,

308
00:18:16.070 --> 00:18:21.068
understanding that our products may
not just be a one-off exercise.

309
00:18:23.110 --> 00:18:27.048
If we were to take into
consideration lean principles and

310
00:18:27.048 --> 00:18:32.215
lean principles talk about minimal waste,
then with every single cycle,

311
00:18:32.215 --> 00:18:36.088
as we release an increment,
we become more efficient.

312
00:18:36.088 --> 00:18:39.029
Because we conduct those
