retrospectives and

313
00:18:39.029 --> 00:18:43.825
we conduct our lessons learned, and
then we learn about efficiencies and

314
00:18:43.825 --> 00:18:46.932
we learn about how we can
be more effectivness.

315
00:18:46.932 --> 00:18:49.073
And we also enhanced our skills, as well,

316
00:18:49.073 --> 00:18:51.580
because we have collaboration
across our teams.

317
00:18:53.250 --> 00:18:56.350
So Agile provides for
iterative development.

318
00:18:56.350 --> 00:18:59.830
It provides for learning.

319
00:18:59.830 --> 00:19:05.340
It gives us an environment where
we can introduce functionality,

320
00:19:05.340 --> 00:19:07.820
still in a controlled manner, but

321
00:19:07.820 --> 00:19:13.152
also at a frequency where our customers
are happy with our development.

322
00:19:13.152 --> 00:19:18.000
And they're happy with our responsiveness
to their environment into their

323
00:19:18.000 --> 00:19:18.570
requirements.

324
00:19:20.370 --> 00:19:25.830
So that's it for
our quick delve into the Agile life cycle.

325
00:19:25.830 --> 00:19:30.330
Now, in future episodes, we're actually
going to be looking at all of those

326
00:19:30.330 --> 00:19:33.040
activities that we've just
discussed in a lot more depth.

327
00:19:34.240 --> 00:19:38.200
But for now, for our next episode we're
going to be taking a quick look into

328
00:19:38.200 --> 00:19:43.110
the roles that we have within an Agile
environment and we'll hopefully see

329
00:19:43.110 --> 00:19:45.220
you in our next episode.
>> Awesome, Jo,

330
00:19:45.220 --> 00:19:49.740
I'm just super excited that now instead
of going to my afternoon meeting,

331
00:19:49.740 --> 00:19:53.700
I can inform everyone that we
are going to have an artifact update.

332
00:19:53.700 --> 00:19:56.870
So instead of giving my show count today,
how many shows I recorded,

333
00:19:56.870 --> 00:20:01.680
I can say, my artifact update is, artifact
update, if I can say that properly,

334
00:20:01.680 --> 00:20:03.670
is blah, blah, blah.

335
00:20:03.670 --> 00:20:05.770
So, pretty cool, thank you for
that information.

336
00:20:05.770 --> 00:20:09.146
And thank you for joining us as well,
but we are out of time for this show, so

337
00:20:09.146 --> 00:20:10.020
we'll sign out.

338
00:20:10.020 --> 00:20:12.605
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

339
00:20:12.605 --> 00:20:15.089
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

340
00:20:15.089 --> 00:20:21.266
[MUSIC]

341
00:20:21.266 --> 00:20:24.354
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: We discuss the common roles to be found in Agile project management methodologies. We expand on the concept of the Product Owner and look at other commonly found roles such as the scrum Master (from the Scrum methodology) and the Project Manager.
episodes.title: Agile Roles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:01.495
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.495 --> 00:00:02.913
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.913 --> 00:00:07.390
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.390 --> 00:00:08.340
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.340 --> 00:00:13.014
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.
>> Welcome back to your

6
00:00:13.014 --> 00:00:15.221
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

7
00:00:15.221 --> 00:00:17.121
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.121 --> 00:00:20.618
In this episode,
we'll be taking a look at Agile roles.

9
00:00:20.618 --> 00:00:25.120
And of course, with us today to explain
those roles, we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:27.690
How's it going today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, Cherokee.

11
00:00:27.690 --> 00:00:29.090
How are you?
>> I'm good but

12
00:00:29.090 --> 00:00:31.780
I'm not really sure about my
role in this whole show thing.

13
00:00:31.780 --> 00:00:33.320
So you're gonna have to
help me out with that

14
00:00:33.320 --> 00:00:34.202
here.
>> No,

15
00:00:34.202 --> 00:00:36.651
I think you're gonna have to
figure it out as we go along.

16
00:00:36.651 --> 00:00:39.432
I think that's the best option.
>> But you are the scrum master,

17
00:00:39.432 --> 00:00:42.405
right?
>> No, not really, no.

18
00:00:42.405 --> 00:00:45.264
Cuz there is somethings
that are just beyond hope.

19
00:00:45.264 --> 00:00:47.810
>> So maybe we can send some light on

20
00:00:47.810 --> 00:00:48.432
the roles.

21
00:00:48.432 --> 00:00:51.909
What a scrum master is and what they
should and should not be doing and

22
00:00:51.909 --> 00:00:55.560
I'll let you decide.
>> Well, I think we should probably start

23
00:00:55.560 --> 00:01:01.200
off by telling them that we're
looking at Agile projects right now.

24
00:01:01.200 --> 00:01:05.430
And we've been in previous episodes
looking at Agile methodologies.

25
00:01:05.430 --> 00:01:07.419
And we've taken a very, very,

26
00:01:07.419 --> 00:01:12.220
very high level look at the activities
that are involved in an Agile project.

27
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:16.220
And of course, we've looked at the
principles of an Agile project as well.

28
00:01:16.220 --> 00:01:19.550
And so in this particular episode,
as Cherokee says,

29
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:24.090
we're going to look at the roles
that there are in Agile.

30
00:01:24.090 --> 00:01:26.720
And I'm gonna be perfectly
honest with you.

31
00:01:26.720 --> 00:01:31.440
There aren't many specific
roles within an Agile project.

32
00:01:31.440 --> 00:01:33.970
There aren't many defined roles.

33
00:01:33.970 --> 00:01:39.480
What we do have though, is we do have,
well, four roles that we've got defined.

34
00:01:40.530 --> 00:01:42.770
And it says here these are common roles.

35
00:01:42.770 --> 00:01:47.395
And in fact you'll see one of them,
certainly the role of a scrum master,

36
00:01:47.395 --> 00:01:50.350
is well, we've seen that before.

37
00:01:50.350 --> 00:01:51.590
We've seen that in scrum.

38
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:56.800
And scrum is a methodology that these
adhering to the Agile principles,

39
00:01:56.800 --> 00:02:00.530
so we consider that to
be an Agile methodology.

40
00:02:00.530 --> 00:02:03.890
And it says in that bottom bullet point
that the roles may vary depending on

41
00:02:03.890 --> 00:02:06.020
the methodology that we used.

42
00:02:06.020 --> 00:02:10.290
But for the most part, certainly the roles
of scrum master and the roles of product

43
00:02:10.290 --> 00:02:16.020
owner are roles that appear in most Agile
projects, whether they're scrum or not.

44
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:18.760
We tend to refer a lot
to the scrum master.

45
00:02:20.090 --> 00:02:23.400
So let's knock off two of these,
really easy, right now and

46
00:02:23.400 --> 00:02:24.770
then we'll take a look at the other two.

47
00:02:25.930 --> 00:02:28.550
So we take a look at the team member.

48
00:02:28.550 --> 00:02:29.750
And the team member, well,

49
00:02:29.750 --> 00:02:35.890
as it says performs the daily
work of building the solution.

50
00:02:35.890 --> 00:02:38.260
These are our developers,
these are our programmers.

51
00:02:38.260 --> 00:02:41.420
These are the people that
are actually doing the coding.

52
00:02:41.420 --> 00:02:46.290
And these are the people that are,
well, at the call face as it were.

53
00:02:46.290 --> 00:02:51.040
So these are the people that are going
to help us plan our iteration.

54
00:02:51.040 --> 00:02:55.090
These are the people that are going to
help us prioritize the user stories that

55
00:02:55.090 --> 00:02:56.600
are in our iteration.

56
00:02:56.600 --> 00:02:59.370
And these are the people that
are actually going to delivery the work.

57
00:02:59.370 --> 00:03:01.860
And then they're going to be
conducting the reviews and

58
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:04.380
the retrospectives as well afterwards.

59
00:03:04.380 --> 00:03:06.490
And of course I expect
all of these people,

60
00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:11.350
all of them, to be present in
the daily standup meeting.

61
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:13.470
And it's really important that, and

62
00:03:13.470 --> 00:03:16.310
I put emphasis on all of them being
present at the daily standup.

63
00:03:16.310 --> 00:03:20.510
It's really important that all of them
are present at the daily standup.

64
00:03:20.510 --> 00:03:23.780
Because the daily standup meeting,
or the scrum meeting.

65
00:03:23.780 --> 00:03:28.040
Whatever you want to call it depending
on what methodology you're using.

66
00:03:28.040 --> 00:03:32.830
That's the opportunity for everybody
to outline what their role is for

67
00:03:32.830 --> 00:03:34.750
that particular day.

68
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:37.580
And some days,
my role might be as a developer.

69
00:03:37.580 --> 00:03:42.390
But other days my role might as a tester,
for instance.

70
00:03:42.390 --> 00:03:44.960
Other days I might me an estimator.

71
00:03:44.960 --> 00:03:48.270
So it's really important that
we have that daily meeting so

72
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:51.700
that we can identify who's
doing what on any given day.

73
00:03:51.700 --> 00:03:57.150
And that if there are any gaps in our
tasks, in other words, that we've

74
00:03:57.150 --> 00:04:01.910
got people with different skills that
aren't quite able to do certain tasks.

75
00:04:01.910 --> 00:04:04.380
Then somebody else can step in.

76
00:04:04.380 --> 00:04:08.840
So it's very important that all of our
team members are in place at our team

77
00:04:08.840 --> 00:04:10.470
meetings, at our daily standups.

78
00:04:11.480 --> 00:04:16.664
We also have, and it's the second one
down on that particular list there,

79
00:04:16.664 --> 00:04:18.573
the role of an Agile coach.

80
00:04:18.573 --> 00:04:22.995
The role of an Agile coach
is quite an unusual one,

81
00:04:22.995 --> 00:04:30.490
inasmuch as it's something that we will
generally not utilize, and yet we should.

82
00:04:32.140 --> 00:04:36.920
And that really is the person
who will come in and

83
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:40.220
will guide the team, and
guide maybe the scrum master and

84
00:04:40.220 --> 00:04:43.580
the product owner,
through what they should be doing.

85
00:04:43.580 --> 00:04:44.650
And through roles and

86
00:04:44.650 --> 00:04:49.490
responsibilities and maybe would provide
advice on who should take charge of what.

87
00:04:51.060 --> 00:04:54.210
Let's be honest, there are quite often,
within any team,

88
00:04:54.210 --> 00:04:56.940
there's quite often sort
of contentious times.

89
00:04:56.940 --> 00:05:00.760
When we don't always agree when
we're working within a team.

90
00:05:00.760 --> 00:05:03.600
And it's the Agile coach that
will come in and will say, right.

91
00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:05.970
Well as far as Agile is concerned,

92
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:08.870
this would be the most efficient
way to work with that.

93
00:05:08.870 --> 00:05:11.970
And as far as Agile
methodologies are concerned,

94
00:05:11.970 --> 00:05:13.990
this is where we should put this.

95
00:05:13.990 --> 00:05:17.990
So we should have a board and we should
put everything on this particular board

96
00:05:17.990 --> 00:05:21.350
according to whatever methodology
it is that you're using.

97
00:05:21.350 --> 00:05:25.130
So the role of the Agile coach
shouldn't actually be underestimated.

98
00:05:25.130 --> 00:05:28.980
There should be somebody
within that development team,

99
00:05:28.980 --> 00:05:32.830
who is fully aware of Agile methodologies.

100
00:05:32.830 --> 00:05:38.238
It's really easy as a team member to
walk into an Agile project team and

101
00:05:38.238 --> 00:05:43.750
not actually realize that you're
working to a specific methodology.

102
00:05:43.750 --> 00:05:47.090
Or not actually realize that you're
working as a part of an Agile team.

103
00:05:48.090 --> 00:05:48.850
You may just think,

104
00:05:48.850 --> 00:05:50.710
well that's the way the team works and-
>> Right, and

105
00:05:50.710 --> 00:05:53.360
that's exactly what happened to
me when I started working here.

106
00:05:53.360 --> 00:05:56.780
I wasn't like, hey, during orientation.

107
00:05:56.780 --> 00:05:58.580
And we're Agile, and
this is what we're gonna do.

108
00:05:58.580 --> 00:06:01.652
It just kind of happened natively, or

109
00:06:01.652 --> 00:06:02.876
naturally.
>> And

110
00:06:02.876 --> 00:06:04.760
I wonder how many people have walked in.

111
00:06:04.760 --> 00:06:09.860
And we have daily standups ourselves
where we will do exactly that.

112
00:06:09.860 --> 00:06:13.433
The 15 minutes where we all stand around
and discuss what we're going to do for

113
00:06:13.433 --> 00:06:14.350
the rest of the day.

114
00:06:14.350 --> 00:06:15.840
We go around the group.

115
00:06:15.840 --> 00:06:19.959
And I wonder how many people realize that
that's actually got something to do with

116
00:06:19.959 --> 00:06:22.130
Agile and what the purpose is.

117
00:06:22.130 --> 00:06:25.590
And I'm sure that, unless it's explained
to you, I'm sure that there are probably

118
00:06:25.590 --> 00:06:28.380
people who probably don't
want to admit it as well.

119
00:06:28.380 --> 00:06:33.099
But they're probably people within our
organization who wonder why they're doing

120
00:06:33.099 --> 00:06:35.445
it and
think of it as being a bit of a pain.

121
00:06:35.445 --> 00:06:39.400
[LAUGH] A little bit of a chore and
fairly cumbersome, and

122
00:06:39.400 --> 00:06:40.770
that's the purpose behind it.

123
00:06:40.770 --> 00:06:43.201
And when you understand
the purpose it all makes sense.

124
00:06:43.201 --> 00:06:45.710
And that's what the Agile
coach is there for.

125
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:48.700
It doesn't have to be somebody external.

126
00:06:48.700 --> 00:06:50.260
It doesn't have to be a consultant.

127
00:06:50.260 --> 00:06:51.550
It doesn't have to be a trainer.

128
00:06:51.550 --> 00:06:54.520
It doesn't have to be somebody like me,
that walks in and

129
00:06:54.520 --> 00:06:57.840
then oversees everybody to make sure
everybody's doing the right thing.

130
00:06:59.120 --> 00:07:00.770
Did you have a,
you put your hand up there.

131
00:07:00.770 --> 00:07:02.010
>> I did, I was like, hold on.

132
00:07:02.010 --> 00:07:05.560
No, because when you said that
it made sense because, so

133
00:07:05.560 --> 00:07:08.660
we do surveys from the employees.

134
00:07:08.660 --> 00:07:13.250
And one of the comments on one
of the employee surveys was

135
00:07:13.250 --> 00:07:15.490
why do we have this long
meeting in the morning?

136
00:07:15.490 --> 00:07:19.190
And I think that at that point in time,
and this was a while back, but

137
00:07:19.190 --> 00:07:22.932
it brought to the forefront
the need of that explanation.

138
00:07:22.932 --> 00:07:27.200
So that's something that we do do talk
about often as we're onboarding new

139
00:07:27.200 --> 00:07:28.980
people at this point in time.

140
00:07:28.980 --> 00:07:32.360
Because it is a question that
someone may genuinely have.

141
00:07:32.360 --> 00:07:34.060
Why are we doing this?

142
00:07:34.060 --> 00:07:38.615
Right, and that's exactly why you need
somebody who is willing to step up and

143
00:07:38.615 --> 00:07:39.749
be an Agile coach.

144
00:07:39.749 --> 00:07:43.032
You see, what we don't want to do, and
we're going to get into the roles of

145
00:07:43.032 --> 00:07:45.810
scrum master, product owner and
product manager in a moment.

146
00:07:45.810 --> 00:07:49.350
But what we don't want to do is we don't
want to distract the scrum master and

147
00:07:49.350 --> 00:07:52.070
the product owner from their work.

148
00:07:52.070 --> 00:07:54.343
And this is why the Agile
coach would get involved and

149
00:07:54.343 --> 00:07:57.457
would actually sit down with that
person and say this is the reason why.

150
00:07:57.457 --> 00:08:01.154
Or maybe the Agile coach
will be somebody who before,

151
00:08:01.154 --> 00:08:05.674
in orientation for instance Before
we start work on any project,

152
00:08:05.674 --> 00:08:10.792
we'll explain all of the concepts of
that project and that methodology.

153
00:08:10.792 --> 00:08:14.027
It doesn't have to be
something that's complex, and

154
00:08:14.027 --> 00:08:16.711
it doesn't have to be
via a formal training.

155
00:08:16.711 --> 00:08:21.050
It could be just simply a sit down,
this is how we work.

156
00:08:21.050 --> 00:08:24.428
So we've also got another two roles,
and I haven't ignored them.

157
00:08:24.428 --> 00:08:28.341
And these are the roles of product
owner and the role of scrum master.

158
00:08:28.341 --> 00:08:32.474
And so let's just take a look
at the role of product owner.

159
00:08:32.474 --> 00:08:37.613
Now the responsibilities,
even though in an agile project

160
00:08:37.613 --> 00:08:42.546
we will say that we don't
have rigid responsibilities,

161
00:08:42.546 --> 00:08:46.451
we don't have rigid roles, nevertheless,

162
00:08:46.451 --> 00:08:51.588
we still have to understand that
the role of scrum master and

163
00:08:51.588 --> 00:08:56.964
the role of product owner do
have defined responsibilities.

164
00:08:56.964 --> 00:09:01.674
I want you to think of the product
owner as being the person that takes

165
00:09:01.674 --> 00:09:06.648
ownership and takes accountability for
the technical side of things.

166
00:09:06.648 --> 00:09:08.707
So they take accountability for

167
00:09:08.707 --> 00:09:13.420
ensuring that the requirements
meet the business needs.

168
00:09:13.420 --> 00:09:17.766
They take accountability for
all of the coding.

169
00:09:17.766 --> 00:09:22.841
They define what the prioritization
is on the use of stories,

170
00:09:22.841 --> 00:09:26.560
and they define the product
backlog itself.

171
00:09:26.560 --> 00:09:31.090
So they look at the functionality
that's required by the business, and

172
00:09:31.090 --> 00:09:34.496
they work with a team on functionality.

173
00:09:34.496 --> 00:09:38.560
So if you've got any technical queries,
you go to the product owner.

174
00:09:39.590 --> 00:09:45.040
If you've got any queries concerning
the requirements and whether a particular

175
00:09:45.040 --> 00:09:50.103
piece of coding will meet requirements,
then you go to the product owner.

176
00:09:50.103 --> 00:09:52.419
And the product owner owns the product,

177
00:09:52.419 --> 00:09:55.702
that's why they're called
a product owner obviously.

178
00:09:55.702 --> 00:09:57.142
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

179
00:09:57.142 --> 00:09:58.047
>> Yeah, I know.

180
00:09:58.047 --> 00:10:01.101
I just said that and I suddenly thought,
that sounds ridiculous.

181
00:10:01.101 --> 00:10:04.804
But yeah, that's why they're called that,
they own the product.

182
00:10:04.804 --> 00:10:11.097
So they own the functionality, and they
will make decisions on the functionality.

183
00:10:11.097 --> 00:10:13.741
They define what the team works on next,
but

184
00:10:13.741 --> 00:10:17.178
they actually make the decisions
on the functionality.

185
00:10:17.178 --> 00:10:20.646
And then we have the scrum master.

186
00:10:20.646 --> 00:10:25.559
The scrum master, I love that bottom
bullet point, the enforcer of rules.

187
00:10:25.559 --> 00:10:28.473
No, they do not stand there
with a baseball bat, all right?

188
00:10:28.473 --> 00:10:30.876
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] As much as you probably would

189
00:10:30.876 --> 00:10:32.687
like that, but-
>> Well, I don't know.

190
00:10:32.687 --> 00:10:34.843
I mean from a sadistic perspective,
yeah, probably.

191
00:10:34.843 --> 00:10:35.554
>> [LAUGH] No,

192
00:10:35.554 --> 00:10:39.644
I'm just joking with you, Jo.
>> [LAUGH] No, I mean as a scrum master,

193
00:10:39.644 --> 00:10:43.708
yeah, I'd love to have that power,
but no, that's not what they do.

194
00:10:43.708 --> 00:10:49.528
All right, the enforcer of rules
means that, I mean, bear it in mind,

195
00:10:49.528 --> 00:10:56.124
we don't have the huge defined processes
that may exist in a waterfall project,

196
00:10:56.124 --> 00:10:59.810
so these guys,
these people are the people or

197
00:10:59.810 --> 00:11:03.890
the person that ensures
that the team is working.

198
00:11:03.890 --> 00:11:08.175
So ensures collaboration,
gets the team working together.

199
00:11:08.175 --> 00:11:11.388
I think in a previous episode,
we talked about what if you and

200
00:11:11.388 --> 00:11:12.968
I weren't seeing eye to eye.

201
00:11:12.968 --> 00:11:14.508
Who would resolve that?

202
00:11:14.508 --> 00:11:16.920
It's the scrum master
that would resolve that.

203
00:11:16.920 --> 00:11:19.786
If you and
I couldn't agree on our responsibilities,

204
00:11:19.786 --> 00:11:22.101
it's the scrum master that resolves that.

205
00:11:22.101 --> 00:11:24.388
So let me ask you a question then.

206
00:11:24.388 --> 00:11:27.976
Let's say that you and I were developers.

207
00:11:27.976 --> 00:11:32.106
I can dream, but anyway, [LAUGH]
let's say that we were developers and

208
00:11:32.106 --> 00:11:33.928
we were developing a product.

209
00:11:33.928 --> 00:11:36.016
And we couldn't agree on functionality.

210
00:11:36.016 --> 00:11:39.913
I wanted to do it one way, and
you wanted to do it another way.

211
00:11:39.913 --> 00:11:40.865
Who would we go to?

212
00:11:40.865 --> 00:11:45.475
Who would decide what to do?
>> Our mommy.

213
00:11:45.475 --> 00:11:46.876
>> [LAUGH]

214
00:11:46.876 --> 00:11:50.103
>> [LAUGH] No, Jo, our scrum master.

215
00:11:50.103 --> 00:11:50.812
I had to say that.

216
00:11:50.812 --> 00:11:54.912
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, so somebody not only needs mommy,

217
00:11:54.912 --> 00:11:59.090
but somebody hasn't been paying attention.
>> [LAUGH]

218
00:11:59.090 --> 00:12:00.240
>> Because what I asked you was, and

219
00:12:00.240 --> 00:12:02.473
this is where we've gotta
get responsibilities right.

220
00:12:02.473 --> 00:12:05.847
>> Not to bother our scrum master.

221
00:12:05.847 --> 00:12:07.495
>> Did I say not to bother our scrum

222
00:12:07.495 --> 00:12:08.006
master?

223
00:12:08.006 --> 00:12:12.534
No, what I said was our product
owner owns the product, and

224
00:12:12.534 --> 00:12:15.896
they make decisions to
do with the product.

225
00:12:15.896 --> 00:12:18.601
So it's the product owner
that would resolve that.

226
00:12:18.601 --> 00:12:19.472
>> Okay.

227
00:12:19.472 --> 00:12:20.989
>> Now the scrum master would resolve any

228
00:12:20.989 --> 00:12:24.183
interpersonal issues that you have.
>> Okay, thanks for

229
00:12:24.183 --> 00:12:27.981
clarifying because okay.
>> Yeah?

230
00:12:27.981 --> 00:12:29.746
>> I got it.

231
00:12:29.746 --> 00:12:31.858
>> So the scrum master is responsible for

232
00:12:31.858 --> 00:12:35.818
the fact that I have threatened to
take you outside with a baseball bat,

233
00:12:35.818 --> 00:12:36.476
right?
>> [LAUGH]

234
00:12:36.476 --> 00:12:37.611
>> Because you clearly weren't

235
00:12:37.611 --> 00:12:38.384
paying attention.

236
00:12:38.384 --> 00:12:40.961
[LAUGH] That's the scrum master.

237
00:12:40.961 --> 00:12:44.336
But the product owner is the person
that will make the decision to do with

238
00:12:44.336 --> 00:12:45.356
the functionality.

239
00:12:45.356 --> 00:12:48.500
So if you and
I had a disagreement on functionality,

240
00:12:48.500 --> 00:12:50.787
on which way to do the development, or

241
00:12:50.787 --> 00:12:55.575
on what the output of the development
should look like, it's the product owner

242
00:12:55.575 --> 00:12:58.971
that makes that decision.
>> Would the agile coach ever

243
00:12:58.971 --> 00:13:03.923
step in in this type of situation?
>> The agile coach might advise.

244
00:13:03.923 --> 00:13:08.050
I mean, the agile coach may pull the scrum
master and the product owner aside and

245
00:13:08.050 --> 00:13:10.270
say, you've got to decide on this.

246
00:13:10.270 --> 00:13:13.210
And if I were the agile coach
in that particular instance,

247
00:13:13.210 --> 00:13:16.450
I would go back to the product owner and
I would simply say right,

248
00:13:16.450 --> 00:13:19.270
you've gotta make the decision
on functionality, but

249
00:13:19.270 --> 00:13:21.312
you need to sort them two out-
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

250
00:13:21.312 --> 00:13:22.430
>> Cuz they keep arguing.

251
00:13:22.430 --> 00:13:26.691
[LAUGH] All right, so the agile coach
might advise in that respect, but

252
00:13:26.691 --> 00:13:28.219
nothing more than that.

253
00:13:28.219 --> 00:13:30.959
The agile coach is not
going to get involved.

254
00:13:30.959 --> 00:13:35.595
They're just going to sort of we
want the team to work efficiently.

255
00:13:35.595 --> 00:13:40.347
And so what they're gonna do is
really just give the managers

256
00:13:40.347 --> 00:13:45.016
the tools with which to ensure
the team works efficiently.

257
00:13:45.016 --> 00:13:50.360
So the scrum master is the person that, it
says removes impediments to the backlog.

258
00:13:50.360 --> 00:13:57.259
So if the scrum master sees any potential
conflict or sees any potential obstacles,

259
00:13:57.259 --> 00:14:03.101
it's the scrum master's responsibility
to remove those obstacles.

260
00:14:03.101 --> 00:14:06.462
Now they may well be technical obstacles,
in which case,

261
00:14:06.462 --> 00:14:10.030
then the scrum master may
refer to the product owner.

262
00:14:10.030 --> 00:14:14.261
But remember, the product owner is
responsible for the technical aspect.

263
00:14:14.261 --> 00:14:17.853
The scrum master is also responsible for
communication.

264
00:14:17.853 --> 00:14:21.929
And in a previous episode,
we looked at communication as being in

265
00:14:21.929 --> 00:14:25.498
the language of whoever it
is you're communicating to.

266
00:14:25.498 --> 00:14:29.338
So the scrum master's role is to
ensure that if we're communicating to

267
00:14:29.338 --> 00:14:32.602
the customers,
we're communicating in their language and

268
00:14:32.602 --> 00:14:35.355
that we're communicating
what they need to hear.

269
00:14:35.355 --> 00:14:39.117
With any communication, the recipient
always wants to answer the question,

270
00:14:39.117 --> 00:14:40.145
what's in it for me?

271
00:14:40.145 --> 00:14:42.460
And that's that the scrum
master's got to be able to do.

272
00:14:42.460 --> 00:14:47.806
And so when the scrum master is the person
that is managing the team as it were,

273
00:14:47.806 --> 00:14:52.593
then the scrum master needs to
communicate in the team's language.

274
00:14:52.593 --> 00:14:53.963
So who do you think then,

275
00:14:53.963 --> 00:14:56.223
here's a question.
>> Gosh.

276
00:14:56.223 --> 00:15:01.243
[LAUGH]
>> Who do you think that drives or

277
00:15:01.243 --> 00:15:06.312
ensures that the daily stand
up meeting runs on time?

278
00:15:08.355 --> 00:15:10.467
I love these trick questions.
>> I know, I'm so nervous now.

279
00:15:10.467 --> 00:15:12.475
I don't know what to say.
>> [CROSSTALK] in the episode, right?

280
00:15:12.475 --> 00:15:16.051
[LAUGH] I wanna say scrum master.
>> It is, yeah.

281
00:15:16.051 --> 00:15:17.548
>> Okay.

282
00:15:17.548 --> 00:15:18.917
>> Because it's to do [LAUGH] with

283
00:15:18.917 --> 00:15:20.346
the facilitation of the team.

284
00:15:20.346 --> 00:15:22.692
And it's to do with
the efficiency of the team.

285
00:15:22.692 --> 00:15:24.642
So yes,
it's the scrum master that would do that.

286
00:15:24.642 --> 00:15:26.840
>> Okay.

287
00:15:26.840 --> 00:15:28.244
>> Yeah, so product owner just remember,

288
00:15:28.244 --> 00:15:30.776
product owner takes accountability for
the functional side of things.

289
00:15:30.776 --> 00:15:35.796
And the scrum master takes accountability
for the actual efficiency of the team.

290
00:15:35.796 --> 00:15:39.765
Ensures that the team is functional and
productive, okay?

291
00:15:39.765 --> 00:15:42.981
Now we've got one more role here
that I just wanna talk about.

292
00:15:42.981 --> 00:15:46.253
And I don't wanna spend too
long talking about this, but

293
00:15:46.253 --> 00:15:49.880
I know that this is a role that
exists in a lot of organizations.

294
00:15:49.880 --> 00:15:53.043
And it's a role that,
I guess psychologically,

295
00:15:53.043 --> 00:15:55.611
we can't get away from for some reason.

296
00:15:55.611 --> 00:15:59.518
It's also a role that most people
outside of IT are familiar with as well.

297
00:15:59.518 --> 00:16:02.909
If you go outside of IT and
start talking about scrum masters,

298
00:16:02.909 --> 00:16:06.054
they might look at you as
though you're slightly crazy.

299
00:16:06.054 --> 00:16:10.131
And certainly in the UK,
if you start talking about scrum masters,

300
00:16:10.131 --> 00:16:12.643
then people start thinking about rugby.

301
00:16:15.121 --> 00:16:17.750
You don't know that, yeah.
>> I know what rugby is, but

302
00:16:17.750 --> 00:16:22.710
I have no clue what role a scrum
master plays in the rugby family.

303
00:16:22.710 --> 00:16:25.224
>> Right, okay, so rugby scrum is, and

304
00:16:25.224 --> 00:16:30.184
now I'm gonna get, I'm gonna get
death threats, I can tell you now.

305
00:16:30.184 --> 00:16:32.219
>> [LAUGH] But a rugby scrum is basically,

306
00:16:32.219 --> 00:16:35.272
I've seen something similar
in American football, but

307
00:16:35.272 --> 00:16:39.342
it's really when all of the players on
the field just sort of get together and

308
00:16:39.342 --> 00:16:41.660
they're all just-
>> Huddle?

309
00:16:41.660 --> 00:16:43.685
>> Yeah, it could well be, it could be.

310
00:16:43.685 --> 00:16:44.544
>> Tackle?

311
00:16:44.544 --> 00:16:47.124
>> Yeah, no, it's more of a pile on more

312
00:16:47.124 --> 00:16:49.141
than anything else.
>> Okay.

313
00:16:49.141 --> 00:16:49.997
>> Okay, so this so

314
00:16:49.997 --> 00:16:52.259
the scrum master has
the responsibility for

315
00:16:52.259 --> 00:16:57.350
organizing the team.
>> Rugby is just like American football,

316
00:16:57.350 --> 00:17:00.880
but because we're tough and hard we
just don't have all of the armor and

317
00:17:00.880 --> 00:17:02.030
everything.
>> Okay.

318
00:17:02.030 --> 00:17:05.169
>> Yeah, we just get the injuries instead,

319
00:17:05.169 --> 00:17:05.800
right?

320
00:17:05.800 --> 00:17:07.530
Yeah, it's not good.

321
00:17:07.530 --> 00:17:09.790
It's quite, yes.

322
00:17:10.860 --> 00:17:13.920
As scrum master then,
it's probably something that,

323
00:17:13.920 --> 00:17:17.490
certainly in the UK you've heard the words
scrum burden, not anywhere else.

324
00:17:17.490 --> 00:17:22.170
And so it's not something I expect
the business to be aware of.

325
00:17:22.170 --> 00:17:24.651
So the business is generally aware
of the project manager role.

326
00:17:24.651 --> 00:17:27.160
>> Right.

327
00:17:27.160 --> 00:17:28.820
>> What you may wanna do,

328
00:17:28.820 --> 00:17:34.100
in your Agile project,
is you may want to refer to the project,

329
00:17:34.100 --> 00:17:36.670
or to the scrum master
as a project manager.

330
00:17:36.670 --> 00:17:37.690
We don't care.

331
00:17:37.690 --> 00:17:42.500
I mean, it's a methodology and it's up to
you to decide which methodology you use,

332
00:17:42.500 --> 00:17:43.516
and what roles and

333
00:17:43.516 --> 00:17:48.940
what responsibilities you give each role.
>> However, if all of those practitioners

334
00:17:48.940 --> 00:17:54.210
and all of those developers have
been trained in Agile methods,

335
00:17:54.210 --> 00:17:59.240
then they'll be aware of the terminology
and the difference in the responsibilities

336
00:17:59.240 --> 00:18:01.680
between the scrum master and
the product owner.

337
00:18:01.680 --> 00:18:06.630
So introducing a role like project
manager might confuse the team.

338
00:18:06.630 --> 00:18:09.930
So if you're going to use
the role of project manager,

339
00:18:09.930 --> 00:18:12.540
please make sure-
>> Define it.

340
00:18:12.540 --> 00:18:13.710
>> It's defined, yeah,

341
00:18:13.710 --> 00:18:16.290
that we understand roles and
responsibilities.

342
00:18:16.290 --> 00:18:20.120
The project manager is,
in traditional waterfall projects,

343
00:18:20.120 --> 00:18:24.130
is somebody that's responsible for
the overall project.

344
00:18:24.130 --> 00:18:27.120
So they do both scrum
master possibilities, and

345
00:18:27.120 --> 00:18:29.200
they will also make
decisions of functionality.

346
00:18:29.200 --> 00:18:30.830
So they do product owner as well.

347
00:18:31.970 --> 00:18:36.490
So a project manager, if you're going to
bring one in, you've got to be really,

348
00:18:36.490 --> 00:18:38.720
really careful as to
what you want them to do.

349
00:18:38.720 --> 00:18:43.620
Do you want them to oversee the scrum
master and the product owner?

350
00:18:43.620 --> 00:18:45.820
But then, do you need that role?

351
00:18:45.820 --> 00:18:50.600
Because if a scrum master facilitates the
team and the product owner takes ownership

352
00:18:50.600 --> 00:18:54.630
of the product, and literally our
iterations are between one and

353
00:18:54.630 --> 00:18:58.180
four weeks long, do you really
need the project manager role?

354
00:18:59.290 --> 00:19:00.310
So define it.

355
00:19:00.310 --> 00:19:05.250
If you're going to bring in a project
manager, then everyone in the team, and

356
00:19:05.250 --> 00:19:09.160
I mean everybody, has got to be
aware of the responsibilities that

357
00:19:09.160 --> 00:19:13.410
you are giving that project manager.
>> So

358
00:19:13.410 --> 00:19:19.080
what we've done in that particular episode
is we've just taken a very brief look at

359
00:19:19.080 --> 00:19:24.640
the roles that we've got described within
Agile and within the Agile methodologies.

360
00:19:24.640 --> 00:19:29.111
And more importantly, we've taken a look
at what we would consider to be common

361
00:19:29.111 --> 00:19:30.388
roles within our job.

362
00:19:30.388 --> 00:19:35.321
And when we come back in our next episode
we're going to start to delve more into

363
00:19:35.321 --> 00:19:39.730
Agile itself and look at
the activities of an Agile project.

364
00:19:39.730 --> 00:19:40.786
>> Awesome, so

365
00:19:40.786 --> 00:19:45.208
I guess I can officially say
now I know my role, right?

366
00:19:45.208 --> 00:19:48.678
[LAUGH] Thank you for that, Jo, and
thank you guys for joining us as well, but

367
00:19:48.678 --> 00:19:49.880
we are going to sign out.

368
00:19:49.880 --> 00:19:52.480
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

369
00:19:52.480 --> 00:19:54.862
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

370
00:19:54.862 --> 00:20:00.854
[MUSIC]

371
00:20:00.854 --> 00:20:04.333
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: An introductory look at the Agile methodologies of Scrum and Extreme Programming (XP). We cover the basic methods, terminology, and concepts of each.
episodes.title: Agile Methodologies: Scrum and XP
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.339
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.339 --> 00:00:06.476
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.476 --> 00:00:08.156
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.156 --> 00:00:13.044
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome everyone to

5
00:00:13.044 --> 00:00:16.390
your Agile Project Management Concepts
series.

6
00:00:16.390 --> 00:00:18.590
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.590 --> 00:00:23.540
In this episode, we'll be taking a look at
some agile methodologies, specifically,

8
00:00:23.540 --> 00:00:25.650
Scrum and XP.

9
00:00:25.650 --> 00:00:30.116
And I'm so glad we have Mrs.
Jo Peacock in studios today cuz I can just

10
00:00:30.116 --> 00:00:35.049
about spell those acronyms, but
I'm hoping you can provide more insight.

11
00:00:35.049 --> 00:00:37.945
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I certainly try, if you can't XP,

12
00:00:37.945 --> 00:00:41.812
we've got more problems-
>> Well, here's the thing, I see XP, and

13
00:00:41.812 --> 00:00:44.512
my mind automatically goes
to the operating system.

14
00:00:44.512 --> 00:00:46.800
But that's not the direction
we need to go in,

15
00:00:46.800 --> 00:00:48.805
is it?
>> Not right now, no.

16
00:00:48.805 --> 00:00:49.637
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:49.637 --> 00:00:51.906
>> What we're gonna do in this particular

18
00:00:51.906 --> 00:00:56.513
episode is we're going to be looking at
just a couple of methodologies that fall

19
00:00:56.513 --> 00:00:57.970
under the agile banner.

20
00:00:57.970 --> 00:01:02.632
We've already looked in previous
episodes at the fact that agile,

21
00:01:02.632 --> 00:01:05.506
it's a concept, it's a way of working.

22
00:01:05.506 --> 00:01:10.221
But there are many more, I dont like
to use the word prescriptive, but

23
00:01:10.221 --> 00:01:14.970
more defined methodologies that
actually operate in an agile way.

24
00:01:14.970 --> 00:01:22.110
And that abide to those 12 principles of
agile, abiding by the values of agile.

25
00:01:22.110 --> 00:01:25.915
So were gonna look at two of them in just
a little bit more depth, bearing in mind

26
00:01:25.915 --> 00:01:32.370
that this particular series is not
about these individual methodologies.

27
00:01:32.370 --> 00:01:35.150
We can look at those in other series.

28
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:38.070
This series is just about
looking at agile concepts.

29
00:01:38.070 --> 00:01:41.747
And all of these methodologies that
we're going to cover in this episode and

30
00:01:41.747 --> 00:01:48.650
in another episode, Well,
they adhere to the agile principles.

31
00:01:48.650 --> 00:01:54.744
And so these are just very specific or
more defined ways of employing an agile.

32
00:01:54.744 --> 00:01:56.770
So we're gonna start off with Scrum.

33
00:01:56.770 --> 00:02:01.307
And Scrum is probably,
I would like to say, the most well-known,

34
00:02:01.307 --> 00:02:06.300
the most used methodology that
applies to the agile principle.

35
00:02:06.300 --> 00:02:11.460
And Scrum is where you will
hear words like sprint,

36
00:02:11.460 --> 00:02:14.230
and the daily scrum, etc.

37
00:02:14.230 --> 00:02:17.521
And you'll hear those words, and
yeah, this is where it comes from.

38
00:02:17.521 --> 00:02:18.826
You hear terms like a scrum master,

39
00:02:18.826 --> 00:02:20.064
we'll take a look at that.
>> Yeah,

40
00:02:20.064 --> 00:02:22.184
I'm unfamiliar with those terms so.
>> Right, and so

41
00:02:22.184 --> 00:02:27.160
we'll take a look at that in another
episode when we look at agile roles.

42
00:02:27.160 --> 00:02:31.840
But Scrum adheres to the agile principles,
as we've already said.

43
00:02:31.840 --> 00:02:35.340
And it is pretty much as it says,
really, right in front of us.

44
00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:39.340
It's an iterative, incremental framework
for managing product development.

45
00:02:40.530 --> 00:02:46.440
And it goes on, and
this is the definition of Scrum.

46
00:02:46.440 --> 00:02:47.910
For complex problems,

47
00:02:47.910 --> 00:02:52.410
while productively delivering
products of highest possible value.

48
00:02:52.410 --> 00:02:55.310
We've already said this
in previous episodes.

49
00:02:55.310 --> 00:02:59.510
We are all about delivering
value to our customers.

50
00:02:59.510 --> 00:03:03.945
If we don't deliver valuable,
working software to our customers,

51
00:03:03.945 --> 00:03:06.280
they're going to go elsewhere.

52
00:03:06.280 --> 00:03:09.708
And we have to deliver that
in an iterative manner.

53
00:03:09.708 --> 00:03:16.220
Customers, users, expect software to be
updated and enhanced on a regular basis.

54
00:03:16.220 --> 00:03:19.740
And so
Scrum as a methodology will do that.

55
00:03:19.740 --> 00:03:23.550
So Scrum concentrates on the actual team.

56
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:26.770
Thats the team working on
product development and

57
00:03:26.770 --> 00:03:28.370
the individuals within the team.

58
00:03:28.370 --> 00:03:33.740
Now we already know that,
in Agile, we value our team.

59
00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:36.350
And we value the collaboration
with our customers.

60
00:03:36.350 --> 00:03:39.220
And we value collaboration
within our team.

61
00:03:39.220 --> 00:03:41.170
And that's exactly what Scrum does.

62
00:03:41.170 --> 00:03:44.580
Scrum concentrates on our team,
their skills, and

63
00:03:44.580 --> 00:03:49.590
how they work together, empowering
them to be able to deliver software.

64
00:03:49.590 --> 00:03:51.980
And then weve got events.

65
00:03:51.980 --> 00:03:54.622
And we've got words here
were all familiar with.

66
00:03:54.622 --> 00:03:57.386
And you said you were familiar
with the Scrum master.

67
00:03:57.386 --> 00:04:02.350
So we've got a sprint, now a sprint,
we call this, in agile,

68
00:04:02.350 --> 00:04:04.130
we call that an iteration.

69
00:04:04.130 --> 00:04:06.848
And thats what were delivering
at that point in time.

70
00:04:06.848 --> 00:04:09.400
Thats what were developing and
delivering.

71
00:04:09.400 --> 00:04:12.067
Now that's slightly
different to a release.

72
00:04:12.067 --> 00:04:16.961
And we'll look at that in more of our
agile concepts in another episode.

73
00:04:16.961 --> 00:04:20.790
So we have our sprint, and
our sprint is our iteration.

74
00:04:20.790 --> 00:04:24.530
That is what we are developing
at that point in time.

75
00:04:24.530 --> 00:04:26.955
So that's we've agreed to develop.

76
00:04:26.955 --> 00:04:28.210
Then we have a daily scrum.

77
00:04:28.210 --> 00:04:30.892
Now you might wanna call
that a stand-up meeting.

78
00:04:30.892 --> 00:04:33.420
And it's something that a lot
of people are familiar with.

79
00:04:33.420 --> 00:04:34.854
It's something that we're familiar with,
as well.

80
00:04:34.854 --> 00:04:35.558
>> Right.

81
00:04:35.558 --> 00:04:37.145
>> Whereas every morning,

82
00:04:37.145 --> 00:04:40.170
it should go on for
no longer than 15 minutes.

83
00:04:40.170 --> 00:04:43.590
Every morning we have
a stand-up where we just simply

84
00:04:43.590 --> 00:04:46.750
tell everybody what we're
planning on doing for that day.

85
00:04:46.750 --> 00:04:51.550
And also we want to tell
the team what issues

86
00:04:51.550 --> 00:04:56.850
that we have experienced the day before,
how much progress we made the day before,

87
00:04:56.850 --> 00:05:01.910
and also, what issues we are expecting
to experience during that

88
00:05:01.910 --> 00:05:04.830
coming day.
>> So Jo, this is actually the first

89
00:05:04.830 --> 00:05:09.910
company that I've worked for that
implements a stand-up or scrum meeting.

90
00:05:09.910 --> 00:05:13.770
And I think it's pretty interesting
because you said no more than 15 minutes.

91
00:05:13.770 --> 00:05:15.730
And our company is growing.

92
00:05:15.730 --> 00:05:20.200
And so in order for us to get around
the circle for each person to explain

93
00:05:20.200 --> 00:05:23.820
their obstacles, challenges, or
maybe achievements, we're getting close.

94
00:05:23.820 --> 00:05:25.226
We're at like 14 minutes.

95
00:05:25.226 --> 00:05:29.575
And Tim is watching his watch
every morning as we go around.

96
00:05:29.575 --> 00:05:34.854
Because, at some point, that meeting
may in turn become ineffective or

97
00:05:34.854 --> 00:05:38.190
counterintuitive by taking up more time.

98
00:05:38.190 --> 00:05:42.290
But I think its really cool because,
several times, I, personally,

99
00:05:42.290 --> 00:05:47.130
may have had an issue with something that
someone else has overcame in the past.

100
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:50.850
Or its an obstacle they've
already tackled and completed.

101
00:05:50.850 --> 00:05:51.850
And they can help me out.

102
00:05:51.850 --> 00:05:54.440
So it's a great opportunity
to still have that

103
00:05:54.440 --> 00:05:56.010
collaboration.
>> Well,

104
00:05:56.010 --> 00:05:58.820
we've got an episode where we're
actually going to look at meetings.

105
00:05:58.820 --> 00:06:02.045
And we're going to look
at the daily stand-up or,

106
00:06:02.045 --> 00:06:04.970
the case of scrum,
our daily scrum meeting.

107
00:06:04.970 --> 00:06:09.004
Now let's just think about that
dilemma just for a moment.

108
00:06:09.004 --> 00:06:12.829
That a team gets so
large that the scrum meeting,

109
00:06:12.829 --> 00:06:18.520
the daily stand-up,
becomes inefficient because it's so large.

110
00:06:18.520 --> 00:06:20.333
But it's still effective.
>> Okay.

111
00:06:20.333 --> 00:06:22.208
>> But it's at the point in time when it

112
00:06:22.208 --> 00:06:23.459
becomes ineffective,

113
00:06:23.459 --> 00:06:27.035
that's when we've gotta start
thinking about what else we can do.

114
00:06:27.035 --> 00:06:31.540
And maybe splitting it down
into individual scrum meetings.

115
00:06:31.540 --> 00:06:36.690
The scrum meeting, itself, should
take place within the actual project.

116
00:06:36.690 --> 00:06:40.045
So it should be within the project team.
>> Okay.

117
00:06:40.045 --> 00:06:41.795
>> However, when we start looking at

118
00:06:41.795 --> 00:06:46.255
scalability, it may be that
it makes more sense then

119
00:06:46.255 --> 00:06:50.764
to split that scrum meeting
into smaller scrum meetings.

120
00:06:50.764 --> 00:06:53.636
But you have to think about the
effectiveness, as well as the efficiency.

121
00:06:53.636 --> 00:06:58.507
The efficiency, you'd like to think,
was taken care of by putting in that 15

122
00:06:58.507 --> 00:07:04.362
minute threshold, to say that everybody's
gotta have a say within 15 minutes.

123
00:07:04.362 --> 00:07:08.822
So you like to think that took
the part of the efficiency, but

124
00:07:08.822 --> 00:07:10.042
think about effectiveness.

125
00:07:10.042 --> 00:07:13.760
You see, when you stand up in your scrum
meeting, and you'll say, right, and

126
00:07:13.760 --> 00:07:16.766
I envisage this particular problem today.
>> Mm-hm.

127
00:07:16.766 --> 00:07:21.766
Or I think we're gonna have this obstacle,
if you don't have everybody in the room-

128
00:07:21.766 --> 00:07:23.086
>> Yeah, what if we miss someone?

129
00:07:23.086 --> 00:07:23.633
>> Right,

130
00:07:23.633 --> 00:07:29.350
you're not having the opportunity then for
everybody to say, but I can help you.

131
00:07:30.570 --> 00:07:33.030
And at what point in time
does that become ineffective?

132
00:07:34.030 --> 00:07:36.690
Because you've gotta give people
the opportunity to say, yes,

133
00:07:36.690 --> 00:07:37.960
I can help with that.

134
00:07:37.960 --> 00:07:41.038
Because they may be able to
do it in an efficient way.

135
00:07:41.038 --> 00:07:45.727
Another one of the principles of
agile which is applied to Scrum

136
00:07:45.727 --> 00:07:48.479
really well is that understanding.

137
00:07:48.479 --> 00:07:51.092
And I know that you and
I have had conversations,

138
00:07:51.092 --> 00:07:54.106
that understanding that we've
all got our own skills.

139
00:07:54.106 --> 00:08:00.350
And that my issues will probably be
better off resolved by somebody else.

140
00:08:00.350 --> 00:08:02.760
I've got way too many
issues with one person.

141
00:08:02.760 --> 00:08:07.920
[LAUGH] But my issues might be better
off resolved by somebody else than for

142
00:08:07.920 --> 00:08:09.110
me trying to work it out.

143
00:08:10.200 --> 00:08:13.030
Let's think about this in a realistic way.

144
00:08:14.160 --> 00:08:15.590
Is it actually efficient for

145
00:08:15.590 --> 00:08:19.670
me to spend half an hour trying to
figure out how to do something?

146
00:08:19.670 --> 00:08:23.070
Or is it more efficient for
me to ask somebody else

147
00:08:23.070 --> 00:08:27.725
to spend five minutes using their
skills to do something for me?

148
00:08:27.725 --> 00:08:32.896
This morning, or
earlier on in a previous episode,

149
00:08:32.896 --> 00:08:37.720
I was having an issue with
a USB stick on a laptop.

150
00:08:37.720 --> 00:08:41.508
Now sure, I can try and figure this one
out myself, I could have done that,

151
00:08:41.508 --> 00:08:42.121
I'm sure.

152
00:08:42.121 --> 00:08:44.347
But it probably would
have taken me 30 minutes,

153
00:08:44.347 --> 00:08:47.156
when it took me five minutes to go and
ask somebody else to do it.

154
00:08:47.156 --> 00:08:50.795
And so that's really what
a Scrum meeting is about.

155
00:08:50.795 --> 00:08:54.233
It's about not just saying, hey look,
this is what I'm working on.

156
00:08:54.233 --> 00:08:57.986
And allows everybody to give input into
that and say, hey look, I can help you,

157
00:08:57.986 --> 00:09:01.082
we're both doing the same thing,
we can work more efficiently.

158
00:09:01.082 --> 00:09:05.797
But it also gives somebody like Nate,
who is the person that I badgered [LAUGH]

159
00:09:05.797 --> 00:09:10.070
This morning, and it also gives
them the opportunity to say, look,

160
00:09:10.070 --> 00:09:14.730
I can help you with that, and I'm gonna
do this more efficiently than you.

161
00:09:14.730 --> 00:09:18.243
And yet again, it really concentrates
on working within a team and

162
00:09:18.243 --> 00:09:21.925
understanding that everybody in
the team has got different skills.

163
00:09:21.925 --> 00:09:26.016
>> Right, unfortunately, Ive met people

164
00:09:26.016 --> 00:09:30.796
who that process would aggravate or
bother them.

165
00:09:30.796 --> 00:09:34.778
But those are the characters or
the personalities, and

166
00:09:34.778 --> 00:09:37.800
you talked about finding the right team.

167
00:09:37.800 --> 00:09:43.360
Motivated individuals who are trying
to find people who are not in it for

168
00:09:43.360 --> 00:09:44.500
the fame and the glory.

169
00:09:44.500 --> 00:09:46.770
But they're in it for the team as a unit,

170
00:09:46.770 --> 00:09:48.610
right?
>> Right, and

171
00:09:48.610 --> 00:09:52.122
it's really important that we
all work together as a team.

172
00:09:52.122 --> 00:09:53.850
The team's gonna get
the glory if we all succeed.

173
00:09:53.850 --> 00:09:55.329
>> Exactly.

174
00:09:55.329 --> 00:09:56.537
>> If you're in it for

175
00:09:56.537 --> 00:10:00.319
yourself and you're trying to
get the glory for yourself.

176
00:10:00.319 --> 00:10:04.833
If you're going to try and
make the team look bad in order for

177
00:10:04.833 --> 00:10:09.180
you to look good,
then you're not seen as a team player.

178
00:10:09.180 --> 00:10:15.073
And then how much in demand will you be
in the future by future team managers?

179
00:10:15.073 --> 00:10:17.950
They want somebody on board
who's going to be motivated and

180
00:10:17.950 --> 00:10:19.900
who's going to be a team player.

181
00:10:19.900 --> 00:10:23.610
And who's going to be working for
the effectiveness of the team, and

182
00:10:23.610 --> 00:10:26.120
not just make themselves look good.

183
00:10:26.120 --> 00:10:31.580
So yeah, we've gotta make sure that,
within any sort of Agile team and

184
00:10:31.580 --> 00:10:36.830
within the Scrum project, we have
individuals that are part of a team.

185
00:10:36.830 --> 00:10:40.910
And that we all recognize that everybody
has their own individual skills.

186
00:10:40.910 --> 00:10:46.000
There is absolutely no point in
me trying to add in my MCSE,

187
00:10:46.000 --> 00:10:49.680
absolutely years ago,
nearly 20 years ago now.

188
00:10:49.680 --> 00:10:51.080
It was a long, long time ago.

189
00:10:51.080 --> 00:10:54.650
So if I wanted something technical,
then I'm gonna come to you and ask you.

190
00:10:54.650 --> 00:10:56.830
Why?
Because you got your MCSE really,

191
00:10:56.830 --> 00:10:58.190
really recently.

192
00:10:58.190 --> 00:11:02.820
But more importantly than that,
you've been working with the technical

193
00:11:02.820 --> 00:11:06.440
things a lot more recently than I have.

194
00:11:06.440 --> 00:11:11.239
So I recognize that, and you'd recognize
that, yeah, I've got other skills.

195
00:11:11.239 --> 00:11:12.210
>> Mm-hm.

196
00:11:12.210 --> 00:11:13.840
>> That I could help you with.

197
00:11:13.840 --> 00:11:18.570
So, we work together as a team, and that's
exactly what a Scrum team should be doing.

198
00:11:18.570 --> 00:11:22.140
And this is why we should be having our

199
00:11:22.140 --> 00:11:25.390
daily stand up meeting to
encourage that collaboration.

200
00:11:26.660 --> 00:11:28.659
And then we also have reviews and

201
00:11:28.659 --> 00:11:33.114
retrospectives where we look back,
where we review the user stories.

202
00:11:33.114 --> 00:11:37.421
And we review exactly what's going
to be in that particular sprint and

203
00:11:37.421 --> 00:11:39.540
whether it's achievable or not.

204
00:11:39.540 --> 00:11:44.017
And also, the retrospect is where we
look back at what we have achieved.

205
00:11:44.017 --> 00:11:47.020
And then we have our artifacts,
as we call them.

206
00:11:47.020 --> 00:11:51.360
These are our remnants,
[LAUGH] Which is the backlogs.

207
00:11:51.360 --> 00:11:55.650
And the backlogs are really
what's left still to do.

208
00:11:55.650 --> 00:11:59.460
So what sprints have we got left, or
what iterations have we got left?

209
00:11:59.460 --> 00:12:02.620
And what have we got left to
do within the product itself,

210
00:12:02.620 --> 00:12:07.210
within the actual
development project itself?

211
00:12:07.210 --> 00:12:13.730
And then our burn down chart is how much
progress are we making on that backlog?

212
00:12:13.730 --> 00:12:18.650
And then we've also got our, what we call
rules of the game, as well, within Scrum.

213
00:12:18.650 --> 00:12:23.400
And the rules of the game are really
how everything works together.

214
00:12:23.400 --> 00:12:28.850
How our technical team work together,
but also how our

215
00:12:28.850 --> 00:12:33.568
components of our services and
how the products work together, as well.

216
00:12:33.568 --> 00:12:39.172
We've got five Scrum values that we
really concentrate on in a Scrum project.

217
00:12:39.172 --> 00:12:44.022
And so the first three on
the slide in front of you, focus,

218
00:12:44.022 --> 00:12:46.400
[LAUGH] And that's really important.

219
00:12:46.400 --> 00:12:49.667
And in a previous episode,
I've talked about time management.

220
00:12:49.667 --> 00:12:54.180
And I've talked about working out
when your productive time is and

221
00:12:54.180 --> 00:12:59.535
making sure that the difficult tasks you
do when your most productive time is.

222
00:12:59.535 --> 00:13:03.600
And when you're at your least productive
time, like 3:00 PM in the afternoon for

223
00:13:03.600 --> 00:13:04.790
me, for instance.

224
00:13:04.790 --> 00:13:08.550
Then, that's where you do things that
are almost second nature to you.

225
00:13:08.550 --> 00:13:10.550
Things that you don't
have to concentrate on.

226
00:13:10.550 --> 00:13:12.300
>> Like go grab a Snickers.

227
00:13:12.300 --> 00:13:13.285
>> Right, yeah, yeah [LAUGH]

228
00:13:13.285 --> 00:13:14.700
>> [LAUGH] Isn't that their

229
00:13:14.700 --> 00:13:18.010
newest commercial theme?
>> Is that what it is?

230
00:13:18.010 --> 00:13:19.190
>> Yeah, when you hit your afternoon

231
00:13:19.190 --> 00:13:22.040
slump, go grab a Snickers.
>> I'll go and grab chocolate anytime.

232
00:13:22.040 --> 00:13:24.408
[LAUGH] Hey,
>> [LAUGH] You don't have to tell me

233
00:13:24.408 --> 00:13:25.673
twice.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

234
00:13:25.673 --> 00:13:28.830
anytime's chocolate time, right?

235
00:13:28.830 --> 00:13:33.190
So focus on what you're doing right now,
and try not to be distracted And,

236
00:13:33.190 --> 00:13:37.245
in a previous episode, yet again,
we looked at social media.

237
00:13:37.245 --> 00:13:41.190
[LAUGH] And I made that face
because social media is a huge,

238
00:13:41.190 --> 00:13:44.190
big distraction for most people.

239
00:13:44.190 --> 00:13:45.980
You're not productive
when you're doing that.

240
00:13:45.980 --> 00:13:49.530
So, you have to focus
on the task at hand and

241
00:13:49.530 --> 00:13:53.620
rely on your Scrum master, and we'll
look at that role in another episode.

242
00:13:53.620 --> 00:13:57.460
But a Scrum master is somebody who will
come along and who will ensure that your

243
00:13:57.460 --> 00:14:02.210
working environment is conducive
to you being able to develop.

244
00:14:02.210 --> 00:14:04.750
They will remove any impediments.

245
00:14:04.750 --> 00:14:09.156
And then you've got a product owner,
somebody who's responsible for

246
00:14:09.156 --> 00:14:11.953
the functional aspects of the development.

247
00:14:11.953 --> 00:14:14.733
And they're going to ensure
that the work's prioritized, so

248
00:14:14.733 --> 00:14:16.830
you know what you should be working on.

249
00:14:16.830 --> 00:14:20.760
Now, we talk about
empowering people in Agile.

250
00:14:20.760 --> 00:14:24.975
Empowering people to do the work doesn't
mean that we empower people to decide what

251
00:14:24.975 --> 00:14:27.160
they're going to work on, when, and where.

252
00:14:27.160 --> 00:14:32.032
We still have to know what's being
delivered in each sprint in this

253
00:14:32.032 --> 00:14:33.340
case with Scrum.

254
00:14:33.340 --> 00:14:34.223
And therefore,

255
00:14:34.223 --> 00:14:38.636
we have to make sure that those developers
are actually doing the work that they're

256
00:14:38.636 --> 00:14:40.053
supposed to be doing.
>> But

257
00:14:40.053 --> 00:14:42.308
helping them get to that goal, right?

258
00:14:42.308 --> 00:14:46.453
Like providing the right resources for
them, the right equipment, or

259
00:14:46.453 --> 00:14:48.837
whatever it may be.
>> And the roles combined,

260
00:14:48.837 --> 00:14:51.590
Scrum master and product owner,
will facilitate that.

261
00:14:51.590 --> 00:14:56.160
The product owner will keep them
focused on their priorities.

262
00:14:56.160 --> 00:15:00.910
And the Scrum master will give them
the right tools to be able to do the job.

263
00:15:00.910 --> 00:15:05.647
So the team's gotta be finished, or gotta
be focused on finishing the user stories.

264
00:15:05.647 --> 00:15:08.519
And making sure that we
will resolve whatever

265
00:15:08.519 --> 00:15:11.096
problem it is we're trying to resolve.

266
00:15:11.096 --> 00:15:16.027
Or implement whatever functionality
we're trying to implement, and

267
00:15:16.027 --> 00:15:17.677
that we complete that.

268
00:15:17.677 --> 00:15:22.270
And I really like, as a value,
I love the word, courage.

269
00:15:24.300 --> 00:15:27.250
But then if I look a little
bit more at the bullet points,

270
00:15:27.250 --> 00:15:28.910
I see the word, commitment.

271
00:15:28.910 --> 00:15:30.630
And I see the word, trust.

272
00:15:30.630 --> 00:15:32.410
And I see the word, guide.

273
00:15:32.410 --> 00:15:35.350
It's about being empowered.

274
00:15:35.350 --> 00:15:37.230
It's about empowering the team.

275
00:15:37.230 --> 00:15:40.378
But it's also about the team saying,
look, this is what I'm gonna do.

276
00:15:40.378 --> 00:15:42.170
And then this is what you do.

277
00:15:43.450 --> 00:15:47.581
The last bullet point in courage,
while the team must commit

278
00:15:47.581 --> 00:15:51.721
to as much work as they can achieve,
you can't over commit.

279
00:15:51.721 --> 00:15:57.183
If you over commit, you're not going to
achieve what it is you set out to achieve.

280
00:15:57.183 --> 00:16:01.638
But also you don't wanna by sitting around
twiddling your thumbs with your feet up on

281
00:16:01.638 --> 00:16:02.650
your desk either.

282
00:16:03.730 --> 00:16:06.720
So you have to make sure that
the workload that you commit to

283
00:16:06.720 --> 00:16:11.400
is actually a viable workload, and
that you're not just sitting around.

284
00:16:11.400 --> 00:16:14.499
And this is where that trust comes
in about empowering the team.

285
00:16:15.600 --> 00:16:18.240
And this is why it's important to be open.

286
00:16:18.240 --> 00:16:22.310
That's the other value there on our slide,
openness.

287
00:16:22.310 --> 00:16:27.500
Making sure that everybody is fully aware
of what it is that they've got to do,

288
00:16:27.500 --> 00:16:29.636
and also what's outstanding, as well.

289
00:16:29.636 --> 00:16:36.780
And I like open, and I like the word
objective, as well, that's mentioned.

290
00:16:36.780 --> 00:16:40.390
Because you have to have,
I guess it goes back to courage as well,

291
00:16:40.390 --> 00:16:44.490
you have to have the courage to
be able to say I don't know.

292
00:16:44.490 --> 00:16:47.300
I'm not the best person for
this particular role.

293
00:16:47.300 --> 00:16:49.810
I'm not the best person for this job.

294
00:16:49.810 --> 00:16:51.530
It's being open.

295
00:16:51.530 --> 00:16:56.130
Having the courage to say I can't do it,
and being open to the fact that somebody

296
00:16:56.130 --> 00:17:00.450
else may be better at that
particular task than you are.

297
00:17:00.450 --> 00:17:03.190
And this is why we talk about objective.
