but what we're saying is that
we've got some rules here.

528
00:29:25.890 --> 00:29:30.250
And these are our sort of technical
rules when it comes to agile,

529
00:29:30.250 --> 00:29:34.900
though a little bit more granular than
anything else that we've looked at.

530
00:29:34.900 --> 00:29:35.401
I mean,

531
00:29:35.401 --> 00:29:40.082
we do have some issues with XP because
we're focusing on the technical here.

532
00:29:40.082 --> 00:29:44.431
So we have to make sure that
we do have somebody managing

533
00:29:44.431 --> 00:29:46.993
the team that is able to manage.

534
00:29:46.993 --> 00:29:52.961
And that's able to manage things like,
well, personalities,

535
00:29:52.961 --> 00:29:57.852
for instance, and
is able to ensure collaboration.

536
00:29:57.852 --> 00:30:01.307
I've come across some
developers who are really good

537
00:30:01.307 --> 00:30:06.219
at sort of interpersonal relationships,
and are people people as it were,

538
00:30:06.219 --> 00:30:08.771
and get on very well with other people.

539
00:30:08.771 --> 00:30:11.821
But I've also come across
developers that work better when

540
00:30:11.821 --> 00:30:14.410
they're left to themselves.
>> I have met a lot

541
00:30:14.410 --> 00:30:15.760
of developers like that.

542
00:30:15.760 --> 00:30:18.564
And if you are a developer,
you'll know what I'm talking about.

543
00:30:18.564 --> 00:30:22.286
>> [LAUGH] Exactly, I have too.

544
00:30:22.286 --> 00:30:24.788
>> I'm not saying they're all like that,

545
00:30:24.788 --> 00:30:25.311
but.
>> And

546
00:30:25.311 --> 00:30:27.152
this is why I wanted that caveat there.
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

547
00:30:27.152 --> 00:30:28.681
>> I've come across some that are really

548
00:30:28.681 --> 00:30:29.880
sociable people.

549
00:30:29.880 --> 00:30:33.920
But I've also come across some
developers that are very quiet, and

550
00:30:33.920 --> 00:30:36.540
work best when they're on their own, and

551
00:30:36.540 --> 00:30:41.050
left to their own sort of thoughts,
and to their own ideas.

552
00:30:41.050 --> 00:30:46.831
Now, XP really does, the rules in XP
will kind of drag them out of there and

553
00:30:46.831 --> 00:30:50.491
say, no, we've gotta work in pairs, okay.

554
00:30:50.491 --> 00:30:55.336
We've got to make sure that if
I'm run over by a bus today that

555
00:30:55.336 --> 00:30:58.580
you're able to pick up where I left off.

556
00:30:58.580 --> 00:31:01.280
And it's about the efficiency of the team.

557
00:31:01.280 --> 00:31:05.780
It's about the fact that we've
got a product to deliver, and so

558
00:31:05.780 --> 00:31:08.320
we've both got to work together.

559
00:31:08.320 --> 00:31:12.971
We've got to be really careful,
we're techy people.

560
00:31:12.971 --> 00:31:15.740
We've got to be careful that we
don't try and automate too much.

561
00:31:17.360 --> 00:31:19.020
I look at that third bullet point and

562
00:31:19.020 --> 00:31:22.150
it talks there about
automated acceptance testing.

563
00:31:23.860 --> 00:31:25.970
Be careful.

564
00:31:25.970 --> 00:31:29.760
You don't want to automate too much
when it comes to your testing.

565
00:31:29.760 --> 00:31:32.710
And you want to make sure that
what we're actually testing is

566
00:31:32.710 --> 00:31:34.570
against the specification.

567
00:31:34.570 --> 00:31:36.950
And we're not just testing
how something works,

568
00:31:36.950 --> 00:31:41.790
we're testing that it's actually going to
deliver what it's supposed to deliver.

569
00:31:41.790 --> 00:31:47.610
There's a difference between whether
something will deliver an output and

570
00:31:47.610 --> 00:31:50.660
whether it will do it in an efficient way.

571
00:31:50.660 --> 00:31:55.050
And so we don't just want to be able
to test that maybe that new patch or

572
00:31:55.050 --> 00:31:58.750
that new update will allow
email to be sent and received.

573
00:31:58.750 --> 00:32:03.280
We also want to test that it works in an
efficient way, and that we're not waiting

574
00:32:03.280 --> 00:32:06.580
for half an hour for
an email to come through from somebody.

575
00:32:06.580 --> 00:32:11.186
So we want to make sure that our
acceptance tests both the output,

576
00:32:11.186 --> 00:32:15.140
but also the usability of
any functionality, as well.

577
00:32:16.210 --> 00:32:20.954
Now, the last bullet point is
a really important bullet point.

578
00:32:20.954 --> 00:32:25.630
And it simply states that the customer can
become a single point of failure if they

579
00:32:25.630 --> 00:32:30.640
don't approve the designs, or
if they don't approve the test results.

580
00:32:30.640 --> 00:32:31.587
Yes, they can.

581
00:32:31.587 --> 00:32:36.302
But we also have to remember
that we are designing to deliver

582
00:32:36.302 --> 00:32:38.260
value to the customer.

583
00:32:38.260 --> 00:32:43.170
And so while that customer can be
seen as a single point of failure,

584
00:32:43.170 --> 00:32:46.060
our customer is also the person
that we want to deliver value to.

585
00:32:46.060 --> 00:32:48.300
So it's really important
that they're happy.

586
00:32:48.300 --> 00:32:51.450
So don't make your customer
a single point of failure.

587
00:32:51.450 --> 00:32:56.480
Make your customer as the person that
you want to deliver your results to.

588
00:32:56.480 --> 00:32:59.190
So they are, in reality, your customer.

589
00:33:00.680 --> 00:33:04.600
So in this particular episode, then, we
looked at scrum, and we've looked at XP,

590
00:33:04.600 --> 00:33:06.130
extreme programming.

591
00:33:06.130 --> 00:33:11.080
And when we come back in our next episode,
we're going to look at another two

592
00:33:11.080 --> 00:33:15.350
agile methodologies.
>> Another teaser, thanks for that, Jo.

593
00:33:15.350 --> 00:33:16.740
Come back and look at those,.

594
00:33:16.740 --> 00:33:19.530
And you don't want to miss them,
but for now, let's sign out.

595
00:33:19.530 --> 00:33:21.936
I've been your host ,Cherokee Bose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

596
00:33:21.936 --> 00:33:24.069
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

597
00:33:24.069 --> 00:33:30.217
[MUSIC]

598
00:33:30.217 --> 00:33:33.211
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: An introductory look at the Agile methodologies of Kanban and Lean. We cover the basic methods, terminology, and concepts of each.
episodes.title: Agile Methodologies: Kanban and Lean
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:03.424
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.424 --> 00:00:06.221
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:06.221 --> 00:00:07.867
California [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.867 --> 00:00:12.000
[MUSIC]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.000 --> 00:00:12.880
>> Welcome to your

6
00:00:12.880 --> 00:00:15.580
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

7
00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:17.640
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.640 --> 00:00:22.180
In this episode we'll continue taking a
look at different agile methodologies and

9
00:00:22.180 --> 00:00:25.970
specifically we'll be taking
a look at Canban and Lean.

10
00:00:25.970 --> 00:00:30.100
And of course, with us today back
in studios, we have Mrs.Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:32.080
Thank you for joining us today,
Jo, how are you?

12
00:00:32.080 --> 00:00:32.674
>> I'm fine, thank you,

13
00:00:32.674 --> 00:00:33.950
how are you, Cherokee?
>> I'm good,

14
00:00:33.950 --> 00:00:38.365
I'm really happy you didn't leave me all
on my own to go ahead with these topics.

15
00:00:38.365 --> 00:00:41.590
[LAUGH] Because we'd
learn a few things but

16
00:00:41.590 --> 00:00:44.290
definitely not to
the extent that you would.

17
00:00:44.290 --> 00:00:46.877
I'd be talking about other Japanese

18
00:00:46.877 --> 00:00:47.994
cultures
>> [LAUGH]

19
00:00:47.994 --> 00:00:50.058
>> Like going to Disney.

20
00:00:50.058 --> 00:00:52.434
And things like that.
>> Yeah,

21
00:00:52.434 --> 00:00:55.878
now she is desperate to go to Disney now.
>> [LAUGHS]

22
00:00:55.878 --> 00:01:00.047
>> I can tell you yeah am getting all

23
00:01:00.047 --> 00:01:03.824
diagram, the fish bone,
>> That's right, that was, For

24
00:01:03.824 --> 00:01:05.380
use in problem management.

25
00:01:05.380 --> 00:01:08.370
When we were looking at retail.
>> Yeah, and real cause and

26
00:01:08.370 --> 00:01:09.560
things like that.

27
00:01:09.560 --> 00:01:11.020
But then we'd be like, and

28
00:01:11.020 --> 00:01:13.394
that was it folks.
>> I'm impressed,

29
00:01:13.394 --> 00:01:17.375
well we're all going to get into
a little bit more of a Japanese lesson.

30
00:01:17.375 --> 00:01:21.962
In the first sort of few
minutes of our episode now.

31
00:01:21.962 --> 00:01:23.580
And in this particular episode.

32
00:01:23.580 --> 00:01:24.889
In our last episode,

33
00:01:24.889 --> 00:01:29.341
we looked at a couple of methodologies
that fall under the Agile banner.

34
00:01:29.341 --> 00:01:32.927
And now we're gonna look at another
two methodologies that fall under

35
00:01:32.927 --> 00:01:34.320
the Agile banner.

36
00:01:34.320 --> 00:01:40.810
So in our last episode we looked at Scrum
and we looked at XP, X3 Programming.

37
00:01:40.810 --> 00:01:46.400
And now we're going to look at Kanban and
we're also going to look at lean.

38
00:01:46.400 --> 00:01:53.060
So Kanban is Japanese, and
it actually literally means visual board.

39
00:01:54.115 --> 00:01:56.725
There you go, that's it,
that's Kanban in a nutshell.

40
00:01:56.725 --> 00:01:58.745
It's a visual board.

41
00:01:58.745 --> 00:02:03.715
We have been talking about the application
of Agile methodologies and

42
00:02:03.715 --> 00:02:08.835
about the application of some of our
other principles as well including iTELL.

43
00:02:08.835 --> 00:02:11.375
And one of the conversations
that we've had is just how

44
00:02:11.375 --> 00:02:14.115
applicable this is in the real world.

45
00:02:14.115 --> 00:02:16.775
We can step this outside of IT.

46
00:02:16.775 --> 00:02:21.820
And we can use these principles to
apply to many other projects that

47
00:02:21.820 --> 00:02:25.490
just don't necessarily have
anything to do with IT.

48
00:02:25.490 --> 00:02:27.570
And this is very true, and

49
00:02:27.570 --> 00:02:31.960
this is one of those methodologies that we
can most definitely take outside of IT.

50
00:02:33.630 --> 00:02:39.310
This is an agile methodology, and
it is based on the agile principles,

51
00:02:39.310 --> 00:02:42.690
there's 12 agile principles,
and the agile values.

52
00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:46.410
But its focus is on simplicity.

53
00:02:46.410 --> 00:02:50.520
Its focus is on just getting the job done,
but

54
00:02:50.520 --> 00:02:54.850
in as easy a way as possible,
keeping things simple.

55
00:02:54.850 --> 00:02:59.490
So we don't have any prescribed roles,
which is not something that

56
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:03.990
we've looked at really in depth in any
of the other Agile methodologies either.

57
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:09.740
We want to ensure that we can detect and
resolve any bottlenecks,

58
00:03:09.740 --> 00:03:14.700
as quickly as we possibly can,
and as early as we possibly can.

59
00:03:14.700 --> 00:03:19.580
The focus is on sort of a continual
flow of just in time delivery.

60
00:03:19.580 --> 00:03:21.780
The focus is on eliminating waste.

61
00:03:21.780 --> 00:03:24.604
It's eliminating, it's being efficient.

62
00:03:24.604 --> 00:03:27.638
And efficiency means minimal waste.
>> Right.

63
00:03:27.638 --> 00:03:31.360
>> Now, interestingly enough, Muda, and

64
00:03:31.360 --> 00:03:33.180
I don't know whether I'm
pronouncing that right.

65
00:03:33.180 --> 00:03:37.030
So Muda is the Japanese word for waste.

66
00:03:37.030 --> 00:03:40.420
And, you know,
I mention that because that has some

67
00:03:40.420 --> 00:03:44.950
influence on our next methodology,
and our next methodology that

68
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:46.750
we're going to look at is Lean.
>> Right.

69
00:03:46.750 --> 00:03:49.230
>> And we talk about mudah in mean

70
00:03:49.230 --> 00:03:50.550
as well.

71
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:55.936
So, Kanban as I've already said
literally means just a visual board,

72
00:03:55.936 --> 00:03:59.001
and here is an example of a Kanban board.

73
00:03:59.001 --> 00:04:02.200
And really, look at that,
talk about keeping it simple.

74
00:04:03.390 --> 00:04:05.146
This is, well, it's just a board.

75
00:04:05.146 --> 00:04:10.610
And it's split into, we've got three
business units, or three tasks.

76
00:04:10.610 --> 00:04:13.860
We've got our to-do list,
we've got our in progress list, and

77
00:04:13.860 --> 00:04:15.440
we've got our done list.

78
00:04:15.440 --> 00:04:16.670
And that's it.

79
00:04:16.670 --> 00:04:19.220
That's our Kanban Board.

80
00:04:19.220 --> 00:04:22.932
Nothing elaborate about that at all.

81
00:04:22.932 --> 00:04:28.069
You see, in Kanban timebox development,
which is something

82
00:04:28.069 --> 00:04:33.417
that we have within Scrum, well,
timebox development is out.

83
00:04:33.417 --> 00:04:38.606
So our stories, our user stories, in
other words what we're actually trying to

84
00:04:38.606 --> 00:04:44.790
develop is, well, larger, we've got less
stories, because they're larger stories.

85
00:04:44.790 --> 00:04:49.034
Now in Scrum, what we're trying
to achieve is small stories.

86
00:04:49.034 --> 00:04:53.274
We're trying especially in XP,
in extreme programming,

87
00:04:53.274 --> 00:05:00.020
we're trying to achieve very small stories
that are released every one to two weeks.

88
00:05:00.020 --> 00:05:04.220
Here, we're at the other end of the scale
where our stories are larger and

89
00:05:04.220 --> 00:05:06.580
we have less of them.

90
00:05:06.580 --> 00:05:10.540
Which means that we're quite
often releasing, well,

91
00:05:10.540 --> 00:05:13.940
we're releasing larger developments.

92
00:05:13.940 --> 00:05:16.224
We're releasing more functionality.

93
00:05:16.224 --> 00:05:18.934
So estimation is an option within Kanban,
and

94
00:05:18.934 --> 00:05:22.067
estimation is quite often
just omitted completely.

95
00:05:22.067 --> 00:05:27.500
So we're not estimating exactly when
we're going to be doing something.

96
00:05:27.500 --> 00:05:29.450
We don't have velocity,

97
00:05:29.450 --> 00:05:33.960
which is something that we're going to
look at in one of our other episodes.

98
00:05:33.960 --> 00:05:35.840
We have what we call cycle time.

99
00:05:37.240 --> 00:05:41.390
And as we've already said, there are no
prescribed roles when it comes to Kanban.

100
00:05:42.570 --> 00:05:45.140
And that is Kanban in a nutshell.

101
00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:49.570
We don't have too much more to say to
that, it's one of those methodologies,

102
00:05:49.570 --> 00:05:55.840
where I wouldn't say that it is
widely used in the Western world.

103
00:05:55.840 --> 00:06:00.375
It is still an Agile methodology,
but it really focuses on simplicity.

104
00:06:00.375 --> 00:06:03.270
And so Kanban, I would say,
would be used for

105
00:06:03.270 --> 00:06:09.593
the very simple implementations.
>> When I was originally learning about

106
00:06:09.593 --> 00:06:15.866
project and process management, I believe
it was more for manufacturing industries.

107
00:06:15.866 --> 00:06:19.985
That really where you see
that the most being utilized.

108
00:06:19.985 --> 00:06:20.760
>> Yes, yeah,

109
00:06:20.760 --> 00:06:23.229
it's something that has been used in IT.

110
00:06:23.229 --> 00:06:27.991
And I have seen it used, but
it is really for It's almost as though

111
00:06:27.991 --> 00:06:33.620
it's a stepping stone from Agile
into the waterfall approach.

112
00:06:33.620 --> 00:06:38.650
In other words it's quite simple but
it incorporates larger projects,

113
00:06:38.650 --> 00:06:42.720
it incorporates larger
development initiatives.

114
00:06:42.720 --> 00:06:47.510
But, it's a simple way of managing
a project as opposed to utilizing

115
00:06:47.510 --> 00:06:51.690
a huge waterfall approach like PRINCE2 or
PMI for instance.

116
00:06:51.690 --> 00:06:54.056
And as you say,
it comes from manufacturing.

117
00:06:54.056 --> 00:06:58.366
And that's exactly where it really
has been at its most useful.

118
00:06:58.366 --> 00:07:00.495
But we started to see it creep into IT.

119
00:07:00.495 --> 00:07:05.299
And so we'll use this as
an Agile methodology because

120
00:07:05.299 --> 00:07:08.830
the Kanban Board I find really useful.

121
00:07:09.830 --> 00:07:11.620
And in fact I would always recommend, and

122
00:07:11.620 --> 00:07:14.690
we'll talk about this more
when we get into our Agile.

123
00:07:15.690 --> 00:07:20.520
When we get into our activities within
Agile, but we'll talk about the boards and

124
00:07:20.520 --> 00:07:22.010
how useful they really are.

125
00:07:22.010 --> 00:07:24.360
It's that snapshot,
it's where we are right now.

126
00:07:24.360 --> 00:07:26.443
>> And look, you'll be gettin' her done.

127
00:07:26.443 --> 00:07:27.345
>> Exactly, yeah.

128
00:07:27.345 --> 00:07:28.188
>> [LAUGH]

129
00:07:28.188 --> 00:07:28.900
>> And if you're not

130
00:07:28.900 --> 00:07:31.132
too sure about that joke [CROSSTALK]
>> Bad joke you'll have to go

131
00:07:31.132 --> 00:07:33.083
back to another episode.
>> Go back to another episode.

132
00:07:33.083 --> 00:07:35.007
>> [LAUGH]

133
00:07:35.007 --> 00:07:37.607
>> So let's take a look then at Lean,

134
00:07:37.607 --> 00:07:42.450
and Lean is another Agile methodology and
I know that Cherokee is

135
00:07:42.450 --> 00:07:46.150
quite familiar with Lean, right?
>> [LAUGH] That's right, yeah.

136
00:07:46.150 --> 00:07:49.213
We've gotten better, faster,
and more cost effective.

137
00:07:49.213 --> 00:07:49.884
[LAUGH]
>> Right,

138
00:07:49.884 --> 00:07:53.976
that Lean really focuses on
the elimination of waste.

139
00:07:53.976 --> 00:07:59.282
In previous episodes, I've talked about
eliminating unnecessary documentation,

140
00:07:59.282 --> 00:08:03.216
and I've talked about eliminating
unnecessary programming.

141
00:08:03.216 --> 00:08:05.610
Only develop what is needed And

142
00:08:05.610 --> 00:08:10.920
don't develop enhanced features
if they are not needed.

143
00:08:10.920 --> 00:08:16.600
And in Lean, we also look at
efficient processes as well.

144
00:08:16.600 --> 00:08:22.499
So Lean as a development methodology
actually comes from sort of six sigma and

145
00:08:22.499 --> 00:08:25.130
Lean production principles.

146
00:08:25.130 --> 00:08:28.440
And it's just really
focusing on efficiency.

147
00:08:28.440 --> 00:08:32.170
So it's about expenditure
of our resources and

148
00:08:32.170 --> 00:08:38.170
how we use our resources rather
than just about delivering value.

149
00:08:38.170 --> 00:08:39.950
We don't want to be wasteful.

150
00:08:39.950 --> 00:08:41.975
We want to eliminate waste.

151
00:08:43.085 --> 00:08:44.915
So, we still want to deliver value,

152
00:08:44.915 --> 00:08:48.495
because bearing in mind this is
what all about projects are about.

153
00:08:48.495 --> 00:08:51.705
It's about delivering value
to our customers, but

154
00:08:51.705 --> 00:08:54.165
we want to do it in a way
that eliminates waste.

155
00:08:54.165 --> 00:08:58.540
We want to do it in a way that we
take away unnecessary documentation.

156
00:08:58.540 --> 00:09:02.920
We take away unnecessary bureaucracy,
and unnecessary red tape, and

157
00:09:02.920 --> 00:09:05.080
anything that's not bringing that value.

158
00:09:05.080 --> 00:09:10.430
Like waste can come in many forms,
just, down time, rework.

159
00:09:10.430 --> 00:09:14.350

And I use Excel as an example because it's

And it also involves understanding

00:11:31.190 --> 00:11:35.480
The other thing that Lean
does is it eliminates sort of

00:11:35.480 --> 00:11:40.500
fluctuations in quality and
fluctuations in the deliverable.

209
00:11:40.500 --> 00:11:45.680
By really focusing on our way of working,

210
00:11:45.680 --> 00:11:49.388
So in previous sessions,
in previous episodes,

we've looked at the fact that we don't

We don't wanna bring in

And that process has got to be lean,

00:12:07.830 --> 00:12:12.160
We've got to try and reduce

the fluctuations in our output.

And we've got to be efficient.

So we still need to have
processes in place.

It's just got to be efficient processes.

there are seven areas of waste

00:12:44.890 --> 00:12:49.520
And so anything that's been partially

00:12:49.520 --> 00:12:52.140
I don't know, seems like a simple

00:12:52.140 --> 00:12:53.520
If you're not gonna finish it,

with that rigid structure,
what if the project does change?

When there's no need?
>> Right, yeah, so

235
00:13:04.686 --> 00:13:08.257
only start what you're going to finish.

236
00:13:08.257 --> 00:13:11.390
If you're not going to finish
it then don't start it.

237
00:13:11.390 --> 00:13:14.419
There are the things that I like, I mean,

we know about additional features,

I mentioned earlier on that in a previous

I've got mine too, but that was a long,

But nevertheless, I mean, it might not

my time re-learning all of this when

00:14:04.430 --> 00:14:09.410
Because it's going to take me potentially

stuff whereas Cherokee's got

I am so glad you have all

But this is down to collaboration.

It is down to understanding

00:14:30.150 --> 00:14:33.680
And I talked in previous

And it really is about that acceptance and

00:14:37.360 --> 00:14:41.860
That certain people have got certain

00:14:42.920 --> 00:14:47.857
And that will mean that we can be

00:14:53.832 --> 00:14:59.020
And we're not wasting time teaching skills

265
00:15:00.090 --> 00:15:04.540
Now something else that I wanna
draw your attention to is the tasks

00:15:05.660 --> 00:15:07.950
switching if I could
even manage to say it.

I have to admit to being guilty of

own principles really because I-

>> Yes, yeah.

00:15:20.180 --> 00:15:22.461
I do this all the time.

00:15:22.461 --> 00:15:24.586
>> And we talk about being distracted on

272
00:15:24.586 --> 00:15:26.100
here with social media.

273
00:15:26.100 --> 00:15:28.940
Yeah, the tasks switching.

274
00:15:30.190 --> 00:15:33.650
I started on this, but now I'm
gonna go and do something else, and

275
00:15:33.650 --> 00:15:36.190
now I'm gonna go and do something else.

276
00:15:36.190 --> 00:15:42.020
Time management really is important
when we talk about Lean development.

277
00:15:42.020 --> 00:15:45.430
And I have talked about
this in previous episodes.

278
00:15:45.430 --> 00:15:48.562
But we have a time of day when
we are at our most productive.

279
00:15:48.562 --> 00:15:52.879
And that is when we should be
doing those challenging tasks,

280
00:15:52.879 --> 00:15:54.919
the ones that make us think.

281
00:15:54.919 --> 00:15:59.300
And then bring in lean principles, and
we don't want to partially complete it.

282
00:15:59.300 --> 00:16:04.054
So we complete that task The tasks that
don't make us think, that aren't so

283
00:16:04.054 --> 00:16:08.607
challenging, are the ones that we
should do at our own productive time.

284
00:16:08.607 --> 00:16:13.844
And we shouldn't jump between the two or
three or four different tasks because

285
00:16:13.844 --> 00:16:19.350
every time you jump, you're starting
again, a little bit further behind.

286
00:16:19.350 --> 00:16:23.090
You have to relearn something
that you've already done.

287
00:16:23.090 --> 00:16:25.080
You have to maybe catch up,

288
00:16:25.080 --> 00:16:29.760
as you might want to say, with where
you were with a particular task.

289
00:16:29.760 --> 00:16:31.560
So yeah, don't do it.

290
00:16:31.560 --> 00:16:32.770
Simple, just don't do it.

291
00:16:34.410 --> 00:16:36.782
So what principles do we have within Lean?

292
00:16:36.782 --> 00:16:40.490
Well, we've already talked about
eliminating waste, such as unnecessary

293
00:16:40.490 --> 00:16:46.250
code, unnecessary documentation,
and I like the inadequate testing.

294
00:16:47.390 --> 00:16:51.420
That doesn't mean don't test,
what it means is don't waste

295
00:16:51.420 --> 00:16:56.195
your time testing something
that is not going to be used.

296
00:16:56.195 --> 00:17:00.180
Don't waste your time testing
functionality that you haven't yet

297
00:17:00.180 --> 00:17:05.940
developed or
that is still in the design parameters or

298
00:17:05.940 --> 00:17:09.655
in that particular frame
of that iteration.

299
00:17:09.655 --> 00:17:13.590
Don't waste your time with testing
what you don't need to test.

300
00:17:15.320 --> 00:17:19.790
But also, if you don't test fully,
then as it says,

301
00:17:19.790 --> 00:17:22.700
inadequate testing means
that you're gonna have to

302
00:17:22.700 --> 00:17:26.590
make changes in the production
environment, in that live environment.

303
00:17:26.590 --> 00:17:29.520
So make sure you test enough, but

304
00:17:29.520 --> 00:17:32.400
don't test those features
that you're not releasing.

305
00:17:34.066 --> 00:17:40.248
Amplifying learning, really well,
it's involving our costumer,

306
00:17:40.248 --> 00:17:44.124
and it's short iterations where we learn,

307
00:17:44.124 --> 00:17:47.910
and we grow based on previous iterations.

308
00:17:47.910 --> 00:17:51.511
So we grow our learning as
we grow our iterations,

309
00:17:51.511 --> 00:17:54.270
as we release more then we learn more.

310
00:17:56.010 --> 00:18:00.965
Deciding late, I like the fact that it
tells you a better decision will be

311
00:18:00.965 --> 00:18:05.678
reached, and uncertainty reduced,
if you make your decisions as to

312
00:18:05.678 --> 00:18:11.200
whether you're going to say release or
not later on in the actual process.

313
00:18:11.200 --> 00:18:13.004
If you decide earlier on,

314
00:18:13.004 --> 00:18:18.670
you kind of put yourself under some
unnecessary pressures, should we say.

315
00:18:18.670 --> 00:18:21.962
You make a decision very, very early on
in the iteration, and this is where our

316
00:18:21.962 --> 00:18:26.090
mistakes lie, in that you'll decide that
right, this is what we're going to program

317
00:18:26.090 --> 00:18:29.900
in this particular iteration, and
that's it, it's cast in stone.

318
00:18:29.900 --> 00:18:33.880
But then you put yourself under pressure,
and you realize that actually,

319
00:18:33.880 --> 00:18:37.110
we're one week into this, and
we're not going to get this delivered.

320
00:18:37.110 --> 00:18:39.070
But we've already made the decision, and

321
00:18:39.070 --> 00:18:42.740
we've already promised the customer
that that's what they're going to get.

322
00:18:42.740 --> 00:18:44.085
So you have to deliver it.

323
00:18:44.085 --> 00:18:46.160
You've put yourself under pressure.

324
00:18:46.160 --> 00:18:48.600
So make the decision as to
what you're going to release

325
00:18:48.600 --> 00:18:51.880
later on because that allows for-
>> Some

326
00:18:51.880 --> 00:18:54.470
flexibility.
>> Flexibility, right, which is one of

327
00:18:54.470 --> 00:18:56.960
course, of those agile principles.
>> Right.

328
00:18:56.960 --> 00:18:58.090
>> That's exactly what we want.

329
00:18:58.090 --> 00:19:00.010
>> You can see that relationship here.

330
00:19:00.010 --> 00:19:01.741
>> Right, yeah, definitely.

331
00:19:01.741 --> 00:19:06.599
I mean, and I've already said, Lean is
one of the agile methodologies, and

332
00:19:06.599 --> 00:19:10.460
it really does,
it promotes agile brilliantly.

333
00:19:10.460 --> 00:19:16.920
So deliver fast, well, you don't want to
spend three weeks just deploying, okay?

334
00:19:16.920 --> 00:19:19.470
The idea is of an iteration,
and a release,

335
00:19:19.470 --> 00:19:23.032
is that we develop, and we release.

336
00:19:23.032 --> 00:19:26.700
And then,
we move on to the next user story.

337
00:19:26.700 --> 00:19:29.010
>> Better, faster, more cost effective.

338
00:19:29.010 --> 00:19:32.260
I can't tell you how many times
I heard that during my training

339
00:19:32.260 --> 00:19:35.250
bacause that's really what it
all stand for here with Lean.

340
00:19:35.250 --> 00:19:36.190
>> Yeah, but

341
00:19:36.190 --> 00:19:38.271
we've gotta bring in that better,
as well ,right?

342
00:19:38.271 --> 00:19:40.050
[LAUGH]
>> Not just faster,

343
00:19:40.050 --> 00:19:41.220
and more cost effective,

344
00:19:41.220 --> 00:19:43.560
you gotta have all three there.
>> Fast,

345
00:19:43.560 --> 00:19:45.930
and cheap, but
we don't care about the quality, right?

346
00:19:45.930 --> 00:19:46.600
No.
>> No [LAUGH]

347
00:19:46.600 --> 00:19:47.890
>> Okay, so

348
00:19:47.890 --> 00:19:50.350
other principles that
are about team empowerment for

349
00:19:50.350 --> 00:19:55.330
instance, I've talked about having
the right people doing the right job.

350
00:19:55.330 --> 00:19:59.850
And we've also talked, in previous
episodes, about self organization as well.

351
00:19:59.850 --> 00:20:02.350
About understanding who's got what skills.

352
00:20:02.350 --> 00:20:05.130
And again,
think about that daily stand up meeting,

353
00:20:05.130 --> 00:20:08.460
where we don't specifically
mention that in Lean development.

354
00:20:08.460 --> 00:20:12.515
But the daily standup meeting
that we utilize in scrum,

355
00:20:12.515 --> 00:20:17.620
where we can all talk about what we
want to achieve during the next day.

356
00:20:17.620 --> 00:20:21.395
And we can talk about what
challenges we perceive happening,

357
00:20:21.395 --> 00:20:24.590
what challenges we might've
had the previous day,

358
00:20:24.590 --> 00:20:28.510
so that then we can bring in other
people with the right skills.

359
00:20:28.510 --> 00:20:31.700
Gives opportunity for other people to say,
hey look, I can help you with that.

360
00:20:33.310 --> 00:20:35.900
We should have direct access
to our customers as well.

361
00:20:35.900 --> 00:20:38.880
Remember, you are delivering for them.

362
00:20:40.940 --> 00:20:47.250
Now, building in integrity, that means
that we don't want to bring in failures.

363
00:20:47.250 --> 00:20:50.760
We want to build in
something that is resilient.

364
00:20:50.760 --> 00:20:55.210
We've got to make sure that all the
components actually work well together.

365
00:20:55.210 --> 00:21:00.180
We want to use automated
testing where we can, but

366
00:21:00.180 --> 00:21:02.790
we wanna make sure that we test fully.

367
00:21:02.790 --> 00:21:07.650
And if we're going to automate testing,
we've got to make sure that there is

368
00:21:07.650 --> 00:21:12.450
some form of customer check at
the end of the testing that says, yes,

369
00:21:12.450 --> 00:21:14.880
I accept this, an acceptance test.

370
00:21:16.110 --> 00:21:19.727
Because otherwise, we could automate
absolutely anything that we want, and

371
00:21:19.727 --> 00:21:23.030
we could say that everything delivers
what it's supposed to deliver.

372
00:21:23.030 --> 00:21:23.858
And it might not actually deliver-
>> Sounds good.

373
00:21:23.858 --> 00:21:24.903
>> Deliver any value, right?

374
00:21:24.903 --> 00:21:27.227
>> [LAUGH]

375
00:21:27.227 --> 00:21:29.726
>> And one of the main principles to Lean

376
00:21:29.726 --> 00:21:32.790
development is to see the whole.

377
00:21:32.790 --> 00:21:37.586
Understand your relationships between all
of our teams, between our developers,

378
00:21:37.586 --> 00:21:42.420
between our developers,
and our operations guys,

379
00:21:42.420 --> 00:21:47.740
between the components of our solutions,
between us, and our customers.

380
00:21:47.740 --> 00:21:49.180
See the big picture.

381
00:21:49.180 --> 00:21:53.680
And I don't really like using sort of
buzz words, and phrases like that, but

382
00:21:53.680 --> 00:22:00.160
you have to see the project as a whole,
you have to see the iteration as a whole.

383
00:22:00.160 --> 00:22:03.340
And what was it you said about lower cost,
and

384
00:22:03.340 --> 00:22:05.360
do it quickly?
>> Better, faster,

385
00:22:05.360 --> 00:22:08.560
more cost effective.
>> Better, faster, more cost effective.

386
00:22:08.560 --> 00:22:13.341
So we've got think big, act small,
fail fast, and learn rapidly,

387
00:22:13.341 --> 00:22:14.732
yeah.
>> Trial by fire.

388
00:22:14.732 --> 00:22:18.084
[LAUGH]
>> It's all about understanding the big

389
00:22:18.084 --> 00:22:22.496
picture, but understanding how your
individual coding, as it were,

390
00:22:22.496 --> 00:22:24.950
contributes to the big picture.
>> Exactly.

391
00:22:24.950 --> 00:22:25.980
>> Yeah, and

392
00:22:25.980 --> 00:22:28.370
failing fast means that if
you're going to get it wrong,

393
00:22:28.370 --> 00:22:30.470
get it wrong in the early stages.
>> Ooh ok.

394
00:22:31.488 --> 00:22:32.380
>> Yeah, it's fail fast,

395
00:22:32.380 --> 00:22:36.430
and then do something about it, which is
where the learn rapidly comes in to it.

396
00:22:36.430 --> 00:22:38.500
Get it wrong in the early stages,
and then,

397
00:22:38.500 --> 00:22:39.937
do something about it.
>> Jo,

398
00:22:39.937 --> 00:22:45.369
I know you're not big on social media, but
recently Will Smith joined social media,

399
00:22:45.369 --> 00:22:47.898
and he's been posting.
>> I'm supposed to be excited,

400
00:22:47.898 --> 00:22:48.501
I'm not too sure.

401
00:22:48.501 --> 00:22:50.760
Just wait, after the show I'm
gonna show you some videos.

402
00:22:50.760 --> 00:22:53.665
But he's been posting some
really good ones, and

403
00:22:53.665 --> 00:22:56.232
failure was a topic that
he did really good.

404
00:22:56.232 --> 00:23:00.616
You guys should check it out, but
it explains how important failure is, and

405
00:23:00.616 --> 00:23:02.410
failing fast does make sense.

406
00:23:02.410 --> 00:23:03.960
Maybe we should email Will Smith,

407
00:23:03.960 --> 00:23:08.750
maybe he'll collaborate with us.
>> After fail fast is

408
00:23:08.750 --> 00:23:09.870
learn rapidly.
>> [LAUGH]

409
00:23:09.870 --> 00:23:10.960
>> You don't learn if you don't

410
00:23:10.960 --> 00:23:11.530
fail.
>> Exactly.

411
00:23:11.530 --> 00:23:13.001
>> You're not actually learning anything

412
00:23:13.001 --> 00:23:13.610
unless we fail.

413
00:23:13.610 --> 00:23:17.265
So we have to accept that our projects
are going to fail because they are,

414
00:23:17.265 --> 00:23:18.620
something's gonna go wrong.

415
00:23:18.620 --> 00:23:22.160
But we wanna make sure that we can
pick up the pieces when it does.

416
00:23:22.160 --> 00:23:27.690
So in these last two episodes then,
we've looked at some agile methodologies.

417
00:23:27.690 --> 00:23:31.970
There are other methodologies out there
in the big wide world that conform to

418
00:23:31.970 --> 00:23:35.690
agile principles, but
they're for another show.

419
00:23:35.690 --> 00:23:40.990
In this particular series we've just taken
a very quick look at those methodologies.

420
00:23:40.990 --> 00:23:44.830
And when we come back, we are actually
going to look at the lifecycle

421
00:23:44.830 --> 00:23:47.910
of an agile project.
>> Well, that was an amazing show.

422
00:23:47.910 --> 00:23:51.130
Thank you so much for your time today,
Jo, and thank you for your time also.

423
00:23:51.130 --> 00:23:53.940
But we are out of time, so we'll sign out.

424
00:23:53.940 --> 00:23:56.390
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

425
00:23:56.390 --> 00:23:59.544
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

426
00:23:59.544 --> 00:24:04.658
[MUSIC]

427
00:24:04.658 --> 00:24:07.080
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: What should we include in a project vision statement and how do we articulate the project and iteration problems? The answer to these questions are explored in this episode.
episodes.title: Vision and Scope
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.340 --> 00:00:06.662
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.662 --> 00:00:08.441
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.441 --> 00:00:11.981
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:11.981 --> 00:00:15.470
>> Welcome to your
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

5
00:00:15.470 --> 00:00:17.690
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.690 --> 00:00:21.640
In this episode we'll be taking a look at
vision and scope, and of course with us

7
00:00:21.640 --> 00:00:25.390
today in studio we have Mrs.
Jo Peacock to help define those terms.

8
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:26.560
How's it going, Jo?

9
00:00:26.560 --> 00:00:27.730
>> Absolutely great, Cherokee.

10
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:28.470
How are you?

11
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:31.220
>> I'm doing well, I have a bit of
a bad hair day, but you know what,

12
00:00:31.220 --> 00:00:34.000
we're not going to let that stop us today.

13
00:00:34.000 --> 00:00:36.067
Well, I don't know it might
stop me actually, it might.

14
00:00:36.067 --> 00:00:40.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> One of those days today I think, yeah.

15
00:00:40.280 --> 00:00:43.180
>> We're gonna persevere and I think you
know maybe we should even talk about

16
00:00:43.180 --> 00:00:45.990
a little bit about a vision, what it is.

17
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:50.740
Maybe our vision could be like,
the perfect hairstyle.

18
00:00:51.740 --> 00:00:52.610
>> Is there such a thing?

19
00:00:52.610 --> 00:00:54.080
>> I don't know.

20
00:00:54.080 --> 00:00:54.830
Is there?

21
00:00:54.830 --> 00:00:57.040
>> Yeah, cuz I haven't found one yet.

22
00:00:57.040 --> 00:01:00.280
>> Do we even care that much?

23
00:01:00.280 --> 00:01:01.530
>> No, I've given up.

24
00:01:01.530 --> 00:01:04.470
Like they say, you get to a certain age,
you just give up.

25
00:01:04.470 --> 00:01:07.270
>> So then what kind of visions
are we really looking at here?

26
00:01:07.270 --> 00:01:09.840
>> Well, what we're gonna look at
in this particular episode is,

27
00:01:09.840 --> 00:01:14.190
we have looked in previous
episodes at Agile.

28
00:01:14.190 --> 00:01:17.229
And the very basic Agile life cycle.

29
00:01:17.229 --> 00:01:21.990
We've looked at the principles of Agile
and we've looked at the values of Agile.

30
00:01:21.990 --> 00:01:25.750
For a moment, in this episode we're
going to look at the vision and

31
00:01:25.750 --> 00:01:28.460
we're going to look at the vision
statement and the problem, and

32
00:01:28.460 --> 00:01:31.820
the problem statement and
the scope of an Agile project.

33
00:01:31.820 --> 00:01:37.930
But for now what I really wanna us to do
is just to have, what I'm gonna call this?

34
00:01:37.930 --> 00:01:42.480
I'm gonna call this a very sort of
common sense discussion about Agile.

35
00:01:42.480 --> 00:01:47.160
It's funny how Agile can be brought
into so many different concepts and so

36
00:01:47.160 --> 00:01:49.810
many different industries.

37
00:01:49.810 --> 00:01:52.560
It's not just about IT.

38
00:01:52.560 --> 00:01:54.810
It's not just about IT
project management either.

39
00:01:54.810 --> 00:01:58.790
And in fact, just this morning,
I was talking to somebody,

40
00:01:58.790 --> 00:02:00.340
on a completely unrelated subject.

41
00:02:00.340 --> 00:02:03.130
And I'd be talking about,
Agile Principles, and

42
00:02:03.130 --> 00:02:05.910
the fact that we want to
do things in iteration.

43
00:02:05.910 --> 00:02:10.980
And so what I really wanna do is just
emphasize how important Agile is

44
00:02:10.980 --> 00:02:13.395
as a project management methodology.

45
00:02:13.395 --> 00:02:17.390
But as a concept for
just day-to-day business.

46
00:02:17.390 --> 00:02:23.160
We've mentioned in previous episodes that
here on ITPRO.TV, we have daily stand ups.

47
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:29.290
And every single morning, we stand up and
actually stand up and we'll

48
00:02:29.290 --> 00:02:34.310
talk about this in another episode about
how we stand up because it keep it short.

49
00:02:34.310 --> 00:02:37.810
We're actually stand up and
we go around the office and

50
00:02:37.810 --> 00:02:39.990
we just all say exactly
what we're going to do,

51
00:02:39.990 --> 00:02:44.360
what we're planning on doing for
the day and how important that is.

52
00:02:44.360 --> 00:02:46.280
And then it gives the opportunity for

53
00:02:46.280 --> 00:02:50.612
other people to sort of chime in and
give us some help or some advice.

54
00:02:50.612 --> 00:02:52.017
[LAUGH] Or maybe tell us that-
>> To make fun of us?

55
00:02:52.017 --> 00:02:53.860
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, to make fun of us.

56
00:02:53.860 --> 00:02:57.070
So maybe tell us that we
shouldn't be doing something.

57
00:02:57.070 --> 00:03:00.920
But the stand up,
this is not at a particular project.

58
00:03:00.920 --> 00:03:03.940
And yet we still doing daily stand ups.

59
00:03:03.940 --> 00:03:06.140
And I will get us.

60
00:03:06.140 --> 00:03:11.020
Why do we used stand ups say in
a situation we don't have a project.

61
00:03:11.020 --> 00:03:13.450
Well, because it makes
sense both to do that.

62
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:16.145
We work in a way,
we want to work in a way that's efficient.

63
00:03:17.310 --> 00:03:19.440
And we can take our job principles and

64
00:03:19.440 --> 00:03:23.090
we can apply them to other
aspects of our work.

65
00:03:23.090 --> 00:03:26.200
And even if we're not
managing a specific project,

66
00:03:26.200 --> 00:03:31.450
we can apply that particular Agile concept
because it allows us to interact and

67
00:03:31.450 --> 00:03:33.640
collaborate with our other team members.

68
00:03:33.640 --> 00:03:37.020
And it's at that point in time where
we can highlight things like, look,

69
00:03:37.020 --> 00:03:39.950
I've got an appointment throughout today.

70
00:03:39.950 --> 00:03:41.740
I've got an important meeting.

71
00:03:41.740 --> 00:03:44.350
I know I need somebody to stand in for me,

72
00:03:44.350 --> 00:03:47.390
that's what we'll do as
part of the standup.

73
00:03:47.390 --> 00:03:50.100
Now I think you mentioned
that in a previous episode

74
00:03:50.100 --> 00:03:54.270
that we've got a colleague that takes
in all the reports to problem solving.

75
00:03:55.360 --> 00:03:58.350
>> For the rock, paper, scissors?

76
00:03:58.350 --> 00:03:59.040
>> Yes.
>> Yeah

77
00:04:00.270 --> 00:04:00.770
>> Right.

78
00:04:00.770 --> 00:04:01.490
Do you want to tell us

79
00:04:01.490 --> 00:04:02.560
a little bit about that?

80
00:04:02.560 --> 00:04:04.400
>> Gosh,
we really need to get him on this show.

81
00:04:04.400 --> 00:04:06.370
Rob, if you're listening, yeah, so.

82
00:04:06.370 --> 00:04:06.957
>> Get in here.

83
00:04:06.957 --> 00:04:08.940
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

84
00:04:08.940 --> 00:04:12.390
No, when they're trying to
estimate time frames for

85
00:04:12.390 --> 00:04:18.330
different stories that they're working on,
they will go like one, two, three shoot.

86
00:04:18.330 --> 00:04:21.590
And of course it's not like a scissors but
it means like two hours for

87
00:04:21.590 --> 00:04:26.530
this estimated like the estimation for
that project or story completion.

88
00:04:26.530 --> 00:04:30.640
But then if someone else think it will
take five hours then they're gonna say,

89
00:04:30.640 --> 00:04:31.790
what's going on here?

90
00:04:31.790 --> 00:04:36.230
Does this person just not know how to
do this or end I'm, It just brings

91
00:04:36.230 --> 00:04:40.370
awareness to the situations, I guess,
when they're trying to task things out.

92
00:04:40.370 --> 00:04:45.060
>> Right, and it sounds like it's just
something that's a little bit of fun.

93
00:04:45.060 --> 00:04:48.750
And it is a little bit of fun, but-
>> We can do it now, if you want.

94
00:04:48.750 --> 00:04:49.299
>> In what respect?

95
00:04:49.299 --> 00:04:52.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just for fun.

96
00:04:52.020 --> 00:04:54.893
>> What are we trying to prioritize here?

97
00:04:54.893 --> 00:04:58.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> Prioritize whether I'm more important

98
00:04:58.360 --> 00:04:59.366
than she is-
>> [LAUGH]

99
00:04:59.366 --> 00:05:00.968
>> That's what we're prioritizing, right?

100
00:05:00.968 --> 00:05:01.581
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

101
00:05:01.581 --> 00:05:02.340
>> [LAUGH] I always

102
00:05:02.340 --> 00:05:03.252
lose at that game anyway.

103
00:05:03.252 --> 00:05:05.231
>> [LAUGH]
>> I've never played it.

104
00:05:06.707 --> 00:05:09.488
>> Okay, there's an admission live on air.

105
00:05:09.488 --> 00:05:11.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But

106
00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:15.410
you know what we're really doing there in
that instance is we're prioritizing, but

107
00:05:15.410 --> 00:05:19.170
we're doing it in a fun way that
everyone wants to participate in.

108
00:05:19.170 --> 00:05:21.120
You imagine if you called a meeting and
said,

109
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:25.360
okay, we're gonna have a meeting every day
or we're gonna have a meeting every week.

110
00:05:25.360 --> 00:05:28.670
Where we're going to prioritize
all of our outstanding activities.

111
00:05:28.670 --> 00:05:30.090
You mentioned the word stories, and

112
00:05:30.090 --> 00:05:33.030
I'm gonna get on to stories
in another episode.

113
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:35.730
But for now,
let's just think about them as activities.

114
00:05:35.730 --> 00:05:40.420
If we had a meeting every day or
every week where

115
00:05:40.420 --> 00:05:45.040
we sat down around the table and
we prioritized all of our activities.

116
00:05:45.040 --> 00:05:45.635
>> Boring.

117
00:05:45.635 --> 00:05:48.240
[LAUGH]
>> Right, exactly, and

118
00:05:48.240 --> 00:05:50.450
what about the attendance?

119
00:05:50.450 --> 00:05:52.070
>> It might start to decline.

120
00:05:52.070 --> 00:05:53.480
>> Might start to decline.

121
00:05:53.480 --> 00:05:54.640
>> It might fall asleep.

122
00:05:54.640 --> 00:05:55.200
I don't know.

123
00:05:55.200 --> 00:05:55.960
>> Right.
I mean I

124
00:05:55.960 --> 00:05:58.400
don't think it' ever going to
be up to its most optimum.

125
00:05:58.400 --> 00:05:58.950
Is it?

126
00:05:58.950 --> 00:05:59.960
>> Right.
>> And yet

127
00:05:59.960 --> 00:06:04.380
having five minutes worth of rock
paper scissors or something similar.

128
00:06:04.380 --> 00:06:07.900
Other prioritization means
that everybody's involved.

129
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:10.900
Because everybody wants to be
involved because it's a bit of fun.

130
00:06:10.900 --> 00:06:14.620
But we still actually get the job done or
what is it, get it done or

131
00:06:14.620 --> 00:06:15.575
whatever you say.

132
00:06:15.575 --> 00:06:16.870
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> Yeah, all right.

133
00:06:16.870 --> 00:06:17.639
>> You're learning, Jill.

134
00:06:17.639 --> 00:06:20.000
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I kinda wish I wasn't.

135
00:06:20.000 --> 00:06:20.740
>> I know, right.

136
00:06:20.740 --> 00:06:25.020
>> But we're getting the job done because
we prioritize in all of our tasks and

137
00:06:25.020 --> 00:06:27.360
all of our activities whilst
to having a bit of fun.

138
00:06:27.360 --> 00:06:28.230
Phone.
>> Right.

139
00:06:28.230 --> 00:06:31.600
>> Nobody said that managing a project or

140
00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:35.860
managing any particular team or managing
any particular work had to be boring.

141
00:06:37.120 --> 00:06:41.390
And I think we get caught up
sometimes especially in IT

142
00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:43.850
in all of the nitty-gritty.

143
00:06:43.850 --> 00:06:45.580
We get caught up in the coding.

144
00:06:45.580 --> 00:06:47.210
We get caught up in

145
00:06:47.210 --> 00:06:48.720
the technical side of things-

146
00:06:48.720 --> 00:06:50.075
>> Deadlines
>> Right.

147
00:06:50.075 --> 00:06:54.390
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we forget that we're still people.

148
00:06:54.390 --> 00:06:56.630
And we still need to what?

149
00:06:56.630 --> 00:06:57.410
Enjoy what we do.

150
00:06:57.410 --> 00:07:00.160
Cuz if you don't enjoy what you do
then you're gonna start looking for

151
00:07:00.160 --> 00:07:00.690
another job.

152
00:07:00.690 --> 00:07:01.990
>> And you're gonna burned out.

153
00:07:01.990 --> 00:07:03.650
>> And that might seem trivial.

154
00:07:03.650 --> 00:07:07.180
And I know that there's probably people
that they're looking at this right now and

155
00:07:07.180 --> 00:07:10.130
thinking to themselves what's this
gotta do with project management?

156
00:07:10.130 --> 00:07:12.145
It's got everything to do
with project management.

157
00:07:12.145 --> 00:07:14.810
Because this is about valuing your people.

158
00:07:14.810 --> 00:07:18.700
And I can't stress this enough, and
it's part of a lot of consultancy work

159
00:07:18.700 --> 00:07:23.460
that I do where I'll tell people, really,

160
00:07:23.460 --> 00:07:29.470
that your team are the most
valuable commodity that you have.

161
00:07:29.470 --> 00:07:33.910
And if you don't value them, then your
project's gonna fail, it's really simple.

162
00:07:33.910 --> 00:07:37.180
>> And something Tim likes to reiterate
here is if you take care of your team,

163
00:07:37.180 --> 00:07:39.150
they're gonna take care of your members,
your customers, or

164
00:07:39.150 --> 00:07:41.580
whomever it is you're looking to service.

165
00:07:41.580 --> 00:07:43.880
>> Right, and
if you take care of your project team,

166
00:07:43.880 --> 00:07:45.870
then they're gonna deliver the work for
you.

167
00:07:45.870 --> 00:07:47.570
If you don't take care
of your project team,

168
00:07:47.570 --> 00:07:49.650
then they're not going
to deliver the work.

169
00:07:49.650 --> 00:07:53.140
If you don't look after your team, if you
don't show them that they're valuable,

170
00:07:53.140 --> 00:07:57.250
if you don't provide them with certain
things that they need to do to their job

171
00:07:57.250 --> 00:08:01.140
and make learning or
make their environment fun,

172
00:08:01.140 --> 00:08:04.190
then quite frankly they're
not gonna give you a 100%.

173
00:08:04.190 --> 00:08:08.190
And those times when you do need a little
bit more because you get into the end of

174
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:11.400
an iteration or
get into the end of a sprint, those times

175
00:08:11.400 --> 00:08:15.060
when you need that little bit more
from them, they're not going to do it.

176
00:08:15.060 --> 00:08:19.300
Remember, remember that we value people,
and we value collaboration, and

177
00:08:19.300 --> 00:08:24.830
we value people over things
like contract negotiation.

178
00:08:24.830 --> 00:08:29.320
It's not what's about in
your contract of employment,

179
00:08:29.320 --> 00:08:35.690
it's about the fact that we want to
nurture an environment of collaboration,

180
00:08:35.690 --> 00:08:40.340
and we want to nurture an environment
where people, will, have fun.

181
00:08:41.360 --> 00:08:42.910
We see a lot of tech companies now,

182
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:47.710
and I think it's sort of spreading
into the non-tech arena, as well.

183
00:08:47.710 --> 00:08:50.530
You see a lot of tech companies
where their environment so

184
00:08:50.530 --> 00:08:54.722
completely different to anything
else that you've ever worked in.

185
00:08:54.722 --> 00:08:56.900
>> Yeah.
>> I think there's, is it Google?

186
00:08:56.900 --> 00:09:01.430
Their head offices have got
kind of little pods in places.

187
00:09:01.430 --> 00:09:03.440
>> Right.
>> It can take maps of certain areas.

188
00:09:03.440 --> 00:09:06.610
>> This is great because you think
about productivity if you're tired.

189
00:09:06.610 --> 00:09:11.550
Take a little nap you're energized instead
of that person at five o'clock ready to go

190
00:09:11.550 --> 00:09:16.550
home to get ready for bed like just gives
a little bit of incentive to stay and

191
00:09:16.550 --> 00:09:18.460
hang out and do things like that.

192
00:09:18.460 --> 00:09:22.010
Fun things like I think I had
mentioned no I did not here but

193
00:09:22.010 --> 00:09:26.380
like we're getting a little robot
here in the office so that's fun, and

194
00:09:26.380 --> 00:09:29.680
it's just something exciting
to keep people engaged.

195
00:09:29.680 --> 00:09:33.690
>> Right, and meetings don't have
to take place around a table.

196
00:09:33.690 --> 00:09:36.840
They don't have to take
place in a meeting room.

197
00:09:36.840 --> 00:09:40.540
They don't have to take
place with a formal agenda.

198
00:09:40.540 --> 00:09:43.460
You walk into a meeting and you know
what points you want to cover, but

199
00:09:43.460 --> 00:09:45.990
then there's no reason
why you can't go and sit

200
00:09:45.990 --> 00:09:50.320
in a cafeteria where you can go and sit
in the garden, I'm American, I'm British.

201
00:09:50.320 --> 00:09:51.430
>> No, no.
>> I'm British right?

202
00:09:51.430 --> 00:09:52.415
We don't have yards.

203
00:09:52.415 --> 00:09:54.035
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay we have gardens.

204
00:09:54.035 --> 00:09:56.130
[LAUGH] It sounds nicer yeah?

205
00:09:56.130 --> 00:09:57.890
>> Yeah, but
if you look at larger companies,

206
00:09:57.890 --> 00:10:01.000
even like the Microsoft Campus
it's gorgeous.

207
00:10:01.000 --> 00:10:04.070
They've got these beautiful cherry
trees and walking paths everywhere.

208
00:10:04.070 --> 00:10:06.940
And so just even getting people up and
moving around,

209
00:10:06.940 --> 00:10:11.070
getting their blood flowing
just creates and in certain

210
00:10:11.070 --> 00:10:16.390
areas you feel like that energy and you
feel like people just wanting to excel.

211
00:10:16.390 --> 00:10:21.330
>> There is a large company in UK that
I spent a lot of time on site with

212
00:10:21.330 --> 00:10:24.610
at there head office which
is in the middle of London

213
00:10:24.610 --> 00:10:26.500
actually which is the global head office.

214
00:10:27.710 --> 00:10:31.290
Has a village on the,
well what I would call the ground floor,

215
00:10:31.290 --> 00:10:34.080
what you would call the first floor.

216
00:10:34.080 --> 00:10:38.130
And it has a complete village,
and it has a hairdressing salon.

217
00:10:38.130 --> 00:10:43.090
It has a cycle shop where you
can get your cycles fixed and

218
00:10:43.090 --> 00:10:44.470
wheels on your bike fixed.

219
00:10:44.470 --> 00:10:47.150
It has four different cafeterias.

220
00:10:47.150 --> 00:10:48.180
It has a coffee shop.

221
00:10:48.180 --> 00:10:49.820
It has convenience store.

222
00:10:49.820 --> 00:10:52.840
It has absolutely in there
that you could want.

223
00:10:52.840 --> 00:10:57.060
You can go and have a meeting with a
colleague while you're getting your nails

224
00:10:57.060 --> 00:10:58.155
done at the same time.

225
00:10:58.155 --> 00:10:59.535
>> That sounds like a dream.

226
00:10:59.535 --> 00:11:01.580
[LAUGH]
>> Work's getting done.

227
00:11:02.710 --> 00:11:03.440
>> Right.
>> So

228
00:11:04.530 --> 00:11:09.410
despite the fact that you could say yeah,
we're just having a conversation, but

229
00:11:09.410 --> 00:11:12.100
that's really important
to the Agile environment.

230
00:11:12.100 --> 00:11:15.740
It's really important to the project.

231
00:11:15.740 --> 00:11:19.530
We've got deadlines and in an Agile
environment we've got iterations that

232
00:11:19.530 --> 00:11:21.540
we've looked at in previous episodes.

233
00:11:21.540 --> 00:11:24.710
We've got iterations that last
between one and four weeks.

234
00:11:24.710 --> 00:11:29.630
If you've got to deliver a piece of code,
and you've got a deadline,

235
00:11:29.630 --> 00:11:33.000
of say, two weeks to do that,
and you're working in pairs.

236
00:11:33.000 --> 00:11:35.540
We've talked about paired programming,
as well.

237
00:11:35.540 --> 00:11:39.370
You're working in pairs,
you've got two weeks to deliver something,

238
00:11:39.370 --> 00:11:43.850
wouldn't it be great if you and
I could go downstairs.

239
00:11:43.850 --> 00:11:48.440
We could go to the nail bar,
and we could sit

240
00:11:48.440 --> 00:11:52.290
next to each other while we were both
getting a pedicure, working on our coding.

241
00:11:52.290 --> 00:11:53.410
>> That'd be amazing, Jo.

242
00:11:53.410 --> 00:11:55.550
>> Right, and why can't we do that?

243
00:11:56.830 --> 00:11:58.542
We need to have a word with somebody,
right?

244
00:11:58.542 --> 00:11:59.830
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] No, but this is true.

245
00:11:59.830 --> 00:12:05.510
I mean, I've even worked in an environment
where it was very militant-like,

246
00:12:05.510 --> 00:12:09.700
and employees weren't allowed to leave
their chair until, I mean, of course,

247
00:12:09.700 --> 00:12:10.640
use the restroom or whatever.

248
00:12:10.640 --> 00:12:16.780
But they weren't allowed to socialize or
leave their spot until a bell was sounded.

249
00:12:16.780 --> 00:12:17.690
>> Right.

250
00:12:17.690 --> 00:12:18.640
>> I'm not joking.
>> Yeah best.

251
00:12:18.640 --> 00:12:19.690
>> Yeah.

252
00:12:19.690 --> 00:12:23.140
>> Yeah, that's completely
opposing to the Agile concept.

253
00:12:23.140 --> 00:12:26.020
>> Right.
>> And it's completely opposing to,

254
00:12:26.020 --> 00:12:28.560
it's very unsexy common
sense as well right?

255
00:12:28.560 --> 00:12:30.080
>> [INAUDIBLE] Right.
>> You're not gonna get the best out of

256
00:12:30.080 --> 00:12:31.190
people like that.

257
00:12:31.190 --> 00:12:36.820
So once we can say that you know having
fun is not obligatory in the office,

258
00:12:36.820 --> 00:12:39.360
it's definitely part of the Agile mindset.

259
00:12:39.360 --> 00:12:42.540
Definitely, that's what
we want to encourage.

260
00:12:42.540 --> 00:12:44.510
So the Agile mindset and

261
00:12:44.510 --> 00:12:49.700
the Agile concept can be applied
to just pretty much anything.

262
00:12:49.700 --> 00:12:54.590
And not just with the project
works that we are associated with.

263
00:12:54.590 --> 00:12:58.370
So let's get onto
the Agile project itself.

264
00:12:58.370 --> 00:13:01.960
And in fact you'll see there on
our particular slide just to wrap

265
00:13:01.960 --> 00:13:02.520
it up really.

266
00:13:02.520 --> 00:13:03.690
That particular slide.

267
00:13:03.690 --> 00:13:05.510
You'll see that it applies to Sales and

268
00:13:05.510 --> 00:13:09.560
Marketing and Research and
absolutely anything.

269
00:13:09.560 --> 00:13:14.320
Absolutely anything, and the obviously
the Agile project approach or

270
00:13:14.320 --> 00:13:16.630
so applies to absolutely everything too.

271
00:13:16.630 --> 00:13:18.760
We want to start doing things, and

272
00:13:18.760 --> 00:13:23.340
how many times were you told as
a kid to do things baby steps yeah?

273
00:13:23.340 --> 00:13:26.690
One feet at a time, one step at a time.

274
00:13:26.690 --> 00:13:30.650
Don't try and achieve everything
that you want to achieve,

275
00:13:30.650 --> 00:13:32.730
let's do this one step at a time.

276
00:13:32.730 --> 00:13:35.570
That's exactly what Agile
is telling you to do.

277
00:13:37.310 --> 00:13:40.480
So in order to do things
one step at a time,

278
00:13:40.480 --> 00:13:42.990
you have to understand
though where you're going.

279
00:13:44.100 --> 00:13:47.130
And this is where our
vision comes into this,

280
00:13:47.130 --> 00:13:52.160
and every agile project
has to have a vision.

281
00:13:52.160 --> 00:13:56.930
Now, a vision is not
something that you plan,

282
00:13:56.930 --> 00:14:00.580
in great detail right from the word go.

283
00:14:00.580 --> 00:14:02.550
The vision is where you want to get to,

284
00:14:02.550 --> 00:14:05.890
it's what the entire
project wants to achieve.

285
00:14:05.890 --> 00:14:09.990
It's not what individual
iteration wants to achieve.

286
00:14:09.990 --> 00:14:14.810
So your Project Vision, well,
it's where we, and it says on this slide,

287
00:14:14.810 --> 00:14:18.600
we envision our end goal.

288
00:14:18.600 --> 00:14:21.100
It's about preparing
the successful execution.

289
00:14:21.100 --> 00:14:22.900
It's where we want to get to.

290
00:14:22.900 --> 00:14:24.030
And, so

291
00:14:24.030 --> 00:14:28.940
the first thing that we do in any Agile
project is understand what our vision is.

292
00:14:28.940 --> 00:14:31.290
What's your vision for today?

293
00:14:31.290 --> 00:14:32.100
Do you have a vision?

294
00:14:32.100 --> 00:14:34.785
>> Margaritas, sand and sunshine.

295
00:14:34.785 --> 00:14:36.268
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, hold on.

296
00:14:36.268 --> 00:14:41.020
[LAUGH] And what do we have
to do in order to get there?

297
00:14:41.020 --> 00:14:45.510
>> Well, I have to have money to travel so
I guess that means I need

298
00:14:45.510 --> 00:14:50.280
to execute what I'm set out to do for
my J-O-B my job right?

299
00:14:50.280 --> 00:14:52.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> So how about let's focus on that and

300
00:14:52.600 --> 00:14:56.470
create some kind of meaningful show,

301
00:14:56.470 --> 00:14:59.295
something that we can deliver
that adds value to you.

302
00:14:59.295 --> 00:14:59.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right.

303
00:14:59.900 --> 00:15:02.360
Well if your vision is
margaritas at the end of

304
00:15:02.360 --> 00:15:03.640
the day
>> [LAUGH]

305
00:15:03.640 --> 00:15:05.520
>> We've got certain things that we've got

306
00:15:05.520 --> 00:15:08.060
to do before we get to the margaritas.

307
00:15:08.060 --> 00:15:10.010
And by the way, I hope I'm invited.

308
00:15:10.010 --> 00:15:10.985
>> For sure.

309
00:15:10.985 --> 00:15:13.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we have increments.

310
00:15:13.950 --> 00:15:18.380
We have iterations that we have
to achieve throughout the day.

311
00:15:18.380 --> 00:15:21.910
In other words we've got episodes that
we've got to record throughout the day.

312
00:15:21.910 --> 00:15:22.450
>> Right.

313
00:15:22.450 --> 00:15:24.920
>> And we record one episode at a time,

314
00:15:24.920 --> 00:15:29.450
we don't try to do all of them at once
because quite frankly we'd be worn out.

315
00:15:29.450 --> 00:15:32.825
And she'd probably wanna strangle
me by the end of the second one.

316
00:15:32.825 --> 00:15:36.780
[LAUGH] So we have increments and
we have iterations.

317
00:15:36.780 --> 00:15:38.470
You might even call them sprints.

318
00:15:38.470 --> 00:15:42.090
Look at us, applying agile to something
outside of project management.

319
00:15:42.090 --> 00:15:46.250
But we've got a vision, well Cherokee's
got vision and I'm tagging along for

320
00:15:46.250 --> 00:15:47.220
the ride.

321
00:15:47.220 --> 00:15:48.770
We've got a vision.

322
00:15:48.770 --> 00:15:54.170
And what we need is to achieve our
increments in order to get to that vision.

323
00:15:54.170 --> 00:15:56.640
We have to achieve those iterations.

324
00:15:56.640 --> 00:15:59.140
But the vision is the end goal.

325
00:15:59.140 --> 00:16:03.100
And so we need to have what
we call a Vision Statement.

326
00:16:03.100 --> 00:16:08.180
And a Vision Statement as it simply
says there describes the future state.

327
00:16:08.180 --> 00:16:10.630
So once our problem statements
have been redressed,

328
00:16:10.630 --> 00:16:14.120
we're going to look at
those in another episode.

329
00:16:14.120 --> 00:16:16.910
But once our problem statements have been

330
00:16:16.910 --> 00:16:20.280
satisfied then we will
have achieved our vision.

331
00:16:20.280 --> 00:16:21.910
And in our case,

332
00:16:21.910 --> 00:16:27.520
you see once we finish our episodes
then you can then achieve your vision.

333
00:16:27.520 --> 00:16:29.370
>> [LAUGH] You're more great.

334
00:16:29.370 --> 00:16:31.760
>> Yeah that's the last iteration.

335
00:16:31.760 --> 00:16:34.860
So we have to have a sample
Vision Statement because we use that

336
00:16:34.860 --> 00:16:37.010
Vision Statement for communication.

337
00:16:37.010 --> 00:16:39.190
That's our goal and
it's going to be visible.

338
00:16:39.190 --> 00:16:42.680
And it might be on our boards think
about canvan board for instance.

339
00:16:42.680 --> 00:16:44.430
Since we look down in this episode.

340
00:16:44.430 --> 00:16:46.260
It will be on our board.

341
00:16:46.260 --> 00:16:49.150
And see, there's a sample in front of you,
an example there,

342
00:16:49.150 --> 00:16:53.050
it should start with Deliver
a solution that will.

343
00:16:53.050 --> 00:16:56.780
And so, that should be on our board,
a vision should be on our board.

344
00:16:56.780 --> 00:16:59.650
And everyone who's involved
in the project, and

345
00:16:59.650 --> 00:17:04.200
who's involved in the iterations, can
see that this is what we're aiming for.

346
00:17:04.200 --> 00:17:08.820
And so, today on our board, what we're
gonna put on our board is margaritas.

347
00:17:08.820 --> 00:17:11.466
And we're gonna have that up
on the board just behind us.

348
00:17:11.466 --> 00:17:17.063
But we gotta start with deliver a solution
that will foster relaxation and enjoyment.

349
00:17:17.063 --> 00:17:20.890
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, I am impressed by that, yeah.

350
00:17:20.890 --> 00:17:24.912
Deliver a solution that will relax
Cherokee at the end of the day.

351
00:17:24.912 --> 00:17:25.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

352
00:17:25.870 --> 00:17:27.840
Fair enough, so, that's it.

353
00:17:27.840 --> 00:17:29.840
We're going with the margaritas today.

354
00:17:29.840 --> 00:17:31.110
And what we're gonna do then,

355
00:17:31.110 --> 00:17:36.740
throughout the day is we're
going to deliver our increments.

356
00:17:36.740 --> 00:17:41.690
We're going to deliver our iterations that
will allow us to achieve that vision.

357
00:17:41.690 --> 00:17:45.890
The vision should be communicated not just
within IT, and not just within the team.

358
00:17:45.890 --> 00:17:50.260
But the vision also needs to
be agreed with the customer.

359
00:17:50.260 --> 00:17:52.110
Whomever your customer is.

360
00:17:52.110 --> 00:17:55.790
Because your vision is whatever it
is that you're trying to achieve,

361
00:17:55.790 --> 00:17:59.790
which is deliver value to your customer.

362
00:17:59.790 --> 00:18:02.650
Bear in mind that the customer is
the person who pays the bills,

363
00:18:02.650 --> 00:18:05.880
they're asking you to
undertake that project.

364
00:18:05.880 --> 00:18:09.660
So you are delivering your
vision to your customer, and

365
00:18:09.660 --> 00:18:11.950
therefore they've got to agree.

366
00:18:11.950 --> 00:18:16.180
So at the very start of a project,
we agree our Vision Statement.

367
00:18:17.240 --> 00:18:19.090
So what we're going to do for

368
00:18:19.090 --> 00:18:22.700
this particular episode is where
going to wrap that up here.

369
00:18:22.700 --> 00:18:26.350
And then when we come back in our next
episode we are going to take a look

370
00:18:26.350 --> 00:18:28.080
at our problem statements.

371
00:18:28.080 --> 00:18:31.180
And we're gonna take a look at
the scope of our project as well.

372
00:18:31.180 --> 00:18:32.230
>> Sounds like a plan, Jo.

373
00:18:32.230 --> 00:18:35.230
I know we said we'd be taking
a look at vision and scope, but

374
00:18:35.230 --> 00:18:38.170
stay tuned, you don't wanna
miss that second part here.

375
00:18:38.170 --> 00:18:39.220
For now, let's sign out.

376
00:18:39.220 --> 00:18:41.230
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

377
00:18:41.230 --> 00:18:42.160
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

378
00:18:42.160 --> 00:18:44.700
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

379
00:18:44.700 --> 00:18:50.464
[MUSIC]

380
00:18:50.464 --> 00:18:53.980
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: The Scope of a project tells us what we should deliver as an output and so this episode outlines the importance of the Scope statement and helps with defining a relevant and valuable statement.
episodes.title: Vision and Scope Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.150 --> 00:00:02.738
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host Dan Pezet.

2
00:00:02.738 --> 00:00:06.152
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.152 --> 00:00:08.381
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.381 --> 00:00:12.026
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.026 --> 00:00:15.200
>> Welcome to your agile project
management concepts series.

6
00:00:15.200 --> 00:00:17.311
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.311 --> 00:00:19.897
In this episode,
we'll continue taking a look at vision.

8
00:00:19.897 --> 00:00:21.880
While we saw vision in the law episode,

9
00:00:21.880 --> 00:00:25.972
this is actually a part two where we're
coming back to talk about some scope, and

10
00:00:25.972 --> 00:00:30.085
with us today back in studios we were able
to convince Ms. Jo Peacock to return.

11
00:00:30.085 --> 00:00:31.316
How's it going Jo?

12
00:00:31.316 --> 00:00:33.585
>> It's absolutely great,
thank you Cherokee.

13
00:00:33.585 --> 00:00:35.331
How are you?
>> I'm doing wonderful.

14
00:00:35.331 --> 00:00:36.898
>> Looking forward to your margaritas?

15
00:00:36.898 --> 00:00:38.616
>> That's right,
that's what we were talking about.

16
00:00:38.616 --> 00:00:40.300
So how are we gonna get there?

17
00:00:40.300 --> 00:00:42.614
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, no,
it's straight to the point.

18
00:00:42.614 --> 00:00:48.337
[LAUGH] Okay, in our last episode then, we
actually looked at defining the vision for

19
00:00:48.337 --> 00:00:52.691
an Agile project, and so,
Cherokee decided that the vision for

20
00:00:52.691 --> 00:00:56.497
our project today were margaritas
at the end of the day.

21
00:00:56.497 --> 00:00:58.000
>> Sand and sun.

22
00:00:58.000 --> 00:00:59.390
>> Sand and sun, as well?

23
00:00:59.390 --> 00:01:02.930
>> Yeah, but I don't know about
the sun if it's at the end of the day.

24
00:01:02.930 --> 00:01:04.309
I'll take a sunset.

25
00:01:04.309 --> 00:01:05.120
How about that?

26
00:01:05.120 --> 00:01:07.550
>> Okay, sunset and margaritas.

27
00:01:07.550 --> 00:01:09.200
That means we better be wrapped up early,
as well.

28
00:01:09.200 --> 00:01:11.487
>> Sounds like a Jimmy Buffett
song brewing here.

29
00:01:11.487 --> 00:01:13.659
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] If she starts singing,

30
00:01:13.659 --> 00:01:14.401
I'm leaving.

31
00:01:14.401 --> 00:01:15.447
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

32
00:01:15.447 --> 00:01:20.395
we've already defined our vision clearly,
and Cherokee's got a really

33
00:01:20.395 --> 00:01:24.800
well defined vision in her head,
[LAUGH] l by the sounds of things.

34
00:01:24.800 --> 00:01:26.982
So yeah, and if she starts singing.

35
00:01:26.982 --> 00:01:30.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what we've got to understand then,

36
00:01:30.870 --> 00:01:36.010
along with the vision, is that we've got
to understand the problem statement.

37
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:41.451
Now within any particular project, and
it depends on the size of the project,

38
00:01:41.451 --> 00:01:46.576
and this is where Agile really,
really, really sort of shows its value.

39
00:01:46.576 --> 00:01:50.887
Is that, we can have a problem,
statement for an Agile project itself,

40
00:01:50.887 --> 00:01:55.430
as a whole, or we can have a problem
statement for individual user stories.

41
00:01:55.430 --> 00:01:58.670
In other words, a problem statement for
each iteration, and

42
00:01:58.670 --> 00:02:03.150
we look to resolve a particular
problem with each iteration.

43
00:02:04.910 --> 00:02:09.340
Some organizations prefer to
identify the problem statement

44
00:02:09.340 --> 00:02:13.450
right at the very beginning as
we're identifying the vision.
