an organization like us,

507
00:29:16.710 --> 00:29:19.850
then we have to make sure that
our employees over in the UK,

508
00:29:19.850 --> 00:29:23.070
we can not ask them to work more
than a certain number of hours.

509
00:29:23.070 --> 00:29:25.610
So we have to be aware of that.

510
00:29:25.610 --> 00:29:28.880
And that's the job of, and
we spoke about a scrum master,

511
00:29:28.880 --> 00:29:31.170
and that's the job of the scrum master.

512
00:29:31.170 --> 00:29:33.200
His job is there to facilitate the team.

513
00:29:33.200 --> 00:29:35.950
So he needs to be aware of all of that.

514
00:29:35.950 --> 00:29:38.490
And he needs to be aware
of the constraints.

515
00:29:38.490 --> 00:29:43.940
Now the product owner will also
enable the scrum masters to be aware

516
00:29:43.940 --> 00:29:49.350
of any product constraints that there
are any technological constraints.

517
00:29:49.350 --> 00:29:52.710
So with any Agile project [or
with any project let's face it,

518
00:29:52.710 --> 00:29:58.000
we've got to determine what
success means for that project.

519
00:29:58.000 --> 00:30:00.620
In other words, how will we know
when we finish that project?

520
00:30:02.670 --> 00:30:04.780
Now if you remember in a previous episode,

521
00:30:04.780 --> 00:30:08.510
we talked about the fact that
some projects are just ongoing.

522
00:30:08.510 --> 00:30:10.610
Some things are ongoing iterations.

523
00:30:10.610 --> 00:30:12.650
For instance, your operating system.

524
00:30:12.650 --> 00:30:15.800
You never ever set out to develop
an operating system and then suddenly

525
00:30:15.800 --> 00:30:19.600
turn around and say, right, that operating
system's only going to be valid for

526
00:30:19.600 --> 00:30:23.450
the next year or the next two years or
for the next ten years.

527
00:30:23.450 --> 00:30:27.120
But you set out to develop an operating
system, but then what you will do

528
00:30:27.120 --> 00:30:32.350
is you will update that operating
system in iterations and in increments.

529
00:30:32.350 --> 00:30:33.890
But with a lot of projects.

530
00:30:33.890 --> 00:30:38.740
And in fact with most projects,
we will have a defined end date,

531
00:30:38.740 --> 00:30:42.840
or we will have what we
call differing success.

532
00:30:42.840 --> 00:30:46.480
And even with that operating system,
we have that defined success.

533
00:30:46.480 --> 00:30:51.010
We know that we want to do
is we want to facilitate

534
00:30:51.010 --> 00:30:54.530
access to applications
with our operating system.

535
00:30:54.530 --> 00:30:58.650
And we don't want to incur any problems or

536
00:30:58.650 --> 00:31:02.010
incur any delays whilst
we're facilitating that.

537
00:31:02.010 --> 00:31:04.720
And so that would be our project success.

538
00:31:04.720 --> 00:31:07.180
But with most projects we've
got to define success and

539
00:31:07.180 --> 00:31:13.210
that might be implementation of a brand
new service, a brand new functionality.

540
00:31:13.210 --> 00:31:17.000
So in that case then we've
got to ensure that we define

541
00:31:17.000 --> 00:31:19.060
what we consider to be success.

542
00:31:19.060 --> 00:31:21.770
Cuz only then can we sign
off on a project to say,

543
00:31:21.770 --> 00:31:23.640
yes that project has been completed.

544
00:31:24.920 --> 00:31:27.700
We have to focus on the solution,
not the process.

545
00:31:27.700 --> 00:31:30.060
This is not about achieving milestones.

546
00:31:30.060 --> 00:31:33.150
This is not about saying, hey,
look, we've ticked this box, and

547
00:31:33.150 --> 00:31:36.755
we've ticked this box, and we've ticked
this box, so we must be finished.

548
00:31:36.755 --> 00:31:38.075
Thats not the case.

549
00:31:38.075 --> 00:31:41.615
What were focusing on is the deliverable,
and only when weve achieved

550
00:31:41.615 --> 00:31:45.255
the deliverable, can we then say
that the project has been a success.

551
00:31:45.255 --> 00:31:51.175
Which is why our projects assessed
must be defined as being SMART,

552
00:31:51.175 --> 00:31:55.815
specific, measurable, achievable,
realistic, and timebound.

553
00:31:55.815 --> 00:32:00.470
Weve got to have an element of time in
there when we expect this to happen by.

554
00:32:00.470 --> 00:32:07.110
And every single success criteria
has got to have a relevant and

555
00:32:07.110 --> 00:32:10.720
related KPI,
that's a key performance indicator.

556
00:32:12.030 --> 00:32:14.260
So that's very difficult to achieve and

557
00:32:14.260 --> 00:32:16.790
I'm not gonna pretend that this is
something that's gonna be easy.

558
00:32:16.790 --> 00:32:19.660
This is probably gonna be as difficult and

559
00:32:19.660 --> 00:32:22.930
as big an exercise as defined
in the problem statement.

560
00:32:22.930 --> 00:32:28.600
And making sure that the problem
statement is articulated with detail,

561
00:32:28.600 --> 00:32:33.120
and enough detail for you to be able
then to define the success criteria.

562
00:32:33.120 --> 00:32:34.460
And in a lot of instances,

563
00:32:34.460 --> 00:32:39.750
we find success criteria at the same
time as we define the problem statement.

564
00:32:39.750 --> 00:32:43.230
Because we know that if we have
satisfied the problem statement

565
00:32:43.230 --> 00:32:46.510
then we have met our success criteria.

566
00:32:46.510 --> 00:32:52.180
But again, I just want to emphasize
the fact that success criteria is key.

567
00:32:52.180 --> 00:32:56.610
This will determine whether you sign
off on this particular project or

568
00:32:56.610 --> 00:32:59.560
whether you don't sign off
on this particular project.

569
00:32:59.560 --> 00:33:02.420
You have to meet your success criteria.

570
00:33:02.420 --> 00:33:03.870
So in our next episode,

571
00:33:03.870 --> 00:33:08.660
we're actually going to take
a further delve into stakeholders and

572
00:33:08.660 --> 00:33:13.170
identifying stakeholders and
also into defining that success criteria.

573
00:33:13.170 --> 00:33:17.100
So, for now, we will say thank
you very much for watching and

574
00:33:17.100 --> 00:33:19.060
then we'll join you in our next episode.

575
00:33:19.060 --> 00:33:20.910
>> Awesome, Jo, thank you so
much for joining us.

576
00:33:20.910 --> 00:33:22.400
Look forward to that next episode.

577
00:33:22.400 --> 00:33:23.810
You don't want to miss that, either.

578
00:33:23.810 --> 00:33:25.180
But for now, let's sign out.

579
00:33:25.180 --> 00:33:27.270
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

580
00:33:27.270 --> 00:33:28.190
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

581
00:33:28.190 --> 00:33:29.640
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

582
00:33:29.640 --> 00:33:36.896
[MUSIC]

583
00:33:36.896 --> 00:33:39.748
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: All IT projects must deliver an output that is valuable to the customer, but how do we know who our customer is, and what of the other people involved in our project? This episode demonstrates how we can not only identify stakeholders, but also how we can manage them to ensure the efficiency of the project.
episodes.title: Identifying Stakeholders
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.476
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.476 --> 00:00:02.985
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.985 --> 00:00:06.856
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.856 --> 00:00:08.363
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.363 --> 00:00:12.755
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome ladies and

6
00:00:12.755 --> 00:00:15.410
gentlemen to your
Agile Project Management series.

7
00:00:15.410 --> 00:00:17.510
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.510 --> 00:00:21.770
In this episode, we'll be taking a look
at, well, what stakeholders are.

9
00:00:21.770 --> 00:00:23.740
And don't get that confused
with stockholders.

10
00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:25.270
However, they could be stakeholders.

11
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:26.130
But you know what?

12
00:00:26.130 --> 00:00:29.210
We'll just let Jo sort that all out for
you.

13
00:00:29.210 --> 00:00:32.310
How's it going today Jo?
>> Well it was fine until a moment ago and

14
00:00:32.310 --> 00:00:34.280
now you've just given
me a mess to sort out.

15
00:00:34.280 --> 00:00:36.510
>> I know, I'm great at that.

16
00:00:36.510 --> 00:00:39.790
I always like to just say these
little confusing things, and

17
00:00:39.790 --> 00:00:42.445
then let you deal with it, Jo.
>> Yeah, thanks.

18
00:00:42.445 --> 00:00:43.140
>> [LAUGH]

19
00:00:43.140 --> 00:00:44.480
>> Thank you very much.

20
00:00:44.480 --> 00:00:45.090
Yes, we are.

21
00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:49.220
In this particular episode, we're actually
going to look at identifying stakeholders.

22
00:00:49.220 --> 00:00:53.030
How do we work out what a stakeholder is,
and who our stakeholders are?

23
00:00:53.030 --> 00:00:57.570
And what they actually mean to
the success of our Agile project.

24
00:00:57.570 --> 00:01:03.060
So a stakeholder, really, is just defined
as anybody who has got an interest in

25
00:01:03.060 --> 00:01:08.230
a particular outcome and in a particular
project, or even in an organization.

26
00:01:08.230 --> 00:01:12.450
A stakeholder is literally
anybody that's got an interest.

27
00:01:12.450 --> 00:01:16.042
My nosy neighbor is a stakeholder
in everything that I do.

28
00:01:16.042 --> 00:01:18.660
>> [LAUGH] You have one of those too?

29
00:01:18.660 --> 00:01:20.070
>> I do, yeah.

30
00:01:20.070 --> 00:01:21.760
It's not the same one, but yeah.

31
00:01:21.760 --> 00:01:26.490
Not the same one as yours, but
yeah we have one of those.

32
00:01:26.490 --> 00:01:29.290
We've had quite a few of those
in our lifetime as well.

33
00:01:29.290 --> 00:01:32.420
But they're a stakeholder.

34
00:01:32.420 --> 00:01:36.594
You, on the other end of the TV screen or
your computer screen or whatever,

35
00:01:36.594 --> 00:01:38.200
you are a stakeholder.

36
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:42.600
And you are a stakeholder in what we do
here because what we've gotta make sure is

37
00:01:42.600 --> 00:01:45.870
that what we deliver is
content that you can watch.

38
00:01:45.870 --> 00:01:49.950
And that actually you can relate to and
also that you can learn from as well.

39
00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:54.130
So you're a stakeholder and
you're very important to us.

40
00:01:54.130 --> 00:01:58.826
But other stakeholders, are people
are like stakeholders for instance.

41
00:01:58.826 --> 00:02:02.500
Somebody that owns stock in an
organization has actually got an interest

42
00:02:02.500 --> 00:02:04.900
in how that organization performs.

43
00:02:04.900 --> 00:02:09.390
And so stakeholders can come
from a variety of places.

44
00:02:09.390 --> 00:02:13.640
And whilst it's defined as anybody who's
got an interest or a concern, it really is

45
00:02:13.640 --> 00:02:19.600
anybody that cares about the activities or
the targets or the deliverables.

46
00:02:19.600 --> 00:02:22.460
Stakeholders could be
absolutely anybody and

47
00:02:22.460 --> 00:02:26.200
they come from all levels
of our organization.

48
00:02:26.200 --> 00:02:29.160
And external to our organization as well.
>> That's right,

49
00:02:29.160 --> 00:02:33.760
Jo, I mean, just having that
ideology that it could be anyone.

50
00:02:33.760 --> 00:02:35.861
For instance, maybe I worked for

51
00:02:35.861 --> 00:02:40.750
a company that worked with some kind
of biochemical production or whatever.

52
00:02:40.750 --> 00:02:42.610
And then there was some kind of leak.

53
00:02:42.610 --> 00:02:47.010
And so the general public,
maybe my leak leaked into a water supply.

54
00:02:47.010 --> 00:02:51.020
So at that point in time
anyone could be a stakeholder,

55
00:02:51.020 --> 00:02:54.570
or anyone within that region
that would be affected or

56
00:02:54.570 --> 00:02:58.652
have a vetted interest there.
>> and sometimes I worry where your head

57
00:02:58.652 --> 00:02:59.753
is going.
>> [LAUGH]

58
00:02:59.753 --> 00:03:01.747
>> But, you're right.

59
00:03:01.747 --> 00:03:02.942
She is right.

60
00:03:02.942 --> 00:03:07.454
[LAUGH] A stakeholder is not just
somebody that's got a financial interest.

61
00:03:07.454 --> 00:03:10.960
And I think that's a general
misconception that we have.

62
00:03:10.960 --> 00:03:13.440
And I think that there are cultural
issues to that as well.

63
00:03:13.440 --> 00:03:17.676
Because I know that certainly here in the
US, a stakeholder is generally considered

64
00:03:17.676 --> 00:03:21.520
to be somebody who's got a financial
interest, like a customer.

65
00:03:21.520 --> 00:03:24.730
But as far as we're concerned
in an agile perspective,

66
00:03:24.730 --> 00:03:28.010
a stakeholder is literally just
somebody who is interested,

67
00:03:28.010 --> 00:03:31.660
somebody who has a concern,
whether it's a financial interest or not.

68
00:03:31.660 --> 00:03:35.440
Now I've already mentioned that you're a
stakeholder in what we're producing here.

69
00:03:35.440 --> 00:03:39.732
But as my sort of co-host Cherokee
is also a stakeholder in what I

70
00:03:39.732 --> 00:03:43.560
produce as well and
what we're talking about right now.

71
00:03:43.560 --> 00:03:47.570
And our director Taylor is also
a stakeholder in this entire production.

72
00:03:47.570 --> 00:03:49.466
And every single one of us,

73
00:03:49.466 --> 00:03:53.370
you have an influence over
the content that we deliver.

74
00:03:53.370 --> 00:03:56.190
Cherokee has an influence over
the content that we deliver and

75
00:03:56.190 --> 00:03:58.250
the way that we deliver the content.

76
00:03:58.250 --> 00:04:02.960
I have an influence over the content
that I have compiled and

77
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:04.190
the way it's delivered.

78
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:07.150
And Taylor also has an influence over

79
00:04:07.150 --> 00:04:11.380
the way that our content is delivered
as well and how it's presented.

80
00:04:11.380 --> 00:04:16.830
And so each one of us in this particular
relationship has an interest.

81
00:04:16.830 --> 00:04:19.610
Now they may be slight
different interests.

82
00:04:19.610 --> 00:04:22.984
Taylor has an interest in
how this is produced and

83
00:04:22.984 --> 00:04:26.867
how he's going to ensure that
this is cohesive for you.

84
00:04:26.867 --> 00:04:30.893
You have an interest in whether this
is going to be something that you're

85
00:04:30.893 --> 00:04:34.510
interested in and
also something that you can watch.

86
00:04:34.510 --> 00:04:37.910
Now I have an interest in
the content that I'm producing and

87
00:04:37.910 --> 00:04:39.440
also the way I'm talking.

88
00:04:39.440 --> 00:04:43.610
And Cherokee's also got an interest
in the topic that we're covering and

89
00:04:43.610 --> 00:04:46.800
making sure that she keeps me on track.
>> Some of my

90
00:04:46.800 --> 00:04:50.520
interests are a little bit selfish,
cuz I love this topic to begin with.

91
00:04:50.520 --> 00:04:53.894
But then, of course, yes just
ensuring that you guys are able to

92
00:04:53.894 --> 00:04:57.912
pass your certification or just develop
yourselves professionally also.

93
00:04:57.912 --> 00:04:58.566
>> Right,

94
00:04:58.566 --> 00:05:02.630
so stakeholders come
from a variety of places.

95
00:05:02.630 --> 00:05:04.580
What we've got to do is that we've got to,

96
00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:07.280
and you here this in
business all the time.

97
00:05:07.280 --> 00:05:10.730
We have got to manage
stakeholder expectations.

98
00:05:10.730 --> 00:05:14.894
And you quite often hear
the phrase under-promise and

99
00:05:14.894 --> 00:05:17.170
over-deliver.
>> Yes.

100
00:05:17.170 --> 00:05:18.109
>> Yep, this is about

101
00:05:18.109 --> 00:05:20.450
managing stakeholder expectations.

102
00:05:20.450 --> 00:05:24.920
It's ensuring that your
stakeholders know what to expect.

103
00:05:24.920 --> 00:05:29.080
Right at the very start of this episode
we tried to manage your expectations.

104
00:05:29.080 --> 00:05:33.791
Because we gave you a little insight
into what we were covering as

105
00:05:33.791 --> 00:05:35.458
part of this episode.

106
00:05:35.458 --> 00:05:39.518
Now Cherokee managed your expectations
by telling you who it was

107
00:05:39.518 --> 00:05:44.600
that was actually covering the topic and
who it was that was talking today.

108
00:05:44.600 --> 00:05:49.400
And Taylor, our director, is managing
your expectations by ensuring that

109
00:05:49.400 --> 00:05:52.590
not only you can see us on the camera.

110
00:05:52.590 --> 00:05:56.750
But also that the right sort of content
is displayed at the right time.

111
00:05:56.750 --> 00:06:00.520
And that the right information comes up
at the bottom of the screen at the right

112
00:06:00.520 --> 00:06:01.830
time as well.

113
00:06:01.830 --> 00:06:08.460
So every single stakeholder has a role
in your project and in your activity.

114
00:06:08.460 --> 00:06:13.356
It's up to you as a project manager or
as a scrum master within

115
00:06:13.356 --> 00:06:17.780
an Agile project to define
who your stakeholders are.

116
00:06:18.910 --> 00:06:22.939
And we'll talk in a little while about not
just the definition of stakeholders, but

117
00:06:22.939 --> 00:06:25.840
also about categorization
of stakeholders as well.

118
00:06:25.840 --> 00:06:28.160
Because some stakeholders, well,

119
00:06:28.160 --> 00:06:30.470
they might not be as important
as other stakeholders.

120
00:06:30.470 --> 00:06:33.410
And we've gotta look at this objectively,
and

121
00:06:33.410 --> 00:06:35.610
try not to let our emotions in the way.

122
00:06:35.610 --> 00:06:40.190
Cuz I mean, ultimately,
Cherokee has an interest in what it is

123
00:06:40.190 --> 00:06:44.397
that we produce here, but as-
>> Cherokee can be replaced.

124
00:06:44.397 --> 00:06:48.917
[LAUGH]
>> I didn't say that, I didn't say that.

125
00:06:48.917 --> 00:06:51.826
>> But [LAUGH] as far as this particular

126
00:06:51.826 --> 00:06:57.810
content is concerned, she has
absolutely no influence whatsoever.

127
00:06:57.810 --> 00:07:01.990
[LAUGH] So yeah, she has an interest,
but no influence.

128
00:07:01.990 --> 00:07:06.760
As she said, she can be replaced,
carries on, it will happen.

129
00:07:06.760 --> 00:07:09.100
So how do you know who your
stakeholders are then?

130
00:07:09.100 --> 00:07:11.220
That first one that's up
there is the word really,

131
00:07:12.770 --> 00:07:15.180
that's most important to all of this.

132
00:07:15.180 --> 00:07:18.990
Ask, if you don't know who
your stakeholders are, ask.

133
00:07:18.990 --> 00:07:21.650
Ask who your stakeholders are, ask people.

134
00:07:21.650 --> 00:07:24.140
They could be people
within your organization.

135
00:07:24.140 --> 00:07:26.920
It could be customers both internal and
external.

136
00:07:26.920 --> 00:07:31.090
It could be other people within your team,
for instance.

137
00:07:31.090 --> 00:07:33.044
Subject matter experts,

138
00:07:33.044 --> 00:07:38.030
people that you're working
alongside that have specific roles.

139
00:07:38.030 --> 00:07:41.974
And then think about people that
are outside of your service provider

140
00:07:41.974 --> 00:07:46.150
organization, such as users or
even suppliers and third parties.

141
00:07:46.150 --> 00:07:48.020
These are all stakeholders.

142
00:07:48.020 --> 00:07:52.814
You see, if we didn't have third
parties working with us to help us to

143
00:07:52.814 --> 00:07:58.120
deliver this content to the Internet,
then we wouldn't be able to do that.

144
00:07:58.120 --> 00:08:02.796
And therefore, that would affect
Your enjoyment of it certainly for

145
00:08:02.796 --> 00:08:06.472
those that are watching this live.
>> This goes back to your

146
00:08:06.472 --> 00:08:10.922
new assumptions also, because we can't
assume that we know everyone who is

147
00:08:10.922 --> 00:08:13.230
going to be affected by our decisions.

148
00:08:13.230 --> 00:08:18.451
So having those meetings and putting those
questions out there, like you're saying.

149
00:08:18.451 --> 00:08:22.475
Well, we didn't know that this department
relied on this particular process,

150
00:08:22.475 --> 00:08:25.199
or software, or whatever, so great point.
>> Well,

151
00:08:25.199 --> 00:08:30.650
think about who our stakeholders are in
terms of let's look at external right now.

152
00:08:30.650 --> 00:08:35.448
Right at this particular moment in time

385
00:20:54.140 --> 00:20:58.120
Think also about addressing any
concerns as well that they may have,

386
00:20:58.120 --> 00:21:01.680
which doesn't necessarily direct the
answer the question what's in it for me.

387
00:21:01.680 --> 00:21:03.850
But we want to allay concerns.

388
00:21:03.850 --> 00:21:07.760
Sometimes, especially
large scale projects,

389
00:21:07.760 --> 00:21:10.660
they may mean the restructuring
of your organization.

390
00:21:10.660 --> 00:21:15.285
And sometimes you may have stakeholders
that are feeling very vulnerable or

391
00:21:15.285 --> 00:21:19.810
they're in a position where they're just

392
00:21:19.810 --> 00:21:24.150
uncertain about the future or
uncertain about certain outcomes.

393
00:21:24.150 --> 00:21:28.610
Even if you can't answer the outcome
directly,or you can't answer their concern

394
00:21:28.610 --> 00:21:34.490
directly, you should at least acknowledge
that there is a concern there.

395
00:21:34.490 --> 00:21:39.010
You should at least acknowledge
that that concern exists, and

396
00:21:39.010 --> 00:21:42.120
that, yes, I understand you're
feeling vulnerable right now.

397
00:21:42.120 --> 00:21:45.260
I understand that this is
a period of uncertainty, but

398
00:21:45.260 --> 00:21:47.820
it will all become clear
in two weeks time.

399
00:21:47.820 --> 00:21:50.550
Or this is how we're
going to address that.

400
00:21:50.550 --> 00:21:55.770
Even if you can't answer an question
directly, you should at least address it.

401
00:21:56.810 --> 00:21:58.270
Because if you don't,

402
00:21:58.270 --> 00:22:02.100
we've spoken in previous episodes
about involvement of our team and

403
00:22:02.100 --> 00:22:06.030
involvement of our staff, and it's the
same with involvement of our stakeholder.

404
00:22:06.030 --> 00:22:09.620
We're not going to maintain
the buy-in of our stakeholder

405
00:22:09.620 --> 00:22:12.400
if we don't address their concerns, okay?

406
00:22:12.400 --> 00:22:16.490
And our last bullet point there,

407
00:22:16.490 --> 00:22:19.740
it mentions bringing in
non-core members to the team.

408
00:22:21.630 --> 00:22:25.190
Because we're in an Agile environment,
it means that we're having one iteration,

409
00:22:25.190 --> 00:22:28.270
and then another iteration,
and then another iteration.

410
00:22:28.270 --> 00:22:33.900
And we don't have specific
roles within the team.

411
00:22:33.900 --> 00:22:38.290
And so we have and we encourage a lot
more collaboration across the team.

412
00:22:38.290 --> 00:22:43.480
And every morning, we have our stand-up
and we look to each individual.

413
00:22:43.480 --> 00:22:47.480
And we ask what they're
specifically doing for the day.

414
00:22:47.480 --> 00:22:51.510
And it's at that point in time where we
might decide that other people have got

415
00:22:51.510 --> 00:22:52.950
more skills than you have.

416
00:22:52.950 --> 00:22:56.460
And therefore, they might be best
off doing that particular task.

417
00:22:56.460 --> 00:23:00.570
And it's at that point in time then
that we bring that person in to manage

418
00:23:00.570 --> 00:23:01.600
that task.

419
00:23:01.600 --> 00:23:05.080
So there are no defined roles,
which means that we are very,

420
00:23:05.080 --> 00:23:09.200
very open to bringing in subject matter
experts, to bringing in customers,

421
00:23:09.200 --> 00:23:12.990
or to bringing in other parties
to help with specific task.

422
00:23:14.380 --> 00:23:17.940
Again, if you're going to do that,
they are a stakeholder.

423
00:23:17.940 --> 00:23:22.530
And as such, you need to address that
concern, whatever their concerns may be.

424
00:23:22.530 --> 00:23:25.160
You have to tell them what's in it for
them.

425
00:23:25.160 --> 00:23:27.755
And some times,
it comes down to just simply money.

426
00:23:27.755 --> 00:23:30.610
[LAUGH] Yeah,
I'll pay you if you do that, right, but

427
00:23:30.610 --> 00:23:32.790
you have to address their concerns.

428
00:23:32.790 --> 00:23:36.360
So what we should do, and
this is really simple, and

429
00:23:36.360 --> 00:23:40.590
this concept is just really understand
who your stakeholders are, and

430
00:23:40.590 --> 00:23:44.706
what their interest is,
and what their power is.

431
00:23:44.706 --> 00:23:49.618
You see, Cherokee's highly
interested in what we're covering

432
00:23:49.618 --> 00:23:52.750
here right now and in the subject matter.

433
00:23:52.750 --> 00:23:57.070
But in terms of power, does she have
the power to stop production of this?

434
00:23:57.070 --> 00:24:00.151
No, absolutely not.
>> [LAUGH] So she's got high interest and

435
00:24:00.151 --> 00:24:03.347
low power, and
in which case the I'd keep her informed.

436
00:24:03.347 --> 00:24:04.012
>> Thanks.

437
00:24:04.012 --> 00:24:04.650
>> Right, yeah,

438
00:24:04.650 --> 00:24:06.719
I'm just gonna tell you what's going on,
okay?

439
00:24:06.719 --> 00:24:08.387
That's it.

440
00:24:08.387 --> 00:24:12.856
Now I'm gonna take my, on the other
hand Taylor who's our director,

441
00:24:12.856 --> 00:24:14.410
believe it or not.

442
00:24:14.410 --> 00:24:16.320
He's got high interest.

443
00:24:16.320 --> 00:24:19.404
Because he's the person's that's
watching this and he's the person,

444
00:24:19.404 --> 00:24:22.534
he could cut the cord literally.
>> Yeah, he could yell cut and

445
00:24:22.534 --> 00:24:23.753
we'd be done for.

446
00:24:23.753 --> 00:24:25.940
[LAUGH].
>> We've just been talking to ourselves at

447
00:24:25.940 --> 00:24:27.320
that point in time.

448
00:24:27.320 --> 00:24:29.870
He's got probably low interest
in the subject matter,

449
00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:32.410
now I'm making an assumption here,
all right.

450
00:24:32.410 --> 00:24:34.155
But he's got high power,

451
00:24:34.155 --> 00:24:38.130
in which case that I want to make
sure that we keep him happy.

452
00:24:38.130 --> 00:24:41.655
So we'll buy him a coffee every now and
then even if he doesn't want it.

453
00:24:41.655 --> 00:24:46.250
[LAUGH] We want to make sure that we
keep him happy, we keep him satisfied.

454
00:24:46.250 --> 00:24:47.350
So we do something.

455
00:24:47.350 --> 00:24:50.730
This is really simple but
this is what we call a stakeholder map.

456
00:24:50.730 --> 00:24:52.940
And it just really allows
you just to focus.

457
00:24:52.940 --> 00:24:57.930
We won't, what we wanna do is just take
this particular map and then just put x

458
00:24:57.930 --> 00:25:01.950
in for certain people, and just put
the main to certain places on that map.

459
00:25:01.950 --> 00:25:02.890
>> Bottom out.

460
00:25:02.890 --> 00:25:03.420
>> Yeah,

461
00:25:03.420 --> 00:25:07.940
it allows you just to identify at
a glance who's really important,

462
00:25:07.940 --> 00:25:11.090
who you've gotta manage closely,
and who you've just gotta monitor.

463
00:25:11.090 --> 00:25:14.290
Cuz even though stakeholders
that have low interest and

464
00:25:14.290 --> 00:25:19.500
have lower power can still have
a negative effect on your project.

465
00:25:19.500 --> 00:25:24.980
All it takes is one negative person
to undermine all of the positive

466
00:25:24.980 --> 00:25:28.450
outlook of 500 people of an entire team.
>> So

467
00:25:28.450 --> 00:25:31.090
true.
>> Yeah, all you need is one person.

468
00:25:31.090 --> 00:25:34.980
So, you need to ensure that even
those that have low interest and

469
00:25:34.980 --> 00:25:37.380
low power, you still got to monitor them.

470
00:25:37.380 --> 00:25:40.720
We still don't want any
sources of resistance

471
00:25:40.720 --> 00:25:42.250
cropping up in any of our projects.

472
00:25:44.280 --> 00:25:47.640
And sources of resistance are,
these are the people and

473
00:25:47.640 --> 00:25:53.380
these are the influencers, the negative
influencers that undermine the project.

474
00:25:53.380 --> 00:25:56.300
Now to get over any sources of resistance,

475
00:25:56.300 --> 00:26:00.600
we've got various techniques that
we'll look at in a little bit later.

476
00:26:00.600 --> 00:26:06.030
But one technique or rather one person
that we have that will help us is

477
00:26:06.030 --> 00:26:11.300
a sponsor, and a sponsor is an influencing
stakeholder, as in a figurehead.

478
00:26:11.300 --> 00:26:16.130
It's a business leader or senior manager,
and quite often just because

479
00:26:16.130 --> 00:26:20.850
senior management operation and just
because senior management are seen to be

480
00:26:20.850 --> 00:26:26.110
behind a certain project and
they are reinforcing that project.

481
00:26:26.110 --> 00:26:32.600
Then that will help to overcome some
negativity and some sources of resistance.

482
00:26:32.600 --> 00:26:35.280
Sponsors influence, that's what they do.

483
00:26:35.280 --> 00:26:39.330
The senior management that
influence other stakeholders, okay?

484
00:26:39.330 --> 00:26:43.000
So we want to ensure that we can
identify who our sponsors are.

485
00:26:44.260 --> 00:26:48.080
Ultimately we gotta make sure that
we can mange our stakeholders

486
00:26:48.080 --> 00:26:49.470
throughout the project.

487
00:26:49.470 --> 00:26:53.420
Not just as a one-off exercise, not just
something that we do at the start of

488
00:26:53.420 --> 00:26:57.240
a project, it's something that
we do throughout the project.

489
00:26:57.240 --> 00:27:01.780
So we ensure that we assess our
stakeholders, and it's in the middle

490
00:27:01.780 --> 00:27:06.590
on that particular diagram there,
that we engage with our stakeholders.

491
00:27:06.590 --> 00:27:10.350
And then we can understand, once we've
engaged with them, we understand their

492
00:27:10.350 --> 00:27:14.230
impact and their influence and
what it is they want to achieve.

493
00:27:14.230 --> 00:27:19.400
And of course we can influence that, so we
wanna make sure that we keep them engaged.

494
00:27:19.400 --> 00:27:22.762
And so
once we've identified our stakeholders,

495
00:27:22.762 --> 00:27:26.850
that particular circle just
keeps going around and around.

496
00:27:26.850 --> 00:27:30.382
You see,
if we manage to achieve one iteration and

497
00:27:30.382 --> 00:27:33.243
we can keep our stakeholders engaged and

498
00:27:33.243 --> 00:27:38.750
we keep our stakeholders satisfied and
happy we achieve that iteration.

499
00:27:38.750 --> 00:27:43.200
We deliver their output,
we deliver that deliverable,

500
00:27:43.200 --> 00:27:48.300
then they'll be happy and they'll be
motivated for the next iteration.

501
00:27:48.300 --> 00:27:52.169
But again, we've got to keep them engaged,
and we've got to deliver what they want on

502
00:27:52.169 --> 00:27:56.530
the next iteration because then that keeps
them motivated for the next iteration.

503
00:27:56.530 --> 00:28:00.920
So stakeholder management just doesn't
happen right at the start of the project.

504
00:28:00.920 --> 00:28:05.320
We've got to keep managing our
stakeholders cuz what we do not want

505
00:28:05.320 --> 00:28:09.190
is for any stakeholder to
become a source of resistance.

506
00:28:09.190 --> 00:28:12.650
Cuz the source of resistance will
prevent the success of a project.

507
00:28:14.480 --> 00:28:17.340
Also think about the fact that

508
00:28:17.340 --> 00:28:20.750
different stakeholders have
got different perceptions.

509
00:28:20.750 --> 00:28:24.940
And it goes back to that conversation
that we had about the con.

510
00:28:24.940 --> 00:28:30.190
If you 35 grand, I've gone and get one
car, you go and get something else.

511
00:28:30.190 --> 00:28:32.770
Different stakeholders not
show the title of our job and

512
00:28:32.770 --> 00:28:35.510
go away with something
completely different.

513
00:28:35.510 --> 00:28:38.570
But different stakeholders have
different requirements and

514
00:28:38.570 --> 00:28:41.540
sometimes those requirements conflict.

515
00:28:43.470 --> 00:28:47.390
Then we got to manage it very very
carefully because still got to

516
00:28:47.390 --> 00:28:48.740
deliver a value.

517
00:28:48.740 --> 00:28:54.257
We still got to deliver an output
that the stakeholders want and

518
00:28:54.257 --> 00:28:56.350
that they see value in.

519
00:28:56.350 --> 00:29:01.225
Bearing in mind that we might have
two different perceptionw or 3 or

520
00:29:01.225 --> 00:29:03.800
5 or 20 different perceptions.

521
00:29:03.800 --> 00:29:08.020
And therefore,
20 different preferences, too.

522
00:29:10.300 --> 00:29:14.040
And yet what we've been tasked to do is
deliver a one size fits all solution.

523
00:29:15.150 --> 00:29:18.590
So we've got to make sure that
we manage our stakeholders and

524
00:29:18.590 --> 00:29:22.260
that we understand,
sometimes these requirements conflict.

525
00:29:23.270 --> 00:29:26.530
And so we have to ensure that
we've got our sponsors on

526
00:29:26.530 --> 00:29:29.330
board because sometimes there
are gonna be some decisions

527
00:29:29.330 --> 00:29:34.110
that need to be made that aren't going
to keep every single stakeholder happy.

528
00:29:34.110 --> 00:29:37.760
But then you know what,
there's a word that's really important and

529
00:29:37.760 --> 00:29:39.250
that's the word compromise, and

530
00:29:39.250 --> 00:29:43.130
sometimes we've gotta reach
a compromise between our stakeholders.

531
00:29:43.130 --> 00:29:48.210
You see, each individual stake holder is
always interested in what's in it for me.

532
00:29:48.210 --> 00:29:51.820
They're always interested
in how it affects me.

533
00:29:51.820 --> 00:29:56.420
It's about personal benefit,
personal gain or personal impact.

534
00:29:56.420 --> 00:29:58.930
They don't necessarily
understand the whole and

535
00:29:58.930 --> 00:30:04.140
the whole project, more importantly than
that they don't care for the most part.

536
00:30:04.140 --> 00:30:09.180
Let's face it, we're all interested
in how certain factors influence us.

537
00:30:09.180 --> 00:30:10.950
So, our sponsors are going to help us.

538
00:30:10.950 --> 00:30:12.620
These are our managers.

539
00:30:12.620 --> 00:30:16.670
Guiding sponsors are figureheads
that are help, will help to

540
00:30:16.670 --> 00:30:22.280
reinforce the message of what's in it for
them and also help to see benefits.

541
00:30:22.280 --> 00:30:27.860
Now, I've already said we
need to think about, well,

542
00:30:27.860 --> 00:30:31.220
the issues and
the concerns that stakeholders have.

543
00:30:31.220 --> 00:30:35.300
If you don't address those concerns
you're gonna get negative feeling

544
00:30:35.300 --> 00:30:40.680
in our stakeholders, and you're going
to get conflicts between stakeholders.

545
00:30:40.680 --> 00:30:46.145
I don't want to feel Taylor's in a driving
seat right now, he's a director for

546
00:30:46.145 --> 00:30:51.121
our episode, and I don't want to feel
that Taylor is going to take notice

547
00:30:51.121 --> 00:30:56.122
of Cherokee more than he takes notice
of me, cuz that wouldn't be fair.

548
00:30:56.122 --> 00:31:01.080
But then Cherokee doesn't want to feel
as though Taylor's gonna take more

549
00:31:01.080 --> 00:31:03.053
notice of her than he is of me.

550
00:31:03.053 --> 00:31:10.022
So, we've both got conflicting priorities
as far as we're concerned, right?

551
00:31:10.022 --> 00:31:12.755
Each one of us thinks that we're
more important than the other one.

552
00:31:12.755 --> 00:31:16.267
[LAUGH] It's true, right?
>> Sure.

553
00:31:16.267 --> 00:31:16.790
>> Yeah,

554
00:31:16.790 --> 00:31:19.585
describe me too, just go on, I know.

555
00:31:19.585 --> 00:31:22.511
No, Cherokee's just thinking about
the margarita at the end of [CROSSTALK]

556
00:31:22.511 --> 00:31:23.022
>> That's right.

557
00:31:23.022 --> 00:31:24.831
>> [LAUGH]

558
00:31:24.831 --> 00:31:26.836
>> But you see, we all have different,

559
00:31:26.836 --> 00:31:30.800
we all believe, and we all perceive
that we have different priorities.

560
00:31:30.800 --> 00:31:35.380
But there's only one person that
can actually identify what those

561
00:31:35.380 --> 00:31:40.370
priorities are, and whose priority is,
well, the priority.

562
00:31:40.370 --> 00:31:42.530
And from a product perspective,

563
00:31:42.530 --> 00:31:46.670
from a functionality perspective,
that would be the product owner.

564
00:31:46.670 --> 00:31:51.783
But from a team perspective, and
understanding stakeholders and

565
00:31:51.783 --> 00:31:54.704
understanding the team priorities,

566
00:31:54.704 --> 00:31:59.882
then that would be the scrum master
that would make that decision.

567
00:31:59.882 --> 00:32:03.890
Ultimately, we've got to be able
to identify our stakeholders.

568
00:32:03.890 --> 00:32:06.620
We can't manage them until
we can identify them.

569
00:32:06.620 --> 00:32:11.163
So that's got to be the first step
that we undertake with any project in

570
00:32:11.163 --> 00:32:16.460
a waterfall approach, we still gotta
be able to identify our stakeholders.

571
00:32:16.460 --> 00:32:20.816
So after we've defined our vision and our
scope, and we've understood the problem

572
00:32:20.816 --> 00:32:25.190
statement then we then have to launch into
understanding who our stakeholders are.

573
00:32:25.190 --> 00:32:29.000
And who's going to influence and
be impacted by our project.

574
00:32:30.360 --> 00:32:33.200
And then in our next episode
we're going to move into,

575
00:32:33.200 --> 00:32:38.110
we're going to explore iterations and
what they actually mean for

576
00:32:38.110 --> 00:32:43.040
our agile project and how we move
through our agile project life cycle.

577
00:32:43.040 --> 00:32:43.606
>> All right Jo,

578
00:32:43.606 --> 00:32:46.769
is there anything that you'd like to,
any kind of final thoughts, or anything

579
00:32:46.769 --> 00:32:48.642
you'd like to share before we close out?
>> No,

580
00:32:48.642 --> 00:32:52.112
in our next episode we're gonna be looking
at a specific group of stakeholders,

581
00:32:52.112 --> 00:32:53.506
we're gonna be looking users.

582
00:32:53.506 --> 00:32:57.440
But, for now,
we'll leave that just right where it is.

583
00:32:57.440 --> 00:32:57.990
>> Perfect,

584
00:32:57.990 --> 00:32:59.870
well you don't wanna miss the next show.

585
00:32:59.870 --> 00:33:02.710
But for now let's sign out,
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose,

586
00:33:02.710 --> 00:33:03.560
>> And I'm Jo Pickoff.

587
00:33:03.560 --> 00:33:06.303
>> See you next time here, at ITPro TV.

588
00:33:06.303 --> 00:33:12.241
[MUSIC]

589
00:33:12.241 --> 00:33:15.567
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Users are a specific type of stakeholder and therefore have specific needs. We need to ensure that these needs are captured and that users are involved in our Agile project.
episodes.title: Identifying Stakeholders Part 2 - Users
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.092 --> 00:00:02.611
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.611 --> 00:00:06.025
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.025 --> 00:00:08.312
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.312 --> 00:00:12.904
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> Welcome to your

5
00:00:12.904 --> 00:00:15.840
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

6
00:00:15.840 --> 00:00:17.980
I'm you show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.980 --> 00:00:21.656
This is actually a part two,
a continuation, where we're looking at

8
00:00:21.656 --> 00:00:26.454
our stakeholders, but specifically, we'll
be identifying, well, who the users are,

9
00:00:26.454 --> 00:00:30.281
and with us today, back in studios,
we have the lovely Ms. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:30.281 --> 00:00:33.516
Thank yo for joining us, Jo, how are you?
>> I am great, thank you Cherokee,

11
00:00:33.516 --> 00:00:36.752
how are you?
>> I'm doing really good, and

12
00:00:36.752 --> 00:00:41.075
I feel like you have a question for me.
>> How did you know

13
00:00:41.075 --> 00:00:42.140
that?
>> Well.

14
00:00:42.140 --> 00:00:43.322
>> That's called telepathy.

15
00:00:43.322 --> 00:00:45.308
>> [LAUGH] Well.

16
00:00:45.308 --> 00:00:46.602
>> That's frightening actually.

17
00:00:46.602 --> 00:00:48.511
>> I wish I could take credit for that,

18
00:00:48.511 --> 00:00:52.900
and pretend that I did have that skill,
but you told me you had a question for me.

19
00:00:52.900 --> 00:00:53.450
>> Yeah, I know,

20
00:00:53.450 --> 00:00:54.450
I did give her a head's up.

21
00:00:54.450 --> 00:00:58.030
I just said, I'm gonna put you on
the spot, is exactly what I said.

22
00:00:58.030 --> 00:01:00.080
So I'm gonna put her
on the spot right now.

>> Yeah.

>> Yeah?
>> Yeah.

00:06:04.266 --> 00:06:05.434

00:06:05.434 --> 00:06:08.388
well let's think about,
let's go back into IT and

let's think about sort of

00:06:11.850 --> 00:06:16.555
If I update, the idea of a relational
database is that, if I have a core

database, let's say I have,
let's take a look at this.

00:06:22.470 --> 00:06:24.620
I'm thinking about this

But let's say I have a call login tool,

00:06:48.240 --> 00:06:50.447

00:06:50.447 --> 00:06:51.799

there's a relationship in place.

00:06:53.610 --> 00:06:56.330
So when something updates

00:06:56.330 --> 00:06:59.620
it should automatically update

00:06:59.620 --> 00:07:04.119
As far as that user is concerned and the

151
00:07:11.184 --> 00:07:12.081
>> Right, so

a user is not necessarily a physical

it could be another tool,

One process can use the output

155
00:07:28.941 --> 00:07:30.601

00:07:30.601 --> 00:07:31.506
>> Yeah, so

00:07:31.506 --> 00:07:35.510
now we've explored who could be a user.

00:07:35.510 --> 00:07:40.496
Let's think about what a user wants, and
in terms of a project, [LAUGH] well,

00:07:40.496 --> 00:07:44.732
we've already looked at stakeholders

160
00:07:44.732 --> 00:07:47.053
In part one, we looked at stakeholders and

161
00:07:47.053 --> 00:07:51.185
we identified the fact that different
stakeholders have different needs.

162
00:07:51.185 --> 00:07:55.860
And ordinarily, what we will do with
stakeholders is we will group them.

163
00:07:55.860 --> 00:07:58.190
And so,
we'll divide our stakeholders into groups.

164
00:07:58.190 --> 00:08:02.020
So we have our management, and
then maybe our sponsors for instance.

165
00:08:02.020 --> 00:08:06.180
We might have our external customers,
and then maybe one stakeholder group.

166
00:08:06.180 --> 00:08:10.636
And we also looked at mapping our
stakeholders in terms of their importance

167
00:08:10.636 --> 00:08:14.100
or their power, and the influence
that they can have on the project.

168
00:08:15.530 --> 00:08:19.040
Users are quite often just sort
of lumped into one group really,

169
00:08:19.040 --> 00:08:20.410
that's our user group.

170
00:08:22.010 --> 00:08:24.095
Problem is that we got
different user types.

171
00:08:25.370 --> 00:08:27.780
And in that example that
I've just given you,

172
00:08:27.780 --> 00:08:31.720
when we talk about relational databases,
we've got different user types.

173
00:08:31.720 --> 00:08:37.340
If you think about that HR database, what

174
00:08:37.340 --> 00:08:40.920
You've got HR personnel themselves,
and they're sitting there,

175
00:08:40.920 --> 00:08:42.910
they're inputting data.

176
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:46.833
You might also have another

177
00:08:46.833 --> 00:08:51.121
which might be something like
maybe a taxation system or

178
00:08:51.121 --> 00:08:55.611
the IRS or a financial system

179
00:08:55.611 --> 00:08:58.682
As well as within IT our
core login system and

maybe our configuration management
system may also use the HR database.

181
00:09:04.670 --> 00:09:11.627
So people, those HR personnel,
are only actually one user type and

182
00:09:11.627 --> 00:09:17.618
every single user type, Indeed,
even go down to the individual level,

183
00:09:17.618 --> 00:09:21.410
every single user will have
different wants and needs.

184
00:09:21.410 --> 00:09:25.723
In a previous episode, I made some comment
about understanding your users and

185
00:09:25.723 --> 00:09:29.005
your stakeholders and
then asking you who was colorblind.

186
00:09:29.005 --> 00:09:30.890
>> Mm-hm.

187
00:09:30.890 --> 00:09:32.230
>> We have to understand that they

00:09:32.230 --> 00:09:34.520
are stakeholders and we have to understand

00:09:34.520 --> 00:09:39.900
the nuances like that because everybody
has a different want and a different need.

190
00:09:39.900 --> 00:09:42.250
How many times have you
turned around to somebody and

00:09:42.250 --> 00:09:45.085
said, a want is not the same as a need?

192
00:09:45.085 --> 00:09:49.070
[LAUGH] Quite often,
especially to my children.

193
00:09:49.070 --> 00:09:49.650
>> Right, [LAUGH] and

194
00:09:49.650 --> 00:09:55.220
I could tell you now, when Apple
released this wearable technology,

195
00:09:55.220 --> 00:09:59.970
boy, did I have a watch shaped hole
in my life at that point in time.

196
00:09:59.970 --> 00:10:01.250
I needed it.

197
00:10:02.330 --> 00:10:03.720
No I didn't, I wanted it.

198
00:10:04.910 --> 00:10:09.470
But I wonder when we think about projects,
and this will help

199
00:10:09.470 --> 00:10:13.280
us prioritize our project, by the way,
and prioritize our users' stories.

200
00:10:13.280 --> 00:10:19.620
But when we think about projects, how many
of our user needs are actually just wants?

201
00:10:21.450 --> 00:10:26.955
But the simple fact is that they want
a certain, they want a certain service.

202
00:10:26.955 --> 00:10:30.460
Or they want a certain functionality

203
00:10:30.460 --> 00:10:34.890
because they believe it's going to have
a positive impact on the organization.

204
00:10:34.890 --> 00:10:38.190
And they believe that it's gonna have
positive impact on say, sales for

205
00:10:38.190 --> 00:10:43.730
instance or maybe on our ability to get
to market quicker than anybody else.

206
00:10:43.730 --> 00:10:46.840
So we can't just dismiss wants.

207
00:10:46.840 --> 00:10:51.970
Because essentially, even though we tend
to disguise a lot of our wants as needs,

208
00:10:51.970 --> 00:10:56.960
but essentially those wants,
we want them for a reason.

209
00:10:56.960 --> 00:11:00.670
And it's not just a case of I want
them just to show off, right?

210
00:11:00.670 --> 00:11:05.260
It's a case of I want them because
there's a practical reason behind it.

211
00:11:05.260 --> 00:11:08.660
And quite often,
we can influence those ones by the way.

212
00:11:08.660 --> 00:11:11.675
I think of Apple being a perfect example,

213
00:11:11.675 --> 00:11:15.560
Apple are very proactive
in their product delivery.

214
00:11:15.560 --> 00:11:19.160
They don't wait for us to come to
them as users, and customers, and

215
00:11:19.160 --> 00:11:21.350

216
00:11:21.350 --> 00:11:25.730
They're very proactive in this, and
so, they actually create a need.

217
00:11:25.730 --> 00:11:27.740
They don't even identify needs.

218
00:11:27.740 --> 00:11:29.886
They actually create that need.

219
00:11:29.886 --> 00:11:33.234
And when they launch a new product, and
they launch it with such a fanfare, and

220
00:11:33.234 --> 00:11:35.952
then they show you all these features,
and you have to have it.

221
00:11:35.952 --> 00:11:37.338
>> I didn't even know I needed it.

222
00:11:37.338 --> 00:11:38.879
>> Right, exactly.

223
00:11:38.879 --> 00:11:39.483
>> [LAUGH]

224
00:11:39.483 --> 00:11:41.540
>> I didn't know I needed a watch, but

225
00:11:41.540 --> 00:11:42.860
I needed one.
>> [LAUGH]

226
00:11:42.860 --> 00:11:44.160
>> I absolutely needed it.

227
00:11:44.160 --> 00:11:48.455
I had this huge watch shaped hole
in my life, and then I got it.

228
00:11:48.455 --> 00:11:49.410
>> [LAUGH]

229
00:11:49.410 --> 00:11:50.770
>> We call this an inflated peak

230
00:11:50.770 --> 00:11:52.460
of expectation by the way.

231
00:11:52.460 --> 00:11:55.040
I built this thing up in my head,
and then I got it, and

232
00:11:55.040 --> 00:11:57.390
realized that I'm getting
on a bit in years,

233
00:11:57.390 --> 00:12:00.980
and I need to put my glasses on in
order to be able to see anything on it.

234
00:12:00.980 --> 00:12:05.770
So actually, that need [LAUGH],
we call that the trough of disillusion.

235
00:12:05.770 --> 00:12:09.550
And that realization
that maybe I didn't quite

236
00:12:09.550 --> 00:12:10.949
need it in the way that I thought I did.

237
00:12:12.630 --> 00:12:17.250
Project management have a responsibility
in that, and we talk about the inflated

238
00:12:17.250 --> 00:12:19.870
peak of expectations, and
the trough of disillusionment.

239
00:12:19.870 --> 00:12:24.020
And project management have a huge
part to play in ensuring that

240
00:12:24.020 --> 00:12:28.350
this inflated peak of expectation
isn't actually an inflated peak,

241
00:12:28.350 --> 00:12:31.290
and that we set expectations accordingly.

242
00:12:31.290 --> 00:12:35.790
And we looked at setting stakeholder
expectations in our previous episode.

243
00:12:35.790 --> 00:12:40.547
And we also, I talked about
the fact of underpromising, and

244
00:12:40.547 --> 00:12:44.350
overdelivering, when it comes
to managing expectations.

245
00:12:44.350 --> 00:12:47.240
That's exactly what we should be
doing to prevent then that trough

246
00:12:47.240 --> 00:12:50.390
of disillusionment when we
finally deploy something.

247
00:12:51.390 --> 00:12:52.320
So what we should do is,

248
00:12:52.320 --> 00:12:57.495
we use something called user
stories to capture wants and needs.

249
00:12:57.495 --> 00:12:59.690
And we look at that in
a different episode,

250
00:12:59.690 --> 00:13:01.860
we're gonna be looking
at defining stories.

251
00:13:01.860 --> 00:13:03.900
But a story is a want,

252
00:13:03.900 --> 00:13:09.570
a story is something that we need to
deliver as part of that iteration.

253
00:13:09.570 --> 00:13:14.930
And we have many stories, perhaps,
potentially in in an iteration,

254
00:13:14.930 --> 00:13:18.410
but it's something that we have to
deliver as part of that iteration.

255
00:13:18.410 --> 00:13:23.140
And so we have to ensure that we
prioritize user wants and needs.

256
00:13:24.420 --> 00:13:27.710
And we also talk about reconciling
user wants and needs as well,

257
00:13:27.710 --> 00:13:33.640
because it's down to the project team
to make a decision on priorities too.

258
00:13:33.640 --> 00:13:35.170
Because I might want something,

259
00:13:35.170 --> 00:13:37.260
and Cherokee might want something,
and ultimately,

260
00:13:37.260 --> 00:13:40.540
somebody's got to make the decision
as to what we're gonna deliver first.

261
00:13:41.760 --> 00:13:46.010
And we've already talked about using
various fun ways of doing that.

262
00:13:46.010 --> 00:13:47.883
And rock, paper, scissors perhaps,

263
00:13:47.883 --> 00:13:51.250
I think that was the one we talked
about in a previous episode.

264
00:13:51.250 --> 00:13:53.880
But it's a fun way of prioritizing.

265
00:13:53.880 --> 00:13:57.150
And maybe what I want is only gonna take
take one day's worth of programming, but

266
00:13:57.150 --> 00:14:01.230
maybe what Cherokee wants is gonna take
seven days worth of programming, so I win.

267
00:14:01.230 --> 00:14:04.790
[LAUGH]
Just remember that all

268
00:14:04.790 --> 00:14:08.340
users are stakeholders, but
not all stakeholders are users, and

269
00:14:08.340 --> 00:14:09.930
it's the same with customers.

270
00:14:09.930 --> 00:14:15.520
Our customers, well, they buy, but
they're not necessarily a user.

271
00:14:15.520 --> 00:14:18.970
So we start off by performing
a stakeholder assessment, and

272
00:14:18.970 --> 00:14:23.030
working out which one of
our stakeholders are users.

273
00:14:23.030 --> 00:14:27.850
So think about things like, whose gonna
use that solution that you are developing,

274
00:14:27.850 --> 00:14:32.700
what are they going to use it for, and
also, how are they going to use it.

275
00:14:32.700 --> 00:14:39.600
That will help you to define your user
needs, and also, your training as well.

276
00:14:39.600 --> 00:14:43.120
You have to work out who's
going to use the service, and

277
00:14:43.120 --> 00:14:44.920
exactly how they're going to do it.

278
00:14:44.920 --> 00:14:48.270
To be able to deliver a service that
only not only meet their needs, but

279
00:14:48.270 --> 00:14:50.580
works in a way that they want to work.

280
00:14:51.770 --> 00:14:58.160
It's no good, we talked in a previous
episode about a financial institution, and

281
00:14:58.160 --> 00:15:03.530
the fact that, I've been in to a financial
institution where they have a huge

282
00:15:03.530 --> 00:15:09.530
dilemma, in that they need to well, they
need to bring in new technology, and they

283
00:15:09.530 --> 00:15:14.970
need to bring in sort of new innovative
ways of interacting with customers.

284
00:15:14.970 --> 00:15:19.490
However, their customer demographic
is over sort of 60 years of age.

285
00:15:19.490 --> 00:15:20.944
So how do we do that?

286
00:15:20.944 --> 00:15:26.640
And it's absolutely no good bringing
in something like maybe tap to pay for

287
00:15:26.640 --> 00:15:29.710
instance, when your customers don't have

288
00:15:29.710 --> 00:15:31.310
a cell phone.
>> Right.

289
00:15:31.310 --> 00:15:33.000
>> If they don't have a mobile phone,

290
00:15:33.000 --> 00:15:36.320
then bringing in tap to pay
is not going to work anyway.

291
00:15:36.320 --> 00:15:41.040
So is that something that you need
to be investing in right now?

292
00:15:41.040 --> 00:15:45.210
See, so who your users are really
does influence your project.

293
00:15:45.210 --> 00:15:46.890
And it should influence your project.

294
00:15:48.070 --> 00:15:52.867
But so many organizations when they're
going down the project management route,

295
00:15:52.867 --> 00:15:53.833
when they're.

296
00:15:53.833 --> 00:15:56.466
Coming up with new ideas for new services,

297
00:15:56.466 --> 00:16:00.280
forget about their users and
they forget who their users are.

298
00:16:00.280 --> 00:16:02.839
And they bring out this
wonderful new concept and

299
00:16:02.839 --> 00:16:06.024
this wonderful new functionality and
then they deploy it and

300
00:16:06.024 --> 00:16:10.082
wonder why it's never used, because
they've not thought about their users

301
00:16:10.082 --> 00:16:13.280
they've not thought about the way
their users want to work.

302
00:16:15.340 --> 00:16:18.590
So we like things to be
efficient in Agile, and

303
00:16:18.590 --> 00:16:20.930
we like to keep things simple as well.

304
00:16:22.110 --> 00:16:26.310
We like to keep things visible too, and
we like the use of some story boards,

305
00:16:26.310 --> 00:16:29.080
we like the use of Kanban boards, as well,

306
00:16:29.080 --> 00:16:32.800
to see exactly how much progress
we've made in an iteration.

307
00:16:32.800 --> 00:16:35.350
We also like the use
of sort of user cards.

308
00:16:35.350 --> 00:16:38.210
Now these can be virtual.

309
00:16:38.210 --> 00:16:42.590
They can be, we can have them in
a shared directory, if we want to.

310
00:16:42.590 --> 00:16:47.080
However, they don't have
the same impact as when a card,

311
00:16:47.080 --> 00:16:49.420
written out, and stuck on a board.

312
00:16:49.420 --> 00:16:54.692
And in the same way that we want to make,
we wanna have everybody

313
00:16:54.692 --> 00:16:59.060
in the same team and in the same area and

314
00:16:59.060 --> 00:17:03.850
physically located together, whether that
be sort of using virtual meetings, or

315
00:17:03.850 --> 00:17:07.220
whether that be by actually
physically having people together.

316
00:17:07.220 --> 00:17:12.580
These storyboards and these boards with
the user cards need to be visible.

317
00:17:12.580 --> 00:17:18.230
Everybody should be able to see at
a glance, that's the most efficient.

318
00:17:18.230 --> 00:17:23.077
So we'll use user cards, and
really the user card is just about

319
00:17:23.077 --> 00:17:28.200
thinking of every single or
identifying every single user type and

320
00:17:28.200 --> 00:17:32.900
then summarizing them in terms
of their key activities.

321
00:17:32.900 --> 00:17:36.440
In terms of their desires,
their wants, their ways of working,

322
00:17:36.440 --> 00:17:40.860
their incentives and also the pressures
that they're under as well.

323
00:17:42.200 --> 00:17:44.730
And user cards just highlight
sort of the strengths or

324
00:17:44.730 --> 00:17:47.430
weaknesses as well in terms of skills.

325
00:17:47.430 --> 00:17:49.180
What do our users know?

326
00:17:49.180 --> 00:17:50.420
What don't they know?

327
00:17:50.420 --> 00:17:52.480
What training will they need?

328
00:17:52.480 --> 00:17:54.650
And also what level of support they need?

329
00:17:54.650 --> 00:17:58.260
And that might also include what level
of support they're currently used to?

330
00:17:59.530 --> 00:18:05.230
If you're moving somebody from
a face-to-face user support and

331
00:18:05.230 --> 00:18:09.190
as part of the project, you're moving
them to an online user support,

332
00:18:09.190 --> 00:18:13.850
where they've got chat capability, it's
gonna need more than just training for

333
00:18:13.850 --> 00:18:19.070
your users in order to get to that point,
where they're using the chat.

334
00:18:19.070 --> 00:18:22.830
You're gonna have to have a transitional
period, cuz users are gonna have to get

335
00:18:22.830 --> 00:18:27.920
used to that and they're going to
have to transition to using chat.

336
00:18:27.920 --> 00:18:32.440
We first of all gonna demonstrate success,
and demonstrate that chat works, before we

337
00:18:32.440 --> 00:18:38.080
can then start dropping off support
over the telephone or face-to-face.

338
00:18:38.080 --> 00:18:42.267
So these user cards don't cover
the specific wants and needs,

339
00:18:42.267 --> 00:18:47.718
we document those in the user story, but
the user cards just document a user type,

340
00:18:47.718 --> 00:18:52.221
and they look at the strengths and
weaknesses of that user type, and

341
00:18:52.221 --> 00:18:56.102
they look the way of working
of that particular user type.

342
00:18:57.984 --> 00:19:03.058
Agile is built on collaboration
between both the development team and

343
00:19:03.058 --> 00:19:07.358
the business, so
we can look back at our Agile principles,

344
00:19:07.358 --> 00:19:11.920
back at our first or
second episode in this particular series.

345
00:19:13.560 --> 00:19:17.130
User cards,
they'll supplement collaboration, but

346
00:19:17.130 --> 00:19:23.420
you should always have an open-ended
communication with your user group.

347
00:19:23.420 --> 00:19:28.500
I should always be able to,
as a developer, talk to Cherokee about

348
00:19:28.500 --> 00:19:33.480
the way that she works and about
the product that I'm developing for her.

349
00:19:33.480 --> 00:19:38.600
I should always be able to elicit her
feedback and asked for her ideas as well.

350
00:19:39.655 --> 00:19:43.420
Collaboration is key,
its one of our values in Agile,

351
00:19:43.420 --> 00:19:48.730
and its something that we have to
uphold with every single iteration.

352
00:19:48.730 --> 00:19:53.070
Now that said, we could avoid
this sort of open door policy,

353
00:19:53.070 --> 00:19:58.060
because I dont want Cherokee interrupting
me every single minute of the day.

354
00:19:58.060 --> 00:20:00.980
Now, I'm not saying that we
should close the door and

355
00:20:00.980 --> 00:20:05.220
make sure that nobody can talk to us,
but we have to ensure that

356
00:20:05.220 --> 00:20:10.092
the collaboration is structured.
>> So like providing specific times for

357
00:20:10.092 --> 00:20:13.405
me to stop by and chat with you?
>> Right, and it's also,

358
00:20:13.405 --> 00:20:16.570
it's making sure that I'm productive.
>> Right.

359
00:20:16.570 --> 00:20:19.670
>> So, its really basic time management,

360
00:20:19.670 --> 00:20:21.580
and nothing more than that.

361
00:20:21.580 --> 00:20:26.000
Its about understanding that maybe my
productive time of the day is between

362
00:20:26.000 --> 00:20:31.090
the hours of, say, 8am and 11am,
thats when Im most productive.

363
00:20:31.090 --> 00:20:35.357
So what Im probably going to do, is Im
going to spend between 8 and 8:15 or

364
00:20:35.357 --> 00:20:38.150
8:30 talking to you, And

365
00:20:38.150 --> 00:20:42.120
then I'm gonna spend the rest of
the day working on development work.

366
00:20:42.120 --> 00:20:45.330
And I don't wanna talk to you for
those two and a half hours, or

367
00:20:45.330 --> 00:20:47.670
those three and a half hours,
I just really don't wanna talk to you.

368
00:20:48.680 --> 00:20:51.774
And then in the afternoon,
I'm not quite as productive, and

369
00:20:51.774 --> 00:20:55.236
then I might catch up with you again
mid-way through the afternoon.

370
00:20:55.236 --> 00:20:59.763
But I wanna ensure that I
use my productive time to,

371
00:20:59.763 --> 00:21:02.614
well, to deliver my best work.

372
00:21:02.614 --> 00:21:03.890
>> Right.
>> For you.

373
00:21:03.890 --> 00:21:07.890
I'm not gonna deliver my best work if
you're going to interrupt me during

374
00:21:07.890 --> 00:21:09.260
my productive time.

375
00:21:09.260 --> 00:21:14.300
So I wanna make sure
that I adhere to my own

376
00:21:14.300 --> 00:21:18.370
policy of making my productive time,
productive.

377
00:21:18.370 --> 00:21:22.390
So, we should filter access
through the product owner

378
00:21:22.390 --> 00:21:24.790
if it's appropriate to do so.

379
00:21:24.790 --> 00:21:29.320
We should make sure that, as developers,
that we're not distracted.

380
00:21:29.320 --> 00:21:32.970
And that means that we're not
distracted by people walking around.

381
00:21:32.970 --> 00:21:37.500
If we are going to be productive,
we've gotta be aware of when our

382
00:21:37.500 --> 00:21:41.950
productive time is, and then we've
also gotta keep our conversations and

383
00:21:41.950 --> 00:21:46.550
keep our general interaction to
certain times during the day,

384
00:21:46.550 --> 00:21:49.210
that's how we become efficient and
effective.

385
00:21:50.430 --> 00:21:54.080
And the other thing that we should also
do, and you know what, it should be common

386
00:21:54.080 --> 00:22:00.470
sense, but you should update people
on a regular basis on your progress.

387
00:22:00.470 --> 00:22:04.670
Bear in mind that each iteration is
between one and four weeks in length.

388
00:22:04.670 --> 00:22:08.330
So you should update people on
a regular basis as to your progress,

389
00:22:08.330 --> 00:22:12.740
because I will guarantee,
if I only update Cherokee once a week,

390
00:22:12.740 --> 00:22:15.920
on my progress, she's gonna come,
and she's gonna stop by, and

391
00:22:15.920 --> 00:22:19.292
she's gonna interrupt me, because she's
gonna want to know how things are going.

392
00:22:19.292 --> 00:22:26.260
So you only want interruption
at certain times during the day,

393
00:22:26.260 --> 00:22:30.120
but you also want to be more proactive
to try and prevent those interruptions.

394
00:22:30.120 --> 00:22:32.860
So I've got a good
relationship with Cherokee, so

395
00:22:32.860 --> 00:22:34.630
I am going to update Cherokee.

396
00:22:34.630 --> 00:22:35.920
I know what she wants.

397
00:22:35.920 --> 00:22:38.900
So I'm going to update her with
that on a daily basis maybe or

398
00:22:38.900 --> 00:22:43.295
maybe every other day, and then that
stops her coming and pestering me.

399
00:22:43.295 --> 00:22:45.460
>> [LAUGH]

400
00:22:45.460 --> 00:22:46.610
>> Not that that's a hint or

401
00:22:46.610 --> 00:22:48.820
anything like that, all right?
>> [LAUGH]

402
00:22:48.820 --> 00:22:50.335
>> I'm just soaking it all in Jo.

403
00:22:50.335 --> 00:22:52.840
>> [LAUGH] Yeah I know she's making notes

404
00:22:52.840 --> 00:22:53.460
for later.

405
00:22:54.730 --> 00:22:57.812
Ultimately we don't
wanna exclude our users.

406
00:22:57.812 --> 00:22:59.680
[LAUGH] Maybe we do.

407
00:22:59.680 --> 00:23:01.375
Some of them we probably did.

408
00:23:01.375 --> 00:23:03.810
[LAUGH] We don't wanna exclude our users.

409
00:23:03.810 --> 00:23:06.690
We wanna make sure that they feel as
though they're part of the team and

410
00:23:06.690 --> 00:23:10.740
they understand that what we're delivering
is something for them, and that

411
00:23:10.740 --> 00:23:15.050
they find valuable, but at the same time,
we've gotta make sure that as a team, and

412
00:23:15.050 --> 00:23:20.230
as an Agile team, that we are productive
throughout each iteration.

413
00:23:21.400 --> 00:23:24.690
And so that's it as far as
the stakeholders are concerned.

414
00:23:24.690 --> 00:23:27.790
But if you have any questions
with regards to stakeholders or

415
00:23:27.790 --> 00:23:30.270
stakeholder management, then.
>> Don't ask Jo.

416
00:23:30.270 --> 00:23:31.050
>> Yeah, don't ask me.

417
00:23:31.050 --> 00:23:32.385
>> You can wait a day and

418
00:23:32.385 --> 00:23:35.210
then ask her [LAUGH].
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

419
00:23:35.210 --> 00:23:37.790
only ask me at certain times of the day.

420
00:23:37.790 --> 00:23:42.740
So just send us a message if you have any
questions at certain times of the day and

421
00:23:42.740 --> 00:23:45.620
that's when I'll reply to you.
>> No, but in all seriousness,

422
00:23:45.620 --> 00:23:49.770
if you do have questions,
you can always email Cherokee@ITProTV for

423
00:23:49.770 --> 00:23:52.580
those questions, and
I will be the one to harass and

424
00:23:52.580 --> 00:23:53.500
track down Jo.
>> [LAUGH]

425
00:23:53.500 --> 00:23:55.660
>> And give you those answers.

426
00:23:55.660 --> 00:23:57.710
But I think that's about it for
this episode, right,

427
00:23:57.710 --> 00:23:58.360
Jo?
>> It is,

428
00:23:58.360 --> 00:23:59.222
yes.
>> Okay cool,

429
00:23:59.222 --> 00:24:01.140
well then let's go ahead and sign out.

430
00:24:01.140 --> 00:24:03.890
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

431
00:24:03.890 --> 00:24:06.647
>> See you next time, here at ITPro.TV.

432
00:24:06.647 --> 00:24:12.615
[MUSIC]

433
00:24:12.615 --> 00:24:15.791
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: Unlike traditional waterfall projects the Agile project team is not fixed and there are specific considerations when building an Agile project management team. In this episode we explore the formation of the project team.
episodes.title: Building an Agile Team
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.070 --> 00:00:02.901
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.901 --> 00:00:06.816
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.816 --> 00:00:08.451
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.451 --> 00:00:11.852
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.852 --> 00:00:15.346
>> Welcome to your
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

6
00:00:15.346 --> 00:00:17.387
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.387 --> 00:00:21.313
In this episode we'll take a look
at how we can build an Agile team.

8
00:00:21.313 --> 00:00:27.040
And to help build these concepts up for
us are going to be Mrs. Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:27.040 --> 00:00:28.026
That was really bad.

10
00:00:28.026 --> 00:00:31.179
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I'm not saying anything but yes,

11
00:00:31.179 --> 00:00:32.010
yes it was.

12
00:00:32.010 --> 00:00:34.681
[LAUGH] It's great to be back Cherokee.

13
00:00:34.681 --> 00:00:36.639
>> Yeah, how are you Jo?

14
00:00:36.639 --> 00:00:38.717
>> [LAUGH] I see you need some help.

15
00:00:38.717 --> 00:00:41.100
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, you need my help.

16
00:00:41.100 --> 00:00:47.363
>> I need you to build me a nice structure
to flow in and segue into our topic.

17
00:00:47.363 --> 00:00:49.130
Do you think you could do that for us?

18
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:50.422
>> That was terrible.

19
00:00:50.422 --> 00:00:51.189
>> That was worse.

20
00:00:51.189 --> 00:00:52.339
[LAUGH]
>> That was terrible,

21
00:00:52.339 --> 00:00:53.833
you just carry on digging.

22
00:00:53.833 --> 00:00:57.790
Carry on digging, and I'll build you
a ladder to get out, how about that?

23
00:00:57.790 --> 00:00:59.532
>> Perfect.
>> [LAUGH]

24
00:00:59.532 --> 00:01:00.240
>> Yeah, okay,

25
00:01:00.240 --> 00:01:03.249
in case you haven't guessed,
in this particular section,

26
00:01:03.249 --> 00:01:06.090
we're going to be talking
about building an Agile team.

27
00:01:06.090 --> 00:01:09.748
That makes me very agile in this
particular circumstance, but

28
00:01:09.748 --> 00:01:10.870
we're all right.

29
00:01:10.870 --> 00:01:14.827
We are going to be looking at,
actually resourcing our project and

30
00:01:14.827 --> 00:01:18.855
making sure that we've got the right
people with the right skills,

31
00:01:18.855 --> 00:01:21.625
in order to be able to
deliver the end product.

32
00:01:21.625 --> 00:01:27.002
>> And this is actually a huge,
like it's a very important role or

33
00:01:27.002 --> 00:01:29.850
duty here, it's not easy work.

34
00:01:29.850 --> 00:01:32.877
I mean I guess maybe it comes
naturally to some people.

35
00:01:32.877 --> 00:01:37.515
But finding the right pieces for
this puzzle can be difficult.

36
00:01:37.515 --> 00:01:39.097
>> Well,
I quite like what you just said and

37
00:01:39.097 --> 00:01:41.582
I know that I laugh about some of
the things that Cherokee said.

38
00:01:41.582 --> 00:01:42.624
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I actually quite

39
00:01:42.624 --> 00:01:43.530
like what you said.

40
00:01:43.530 --> 00:01:44.142
>> The puzzle?
>> Yeah,

41
00:01:44.142 --> 00:01:46.380
cuz you talked about pieces in a puzzle.

42
00:01:46.380 --> 00:01:51.915
And building a team for an Agile project
is not quite as simple as it sounds.

43
00:01:51.915 --> 00:01:55.660
In a traditional waterfall style approach,
we assign roles and

44
00:01:55.660 --> 00:01:57.750
responsibilities to those roles.

45
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:01.694
And so what we'll do is we have
various people that are already,

46
00:02:01.694 --> 00:02:05.650
the project analyst,
they're already part of a project team.

47
00:02:05.650 --> 00:02:08.859
And that's who we'll use
within our project, and

48
00:02:08.859 --> 00:02:11.326
then we'll give them specific roles.

49
00:02:11.326 --> 00:02:15.726
Well, we don't do that within our Agile
project because that is not considered to

50
00:02:15.726 --> 00:02:16.910
be efficient.

51
00:02:16.910 --> 00:02:21.512
We want people to come into work on their
