00:29:24.810 --> 00:29:29.310
that's the thing with the concept of done
and we'll see that in our next slide.

513
00:29:29.310 --> 00:29:35.720
We've all gotta agree on what consists
of done, you have a question.

514
00:29:35.720 --> 00:29:38.550
>> It's not a question but
I was just gonna add to that.

515
00:29:38.550 --> 00:29:42.953
So I don't know if you heard this
morning Jo, in our stand up meeting,

516
00:29:42.953 --> 00:29:47.358
some of our developers talking about
they were gonna be partaking, or

517
00:29:47.358 --> 00:29:50.000
participating in a ceremony today.

518
00:29:50.000 --> 00:29:55.990
So that is kind of where they decide,
hey, did everyone meet their goals within

519
00:29:55.990 --> 00:30:00.550
this particular story, are we accepting
it, can we move on during a ceremony.

520
00:30:00.550 --> 00:30:02.550
So that's just their terminology but
I don't know,

521
00:30:02.550 --> 00:30:04.260
other people may call
it something different.

522
00:30:04.260 --> 00:30:07.940
>> I thought somebody was getting married
and we weren't invited, that was all.

523
00:30:07.940 --> 00:30:09.660
I just thought maybe we'd been excluded.

524
00:30:10.720 --> 00:30:14.660
>> No, no,
Rob's had to explain that before.

525
00:30:14.660 --> 00:30:18.587
Because it's not a common term
that everyone even within our

526
00:30:18.587 --> 00:30:19.980
organization uses.

527
00:30:19.980 --> 00:30:22.185
>> Right?
>> So just understanding what that means.

528
00:30:22.185 --> 00:30:29.060
>> So how efficient do you think that
is if we don't all know about this?

529
00:30:30.670 --> 00:30:32.564
>> Not very efficient but
that's why we're moaning.

530
00:30:32.564 --> 00:30:33.850
[LAUGH]
>> Now we're moaning.

531
00:30:33.850 --> 00:30:34.660
But yeah.

532
00:30:34.660 --> 00:30:37.500
>> That's why talk about it at stand up.

533
00:30:37.500 --> 00:30:38.730
But you weren't there for that stand up.

534
00:30:39.940 --> 00:30:41.880
>> No, I wasn't there for
that particular stand up.

535
00:30:41.880 --> 00:30:45.066
But it's not efficient,
it really isn't efficient,

536
00:30:45.066 --> 00:30:48.930
if we've gotta explain something,
then it's not efficient.

537
00:30:48.930 --> 00:30:52.550
However, what we've gotta do is make
sure that when we form the team,

538
00:30:52.550 --> 00:30:56.760
that everybody is aware of
what the norms would be.

539
00:30:56.760 --> 00:31:00.620
But they're gonna develop over time,
they're going to change over time.

540
00:31:00.620 --> 00:31:03.060
Nothing remains static and,
more importantly,

541
00:31:03.060 --> 00:31:06.650
nothing should remain static
in an agile environment.

542
00:31:06.650 --> 00:31:09.700
We should be changing,
we should be improving.

543
00:31:09.700 --> 00:31:10.630
>> For sure.

544
00:31:10.630 --> 00:31:16.530
>> And so that concept of done is just the
team's definition of what we've achieved.

545
00:31:16.530 --> 00:31:20.000
This is what we will consider to be done.

546
00:31:20.000 --> 00:31:25.370
This is when we signed that off and we'll
agree that before we actually do the work

547
00:31:25.370 --> 00:31:28.930
that this is what we consider to be done
and it could mean absolutely anything.

548
00:31:28.930 --> 00:31:31.150
It could mean that the tests
are being written and

549
00:31:31.150 --> 00:31:34.150
we've tested everything and
it's come back without any errors.

550
00:31:34.150 --> 00:31:36.540
Or it could be that the product
owners approved it or

551
00:31:36.540 --> 00:31:41.005
it could be that the customer has signed
off on that particular iteration,

552
00:31:41.005 --> 00:31:45.148
on that particular piece of code,
there's no right or wrong with this.

553
00:31:45.148 --> 00:31:50.000
It is completely subjective
to the iteration but

554
00:31:50.000 --> 00:31:53.770
nevertheless it has to
be an objective measure.

555
00:31:55.280 --> 00:32:00.900
But all of that forms part of
the building, this agile team.

556
00:32:00.900 --> 00:32:04.290
Because what we want to do is
build a team that gets along,

557
00:32:04.290 --> 00:32:09.430
that collaborates with each other,
that allows us to define our norms and

558
00:32:09.430 --> 00:32:11.760
our methods, and our way of working.

559
00:32:11.760 --> 00:32:17.685
And these norms and methods and way of
working, and even how we define done,

560
00:32:17.685 --> 00:32:22.556
it's all gotta be something that we can
all work with as part of the agile team.

561
00:32:22.556 --> 00:32:28.500
And so when we're building that team, the
scrum master or the project manager, well,

562
00:32:28.500 --> 00:32:34.740
they have to be very, very picky, I wanna
say, about who we bring into the team.

563
00:32:34.740 --> 00:32:37.860
Because we have to have people
that are able to work together.

564
00:32:37.860 --> 00:32:38.870
>> That's very important,

565
00:32:38.870 --> 00:32:43.080
I think, just making sure you do have
those right pieces to our puzzle.

566
00:32:43.080 --> 00:32:45.550
>> Exactly,
you've gotta get the right jigsaw, right?

567
00:32:45.550 --> 00:32:46.920
>> Yeah, so what are you?

568
00:32:46.920 --> 00:32:50.020
Would you say you're like a corner piece,

569
00:32:50.020 --> 00:32:53.590
you're there to like be
a foundation element?

570
00:32:53.590 --> 00:32:55.899
>> I'm the biggest guy in the middle and
nobody can figure it out.

571
00:32:55.899 --> 00:32:56.673
That's what I am.

572
00:32:56.673 --> 00:33:00.942
>> [LAUGH] Well, we appreciate that
little bit of obscurity there for

573
00:33:00.942 --> 00:33:04.046
us today, Jo, and
we appreciate you as well but

574
00:33:04.046 --> 00:33:08.020
we still have additional ad job
components headed your way.

575
00:33:08.020 --> 00:33:11.220
Don't miss that on the next show,
for now, let's sign out.

576
00:33:11.220 --> 00:33:12.950
I've been your host, Cherokee Boobs.

577
00:33:12.950 --> 00:33:13.950
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

578
00:33:13.950 --> 00:33:16.949
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

579
00:33:16.949 --> 00:33:22.924
[MUSIC]

580
00:33:22.924 --> 00:33:26.348
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In Episode 14 we introduce the User Story and differing techniques that will help with estimating the amount of effort to develop the solutions for each story, including the Fibonacci sequence and Ideal Days. We also look at Epic stories and Backlogs.
episodes.title: Users Stories
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.063
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm
your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.063 --> 00:00:08.339
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.339 --> 00:00:12.941
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> Welcome everyone to your

4
00:00:12.941 --> 00:00:14.880
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

5
00:00:14.880 --> 00:00:18.340
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.340 --> 00:00:22.550
In this episode, we're gonna gather
round and share some stories together.

7
00:00:24.160 --> 00:00:29.820
Specifically user stories, and of course
we have Mrs. Jo Peacock in studio

8
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:34.000
to help define what a user story is.
>> Well,

9
00:00:34.000 --> 00:00:38.180
it doesn't start off with once upon a
time, and no one lives happily ever after.

10
00:00:38.180 --> 00:00:39.050
>> In a far,

11
00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:42.113
far away land?
>> No, no, you're thinking Shrek.

12
00:00:42.113 --> 00:00:42.766
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:42.766 --> 00:00:44.797
>> [LAUGH] Completely different.

14
00:00:44.797 --> 00:00:45.525
>> Great movie.

15
00:00:45.525 --> 00:00:47.860
>> [LAUGH] Okay, doesn't end up

16
00:00:47.860 --> 00:00:50.470
with happily ever after as well.
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:51.960
>> Although it should end up with happy

18
00:00:51.960 --> 00:00:54.160
people.
>> Okay.

19
00:00:54.160 --> 00:00:55.270
>> Yeah, we should end up with

20
00:00:55.270 --> 00:00:56.100
happy users.

21
00:00:56.100 --> 00:00:58.150
That's the goal, right?
>> That's what a user story should be,

22
00:00:58.150 --> 00:01:00.060
right.
>> That's exactly what the goal is,

23
00:01:00.060 --> 00:01:03.060
is to deliver something of value
to the user, in other words,

24
00:01:03.060 --> 00:01:05.810
customer satisfaction,
that should be our goal.

25
00:01:05.810 --> 00:01:11.140
But no, what a user story
is is really it's a way of

26
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:13.740
capturing user requirements
in any project.

27
00:01:13.740 --> 00:01:15.872
It is specifically in an Agile project.

28
00:01:15.872 --> 00:01:20.710
So we will use user stories and
Scram and will use user stories and

29
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:23.590
all of our other Agile
methodologies as well.

30
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:27.344
When it just really is a way of
capturing their requirements.

31
00:01:27.344 --> 00:01:29.950
So we write it down in a story.

32
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:33.930
And that allows us to
capture those requirements.

33
00:01:33.930 --> 00:01:37.850
And actually, to organize and
then prioritize those requirements.

34
00:01:37.850 --> 00:01:42.800
And actually, in another episode,
we will be looking at a- well,

35
00:01:42.800 --> 00:01:45.170
we'll be looking at prioritization
of our user stories.

36
00:01:45.170 --> 00:01:48.890
That'll probably be in, sort of,
part three of looking at user stories.

37
00:01:48.890 --> 00:01:50.370
>> You'll have to give me a heads up so

38
00:01:50.370 --> 00:01:54.860
we can actually have Rob come in here and
do the full on demonstration then for

39
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:58.460
that prioritization process.
>> He's gonna help with rock, paper,

40
00:01:58.460 --> 00:02:00.241
scissors, is he?
>> Yeah, he'll have to guide us.

41
00:02:00.241 --> 00:02:01.436
[LAUGH]
>> Right, okay, so

42
00:02:01.436 --> 00:02:04.484
that's something to look forward to or
be very frightened of.

43
00:02:04.484 --> 00:02:05.030
>> [LAUGH]

44
00:02:05.030 --> 00:02:07.705
>> It could well be more like a grim story

45
00:02:07.705 --> 00:02:09.161
[LAUGH] than anything else, yeah.

46
00:02:10.570 --> 00:02:15.870
But a user story, really what that should
do is, that should take the problem

47
00:02:15.870 --> 00:02:20.780
that we have and then demonstrate and
describe how to articulate, for

48
00:02:20.780 --> 00:02:24.840
lack of a better word, how the user
is going to use that solution.

49
00:02:24.840 --> 00:02:26.870
That's what the user's story should do.

50
00:02:26.870 --> 00:02:32.000
So how the user's going to perceive,
that's the word we use when we talk about

51
00:02:32.000 --> 00:02:37.990
value, perceive value in that particular
additional functionality, etc.

52
00:02:37.990 --> 00:02:42.310
So the user's story, you might want to
call them stakeholder requirements,

53
00:02:42.310 --> 00:02:43.820
but not in an agile project.

54
00:02:43.820 --> 00:02:50.150
The user's story should be detailed
enough to understand the user needs,

55
00:02:50.150 --> 00:02:54.960
however they shouldn't be so
detailed that it restricts programming.

56
00:02:56.710 --> 00:03:00.820
Sometimes what happens when we're
defining user stories is that we get so

57
00:03:00.820 --> 00:03:06.220
detailed and we get so caught up
in the actual detail of the story,

58
00:03:06.220 --> 00:03:11.320
we then actually pretty much do the design
of the solution at the same time.

59
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:12.770
And that's not what we should be doing.

60
00:03:12.770 --> 00:03:16.570
A User Story should really
describe the endpoint.

61
00:03:16.570 --> 00:03:22.060
What the resulting
functionality should look like.

62
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:25.280
Not how it should be programmed or
how it should work but

63
00:03:25.280 --> 00:03:27.360
just what it should look like.

64
00:03:27.360 --> 00:03:33.490
So it allows us to estimate the size
of the story, it allows us to estimate

65
00:03:33.490 --> 00:03:40.650
how many days programming should be
needed to be able to deliver that story.

66
00:03:40.650 --> 00:03:43.450
What Cherokee was going on
about just a little while ago,

67
00:03:43.450 --> 00:03:47.580
in case you didn't hear any
of our previous episodes,

68
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:53.860
was we've got somebody in our office- Rob-
who will use Rock, Paper, Scissors or

69
00:03:53.860 --> 00:03:59.460
a derivative of Rock, Paper, Scissors
to actually prioritize user's stories.

70
00:03:59.460 --> 00:04:02.890
You see, for every single project,
and therefore for

71
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:06.310
every iteration, we're going to
have a collection of user stories.

72
00:04:06.310 --> 00:04:07.550
We're not just going to have just one.

73
00:04:07.550 --> 00:04:11.300
And we're not just going to deliver
one piece of functionality.

74
00:04:11.300 --> 00:04:15.800
We're going to deliver two, three,
maybe four pieces of functionality.

75
00:04:15.800 --> 00:04:20.270
And maybe it's a case of where
I've coming a bug for instance or

76
00:04:20.270 --> 00:04:25.990
it's an additional feature but
we have to prioritize those stories and

77
00:04:25.990 --> 00:04:30.540
collectively across the entire project
we have to prioritize those stories.

78
00:04:30.540 --> 00:04:34.680
And once we've done that,
that's how we decide then which stories

79
00:04:34.680 --> 00:04:38.780
fit into which iteration
depending on the priority.

80
00:04:39.860 --> 00:04:41.500
So it all makes sense really.

81
00:04:42.680 --> 00:04:50.240
A product owner has the role of not
only defining the user stories,

82
00:04:50.240 --> 00:04:54.650
or at least being able to articulate and
explain the user stories, but

83
00:04:54.650 --> 00:04:59.640
the product owner has the role of
owning the functionality that is that's

84
00:04:59.640 --> 00:05:03.557
what they call the product owner that
is required within those user stories.

85
00:05:04.720 --> 00:05:08.480
So the product owner takes ownership for
the deliverable.

86
00:05:08.480 --> 00:05:13.650
That's what's gonna come out of the
programming that is needed to deliver that

87
00:05:13.650 --> 00:05:14.760
use a story.

88
00:05:16.490 --> 00:05:18.330
So what should be in a user story then?

89
00:05:18.330 --> 00:05:23.950
Well pretty obvious, yeah, the user
interface, what it's going to look like.

90
00:05:23.950 --> 00:05:28.320
Any services that we need, including
third-party or web services, etc.

91
00:05:28.320 --> 00:05:31.500
And also any data services that we need.

92
00:05:31.500 --> 00:05:34.330
Because we might store our data
in a different database, so

93
00:05:34.330 --> 00:05:36.849
the actual tool with which we're using it.

94
00:05:38.050 --> 00:05:43.033
So all of that should be part of our
consideration when it comes to our user

95
00:05:43.033 --> 00:05:48.080
story, however It should be
part of the consideration.

96
00:05:48.080 --> 00:05:52.030
Just go back a slide, and you'll see, and
I've already mentioned that if we go back

97
00:05:52.030 --> 00:05:56.720
a slide, you'll see that it shouldn't
have enough detail to build the solution.

98
00:05:56.720 --> 00:06:01.460
The user story simply
details what the user want's,

99
00:06:01.460 --> 00:06:05.155
it doesn't detail how it should be used.

100
00:06:06.769 --> 00:06:12.072
So here's an example of a user story and
the user story should say something

101
00:06:12.072 --> 00:06:17.375
along the line's of as a user and
whatever particular type of user you are,

102
00:06:17.375 --> 00:06:21.020
this is what I need and
I need it to be able to do this.

103
00:06:22.060 --> 00:06:23.440
So here's an example.

104
00:06:23.440 --> 00:06:27.840
As a retail customer,
I need to be able to order and

105
00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:31.830
buy food from wherever I am so
that I can have food delivered to my

106
00:06:31.830 --> 00:06:35.110
home without having to drive to the shop.
>> Sounds amazing.

107
00:06:35.110 --> 00:06:38.210
>> Well that's a reality depending on

108
00:06:38.210 --> 00:06:39.230
where you're living in the world.
>> I know.

109
00:06:39.230 --> 00:06:42.520
And in some places it's only
within like a two hour or

110
00:06:42.520 --> 00:06:45.470
maybe even a one hour window.
>> We select a one hour window

111
00:06:45.470 --> 00:06:46.180
back in the UK.

112
00:06:48.110 --> 00:06:52.070
Depending on which one you wanna yeah.
>> Gainesville, Florida has not yet

113
00:06:52.070 --> 00:06:57.290
met that particular map yet.
>> You need to

114
00:06:57.290 --> 00:06:58.541
move to London.
>> [LAUGH]

115
00:06:58.541 --> 00:06:59.060
>> [LAUGH] But

116
00:06:59.060 --> 00:07:02.460
then to be fair up in Washington DC,
you can specify one or

117
00:07:02.460 --> 00:07:03.390
two delivery-
>> Yeah.

118
00:07:03.390 --> 00:07:04.110
>> With your Amazon.

119
00:07:04.110 --> 00:07:04.710
>> Yeah.

120
00:07:04.710 --> 00:07:06.560
>> Yeah, so, yeah.

121
00:07:06.560 --> 00:07:08.920
Yeah where I live in South Carolina
we haven't quite gotten to that.

122
00:07:08.920 --> 00:07:10.152
>> Washington State,

123
00:07:10.152 --> 00:07:13.629
Seattle that's where those
big companies are that offer

124
00:07:13.629 --> 00:07:16.222
a lot of those services.
>> [LAUGH]

125
00:07:16.222 --> 00:07:17.173
Yeah.
>> Yeah.

126
00:07:17.173 --> 00:07:17.880
>> Yeah so

127
00:07:17.880 --> 00:07:19.380
here we've got our user story that,

128
00:07:19.380 --> 00:07:22.160
really just articulates
the value that the user sees.

129
00:07:22.160 --> 00:07:26.690
And you can see in that that it says I
wanna be able to order and buy food.

130
00:07:26.690 --> 00:07:31.150
And here is my value statement so I can
have food delivered to my home without

131
00:07:31.150 --> 00:07:34.390
having to go to the store or to the shop.

132
00:07:34.390 --> 00:07:36.210
That's my value statement.

133
00:07:36.210 --> 00:07:43.740
But my need is the functionality
that the developer has to include.

134
00:07:44.950 --> 00:07:49.517
So when it comes to, and we'll talk about
prioritization in another episode, but

135
00:07:49.517 --> 00:07:53.447
when it comes to priorities,
what do you think we base the priority on?

136
00:07:53.447 --> 00:07:57.781
Do we base it on the need or
do we base it on what it

137
00:07:57.781 --> 00:08:02.389
actually allows them to do, the value?
>> Perceived

138
00:08:02.389 --> 00:08:03.406
value.
>> Right,

139
00:08:03.406 --> 00:08:06.486
because we're actually delivering
values to the customer, and

140
00:08:06.486 --> 00:08:08.060
it's what the customer values.

141
00:08:09.080 --> 00:08:13.060
The customer doesn't necessarily value
a particular piece of functionality,

142
00:08:13.060 --> 00:08:17.130
what the customer values is
what it enables them to do.

143
00:08:17.130 --> 00:08:19.610
In other words,
it enables them to have food delivered

144
00:08:19.610 --> 00:08:21.490
home without having to go to the shop.
>> To

145
00:08:21.490 --> 00:08:22.177
the store, yeah.

146
00:08:22.177 --> 00:08:22.930
>> Right.
>> Yeah.

147
00:08:23.950 --> 00:08:25.170
>> And, interestingly enough, and

148
00:08:25.170 --> 00:08:27.290
this why we talk about
iterative development.

149
00:08:27.290 --> 00:08:30.780
Interestingly enough, when you first
deploy a brand new service, and

150
00:08:30.780 --> 00:08:34.900
let's say we were deploying
a brand new service like this.

151
00:08:34.900 --> 00:08:36.940
When we first deploy that service,

152
00:08:36.940 --> 00:08:41.810
you could make that user interface
look however you wanted it to look.

153
00:08:41.810 --> 00:08:44.630
And the customer will perceive value
in that, because it allows them to

154
00:08:44.630 --> 00:08:47.930
do something that they haven't
been able to do previously.

155
00:08:48.930 --> 00:08:53.520
However, they're only going to tolerate
a cumbersome user interface, or

156
00:08:53.520 --> 00:08:58.140
a cumbersome sort of functionality, or
maybe slow performance for so long.

157
00:08:58.140 --> 00:09:04.390
Because you see once you have implemented
something that is a nice to have,

158
00:09:04.390 --> 00:09:10.670
a value driven feature, something new,
very, very quickly it becomes the norm.

159
00:09:10.670 --> 00:09:14.420
It becomes accepted,
it becomes business as usual, and

160
00:09:14.420 --> 00:09:18.620
value perception diminishes over time.
>> Yeah, so if they say, okay,

161
00:09:18.620 --> 00:09:21.990
I'm expecting to have my food delivered,
that's great.

162
00:09:21.990 --> 00:09:23.850
I'm getting accustomed to it, but

163
00:09:23.850 --> 00:09:28.030
then my apples start showing
up bruised every single time.

164
00:09:28.030 --> 00:09:31.870
Or my avocados are extremely ripe,
or something like that,

165
00:09:31.870 --> 00:09:33.410
you never know.
>> Well,

166
00:09:33.410 --> 00:09:34.850
you know what bugs me?
>> [LAUGH]

167
00:09:34.850 --> 00:09:36.447
>> And I could tell you now,

168
00:09:36.447 --> 00:09:41.011
I have used this in the UK before, and
when it comes to the online grocery

169
00:09:41.011 --> 00:09:42.202
shopping,
>> Uh-huh,

170
00:09:42.202 --> 00:09:44.983
it's where they deliver toilet paper,
it's a different color to that

171
00:09:44.983 --> 00:09:46.020
that I asked for.

172
00:09:46.020 --> 00:09:48.301
>> Color?
>> Well,

173
00:09:48.301 --> 00:09:49.124
yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

174
00:09:49.124 --> 00:09:50.217
>> I mean, come on.

175
00:09:50.217 --> 00:09:51.144
>> All right,

176
00:09:51.144 --> 00:09:55.591
Jo you got a color.
>> We have color toilet paper in the UK.

177
00:09:55.591 --> 00:09:57.580
>> [LAUGH] Okay,

178
00:09:57.580 --> 00:10:00.638
I've never actually done that service and
that's something that I'm worried about-

179
00:10:00.638 --> 00:10:01.850
>> The basin is yellow, and

180
00:10:01.850 --> 00:10:03.871
they deliver pink toilet paper, I mean,

181
00:10:03.871 --> 00:10:09.396
what am I gonna do with that?
>> Chemicals, you're

182
00:10:09.396 --> 00:10:12.150
not worried about [CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> Let's move on.

183
00:10:12.150 --> 00:10:13.010
>> Okay,

184
00:10:13.010 --> 00:10:16.293
moving on.
>> So part of defining there, and

185
00:10:16.293 --> 00:10:20.522
once we've defined that user story,
what we have to then define,

186
00:10:20.522 --> 00:10:24.840
is what the acceptance criteria is for
that particular user story.

187
00:10:24.840 --> 00:10:28.126
So in that user story that
I gave you as an example,

188
00:10:28.126 --> 00:10:32.199
the user story was about online
at home delivery of her grocery

189
00:10:32.199 --> 00:10:35.720
shopping with the right
color toilet paper.

190
00:10:35.720 --> 00:10:41.420
I saw Alex except his criteria is defined,
at that point in time with the story.

191
00:10:41.420 --> 00:10:45.640
So we, think about what the customer wants
to achieve, and what the customer wants

192
00:10:45.640 --> 00:10:50.700
to achieve is, well,
we want to have our groceries delivered.

193
00:10:50.700 --> 00:10:54.780
But then as I've said,
over time that scope creep,

194
00:10:54.780 --> 00:11:00.645
as Cherokee likes to call it,
that scope creep might come into it.

195
00:11:00.645 --> 00:11:04.034
But that's not a scope creep,
it's an enhancement, all right,

196
00:11:04.034 --> 00:11:05.855
it's another iteration.

197
00:11:05.855 --> 00:11:09.285
And we might change because we might
change our requirements based on

198
00:11:09.285 --> 00:11:11.068
the deliverables that we receive.

199
00:11:11.068 --> 00:11:14.796
And if I receive my toilet paper,
two of them in the wrong color then,

200
00:11:14.796 --> 00:11:17.645
we can have to make some improvements.

201
00:11:17.645 --> 00:11:22.390
But the acceptance criteria is what
the customers is willing to sign off on.

202
00:11:22.390 --> 00:11:27.180
And it describes what's included that
has to be delivered in order for

203
00:11:27.180 --> 00:11:29.840
the users to accept that.

204
00:11:29.840 --> 00:11:35.650
And so, we should capture the both
the user's story on the card, and also

205
00:11:35.650 --> 00:11:39.900
on the back of that card, which should
capture the acceptance criteria as well.

206
00:11:39.900 --> 00:11:43.050
And it's the acceptance
criteria that we test for.

207
00:11:44.610 --> 00:11:48.067
It includes the must haves,
and nice to haves, as well.

208
00:11:50.085 --> 00:11:54.649
Have you every heard of Moscow?
>> Like, a Moscow mule?

209
00:11:56.706 --> 00:12:00.182
[INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]
>> Always alcohol,

210
00:12:00.182 --> 00:12:03.210
why?
>> Actually, I feel like I really,

211
00:12:03.210 --> 00:12:08.990
really have, it's some kind of project
management tool aside from the city.

212
00:12:08.990 --> 00:12:14.640
I can't dust enough cobwebs off right
now to really define that tool,

213
00:12:14.640 --> 00:12:15.810
maybe you can.
>> Yeah,

214
00:12:15.810 --> 00:12:18.610
I'm gonna put her out of her misery now.
>> [LAUGH]

215
00:12:18.610 --> 00:12:19.966
>> She's thinking alcohol again.

216
00:12:19.966 --> 00:12:24.017
[LAUGH] MoSCoW is must-have, should have,

217
00:12:24.017 --> 00:12:27.572
could have, and would like.
>> Good.

218
00:12:27.572 --> 00:12:30.338
>> Amaze of the functionalities that

219
00:12:30.338 --> 00:12:33.674
are specified when we define user story,

220
00:12:33.674 --> 00:12:38.170
then we have to think about,
what our must-haves are.

221
00:12:39.170 --> 00:12:43.590
But also then, what our should have, and
what our could haves, and what I won't

222
00:12:43.590 --> 00:12:47.570
have right now, or I would like in
the future, what those criteria are.

223
00:12:47.570 --> 00:12:53.680
And the golden rule is really we to need
meet a minimum of 65% of our must haves.

224
00:12:53.680 --> 00:12:57.800
And a lot of organizations will actually
insist on meeting at least 80% of

225
00:12:57.800 --> 00:12:58.600
the must haves.

226
00:12:58.600 --> 00:13:02.156
So the funcationality has to be
able to meet those must haves.

227
00:13:02.156 --> 00:13:05.428
And then it'a up to you to decide
how many the should haves or

228
00:13:05.428 --> 00:13:07.920
could haves you're gonna feature in there.

229
00:13:07.920 --> 00:13:11.952
Now, now that I've said all of
that let's think about Agile, and

230
00:13:11.952 --> 00:13:14.700
remember our lean principles within Agile.

231
00:13:14.700 --> 00:13:17.290
And you don't develop something
that you're not going to use.

232
00:13:18.490 --> 00:13:21.600
So when we talk about must-haves, and
should-haves, and could-haves etc.,

233
00:13:21.600 --> 00:13:24.750
think about what's going
to be used by the customer.

234
00:13:26.860 --> 00:13:29.070
Yes, you can add an additional
functionality, but

235
00:13:29.070 --> 00:13:31.870
if they're not going to use it
then why are you developing it?

236
00:13:31.870 --> 00:13:33.990
That's certainly not an Agile principle.

237
00:13:35.160 --> 00:13:39.700
So think about this,
maybe that in our customer story

238
00:13:39.700 --> 00:13:44.376
we've talked about having our online
grocery shopping delivered to our home.

239
00:13:44.376 --> 00:13:48.240
And maybe as an additional functionality
we could actually get a cup of coffee

240
00:13:48.240 --> 00:13:50.480
delivered along with our grocery order.

241
00:13:50.480 --> 00:13:53.880
But given that our grocery order is
going to sit in the back of a van for

242
00:13:53.880 --> 00:13:57.120
potentially an hour before
it's delivered to our home,

243
00:13:57.120 --> 00:13:59.190
do we really want a cold cup of coffee?

244
00:13:59.190 --> 00:14:04.203
Probably not, so that nice to have
feature is probably not going to be used.

245
00:14:04.203 --> 00:14:10.670
So why are you wasting time in identifying
and defining that particular feature,

246
00:14:10.670 --> 00:14:14.900
if it's nice to have then
it shouldn't be included?

247
00:14:16.240 --> 00:14:20.780
So some examples of acceptance criteria
that we have for this particular

248
00:14:20.780 --> 00:14:25.400
user story, there are things like items
are not delivered until funds are cleared.

249
00:14:26.440 --> 00:14:30.880
Or where a chosen item is not available,
for instance when the user or

250
00:14:30.880 --> 00:14:35.430
the customer chooses something
that a substitution is made.

251
00:14:35.430 --> 00:14:39.720
But then you wanna put rules
in place like, it's no good

252
00:14:39.720 --> 00:14:43.290
if my pork chops aren't available
[LAUGH] when I've ordered my pork chops.

253
00:14:43.290 --> 00:14:45.190
And you want to send me a joint of beef,
and

254
00:14:45.190 --> 00:14:49.300
I have an allergy to beef, then that's
not really going to help me any.

255
00:14:49.300 --> 00:14:53.650
So again you have to consider
how you approach those, and

256
00:14:53.650 --> 00:14:55.210
that's just an example here.

257
00:14:55.210 --> 00:14:59.488
So what do we do,
if we're going to input the option for

258
00:14:59.488 --> 00:15:02.100
substitutions in place, okay?

259
00:15:03.360 --> 00:15:06.770
Or maybe of value of delivery
shouldn't exceed more than $5,000 or

260
00:15:06.770 --> 00:15:10.910
5000 pounds for
the security of the delivery driver.

261
00:15:10.910 --> 00:15:13.930
Or that might not be necessarily
the security of the delivery driver more

262
00:15:13.930 --> 00:15:15.860
likely the safety of the delivery driver,

263
00:15:15.860 --> 00:15:17.805
because he's got to carry
that into your home.

264
00:15:17.805 --> 00:15:22.050
[LAUGH] So these are just
examples of acceptance criteria.

265
00:15:22.050 --> 00:15:26.330
This is the functionality of
the software that you have to deliver.

266
00:15:26.330 --> 00:15:30.960
So you have to ensure that
you have to have the funds,

267
00:15:30.960 --> 00:15:35.580
they've got to have cleared before
somebody then goes around the store and

268
00:15:35.580 --> 00:15:39.980
actually, gets all of the groceries and
puts them into a bag.

269
00:15:41.440 --> 00:15:46.290
You also have to ensure that your
functionality will highlight stock levels,

270
00:15:46.290 --> 00:15:49.815
and highlight where we don't
have the relevant stock and

271
00:15:49.815 --> 00:15:51.736
then suggest substitutions.

272
00:15:51.736 --> 00:15:56.762
You also have to ensure that your
functionality in your software, and

273
00:15:56.762 --> 00:16:02.641
then once it gets to above 5,000 pounds,
well, then it rejects that order or

274
00:16:02.641 --> 00:16:08.200
maybe it gives out an error message to
say it's above our transaction limit.

275
00:16:09.580 --> 00:16:12.300
So these are the examples of
our acceptance criteria, and

276
00:16:12.300 --> 00:16:15.260
we should be testing all of these
to make sure that they work.

277
00:16:16.780 --> 00:16:21.360
Ultimately, when you're defining a good
customer story, a good user story,

278
00:16:21.360 --> 00:16:25.530
we use this acronym,
we used the acronym, INVEST.

279
00:16:26.930 --> 00:16:31.237
INVEST means that, very simply, a good
user story should be independent, okay?

280
00:16:32.560 --> 00:16:36.763
We should be able to, what this means is
you should be able to implement that user

281
00:16:36.763 --> 00:16:39.230
story or that functionality independently.

282
00:16:39.230 --> 00:16:41.880
It's not dependent on another story.

283
00:16:41.880 --> 00:16:45.830
So we don't have to put two
stories in place together.

284
00:16:45.830 --> 00:16:51.160
The user story should be independent, and
the user story should also be negotiable.

285
00:16:51.160 --> 00:16:57.290
Now I have mentioned this right the way
from, our very first episode in Agile.

286
00:16:57.290 --> 00:17:04.290
Agile is about having that flexibility,
it's why we call it Agile, let's face it.

287
00:17:04.290 --> 00:17:07.930
It's not having
the requirements cast in stone,

288
00:17:08.930 --> 00:17:10.945
Cherokee likes to call it scope creep.

289
00:17:10.945 --> 00:17:15.990
[LAUGH] It's not scope creep,
it's really about bringing

290
00:17:15.990 --> 00:17:21.740
in enhancements and adapting to change,
that's what it is, it's negotiable.

291
00:17:21.740 --> 00:17:23.600
We've gotta deliver value, we know this.

292
00:17:24.690 --> 00:17:29.420
But we also have to be able
to accurately estimate

293
00:17:29.420 --> 00:17:34.380
what the story is, well, what it's going
to take us to be able to deliver that.

294
00:17:34.380 --> 00:17:36.770
Now it says within accuracy tolerances.

295
00:17:36.770 --> 00:17:41.530
We don't have to be, and you can't be, it
doesn't matter how good we are within our

296
00:17:41.530 --> 00:17:43.850
team and how skilled we are in our team.

297
00:17:43.850 --> 00:17:49.550
The ability to be able to precisely
estimate, we call it an estimate for

298
00:17:49.550 --> 00:17:54.450
a reason, precisely estimate how long
a particular piece of programming or

299
00:17:54.450 --> 00:17:56.030
coding's going to take.

300
00:17:56.030 --> 00:17:59.220
Well, that not only takes the skill set,
but

301
00:17:59.220 --> 00:18:01.530
also it's very, very difficult to achieve.

302
00:18:03.090 --> 00:18:07.780
A good story should be small, remember our
iterations were a maximum of four weeks.

303
00:18:07.780 --> 00:18:12.730
That's four weeks from beginning to end,
that's four weeks from the user story,

304
00:18:12.730 --> 00:18:18.890
through design, and development, and
testing, and deployment, four weeks.

305
00:18:20.020 --> 00:18:22.720
So that user story better be
achievable within that four weeks.

306
00:18:24.190 --> 00:18:27.470
And your user story has
got to be testable,

307
00:18:27.470 --> 00:18:29.760
that doesn't sound like a word does it,
testable?

308
00:18:29.760 --> 00:18:32.302
But anyway, it works [LAUGH] and
we've gotta be able to test the story.

309
00:18:32.302 --> 00:18:37.870
We've gotta be able to
test the deliverable,

310
00:18:37.870 --> 00:18:42.740
we've got to be able to test the output.

311
00:18:44.390 --> 00:18:47.410
And then we have something called, and
this is where we're gonna leave it for

312
00:18:47.410 --> 00:18:50.550
this particular session, and then we're
gonna come back in our next session and

313
00:18:50.550 --> 00:18:54.080
we're gonna carry on
talking about stories.

314
00:18:54.080 --> 00:18:58.370
But this is where we
discuss our epic stories.

315
00:18:59.870 --> 00:19:04.400
Epic stories are made up of
stories that deliver value.

316
00:19:04.400 --> 00:19:08.040
In other words,
I've already mentioned that the I for

317
00:19:08.040 --> 00:19:10.940
INVEST stands for independent.

318
00:19:10.940 --> 00:19:15.500
Well, all stories should be independent
and we should be capable of programming

319
00:19:15.500 --> 00:19:19.870
and delivering each story
independently of another one.

320
00:19:19.870 --> 00:19:25.730
But nevertheless, we're probably still
going to group some stories together

321
00:19:25.730 --> 00:19:28.910
in order to deliver value to the customer.

322
00:19:28.910 --> 00:19:33.760
Because the customer might not perceive
value in just one individual story.

323
00:19:33.760 --> 00:19:39.272
But they might perceive value in two
stories being delivered at the same time,

324
00:19:39.272 --> 00:19:39.780
okay?

325
00:19:39.780 --> 00:19:44.679
Now, we can develop these stories
in more than one increment or

326
00:19:44.679 --> 00:19:47.540
more than one iteration.

327
00:19:47.540 --> 00:19:51.468
It's still exactly the same, we have
exactly the same principles as the regular

328
00:19:51.468 --> 00:19:54.780
user story but what we're doing
is we're just grouping together.

329
00:19:54.780 --> 00:19:55.910
>> Rolling them out together.

330
00:19:55.910 --> 00:19:57.856
>> Yeah, we're grouping them together,

331
00:19:57.856 --> 00:20:00.212
we'll talk about releases
in another episode.

332
00:20:00.212 --> 00:20:04.983
But we're just grouping together user
stories that will actually deliver

333
00:20:04.983 --> 00:20:06.720
value to the customer.

334
00:20:06.720 --> 00:20:11.370
But, independently,
each story won't deliver value, okay?

335
00:20:11.370 --> 00:20:15.330
So an epic story is just
a collective story.

336
00:20:15.330 --> 00:20:19.155
Now we mind to split those
individual stories, the ones that

337
00:20:19.155 --> 00:20:23.840
make up the epic story, we might split
them over more than one iteration.

338
00:20:23.840 --> 00:20:29.190
Cuz it may be that we're working on
one particular iteration right now,

339
00:20:29.190 --> 00:20:33.910
and the functionality hasn't been
provided to us by the supplier yet.

340
00:20:33.910 --> 00:20:36.150
So we're gonna work on this bit, but

341
00:20:36.150 --> 00:20:40.870
then we're gonna make sure it rolls
forward into our next iteration.

342
00:20:40.870 --> 00:20:41.735
Let's think about this.

343
00:20:41.735 --> 00:20:46.570
Well quite often, so
software suppliers and

344
00:20:46.570 --> 00:20:49.820
providers, they will program and

345
00:20:49.820 --> 00:20:54.330
develop, maybe an app that's going to
work with the next model of phone.

346
00:20:55.420 --> 00:20:57.233
And so they're working that right now.

347
00:20:57.233 --> 00:21:03.125
And there's nothing stopping them from
actually developing and deploying,

348
00:21:03.125 --> 00:21:09.410
rolling out, that model or that particular
version or functionality of that app.

349
00:21:09.410 --> 00:21:12.449
But actually the functionality's not
gonna be available until the phone's

350
00:21:12.449 --> 00:21:14.040
available, right?

351
00:21:14.040 --> 00:21:19.940
Yeah, so we use this we got term,
I think of something I think Apple did and

352
00:21:19.940 --> 00:21:22.330
I'm sure a lot of the other
manufacturers did.

353
00:21:22.330 --> 00:21:25.951
But Apple rolled down a new version of
the operating system that allowed for

354
00:21:25.951 --> 00:21:27.340
fingerprint recognition.

355
00:21:27.340 --> 00:21:31.651
However, your phone won't allow for
fingerprint recognition until you went out

356
00:21:31.651 --> 00:21:36.190
and actually bought the model of phone
that allowed for fingerprint recognition.

357
00:21:36.190 --> 00:21:38.760
And so
this is what we mean by epic stories,

358
00:21:38.760 --> 00:21:44.060
there are two different items of
value there, two different stories.

359
00:21:44.060 --> 00:21:48.230
But you don't actually see value in
one until you've got the other, and

360
00:21:48.230 --> 00:21:50.440
that's what we mean by an epic story.

361
00:21:50.440 --> 00:21:57.129
So it's a story that collectively might
be made up of multiple stories or

362
00:21:57.129 --> 00:22:01.954
it's one story that's split into two.
>> [LAUGH]

363
00:22:01.954 --> 00:22:02.920
>> You're laughing.

364
00:22:02.920 --> 00:22:03.628
>> I know,

365
00:22:03.628 --> 00:22:08.960
it's not about the explanation
is just about the term.

366
00:22:08.960 --> 00:22:14.300
That's one of those words that
have just been totally overused.

367
00:22:14.300 --> 00:22:15.336
>> What, the word story?

368
00:22:15.336 --> 00:22:16.601
>> No, epic.

369
00:22:16.601 --> 00:22:17.111
>> Epic [LAUGH].

370
00:22:17.111 --> 00:22:19.445
>> It was an epic night last night,

371
00:22:19.445 --> 00:22:23.011
like social media.
>> Yeah, but some of our developers do

372
00:22:23.011 --> 00:22:27.202
produce some epic work, right?
>> [LAUGH]

373
00:22:27.202 --> 00:22:28.767
>> I wish I hadn't said that now, right?

374
00:22:28.767 --> 00:22:31.371
>> And that was an epic episode, Jo, so

375
00:22:31.371 --> 00:22:35.077
thanks for that info, but
I think we are out of time.

376
00:22:35.077 --> 00:22:37.592
Or the users are gonna
force us to be out of time

377
00:22:37.592 --> 00:22:40.621
[LAUGH].
>> I'm feeling slightly nauseous with all

378
00:22:40.621 --> 00:22:42.112
of that but anyway, yep.

379
00:22:42.112 --> 00:22:44.909
Yeah, we're out of time, definitely.
>> I think it's time to sign out.

380
00:22:44.909 --> 00:22:47.710
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

381
00:22:47.710 --> 00:22:50.649
>> See you next time, here at ITProTV.

382
00:22:50.649 --> 00:22:56.650
[MUSIC]

383
00:22:56.650 --> 00:22:59.979
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Once user stories have been compiled they then need to be prioritized in this episode we look at prioritizing techniques and the impacts to the project.

WEBVTT

00:12:13.240 --> 00:12:18.070
So when it comes to estimation, precise

00:23:39.710 --> 00:23:43.870

a Fibonacci sequence for your test.

466
00:23:43.870 --> 00:23:46.023
So don't worry about that.

467
00:23:46.023 --> 00:23:51.377
And, really, that just looks at the,
sort of, the points, the story points

468
00:23:51.377 --> 00:23:56.830
that you might have for each individual
story and for each individual feature.

469
00:23:56.830 --> 00:23:59.953
And take a look at your story points
there on the right-hand side.

470
00:23:59.953 --> 00:24:03.909
If you're estimating 100 story points,
then you need to split that down.

471
00:24:03.909 --> 00:24:04.447
>> Right.

472
00:24:04.447 --> 00:24:05.943
>> And you need to, what we call,

473
00:24:05.943 --> 00:24:07.150
slice that story.

474
00:24:07.150 --> 00:24:10.630
But if you're estimating
at one story point,

475
00:24:10.630 --> 00:24:15.020
then that's gotta be something that's
really, really, really simple to do.

476
00:24:15.020 --> 00:24:19.931
And if one person's estimating a five and
one person's estimating a one, then,

477
00:24:19.931 --> 00:24:23.364
as Rob says,
there's a huge disparity between the two.

478
00:24:23.364 --> 00:24:27.878
And really what we wanna make sure that
we do is that we're accurate in our

479
00:24:27.878 --> 00:24:28.700
estimates.

480
00:24:28.700 --> 00:24:31.705
And so that's why Rob didn't believe you.

481
00:24:31.705 --> 00:24:35.835
[LAUGH] It's not that we
don't trust your skills.

482
00:24:35.835 --> 00:24:39.419
But the reason why he [LAUGH] didn't
believe you is because you came in at

483
00:24:39.419 --> 00:24:43.200
a one, which is probably about a couple
of hours' worth of development.

484
00:24:43.200 --> 00:24:44.740
And I'm looking at maybe five and

485
00:24:44.740 --> 00:24:47.666
I'm thinking it's probably
a week's worth of development.

486
00:24:47.666 --> 00:24:51.014
And that sounds, for what we're trying
to do, we're trying to build an app,

487
00:24:51.014 --> 00:24:51.849
right?
>> Right.

488
00:24:51.849 --> 00:24:54.467
>> I don't care how much of a wiz kid you

489
00:24:54.467 --> 00:24:58.139
are, I'd like to see you
do it in that many hours.

490
00:24:58.139 --> 00:25:00.596
Or we can use Ideal Days.

491
00:25:00.596 --> 00:25:05.646
And ideal days, and what it says there,
they reflect the duration or

492
00:25:05.646 --> 00:25:12.000
the amount of time that you are going
to be actually physically developing.

493
00:25:12.000 --> 00:25:15.380
Second bullet point down though says about

494
00:25:15.380 --> 00:25:20.680
getting development to
completion with no distractions.

495
00:25:20.680 --> 00:25:22.660
Remember our basic time management skills.

496
00:25:22.660 --> 00:25:27.210
And our basic time management skills
are really about understanding when

497
00:25:27.210 --> 00:25:29.730
your productive time is.

498
00:25:29.730 --> 00:25:32.380
It says they are complete
with no distractions.

499
00:25:32.380 --> 00:25:34.130
When was the last time
you had a day without

500
00:25:34.130 --> 00:25:35.582
distractions?
>> Never.

501
00:25:35.582 --> 00:25:36.191
>> Right.

502
00:25:36.191 --> 00:25:37.250
>> [LAUGH]

503
00:25:37.250 --> 00:25:37.976
>> I've never had a day

504
00:25:37.976 --> 00:25:39.173
without distractions either.

505
00:25:39.173 --> 00:25:44.220
So we've gotta think that an ideal
day is a day where we don't have any

506
00:25:44.220 --> 00:25:46.820
distractions, and they don't happen.

507
00:25:46.820 --> 00:25:51.776
So most days are probably about
three-quarters of the day,

508
00:25:51.776 --> 00:25:53.630
maybe even half a day.

509
00:25:54.760 --> 00:25:57.720
The fourth bullet point down
looks at emphasizing that

510
00:25:57.720 --> 00:26:00.880
ideal days represent
effort not elapsed time.

511
00:26:02.400 --> 00:26:04.670
An ideal day is a productive day.

512
00:26:04.670 --> 00:26:10.070
So one productive ideal day is
probably equivalent to two.

513
00:26:10.070 --> 00:26:12.170
It's probably equivalent to two days.

514
00:26:12.170 --> 00:26:15.770
Because, in reality, it's gonna be
two half-days' worth of production,

515
00:26:15.770 --> 00:26:18.510
cuz you might be disturbed for
the other half a day.

516
00:26:18.510 --> 00:26:21.185
I mean, Rob,
who's one of our developers, bless him.

517
00:26:21.185 --> 00:26:23.889
What did we just do to him?
>> We disturbed him, Jo.

518
00:26:23.889 --> 00:26:24.994
[LAUGH]
>> We disturbed him,

519
00:26:24.994 --> 00:26:25.730
right?
>> [LAUGH]

520
00:26:25.730 --> 00:26:27.810
>> We kidnapped him and held him hostage.

521
00:26:29.000 --> 00:26:30.920
But we disturbed him.

522
00:26:30.920 --> 00:26:35.420
And so, as a developer, it's very
difficult to say no, which is why we

523
00:26:35.420 --> 00:26:39.300
said in a previous episode,
don't allow yourself to be distracted.

524
00:26:39.300 --> 00:26:42.520
We disturbed him, and we dragged him here,
and we got him to show-

525
00:26:42.520 --> 00:26:44.662
>> We really didn't ask, did we?

526
00:26:44.662 --> 00:26:47.000
>> We kinda just kidnapped him, really,

527
00:26:47.000 --> 00:26:48.840
and held him hostage.
>> [LAUGH]

528
00:26:48.840 --> 00:26:53.050
>> What we also wanna make sure is that we

529
00:26:53.050 --> 00:26:58.430
are consistent with our estimation of
ideal days across our projects as well.

530
00:26:58.430 --> 00:27:03.710
We've got to have the same unit
of measure across our projects,

531
00:27:03.710 --> 00:27:09.680
so that we know how long our projects
are taking, across all of our projects.

532
00:27:09.680 --> 00:27:11.000
And we've got that consistency.

533
00:27:11.000 --> 00:27:12.820
We've got a consistent approach with that.

534
00:27:15.090 --> 00:27:17.910
So we've mentioned backlogs already, and

535
00:27:17.910 --> 00:27:21.580
a backlog is what story points
we have left to complete.

536
00:27:22.610 --> 00:27:27.400
And what we should ensure is that
all of our backlogs adhere to, well,

537
00:27:27.400 --> 00:27:29.930
DEEP, the DEEP acronym.

538
00:27:29.930 --> 00:27:33.600
And DEEP stands for, as it says there,
Detailed appropriately,

539
00:27:33.600 --> 00:27:37.090
Estimated, Emergent and prioritized.

540
00:27:37.090 --> 00:27:40.460
Detailed appropriately means
we've got enough information.

541
00:27:41.490 --> 00:27:44.420
Not too much, remember, lean principles.

542
00:27:44.420 --> 00:27:47.480
We don't want to be estimating-
>> Precise.

543
00:27:47.480 --> 00:27:49.260
>> Yeah, we don't wanna be precise,

544
00:27:49.260 --> 00:27:50.830
it's an estimate.

545
00:27:50.830 --> 00:27:55.830
And again, estimated, each story has got
to have an estimate associated with it.

546
00:27:55.830 --> 00:27:59.520
Whether it's based on Fibonacci sequence,
which is exactly what we looked at with

547
00:27:59.520 --> 00:28:05.490
Rob, or whether it's based on ideal days,
each story has to have an estimate.

548
00:28:05.490 --> 00:28:08.560
And we have to be aware
that each story evolves.

549
00:28:08.560 --> 00:28:14.090
And that means that we add in detail
as we progress with the story.

550
00:28:14.090 --> 00:28:15.874
It's evolved, it's emerging.

551
00:28:15.874 --> 00:28:22.480
And so we may not completely finish
perhaps one story in an iteration.

552
00:28:22.480 --> 00:28:27.490
And we'll make that decision that that
story then remains in the backlog and

553
00:28:27.490 --> 00:28:31.338
moves on to the next iteration
at the end of that first one.

554
00:28:31.338 --> 00:28:32.974
But it's an evolved story.

555
00:28:32.974 --> 00:28:36.360
It's an emergent story, because
we've got more information with it.

556
00:28:37.930 --> 00:28:41.456
And then, of course,
all of our stories should be prioritized.

557
00:28:41.456 --> 00:28:44.794
Yeah, we know what we're
going to deal with first and

558
00:28:44.794 --> 00:28:49.630
what we should be dealing with second and
third and in each iteration, okay?

559
00:28:49.630 --> 00:28:55.640
So Iteration 0, that's our, well,
that's our initial iteration.

560
00:28:55.640 --> 00:28:58.910
But in iteration 0,
do we actually do any development work,

561
00:28:58.910 --> 00:29:01.265
do you think?
>> Hm.

562
00:29:01.265 --> 00:29:03.196
>> [LAUGH]

563
00:29:03.196 --> 00:29:03.703
>> Well,

564
00:29:03.703 --> 00:29:06.828
love it when you put me on the spot.
>> I know.

565
00:29:06.828 --> 00:29:10.478
>> Iteration 0, I'm gonna go with no.

566
00:29:10.478 --> 00:29:13.070
We gotta plan before we can dive in there.
>> Right,

567
00:29:13.070 --> 00:29:16.300
iteration 0 is actually,
it's kind of a misnomer.

568
00:29:16.300 --> 00:29:17.450
It's still an iteration.

569
00:29:17.450 --> 00:29:21.920
It's an iteration of the project,
but don't expect

570
00:29:21.920 --> 00:29:25.021
any development work to be done.
>> Okay.

571
00:29:25.021 --> 00:29:25.848
>> It mentions on that

572
00:29:25.848 --> 00:29:29.259
slide there limited development work,
if there's any development, well,

573
00:29:29.259 --> 00:29:32.010
don't expect any development
work to be done in iteration 0.

574
00:29:32.010 --> 00:29:33.556
It really is about planning.

575
00:29:33.556 --> 00:29:35.781
It's about bringing your team together.

576
00:29:35.781 --> 00:29:38.902
It's about compiling all
of your user stories and

577
00:29:38.902 --> 00:29:44.580
ensuring that we've got our user stories
estimated and we've got them prioritized.

578
00:29:44.580 --> 00:29:48.997
And this allows us to form iterations.

579
00:29:48.997 --> 00:29:52.943
So it allows us to look at our user
stories and say, right, okay, well,

580
00:29:52.943 --> 00:29:55.490
we can group these
together as iteration one.

581
00:29:55.490 --> 00:29:58.884
And we can group these
together as iteration two, and

582
00:29:58.884 --> 00:30:01.834
these stories can be
iteration three as well.

583
00:30:01.834 --> 00:30:06.386
So we want to actually scope
our vision and our scope.

584
00:30:06.386 --> 00:30:11.860
And we want to articulate our problems and
our user stories in iteration zero.

585
00:30:11.860 --> 00:30:12.750
So this is our plan.

586
00:30:12.750 --> 00:30:15.120
This is kind of our admin iteration.

587
00:30:15.120 --> 00:30:18.780
Some organizations don't
call them iteration at all.

588
00:30:18.780 --> 00:30:23.260
Some organizations want to treat it
as just part of project planning, and

589
00:30:23.260 --> 00:30:24.990
they'll call it project planning.

590
00:30:24.990 --> 00:30:27.401
But in Agile terms,
we call it iteration 0.

591
00:30:27.401 --> 00:30:30.176
It's our starting point, okay?

592
00:30:30.176 --> 00:30:33.936
So what we've done there is,
apart from drag Rob in,

593
00:30:33.936 --> 00:30:36.959
[LAUGH] we've taken
a look at user stories.

594
00:30:36.959 --> 00:30:41.599
And in our next episode, we're going to
look at prioritizing those users stories

595
00:30:41.599 --> 00:30:45.935
and actually how we prioritize them and
how we come up with our iterations.

596
00:30:45.935 --> 00:30:46.665
>> All right, perfect, Jo.

597
00:30:46.665 --> 00:30:49.135
Thank you for your time and
your time as well, but

598
00:30:49.135 --> 00:30:51.055
we are gonna go ahead and sign out.

599
00:30:51.055 --> 00:30:54.515
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock and

600
00:30:54.515 --> 00:30:56.340
that was Rob Mcgarry.

601
00:30:56.340 --> 00:30:58.566
Yeah, we gotta thank him also.
>> Yeah, right.

602
00:30:58.566 --> 00:31:02.874
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] See you next time guys, bye.

603
00:31:02.874 --> 00:31:08.723
[MUSIC]

604
00:31:08.723 --> 00:31:13.455
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: Our user stories have been estimated and prioritized and now we need to group them into inclusions for deliverable iterations and plans for releasing the iterations.
episodes.title: User Stories Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.401
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.401 --> 00:00:06.577
I'm your host Don Pezet.
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.577 --> 00:00:08.404
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.404 --> 00:00:13.190
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome everyone to your

5
00:00:13.190 --> 00:00:15.800
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

6
00:00:15.800 --> 00:00:17.640
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.640 --> 00:00:21.400
In this episode, we'll continue
taking a look at stories, and

8
00:00:21.400 --> 00:00:24.750
then we'll specifically be looking
at how to prioritize them.

9
00:00:24.750 --> 00:00:28.460
And of course, we were able to get Ms.
Jo Peacock back in studios with us today.

10
00:00:28.460 --> 00:00:31.570
Thanks for stopping by, Jo, how are you?
>> She said back, but

11
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:32.420
I've never left.
>> [LAUGH]

12
00:00:32.420 --> 00:00:34.273
>> They won't let me leave.

13
00:00:34.273 --> 00:00:36.889
>> [LAUGH] Shh.

14
00:00:36.889 --> 00:00:40.370
>> [LAUGH] I was fine, but not anymore.

15
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:42.880
I'm fine, Cherokee, how are you?
>> Great, great, good to hear,

16
00:00:42.880 --> 00:00:44.680
Jill, thanks, so-
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:44.680 --> 00:00:46.190
>> Slightly malnourished,

18
00:00:46.190 --> 00:00:48.688
but-
>> We'll feed you after this

19
00:00:48.688 --> 00:00:49.314
show.
>> [LAUGH]

20
00:00:49.314 --> 00:00:50.897
>> Okay?

21
00:00:50.897 --> 00:00:55.880
No, but seriously, when we're talking
about stories, we looked at estimations,

22
00:00:55.880 --> 00:00:58.600
but how can we really tell which
ones are more important than others?

23
00:00:58.600 --> 00:01:01.540
Do you have any suggestions?
>> Well, we have a word for

24
00:01:01.540 --> 00:01:04.500
that, a special word and
we call that priority.

25
00:01:04.500 --> 00:01:08.670
[LAUGH] So what we wanna do is we
wanna prioritize our user stories.

26
00:01:08.670 --> 00:01:13.540
And for any vision for any project
itself we wanna make sure that we can

27
00:01:13.540 --> 00:01:17.420
prioritize all of those user
stories that we have collated.

28
00:01:17.420 --> 00:01:24.120
So yes, we do something with that,
we're not just gonna ignore them.

29
00:01:24.120 --> 00:01:28.510
We need to ensure that we use
agile principles to prioritize.

30
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:32.390
We don't wanna spend too long
prioritizing our user's stories.

31
00:01:32.390 --> 00:01:38.480
We don't want to spend forever to
trying to evaluate those stories.

32
00:01:38.480 --> 00:01:39.733
We wanna make sure that,

33
00:01:39.733 --> 00:01:43.860
in the same way that we did our estimation
in our previous episode really quickly.

34
00:01:43.860 --> 00:01:47.150
That actually we use that
estimation to help us prioritize.

35
00:01:48.520 --> 00:01:49.902
Priority should be based on,

36
00:01:49.902 --> 00:01:52.267
what do you think?
>> Okay,

37
00:01:52.267 --> 00:01:56.730
since I have been wrong like 75% in this
series, I am gonna go off the cusp here.

38
00:01:56.730 --> 00:02:03.399
And in my opinion I think it should
be the amount, let me say this,

39
00:02:03.399 --> 00:02:09.340
it's usually the amount of users affected.
>> Right.

40
00:02:09.340 --> 00:02:11.970
>> And in turn, that usually equates to

41
00:02:11.970 --> 00:02:14.880
ROI or revenue produced.
>> Right,

42
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:19.760
we normally base priorities on things
like impact and urgency for instance.

43
00:02:19.760 --> 00:02:22.620
So the impact is the amount
of users that it affects or

44
00:02:22.620 --> 00:02:26.750
the impact of the organization and
such as ROI, revenue, etc.

45
00:02:26.750 --> 00:02:30.230
And also the urgency,
how quickly do we want it as well?

46
00:02:30.230 --> 00:02:34.320
So we have to make sure that we do
prioritize all of our user stories.

47
00:02:34.320 --> 00:02:38.860
And remember, that you can't do everything
all at once, which is why we talk about

48
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:43.200
bringing in agile principles
just to the prioritization.

49
00:02:43.200 --> 00:02:45.340
Because you can't do everything
all at the same time.

50
00:02:45.340 --> 00:02:48.240
As much as we'd like to be able to, yeah,

51
00:02:48.240 --> 00:02:52.510
we wanna deliver all of the customer
requirements, all of, yeah, don't.

52
00:02:52.510 --> 00:02:56.430
But one thing at a time,
agile is iterative.

53
00:02:56.430 --> 00:03:01.020
It's repeatable steps,
it's producing these iterations, and

54
00:03:01.020 --> 00:03:03.308
it's releasing one thing at a time.

55
00:03:03.308 --> 00:03:07.360
But we've gonna make sure that what
we're doing is we're delivering

56
00:03:07.360 --> 00:03:08.790
in a way that the customer values.

57
00:03:08.790 --> 00:03:14.270
And we are delivering the customer let's
say, the most valuable features first or

58
00:03:14.270 --> 00:03:17.850
at least those features that we
know will make a huge difference or

59
00:03:17.850 --> 00:03:19.440
impact to the customer first.

60
00:03:20.880 --> 00:03:24.590
So the customer's really important
in this prioritization, as well.

61
00:03:26.010 --> 00:03:28.960
What do we need to do then
to be able to prioritize?

62
00:03:28.960 --> 00:03:32.950
Well, we've already talked
about impact and urgency.

63
00:03:32.950 --> 00:03:37.190
We need to be able to, well,
we talked about this in the last episode,

64
00:03:37.190 --> 00:03:40.210
about being objective when
it came to our estimation.

65
00:03:40.210 --> 00:03:42.850
We've got to be objective when
it comes to our priority.

66
00:03:44.100 --> 00:03:51.520
You don't bump something up into a high
priority, or into a different iteration,

67
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:55.410
because the person that's asking for
it happens to be your best friend.

68
00:03:55.410 --> 00:03:58.330
And they're gonna buy you
a margarita a little bit later on.

69
00:03:58.330 --> 00:04:00.380
But that's not the reason why we do it.

70
00:04:00.380 --> 00:04:05.670
We have to have objectivity in there, but
we have to have empathy in there as well.

71
00:04:05.670 --> 00:04:09.880
We have to understand the customer,
and understand the user.

72
00:04:11.100 --> 00:04:16.060
You can't just prioritize objectively
without understanding what it

73
00:04:16.060 --> 00:04:18.550
is that the customer wants to achieve.

74
00:04:18.550 --> 00:04:21.920
The customer may have a particular
problem, and we've got a lot of

75
00:04:21.920 --> 00:04:26.000
user stories that have been documented
to resolve a particular problem.

76
00:04:26.000 --> 00:04:27.480
But you have to show empathy and

77
00:04:27.480 --> 00:04:31.460
understanding, which one of those problems
is actually more severe to the customer.

78
00:04:32.640 --> 00:04:34.190
It may not be the obvious one.

79
00:04:35.370 --> 00:04:40.290
The obvious issue there, and we used an
example previously about online shopping.

80
00:04:40.290 --> 00:04:44.654
And about being able to do our
online shopping from wherever

81
00:04:44.654 --> 00:04:48.330
we are anywhere in well,
potentially the world.

82
00:04:48.330 --> 00:04:51.367
But we're at work and
we want to do our online shopping and

83
00:04:51.367 --> 00:04:53.090
have our groceries delivered.

84
00:04:53.090 --> 00:04:57.468
But actually, that may not be our number
one priority, the number one priority to

85
00:04:57.468 --> 00:05:01.940
our customer may be the protection of
their credit card details for instance.

86
00:05:01.940 --> 00:05:04.770
That might be their number one priority,
or

87
00:05:04.770 --> 00:05:08.730
their number one priority
may be to ensure that

88
00:05:08.730 --> 00:05:11.299
the food that they buy is not damaged.
>> And

89
00:05:11.299 --> 00:05:14.755
I think that also goes back to something
you had mentioned earlier on Jo.

90

>> Uh-huh.

328
00:16:53.985 --> 00:16:56.377
>> Well, we're gonna have workshop and

329
00:16:56.377 --> 00:16:59.835
we're going to have other-
>> Ideas of how to prioritize and so-

330
00:16:59.835 --> 00:17:00.806
>> Right, yeah.

331
00:17:00.806 --> 00:17:01.376
>> Yeah.

332
00:17:01.376 --> 00:17:03.489
>> I would suggest that we prioritize by

333
00:17:03.489 --> 00:17:06.623
kind of licking our finger and
sticking into the air and

334
00:17:06.623 --> 00:17:08.543
seeing which way the wind blows.

335
00:17:08.543 --> 00:17:10.840
That's not really a good answer.
>> [LAUGH]

336
00:17:10.840 --> 00:17:12.250
>> And we're certainly not going to

337
00:17:12.250 --> 00:17:14.840
prioritize by rock, paper, scissors.

338
00:17:14.840 --> 00:17:15.481
>> Okay.
>> All right.

339
00:17:15.481 --> 00:17:17.153
No, that's not it.

340
00:17:17.153 --> 00:17:19.732
This is going to have-
>> [CROSSTALK] We need to have some kind

341
00:17:19.732 --> 00:17:23.170
of, what, research to back this up?
>> Well, it's gotta be objective.

342
00:17:23.170 --> 00:17:25.140
And we've looked at all of the criteria,

343
00:17:25.140 --> 00:17:28.778
and your organization will define
the criteria for prioritization.

344
00:17:28.778 --> 00:17:33.769
So it's gotta be an objective view on
prioritization, but nevertheless, there

345
00:17:33.769 --> 00:17:38.160
can still be conflict and this is why-
>> We know that, Jo.

346
00:17:38.160 --> 00:17:39.722
>> [LAUGH] This is why you need,

347
00:17:39.722 --> 00:17:44.310
[INAUDIBLE] your trained facilitator,
but you you need somebody to facilitate.

348
00:17:44.310 --> 00:17:49.080
And you need somebody to agree and
decide on the priorities.

349
00:17:49.080 --> 00:17:52.050
That's gonna be your approach to owner.
>> Okay.

350
00:17:52.050 --> 00:17:52.700
>> Well, your

351
00:17:52.700 --> 00:17:55.510
Agile coach is gonna help you facilitate.
>> Okay.

352
00:17:55.510 --> 00:17:56.532
>> But the product owner

353
00:17:56.532 --> 00:18:00.395
is ultimately going to make the decision.
>> The final decision, yeah, yeah.

354
00:18:00.395 --> 00:18:03.240
I've got it.
>> On the actual priorities themselves.

355
00:18:03.240 --> 00:18:07.180
But an Agile coach, that's that role
that's going to help you come in and say,

356
00:18:07.180 --> 00:18:08.050
okay-
>> Mediate.

357
00:18:08.050 --> 00:18:08.620
>> Yeah,

358
00:18:08.620 --> 00:18:10.310
you need me to help you with this.

359
00:18:10.310 --> 00:18:11.760
Let's facilitate a workshop.

360
00:18:11.760 --> 00:18:13.390
Let's have a workshop.

361
00:18:13.390 --> 00:18:18.100
And by the way, that workshop could
be by way of a very quick stand-up.

362
00:18:18.100 --> 00:18:21.510
It doesn't have to be
a form of sit-down meeting.

363
00:18:21.510 --> 00:18:25.270
Don't forget,
the formality in everything else, well,

364
00:18:25.270 --> 00:18:29.760
that kind of adds in, well,
I was gonna say the boring factor.

365
00:18:29.760 --> 00:18:35.102
But [LAUGH] it adds in more,
I don't know, mundane sort of,

366
00:18:35.102 --> 00:18:40.070
it kinda makes you feel run down,
doesn't it?

367
00:18:40.070 --> 00:18:41.621
Meetings for the sake of having meetings.
>> Right.

368
00:18:41.621 --> 00:18:43.020
>> We've all been to them.

369
00:18:43.020 --> 00:18:43.655
>> I think you're gonna

370
00:18:43.655 --> 00:18:45.400
meeting someone to death.
>> Right.

371
00:18:45.400 --> 00:18:46.292
>> What's the point of that?

372
00:18:46.292 --> 00:18:48.710
>> Yeah, so with any workshop,

373
00:18:48.710 --> 00:18:50.270
it still needs a facilitator.

374
00:18:50.270 --> 00:18:53.890
We still need to have a purpose for
the workshop.

375
00:18:53.890 --> 00:18:56.650
Yeah, you don't just have
a meeting just for the sake of it,

376
00:18:56.650 --> 00:18:57.970
there has to be a purpose.

377
00:18:59.060 --> 00:19:03.520
But nevertheless, what we wanna do is
pinpoint those areas where's there been

378
00:19:03.520 --> 00:19:05.123
some sort of disagreement.

379
00:19:05.123 --> 00:19:07.790
And we wanna work through
those disagreements.

380
00:19:07.790 --> 00:19:11.060
And at the end of that workshop,
we wanna come out with our priority list.

381
00:19:12.280 --> 00:19:16.212
So now we're in iteration
zero at the moment and

382
00:19:16.212 --> 00:19:19.470
now we have agreed on our user stories.

383
00:19:19.470 --> 00:19:22.453
So now what we've gotta is,
and we've prioritized them,

384
00:19:22.453 --> 00:19:23.953
we've assessed them, etc.

385
00:19:23.953 --> 00:19:29.090
Now we've got to agree which
stories fit into which iteration.

386
00:19:29.090 --> 00:19:30.900
But of course,
we're gonna leave that one for

387
00:19:30.900 --> 00:19:33.500
another episode.
>> All right, sounds like a plan, Jo.

388
00:19:33.500 --> 00:19:37.830
Let's go ahead and table this topic,
am I allowed to say that?

389
00:19:37.830 --> 00:19:39.353
>> No, no, please don't.

390
00:19:39.353 --> 00:19:40.641
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

391
00:19:40.641 --> 00:19:43.190
>> Don't, put it back on the story board.

392
00:19:43.190 --> 00:19:47.030
No, we're gonna table it, right?
>> [LAUGH] But thank you so much, Jo.

393
00:19:47.030 --> 00:19:49.830
And thank you guys for joining us too,
but let's go ahead and sign out.

394
00:19:49.830 --> 00:19:52.580
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

395
00:19:52.580 --> 00:19:54.646
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

396
00:19:54.646 --> 00:20:00.442
[MUSIC]

397
00:20:00.442 --> 00:20:04.076
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Our user stories have been estimated and prioritized and now we need to group them into inclusions for deliverable iterations and plans for releasing the iterations.
episodes.title: Iteration Planning
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.300
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.300 --> 00:00:08.326
I'm your host Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.326 --> 00:00:11.962
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:11.962 --> 00:00:13.232
>> Welcome everyone to your

5
00:00:13.232 --> 00:00:15.635
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

6
00:00:15.635 --> 00:00:17.335
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.335 --> 00:00:20.883
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at iteration planning, and

8
00:00:20.883 --> 00:00:23.495
with us back in studios we have Mrs.
Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:23.495 --> 00:00:24.455
Thanks for joining us, Jo.

10
00:00:24.455 --> 00:00:27.185
How are you?
>> I am absolutely fine Cherokee.

11
00:00:27.185 --> 00:00:29.935
I'm slightly worried that
you said the word iteration,

12
00:00:29.935 --> 00:00:33.785
so quickly that you might have set
expectations there that all of our

13
00:00:33.785 --> 00:00:37.110
iterations are gonna be that quick.
>> Iteration.

14
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:39.492
>> Okay, they shouldn't be that slow.

15
00:00:39.492 --> 00:00:44.319
It kind of sounded like,
have you ever seen SpongeBob SquarePants

16
00:00:44.319 --> 00:00:46.703
where he's like imagination?
>> No

17
00:00:46.703 --> 00:00:47.691
>> No.

18
00:00:47.691 --> 00:00:48.983
>> Okay.

19
00:00:48.983 --> 00:00:49.778
>> [LAUGH]

20
00:00:49.778 --> 00:00:53.221
>> You got to say it iteration.

21
00:00:53.221 --> 00:00:55.125
>> A lot of Cherokee's jokes just fall

22
00:00:55.125 --> 00:00:57.827
flat over at this side of the table.
>> I laugh, so

23
00:00:57.827 --> 00:01:00.260
I'm okay with it.
>> As long as she's

24
00:01:00.260 --> 00:01:01.000
happy.
>> [LAUGH]

25
00:01:01.000 --> 00:01:03.580
>> That's kind of the approach we take.

26
00:01:03.580 --> 00:01:05.550
>> Yeah, the medication keeps me happy,

27
00:01:05.550 --> 00:01:07.090
right?
>> Right, yeah,

28
00:01:07.090 --> 00:01:08.450
it's clearly not strong enough.

29
00:01:09.750 --> 00:01:11.160
So in this particular episode,

30
00:01:11.160 --> 00:01:15.810
yeah, we're gonna be looking at
the iteration of an Agile project.

31
00:01:15.810 --> 00:01:20.440
We're also going to be referring to
these iterations as what we call

32
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:21.830
timeboxes as well.

33
00:01:21.830 --> 00:01:25.637
So it's up to you as to what particular
terminology you use within your

34
00:01:25.637 --> 00:01:26.950
organization.

35
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:32.376
One of the good things about Agile as
a methodology is that it doesn't matter or

36
00:01:32.376 --> 00:01:35.710
as a concept it doesn't matter
what methodology you use,

37
00:01:35.710 --> 00:01:40.370
whether it's Scrum, DSDM,
whether it's XP, we're going to

38
00:01:40.370 --> 00:01:44.325
use very similar terminology
across all of those methodologies.

39
00:01:44.325 --> 00:01:47.800
But if you wanna mix, and match your
approaches, and you want to mix, and

40
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:52.830
match your definitions, and your
terminology, then that's absolutely fine.

41
00:01:52.830 --> 00:01:57.560
There's no sort of hard, and fast rule for
you, there's no right or wrong as long

42
00:01:57.560 --> 00:02:01.120
as we're following that Agile approach.
>> So speaking of terminology,

43
00:02:01.120 --> 00:02:04.320
what was that term you used,
and do I need to know that for

44
00:02:04.320 --> 00:02:06.430
the exam?
>> Well, your timebox?

45
00:02:06.430 --> 00:02:07.640
>> Timebox, there we go.

46
00:02:07.640 --> 00:02:09.068
I'm thinking of some kind
of bomb of something.

47
00:02:09.068 --> 00:02:10.937
>> Yeah, you will need to know what

48
00:02:10.937 --> 00:02:11.774
a timebox is.

49
00:02:11.774 --> 00:02:14.725
It's just another word for an iteration.
>> Okay.

50
00:02:14.725 --> 00:02:15.290
>> So

51
00:02:15.290 --> 00:02:18.910
if you're taking this particular
course because you want to study for

52
00:02:18.910 --> 00:02:22.500
your Agile foundation class or
your Agile foundation test.

53
00:02:22.500 --> 00:02:25.635
Then yes you would to
know what a timebox is.

54
00:02:25.635 --> 00:02:28.950
Timebox is just another word for
an iteration.

55
00:02:28.950 --> 00:02:30.190
This particular diagram,

56
00:02:30.190 --> 00:02:34.480
we're gonna look at a couple of times
throughout this particular episode.

57
00:02:34.480 --> 00:02:37.900
And you'll see that,
what we have right in front of us,

58
00:02:37.900 --> 00:02:42.700
the entire thing, iterations 1 through
to iteration 6, that's our project.

59
00:02:43.780 --> 00:02:45.820
But what we have are two releases.

60
00:02:45.820 --> 00:02:47.210
We have R1 and R2, okay?

61
00:02:48.220 --> 00:02:52.245
Now, release one contains four iterations.
>> I see that.

62
00:02:52.245 --> 00:02:55.137
>> And those iterations are the user

63
00:02:55.137 --> 00:02:56.070
stories.

64
00:02:56.070 --> 00:02:59.470
They're the chunks of development,
that's our development work.

65
00:02:59.470 --> 00:03:01.616
We can also call that a timebox as well.

66
00:03:01.616 --> 00:03:03.790
And of course,
an iteration should be how long?

67
00:03:03.790 --> 00:03:05.321
Do you remember?
>> Up to four weeks.

68
00:03:05.321 --> 00:03:07.770
>> Right, between one and four weeks.

69
00:03:07.770 --> 00:03:12.270
And so, you can see in release one we've
got four iterations in that particular

70
00:03:12.270 --> 00:03:16.840
release, and
we've got two iterations in release two.

71
00:03:16.840 --> 00:03:21.750
There's a common misconception that we
should be releasing every single iteration

72
00:03:21.750 --> 00:03:23.280
as we've got it ready.

73
00:03:24.560 --> 00:03:28.330
No, once we've got the iteration ready,
and it's complete, and we've checked its

74
00:03:28.330 --> 00:03:32.750
doneness, and we've got sign off on
the acceptance criteria, we don't go back.

75
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:38.770
And we don't reinvent the wheel,
we don't do any remedial action, we

76
00:03:38.770 --> 00:03:43.630
don't go back and revisit that iteration,
we move on to the next iteration.

77
00:03:43.630 --> 00:03:47.600
But we don't always release
that iteration immediately.

78
00:03:47.600 --> 00:03:50.940
We might bundle our iterations
together to release them.

79
00:03:50.940 --> 00:03:51.920
Because at the end of the day,

80
00:03:51.920 --> 00:03:54.880
what we're doing is delivering value
to our customers and our users.

81
00:03:54.880 --> 00:03:57.680
And we wanna make sure that we don't have

82
00:03:58.740 --> 00:04:04.130
too many iterations or
too many interruptions to them.

83
00:04:04.130 --> 00:04:07.770
Let's think about our cellphone and
our mobile phone.

84
00:04:07.770 --> 00:04:11.430
If each one of those iterations,
1 through to iteration 4, if each

85
00:04:11.430 --> 00:04:16.170
one of those took a week, then we'd be
updating our cell phone every single week.

86
00:04:17.232 --> 00:04:19.210
We kinda get a little
bit fed up with that.

87
00:04:19.210 --> 00:04:21.930
So what we're going to do is,
we'll bundle them all together, and

88
00:04:21.930 --> 00:04:27.390
we'll ensure that each release
is conducted once a month.

89
00:04:27.390 --> 00:04:28.997
So we'll bundle those four together,

90
00:04:28.997 --> 00:04:33.380
and we release those four
together as one release.

91
00:04:33.380 --> 00:04:35.470
Think about these as service packs.
>> Okay.

92
00:04:35.470 --> 00:04:39.550
>> Or think about this as maybe security

93
00:04:39.550 --> 00:04:44.048
releases or security updates,
you might want to bundle them together.

94
00:04:44.048 --> 00:04:49.430
But maybe iterations 5 and
6 might take 4 weeks each, in which

95
00:04:49.430 --> 00:04:53.220
case then we're probably gonna bundle them
together, and release them as release two.

96
00:04:54.240 --> 00:04:55.240
It's entirely up to you.

97
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:57.360
You'll decide how many iterations or

98
00:04:57.360 --> 00:05:01.650
how many timeboxes you want
to appear in each release.

99
00:05:01.650 --> 00:05:05.060
And it's probably going to be
dependent on things like priority, but

100
00:05:05.060 --> 00:05:08.200
it's also gonna be dependent
on the time scale as well.

101
00:05:09.610 --> 00:05:14.290
So an iteration is just a timebox for
producing that increment, and

102
00:05:14.290 --> 00:05:16.280
in Scrum, we refer to that as a sprint.

103
00:05:18.560 --> 00:05:25.260
So all our Agile methodologies, well,
most of them, are based on iterations.

104
00:05:25.260 --> 00:05:29.287
And that's the way we work in Agile,
is that we will release,

105
00:05:29.287 --> 00:05:31.921
we will certainly produce increments or

106
00:05:31.921 --> 00:05:37.430
iterations sort of in a period of one to
four weeks, as we've already talked about.

107
00:05:37.430 --> 00:05:41.400
The one thing that our iteration
should be is consistent in duration.

108
00:05:41.400 --> 00:05:46.190
So we don't want, one iteration of one
week, and then, the next one four weeks,

109
00:05:46.190 --> 00:05:49.100
and the next one two weeks,
and the next one four weeks.

110
00:05:49.100 --> 00:05:50.260
We want consistency.

111
00:05:50.260 --> 00:05:54.390
If we've got one or four weeks or one of
one week, and then, one of four weeks, and

112
00:05:54.390 --> 00:05:57.910
then, another one of one week,
then let's even out the stories.

113
00:05:57.910 --> 00:06:01.663
And even out the stories within each
increment, so we've got one of two weeks,

114
00:06:01.663 --> 00:06:04.307
another one of two weeks, and
another one of two weeks.

115
00:06:04.307 --> 00:06:07.900
You we're gonna say something, Cherokee.
>> Yeah, I'm a little slow Jo,

116
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:11.150
can we just back up for a second.

117
00:06:11.150 --> 00:06:14.142
And I'm asking you to repeat what you said
about the sprint, so I just want to make

118
00:06:14.142 --> 00:06:18.588
sure we're on the same page.
>> Yeah, so what I said about a sprint is

119
00:06:18.588 --> 00:06:23.820
in Scrum we call an iteration a sprint.
>> Okay, so

120
00:06:23.820 --> 00:06:27.510
our iteration is just that other word for
the timebox.

121
00:06:27.510 --> 00:06:30.130
So sprint timebox iteration-
>> It means the same thing.

122
00:06:30.130 --> 00:06:31.470
>> Okay, just want to make sure.

123
00:06:31.470 --> 00:06:33.490
>> Yeah, means exactly the same thing.

124
00:06:33.490 --> 00:06:38.590
And in terms of the exam itself,
if you're doing the foundation exam

125
00:06:38.590 --> 00:06:43.790
then you're not going to be tested
on specific Scrum methodologies

126
00:06:43.790 --> 00:06:47.380
because it's not a Scrum exam
you're doing, it's an Agile exam.

127
00:06:47.380 --> 00:06:49.500
So what we're doing is we're testing, and

128
00:06:49.500 --> 00:06:53.356
right in this particular class we're
looking at the overall concept of Agile.

129
00:06:53.356 --> 00:06:58.523
So we're looking at, if we go back to
episode one in a series where we actually

130
00:06:58.523 --> 00:07:04.007
had a diagram where we looked at the fact
that Agile was an overarching methodology

131
00:07:04.007 --> 00:07:09.574
or an overarching concept that included
methodology specific methodologies like

132
00:07:09.574 --> 00:07:13.800
Scrum, and XP and Kanban, and Lean etc.
>> Right.

133
00:07:13.800 --> 00:07:15.310
>> So what we want then is for

134
00:07:15.310 --> 00:07:21.900
consistency, we want to have all of our
iterations roughly the same in duration.

135
00:07:21.900 --> 00:07:26.690
We accept that not every iteration's
gonna be exactly the same length.

136
00:07:26.690 --> 00:07:29.460
You can't cuz it depends
what stories we're covering.

137
00:07:29.460 --> 00:07:34.014
You can't guarantee that, I mean it's IT,
we don't like to guarantee too much in IT.

138
00:07:34.014 --> 00:07:34.816
>> [LAUGH]

139
00:07:34.816 --> 00:07:37.622
>> But we can't necessarily guarantee it,

140
00:07:37.622 --> 00:07:42.674
but we want to aim for consistency,
because consistency will deliver us,

141
00:07:42.674 --> 00:07:48.226
it'll manage expectations within our
user community, and with our customers.

142
00:07:48.226 --> 00:07:53.006
It also manages expectations in
our development team as well,

143
00:07:53.006 --> 00:07:59.059
in that we know that every two weeks we're
going to be finalizing an iteration.

144
00:07:59.059 --> 00:08:00.182
You look perplexed by that.

145
00:08:00.182 --> 00:08:03.620
You don't like the idea of
expectation management?

146
00:08:03.620 --> 00:08:05.365
>> No, I think it's great.

147
00:08:05.365 --> 00:08:07.040
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

148
00:08:07.040 --> 00:08:08.520
What are you trying to say then?

149
00:08:08.520 --> 00:08:10.320
You don't see it much in the real world?

150
00:08:10.320 --> 00:08:12.929
Cuz I think we do that.
>> I just keep my expectations low,

151
00:08:12.929 --> 00:08:14.530
so I'm always happy, right?

152
00:08:14.530 --> 00:08:17.920
Remember, Jo, trying to stay happy.
>> Yeah, okay.

153
00:08:17.920 --> 00:08:20.120
And that's what we wanna
do in development.

154
00:08:20.120 --> 00:08:24.632
We wanna keep our customers happy, but
preferably not with medication that

155
00:08:24.632 --> 00:08:25.460
Cherokee's on.
>> And

156
00:08:25.460 --> 00:08:29.340
preferably with realistic expectations,
not just

157
00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:33.460
shooting below the belt every single time.
>> Yeah, and

158
00:08:33.460 --> 00:08:36.310
this is one of the things that when
it comes to project management,

159
00:08:36.310 --> 00:08:40.455
I have to say infuriates me,
it really does frustrate me.
