You want to try to make
it as simple as possible.

397
00:20:15.066 --> 00:20:18.000
Remember, keep it simple okay.

398
00:20:18.000 --> 00:20:22.060
And so this is our measurement of unit,
and if I could just take a look at all

399
00:20:22.060 --> 00:20:26.770
those yellow sticky notes that we have
there you'll see that each one of those

400
00:20:26.770 --> 00:20:29.750
stories these are story paths, remember.
>> Yes.

401
00:20:29.750 --> 00:20:32.540
>> And each one of those stories have got

402
00:20:32.540 --> 00:20:36.597
a number attached to them.
>> Story point.

403
00:20:36.597 --> 00:20:39.920
>> Right, and so our velocity for

404
00:20:39.920 --> 00:20:44.520
that sprint or for that iteration
is gonna be 28 story points,

405
00:20:44.520 --> 00:20:46.120
cuz that's all of those added together.

406
00:20:47.280 --> 00:20:50.390
Yeah, we all right?
>> Sure, yeah.

407
00:20:50.390 --> 00:20:52.360
>> You can do the math.

408
00:20:52.360 --> 00:20:53.480
>> I'm trying to think real quick and

409
00:20:53.480 --> 00:20:57.730
I'm like, okay, yeah, I believe you Jo.
>> [LAUGH] It is, we've got 28 story

410
00:20:57.730 --> 00:21:02.510
points for that particular iteration cuz
that's how many stories we're covering.

411
00:21:02.510 --> 00:21:05.810
And we're covering six
stories in that iteration.

412
00:21:05.810 --> 00:21:08.550
I see you trying to work it out again.
>> I believe you.

413
00:21:08.550 --> 00:21:09.435
>> Yeah, just trust me.

414
00:21:09.435 --> 00:21:10.910
>> [LAUGH]

415
00:21:10.910 --> 00:21:13.050
>> So now what we're going to do then,

416
00:21:13.050 --> 00:21:17.200
we can use that to calculate our velocity.

417
00:21:17.200 --> 00:21:23.330
And our velocity there is 28, it's 28
based on 28 story points per iteration.

418
00:21:23.330 --> 00:21:25.120
That's all we can achieve.
>> Okay.

419
00:21:25.120 --> 00:21:26.580
>> The other way of doing this,

420
00:21:26.580 --> 00:21:28.980
is to do it via ideal days.

421
00:21:28.980 --> 00:21:30.810
Do you remember what an ideal day was?

422
00:21:31.900 --> 00:21:34.150
>> One.
>> No.

423
00:21:34.150 --> 00:21:35.990
>> I don't know, I held up one finger and

424
00:21:35.990 --> 00:21:37.450
I said one day.
>> Right, but

425
00:21:37.450 --> 00:21:39.340
what is the definition of an ideal day?

426
00:21:40.350 --> 00:21:41.630
Man, Jo.
>> [LAUGH]

427
00:21:41.630 --> 00:21:43.420
>> I might need to refer back to

428
00:21:43.420 --> 00:21:46.874
the expert on this.
>> An ideal day is the amount of time that

429
00:21:46.874 --> 00:21:49.310
we're productive during the day.

430
00:21:49.310 --> 00:21:50.270
>> Okay, okay.

431
00:21:50.270 --> 00:21:51.130
>> Yeah?
>> Yeah.

432
00:21:51.130 --> 00:21:52.490
>> So the ideal day is when-

433
00:21:52.490 --> 00:21:54.510
>> Maybe I couldn't remember that because

434
00:21:54.510 --> 00:21:58.790
I have exceeded my ideal production for
the day.

435
00:21:58.790 --> 00:22:01.960
>> Right, okay, is that what it is?

436
00:22:01.960 --> 00:22:08.700
So we'll do is we will work out
exactly how productive we are per day.

437
00:22:08.700 --> 00:22:13.250
So in the example on the right hand side,
you'll see that we've got 6 people in our

438
00:22:13.250 --> 00:22:17.900
team, one of them is only half-time or
half, you know, they're part time.

439
00:22:17.900 --> 00:22:19.951
So we've really got five and

440
00:22:19.951 --> 00:22:21.606
a half people per day.
>> Okay.

441
00:22:21.606 --> 00:22:24.135
>> We've got 4 weeks in any

442
00:22:24.135 --> 00:22:25.982
given iteration
>> So

443
00:22:25.982 --> 00:22:31.017
you're including the entire productivity
ideal day for each team member.

444
00:22:31.017 --> 00:22:31.928
>> Right hang on.

445
00:22:31.928 --> 00:22:32.921
>> Okay.

446
00:22:32.921 --> 00:22:34.151
>> We're not there yet,

447
00:22:34.151 --> 00:22:34.927
okay?
>> Okay.

448
00:22:34.927 --> 00:22:36.467
>> So you've got 6 people,

449
00:22:36.467 --> 00:22:40.527
and we've got one who's only part time so
we've got 5.5 people.

450
00:22:40.527 --> 00:22:41.048
>> Okay.

451
00:22:41.048 --> 00:22:44.654
>> We'll give an iteration of say 4 weeks.

452
00:22:44.654 --> 00:22:50.670
But we're going to estimate that
we've got a discount rate in here.

453
00:22:50.670 --> 00:22:58.540
And the discount rate is how much time in
a percentage that we are not productive.

454
00:22:58.540 --> 00:22:59.080
So that's 50.
>> Okay.

455
00:22:59.080 --> 00:22:59.690
>> In other words,

456
00:22:59.690 --> 00:23:04.280
half of our time is not productive.
>> It seems a little high, is that normal?

457
00:23:04.280 --> 00:23:05.050
>> It's actually quite

458
00:23:05.050 --> 00:23:06.410
accurate.
>> Okay.

459
00:23:06.410 --> 00:23:07.060
>> Believe it or

460
00:23:07.060 --> 00:23:09.580
not we're not productive for
about 50% of the day.

461
00:23:09.580 --> 00:23:13.276
By the time we take in breaks,
by the time we have lunch breaks, and

462
00:23:13.276 --> 00:23:16.520
then by the time we have meetings and
disturbances, etc.

463
00:23:16.520 --> 00:23:20.586
We're actually only productive, for the
most part, unless you lock yourself away,

464
00:23:20.586 --> 00:23:23.230
youre generally unproductive for
half the day.

465
00:23:23.230 --> 00:23:27.850
How many times do you get distracted
by social media or things like

466
00:23:27.850 --> 00:23:32.163
that during the day?
>> An unnecessary amount,

467
00:23:32.163 --> 00:23:35.665
I dont know.
>> Again it's another one of these

468
00:23:35.665 --> 00:23:39.285
concepts where we'll say to you,
be realistic about this,

469
00:23:39.285 --> 00:23:40.795
be objective about this.

470
00:23:40.795 --> 00:23:42.291
Don't-
>> Sugar coat it.

471
00:23:42.291 --> 00:23:44.422
>> Right, there's no point in trying to

472
00:23:44.422 --> 00:23:49.021
pretend that you're going to be productive
for say 75% of the day, because you

473
00:23:49.021 --> 00:23:53.567
are not, and what is gonna happen is you
gonna end up with inaccurate estimates.

474
00:23:53.567 --> 00:23:54.269
>> Okay.

475
00:23:54.269 --> 00:23:56.243
>> And then inaccurate prediction.

476
00:23:56.243 --> 00:24:01.036
And you're gonna predict to say
do 15 stories when actually you

477
00:24:01.036 --> 00:24:02.614
can achieve 1 or 2.

478
00:24:02.614 --> 00:24:06.758
All right, so we've gotta be accurate
because if you're not accurate and

479
00:24:06.758 --> 00:24:10.308
you're not objective about how
much of your day is productive,

480
00:24:10.308 --> 00:24:12.628
then you miss setting the expectations.

481
00:24:12.628 --> 00:24:13.251
Right?
And

482
00:24:13.251 --> 00:24:17.080
that doesn't do good from value
perception and for value delivery.

483
00:24:17.080 --> 00:24:24.470
So if we're only then accurate for 50%
of our day, then our estimated velocity,

484
00:24:24.470 --> 00:24:29.390
if I can pronounce it,
is 5.5 people multiplied by

485
00:24:29.390 --> 00:24:35.220
4 weeks multiplied by 5,
cuz there's 5 working days in a week.

486
00:24:35.220 --> 00:24:37.212
But multiply that by 0.5,

487
00:24:37.212 --> 00:24:40.097
because we're only productive for-
>> 50%.

488
00:24:40.097 --> 00:24:40.720
>> Half of the day.

489
00:24:41.860 --> 00:24:43.786
And that gives us 55 ideal days.

490
00:24:43.786 --> 00:24:48.084
That means that we've got
55 working days from that

491
00:24:48.084 --> 00:24:51.053
particular project team per month.

492
00:24:51.053 --> 00:24:54.790
That's a four-week period, so
per four-week period, okay?

493
00:24:54.790 --> 00:24:56.630
So that would be our velocity.

494
00:24:56.630 --> 00:25:01.130
And then we use that to help us
calculate how many stories we can

495
00:25:01.130 --> 00:25:02.900
get into that velocity.

496
00:25:02.900 --> 00:25:04.220
>> Nice.
>> Yeah.

497
00:25:04.220 --> 00:25:05.780
So it actually makes sense.

498
00:25:05.780 --> 00:25:07.710
It is a bit of a calculation.

499
00:25:07.710 --> 00:25:10.560
It's also a little bit of
a rough estimate too and

500
00:25:10.560 --> 00:25:15.380
I think I said on a previous slide,
a brand new team

501
00:25:15.380 --> 00:25:19.220
that's just been formed is gonna
find it difficult to calculate this.

502
00:25:19.220 --> 00:25:22.239
Because you always like to think
you can achieve more than you can.

503
00:25:22.239 --> 00:25:23.732
>> Well, we know that.

504
00:25:23.732 --> 00:25:25.417
>> Yeah, yeah, right, right.

505
00:25:25.417 --> 00:25:29.840
[LAUGH] Okay, yeah, you always like to
think that you know more than you can.

506
00:25:29.840 --> 00:25:31.960
And I don't know who you're
trying to prove it to.

507
00:25:31.960 --> 00:25:35.940
Whether it's to yourself or whether it's
to I don't know maybe a scrum master or

508
00:25:35.940 --> 00:25:36.942
the product owner.

509
00:25:36.942 --> 00:25:39.999
Hey, look at me,
I'm more productive than I think, and

510
00:25:39.999 --> 00:25:43.758
the reality of the situation is that
you get into it with enthusiasm and

511
00:25:43.758 --> 00:25:47.071
you may be really productive at
the start at that iteration but

512
00:25:47.071 --> 00:25:51.045
then as the iteration moves on,
then that productivity might just wane.

513
00:25:51.045 --> 00:25:54.620
So be realistic.
>> Okay.

514
00:25:54.620 --> 00:25:56.297
>> So that's our iteration, so

515
00:25:56.297 --> 00:26:00.128
we've already actually covered
the release and what a release is.

516
00:26:00.128 --> 00:26:04.944
And a release is what we choose
to release at that point in time.

517
00:26:04.944 --> 00:26:10.882
And it can be one iteration or
it can be up to four or five iterations.

518
00:26:10.882 --> 00:26:14.008
Okay?
It just says simply that a release

519
00:26:14.008 --> 00:26:16.810
contains one or more iterations.

520
00:26:18.330 --> 00:26:21.410
You make that decision,
we can't make that decision for you.

521
00:26:21.410 --> 00:26:22.810
You'll make that decision.

522
00:26:22.810 --> 00:26:26.090
But what you must do is
you must plan the release.

523
00:26:27.440 --> 00:26:32.609
When do you think you plan the release?
>> When

524
00:26:32.609 --> 00:26:37.865
you're planning your iteration.
>> Really?

525
00:26:37.865 --> 00:26:39.008
>> Hold on, let me.

526
00:26:39.008 --> 00:26:40.550
>> Take a look at that bottom bullet point

527
00:26:40.550 --> 00:26:44.720
on the screen in front of you.
>> Release plans for immediate future

528
00:26:44.720 --> 00:26:48.410
are more accurate, release plans for
the immediate future are more accurate.

529
00:26:48.410 --> 00:26:50.470
Farther out the release.

530
00:26:50.470 --> 00:26:53.800
So immediate future,
what would classify as immediate future?

531
00:26:53.800 --> 00:26:56.080
>> Right, so that would be your iteration.

532
00:26:56.080 --> 00:27:01.480
So if your release has only got, say,
for instance, one iteration in it.

533
00:27:01.480 --> 00:27:03.600
And I'm going back to this example here.

534
00:27:03.600 --> 00:27:05.500
If your release has only
got one iteration in it,

535
00:27:05.500 --> 00:27:08.580
then your release plan is
going to be very accurate.

536
00:27:08.580 --> 00:27:12.438
But let's say your release has
got four iterations in it.

537
00:27:12.438 --> 00:27:14.784
Four times four weeks,
>> Right, release one pass.

538
00:27:14.784 --> 00:27:17.300
>> Right, that's 16 weeks potentially for

539
00:27:17.300 --> 00:27:18.600
1 release pack.

540
00:27:18.600 --> 00:27:22.150
So right at the beginning, you're gonna
have an idea as to what's going to be in

541
00:27:22.150 --> 00:27:23.376
your release.
>> Correct.

542
00:27:23.376 --> 00:27:25.121
>> But you're really not going to have

543
00:27:25.121 --> 00:27:29.018
a plan for exactly what's going to be in
that release until a lot closer to the end

544
00:27:29.018 --> 00:27:31.234
of Iteration 4.
>> Right, because 16 weeks,

545
00:27:31.234 --> 00:27:33.130
a lot can happen in that time.
>> Yeah, and

546
00:27:33.130 --> 00:27:35.340
that's exactly what we're saying there.
>> Okay.

547
00:27:35.340 --> 00:27:37.300
>> So your release plan

548
00:27:37.300 --> 00:27:40.530
could be based on team's velocity or
work estimates.

549
00:27:40.530 --> 00:27:43.760
If they are not accurate in
your estimates, then yes,

550
00:27:43.760 --> 00:27:47.660
your release is going to change and
things like your minimal viable product.

551
00:27:47.660 --> 00:27:52.000
What is it that we have to release and
what can we leave in the backlog?

552
00:27:52.000 --> 00:27:54.470
Because there are some things,
and don't get me wrong,

553
00:27:54.470 --> 00:27:57.850
when it comes to an agile project,
it's no different to anything else.

554
00:27:57.850 --> 00:28:01.560
You get to the end of an iteration and
you can't necessarily deliver

555
00:28:01.560 --> 00:28:05.680
everything that you set out to do
because maybe testing failed or

556
00:28:05.680 --> 00:28:08.470
because maybe there's some other issue.

557
00:28:08.470 --> 00:28:13.040
So it's only as we get towards
the end of that final iteration that

558
00:28:13.040 --> 00:28:17.418
we're able to really confirm what
it is that we're going to release.

559
00:28:17.418 --> 00:28:24.280
What we've gotta make sure
that we do is that we must

560
00:28:24.280 --> 00:28:28.450
plan our releases to align with
the organization as a whole and

561
00:28:28.450 --> 00:28:32.010
to align with their objectives and
make sure that we're

562
00:28:33.520 --> 00:28:37.610
in tune with the organization and
what the organization wants.

563
00:28:37.610 --> 00:28:41.482
That's what we've gotta do, we've gotta
keep them happy, we're delivering value.

564
00:28:41.482 --> 00:28:44.220
And we're delivering value
by way of new product.

565
00:28:44.220 --> 00:28:48.320
And so we've gotta make sure that we,
if especially they have a deadline,

566
00:28:48.320 --> 00:28:49.810
that we are aligned to that deadline.

567
00:28:49.810 --> 00:28:50.820
Some deadlines,

568
00:28:50.820 --> 00:28:54.800
when we talked about constraints in
a previous episode, we looked at, say,

569
00:28:54.800 --> 00:28:57.020
regulatory constraints for instance.
>> Right.

570
00:28:57.020 --> 00:28:59.320
>> Some deadlines can't be moved.

571
00:28:59.320 --> 00:29:01.120
So we've gotta make sure
that we're aligned to that,

572
00:29:01.120 --> 00:29:05.470
that we're fully aware of that, and that
it's actually part of our project as well.

573
00:29:06.800 --> 00:29:11.320
So that's how we plan a release, okay?

574
00:29:11.320 --> 00:29:14.160
And how we plan an iteration.

575
00:29:14.160 --> 00:29:17.300
And so what's coming up next is, well,

576
00:29:17.300 --> 00:29:20.832
looking at the contents of an iteration.
>> Okay.

577
00:29:20.832 --> 00:29:25.620
All right, so if you really kind of
narrowing or zooming in on a particular

578
00:29:25.620 --> 00:29:29.960
granular component here, so don't miss
that ladies and gentlemen, but for

579
00:29:29.960 --> 00:29:32.190
now let's go ahead and
sign out of the show.

580
00:29:32.190 --> 00:29:34.964
I've been your host Cherokee Boobse.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

581
00:29:34.964 --> 00:29:37.567
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

582
00:29:37.567 --> 00:29:43.523
[MUSIC]

583
00:29:43.523 --> 00:29:46.653
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: All user stories may carry a degree of risk and this episode we discuss the importance of identifying risk and managing risk within the Agile project.
episodes.title: Risk Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2

3

4
00:00:08.563 --> 00:00:12.860
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome, everyone,

to your
Agile Project Management Concepts Theory.

00:00:15.730 --> 00:00:17.590
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.590 --> 00:00:20.862
In this episode we'll be taking a look at
something that I think is really cool,

8
00:00:20.862 --> 00:00:23.890
it's something that we really
need to address and discuss here.

9
00:00:23.890 --> 00:00:27.370
This is going to be risk management,
and of course we have Mrs.

10
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:29.970
Jo Peacock in studios to cover this topic.

11
00:00:31.260 --> 00:00:35.650
On a scale of one to ten Jo- [LAUGH]
>> If you're gonna ask me how cool

12
00:00:35.650 --> 00:00:37.610
risk management is, well-
>> No,

13
00:00:37.610 --> 00:00:42.038
I was gonna say you know what is the risk
to my health that this show may pose?

14
00:00:42.038 --> 00:00:43.152
>> It depends.

15
00:00:43.152 --> 00:00:44.260
>> [LAUGH]

16
00:00:44.260 --> 00:00:46.100
>> If you carry on annoying me,

17
00:00:47.790 --> 00:00:50.690
the risk is gonna be quite high.
>> All right, then I'll stop,

18
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:55.620
because you do scare me.
>> [LAUGH] Wel gee, thanks for that.

19
00:00:55.620 --> 00:00:57.270
I really don't know what to say to that.

20
00:00:57.270 --> 00:00:59.550
Yeah, okay, but
it's not actually the risk.

21
00:01:00.770 --> 00:01:02.810
On a scale of one to
ten it's not the risk.

22
00:01:02.810 --> 00:01:05.110
It's the likelihood of
that risk occurring.

23
00:01:05.110 --> 00:01:06.205
>> Yeah you're right.

24
00:01:06.205 --> 00:01:09.610
[LAUGH]
>> So the risk is that my patience

25
00:01:09.610 --> 00:01:13.940
runs out and I lose my tolerance.
>> Take things into your own hands.

26
00:01:13.940 --> 00:01:15.400
>> Right, yeah, yeah,

27
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:17.740
and the risk is that I might do something.

28
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:20.910
I might do something that might
involve walking away, and

29
00:01:20.910 --> 00:01:22.918
that's just the nice version, right?

30
00:01:22.918 --> 00:01:23.534
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

31
00:01:23.534 --> 00:01:25.710
[LAUGH]
>> But it's the likelihood this thing that

32
00:01:25.710 --> 00:01:27.180
we're gonna worry about.
>> Exactly.

33
00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:28.480
>> And it's the combination of the risk

34
00:01:28.480 --> 00:01:31.160
and the likelihood and
that's what we've gotta mitigate against.

35
00:01:31.160 --> 00:01:33.500
So you see,
we have to mitigate against this, and

36
00:01:33.500 --> 00:01:37.425
I know that how we mitigate against
risks is by not giving you caffeine.

37
00:01:37.425 --> 00:01:39.180
>> [LAUGH]

38
00:01:39.180 --> 00:01:41.200
>> That's how we mitigating against it.

39
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:41.870
>> Okay.

40
00:01:41.870 --> 00:01:43.920
>> So yeah, you're right Cherokee in this

41
00:01:43.920 --> 00:01:48.280
particular episode, we're actually gonna
be looking a risk management and more

42
00:01:48.280 --> 00:01:54.480
importantly, identifying risks and making
decisions is to what we do with risk.

43
00:01:54.480 --> 00:01:58.310
So the first thing that I guess we've
gotta do is identify what a risk is.

44
00:01:58.310 --> 00:02:01.410
We've been talking about all of this.
>> Yeah, I'm just assuming that everyone

45
00:02:01.410 --> 00:02:04.080
knows, but that's not always the case.
>> It's not always the case,

46
00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:06.290
and especially not in IT either.

00:02:06.290 --> 00:02:09.060
It can be very difficult to define risk.

00:02:09.060 --> 00:02:11.640
A risk is something that might or

00:02:11.640 --> 00:02:17.080

impact the outcome if it does occur.

50
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:20.240
But risk can either be positive or
they can be negative.

51
00:02:20.240 --> 00:02:21.370
>> That is true.

52
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:23.330
>> Right so

00:02:23.330 --> 00:02:28.370
we've got to work as a team and

00:02:28.370 --> 00:02:33.670

to our development work.

55
00:02:33.670 --> 00:02:36.620
So a risk could be absolutely anything.

00:02:36.620 --> 00:02:39.490
And we look at the risks
of something happening but

00:02:39.490 --> 00:02:42.750

00:02:42.750 --> 00:02:46.420
Which is why we are talking about risks

00:02:46.420 --> 00:02:51.345

the solution could be higher

00:02:51.345 --> 00:02:54.685

00:02:54.685 --> 00:02:57.825
You see if we implement a solution

64
00:03:06.863 --> 00:03:10.069

00:03:11.870 --> 00:03:16.090

Management of risk,

The likelihood and even the impact

00:14:26.870 --> 00:14:28.560
And it's gotta be somebody
within the team as well.

283
00:14:29.940 --> 00:14:31.633
>> I know it's kinda crazy, but

284
00:14:31.633 --> 00:14:33.190
I remember hearing this for

285
00:14:33.190 --> 00:14:36.720
the first time that even avoiding
it is a possibility as well.

286
00:14:36.720 --> 00:14:41.563
So if you have risk avoidance, you could
basically just be saying, hey, our quarter

287
00:14:41.563 --> 00:14:45.956
one budget doesn't allow for this
particular control at this point in time.

288
00:14:45.956 --> 00:14:48.850
So we're going to avoid it for
this quarter.

289
00:14:48.850 --> 00:14:51.700
We'll come back and look at it second
quarter when our budget reups.

290
00:14:51.700 --> 00:14:53.849
>> Right, or you might that avoidance or

291
00:14:53.849 --> 00:14:56.216
you might call that just delay.
>> Delay, okay.

292
00:14:56.216 --> 00:14:57.876
>> We're just trying to delay that risk.

293
00:14:57.876 --> 00:15:00.674
Yeah, but it's up to you.

294
00:15:00.674 --> 00:15:04.880
It's up to you to decide what
you want to do with that risk.

295
00:15:04.880 --> 00:15:06.520
But it has to be documented.

296
00:15:06.520 --> 00:15:09.750
And somebody has to take ownership
of that specific risk and

297
00:15:09.750 --> 00:15:12.410
somebody has to document what it is.

298
00:15:12.410 --> 00:15:15.890
We've got to agree what we're
going to do with that risk.

299
00:15:15.890 --> 00:15:18.050
And if we're going to do
anything with the risk.

300
00:15:18.050 --> 00:15:20.340
If we're actually going to
undertake any activities,

301
00:15:20.340 --> 00:15:22.880
then of course they've got
to be planned out as well.

302
00:15:22.880 --> 00:15:26.630
You don't just wave a magic wand and
things happen.

303
00:15:26.630 --> 00:15:29.990
So we have residual risks and
we have secondary risks.

304
00:15:29.990 --> 00:15:35.060
And a residual risk is that portion
of the risk that's still left over

305
00:15:35.060 --> 00:15:38.220
after we have taken any actions.

306
00:15:38.220 --> 00:15:43.290
So, a residual risk is, let's say we've
installed a sprinkler system, but

307
00:15:43.290 --> 00:15:46.520
there may still be some
portion of risk left over.

308
00:15:46.520 --> 00:15:49.538
That's considered to be a residual risk.

309
00:15:49.538 --> 00:15:52.742
A fire could still start after we
have installed a sprinkler system.

310
00:15:52.742 --> 00:15:54.263
>> [LAUGH] True.

311
00:15:54.263 --> 00:15:57.417
>> So that's the residual risk.

312
00:15:57.417 --> 00:16:02.354
But a secondary risk is the entire reason
why sprinkler systems aren't really

313
00:16:02.354 --> 00:16:03.630
big in Europe.

314
00:16:03.630 --> 00:16:08.660
Because the secondary risk is a new
risk that's introduced by the actions.

315
00:16:08.660 --> 00:16:14.753
So we bring in a sprinkler system to try
and mitigate against the risk of fire,

316
00:16:14.753 --> 00:16:20.300
and what we actually do is cause flooding.
>> Shorting out our electrical equipment?

317
00:16:20.300 --> 00:16:21.080
>> Right, and

318
00:16:21.080 --> 00:16:24.746
this is why they're in various places,
like in the UK,

319
00:16:24.746 --> 00:16:29.738
they would be considered to be the fact
is the secondary risk is considered to

320
00:16:29.738 --> 00:16:33.101
actually cause more damage
than the primary risk.

321
00:16:33.101 --> 00:16:36.820
And so, therefore, we don't tend
to use those sprinkler systems.

322
00:16:36.820 --> 00:16:37.516
>> More like a halon or

323
00:16:37.516 --> 00:16:41.008
some kind of gas system.
>> Right, we'd use something like that

324
00:16:41.008 --> 00:16:46.168
perhaps, or we'd use other ways,
such as isolating the fire completely.

325
00:16:46.168 --> 00:16:51.690
So yeah, we've got various different
ways of mitigating against risk.

326
00:16:51.690 --> 00:16:54.294
But just remember that you might
mitigate against one particular risk and

327
00:16:54.294 --> 00:16:56.975
you might introduce another one.
>> Introduce another one.

328
00:16:56.975 --> 00:16:57.885
>> Right, okay,

329
00:16:57.885 --> 00:17:02.295
so we've got to assess every single risk,
whether it's secondary risk,

330
00:17:02.295 --> 00:17:04.440
primary risk or residual risk.

331
00:17:04.440 --> 00:17:07.655
It's all gotta be assessed, and
it's all got to be documented.

332
00:17:07.655 --> 00:17:11.891
It's all got to be accounted for.

333
00:17:11.891 --> 00:17:16.051
Now, of course, with any project,
we've always got constraints, and

334
00:17:16.051 --> 00:17:19.700
we've talked about constraints
with all of our projects.

335
00:17:19.700 --> 00:17:22.070
You might even consider
these to be a risk as well.

336
00:17:23.310 --> 00:17:26.520
With any project, we've got the scope of
the project,, we've got schedule, and

337
00:17:26.520 --> 00:17:29.830
we've got the budget of
our project as well.

338
00:17:29.830 --> 00:17:34.040
Invariably, the budget and
the schedule are fixed, but

339
00:17:34.040 --> 00:17:37.100
it's the scope that's actually flexible.

340
00:17:37.100 --> 00:17:42.180
And we mentioned this when we talk
about risk management, because what

341
00:17:42.180 --> 00:17:46.830
we've gotta make sure is that we meet
budget and that we meet schedule.

342
00:17:46.830 --> 00:17:52.400
But we've also gotta consider how much
scope we introduce as part of that.

343
00:17:52.400 --> 00:17:55.650
If our budget is so small and

344
00:17:55.650 --> 00:18:01.340
our schedule is so short, then we might
not be able to deliver anything at all.

345
00:18:01.340 --> 00:18:07.390
So we really need to ensure that,
it's part of risk management,

346
00:18:07.390 --> 00:18:12.030
but it's managing stakeholder expectation
cause that in itself is a risk.

347
00:18:12.030 --> 00:18:15.294
We run the risk of over-promising and
then under-delivering, and

348
00:18:15.294 --> 00:18:17.100
that's exactly what we don't want.

349
00:18:17.100 --> 00:18:19.160
We want to deliver value.

350
00:18:19.160 --> 00:18:23.070
So we have to ensure that all of
our stories are prioritized, and

351
00:18:23.070 --> 00:18:26.680
that we are able to, and
when we talk about overestimation and

352
00:18:26.680 --> 00:18:31.190
underestimation in previous episodes,
we're able to accurately relate

353
00:18:31.190 --> 00:18:35.360
to our stakeholders and
to our customers what we can produce for

354
00:18:35.360 --> 00:18:41.920
them with each iteration given the time
and the budget constraints that we have.

355
00:18:41.920 --> 00:18:45.510
That's why we've gotta be really
accurate in our estimating.

356
00:18:46.990 --> 00:18:49.350
And I say accurate, but
accurate within tolerances, and

357
00:18:49.350 --> 00:18:52.090
we've gotta be really
objective with our estimating.

358
00:18:52.090 --> 00:18:54.900
In our previous episode,
we looked at ideal days, and

359
00:18:54.900 --> 00:18:57.699
we looked at sort of productive
time in our ideal days.

360
00:18:58.990 --> 00:19:03.730
Be realistic, be objective about it,
and let's welcome the premise

361
00:19:03.730 --> 00:19:08.500
that we're only really productive for
50% of our working day.

362
00:19:08.500 --> 00:19:11.430
And that some days we're gonna be
productive for a little bit more.

363
00:19:11.430 --> 00:19:15.460
But some days we might get distracted and
we might even be productive for less.

364
00:19:15.460 --> 00:19:18.290
So be realistic,
because it's only then that you can

365
00:19:18.290 --> 00:19:22.560
manage stakeholder expectations and
manage customer expectations as well.

366
00:19:24.395 --> 00:19:29.251
Now, of course, Agile is a methodology
where we work on iterations.

367
00:19:29.251 --> 00:19:32.675
So we do adopt a just-in-time approach.

368
00:19:32.675 --> 00:19:37.283
And so this fail fast and get-it-done
quick, that actually applies to help us

369
00:19:37.283 --> 00:19:41.775
reduce risk, which means that we've
gotta identify failure immediately.

370
00:19:41.775 --> 00:19:43.295
We've got to identify risk.

371
00:19:43.295 --> 00:19:47.940
And we've got to identify where somethings
going to go wrong and then fix it, and

372
00:19:47.940 --> 00:19:49.370
fix it now.

373
00:19:49.370 --> 00:19:53.230
And we consider those risks
in our story prioritization.

374
00:19:53.230 --> 00:19:55.400
How much of a risk is this story?

375
00:19:55.400 --> 00:19:58.270
How much of a risk do we have

376
00:19:58.270 --> 00:20:01.810
to our current infrastructure
by implementing this story?

377
00:20:03.110 --> 00:20:05.000
And you don't just forget about a risk.

378
00:20:05.000 --> 00:20:07.290
You can't just forget about a risk.

379
00:20:07.290 --> 00:20:10.730
Just because you have identified
a risk and you've assessed it and

380
00:20:10.730 --> 00:20:14.010
you've decided what to do about it,
you don't just then forget about it.

381
00:20:14.010 --> 00:20:16.200
You just say, well, okay, well,
I've documented it, that's it.

382
00:20:16.200 --> 00:20:17.682
We can just move on.

383
00:20:17.682 --> 00:20:20.890
And the fact of the matter is that
even though you've documented this and

384
00:20:20.890 --> 00:20:23.370
you've documented your plan,
it still could happen.

385
00:20:24.700 --> 00:20:26.900
So we need to be aware of this.

386
00:20:26.900 --> 00:20:31.540
And all of our mitigation actions,
if we're going to implement any mitigation

387
00:20:31.540 --> 00:20:35.210
actions, they've got to be added
to the backlog as activities.

388
00:20:35.210 --> 00:20:39.110
They've got to go into
iterations at some point.

389
00:20:39.110 --> 00:20:43.340
So risk is not something
that can just be ignored.

390
00:20:43.340 --> 00:20:46.695
Even though we might accept risk,
we can't just ignore risk.

391
00:20:48.220 --> 00:20:50.320
So in this particular episode,

392
00:20:50.320 --> 00:20:56.990
we've taken a very brief look at risk
management for out Agile project.

393
00:20:56.990 --> 00:20:59.820
And when we come back,
in our next episode,

394
00:20:59.820 --> 00:21:05.850
we're going to be delving deeper into
our project iteration and working

395
00:21:05.850 --> 00:21:08.600
towards getting our project completed.
>> All right,

396
00:21:08.600 --> 00:21:11.190
it sounds like you've
thoroughly planned that out.

397
00:21:11.190 --> 00:21:13.773
You've taken full account of all

398
00:21:13.773 --> 00:21:16.788
the risks possible.
>> Planned only in the short term

399
00:21:16.788 --> 00:21:17.598
though, right?

400
00:21:17.598 --> 00:21:19.620
Yeah, we haven't planned the long term,
yeah.

401
00:21:19.620 --> 00:21:21.188
>> We've got an idea of what we're gonna

402
00:21:21.188 --> 00:21:23.602
do in the next episode, but
that could change folks, so.

403
00:21:23.602 --> 00:21:26.133
>> Right, that's our interation.

404
00:21:26.133 --> 00:21:27.490
>> Awesome, well, thank you, Jo.

405
00:21:27.490 --> 00:21:30.080
And thank you for joining us as well,
but let's sign out.

406
00:21:30.080 --> 00:21:32.510
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

407
00:21:32.510 --> 00:21:34.631
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

408
00:21:34.631 --> 00:21:40.436
[MUSIC]

409
00:21:40.436 --> 00:21:43.466
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: Without effective and efficient communication projects will fail and in this episode we explore the importance of planning regular communication and look at techniques and tools such as information radiators.
episodes.title: Planning Communication
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.902
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.902 --> 00:00:08.324
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.324 --> 00:00:12.028
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.028 --> 00:00:12.645
>> Welcome to

5
00:00:12.645 --> 00:00:15.590
your Agile Project Management Concepts
series.

6
00:00:15.590 --> 00:00:17.710
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.710 --> 00:00:20.350
In this episode we'll be talking
about something very important.

8
00:00:20.350 --> 00:00:23.720
We'll be looking at, well,
planning communication.

9
00:00:23.720 --> 00:00:26.100
And nothing worse than
having poor communication,

10
00:00:26.100 --> 00:00:28.010
especially here within our teams.

11
00:00:28.010 --> 00:00:31.630
So with us today we have Jo Peacock
to help deliver this topic.

12
00:00:31.630 --> 00:00:34.238
How's it going, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, thank you, Cherokee.

13
00:00:34.238 --> 00:00:36.120
How are you?
>> I'm doing well.

14
00:00:36.120 --> 00:00:40.280
And I see that we're able to communicate
effectively as of the moment, but

15
00:00:40.280 --> 00:00:42.286
I'm looking to enhance those skills.
>> Well,

16
00:00:42.286 --> 00:00:45.762
we always start off with that first
question when it comes to communication,

17
00:00:45.762 --> 00:00:47.390
don't we?
>> What's the first question?

18
00:00:47.390 --> 00:00:48.580
>> The first question is always about

19
00:00:48.580 --> 00:00:49.390
language, isn't it?

20
00:00:49.390 --> 00:00:51.743
What language do we communicate in?
>> That's right,

21
00:00:51.743 --> 00:00:54.817
we've already learned this.
>> You've learned this many times.

22
00:00:54.817 --> 00:00:57.364
It hasn't sunk in, but
you've learned this many times.

23
00:00:57.364 --> 00:00:59.865
So Cherokee,
what language do we communicate in?

24
00:00:59.865 --> 00:01:01.491
>> The language of the audience.

25
00:01:01.491 --> 00:01:05.434
>> Hey look at that, it has sunk in.

26
00:01:05.434 --> 00:01:09.300
Well, we're still working on
the application, but it's sunk in.

27
00:01:09.300 --> 00:01:12.510
Yeah, we always communicate in
the language of the audience.

28
00:01:12.510 --> 00:01:16.360
But at the same time,
we've got to plan effective communication.

29
00:01:16.360 --> 00:01:19.010
If we communicate in an ad hoc way,

30
00:01:19.010 --> 00:01:22.040
bearing in mind that Agile is
looking at efficiencies here.

31
00:01:22.040 --> 00:01:24.050
If we communicate in an ad hoc way,

32
00:01:24.050 --> 00:01:28.810
if we communicate in a way that
is just completely disorganized.

33
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:33.012
Then what's going to happen is that
everybody is going to be subject to

34
00:01:33.012 --> 00:01:34.091
interruptions.

35
00:01:34.091 --> 00:01:37.389
All of the recipients, or
the audience for any communication,

36
00:01:37.389 --> 00:01:41.190
are going to be unsure of what
the message is that's being communicated.

37
00:01:41.190 --> 00:01:45.352
And they're also not going to know
whether any communication is important or

38
00:01:45.352 --> 00:01:47.025
whether it's not important.

39
00:01:47.025 --> 00:01:51.450
So it is really important that
we plan our communication.

40
00:01:51.450 --> 00:01:54.260
So in this particular episode,
we're going to be looking at

41
00:01:54.260 --> 00:01:57.680
various methods of communication
within an Agile project.

42
00:01:57.680 --> 00:02:03.170
And it's not just by talking,
it's actually by planning and

43
00:02:03.170 --> 00:02:06.450
using what we call information radiators,
and we're going to look at those.

44
00:02:07.840 --> 00:02:11.800
And making sure that those information
radiators are planned and are used

45
00:02:11.800 --> 00:02:17.610
effectively as well as efficiently, so
that we are all working at our optimum.

46
00:02:17.610 --> 00:02:20.790
We talked in previous episodes
about having ideal days.

47
00:02:20.790 --> 00:02:26.118
Do you remember what an ideal day was?
>> Yes, we went through that algorithm or

48
00:02:26.118 --> 00:02:30.983
the equation to look at how to set that
up to determine the amount of hours

49
00:02:30.983 --> 00:02:35.600
that were actually usable where
we were really productive.

50
00:02:35.600 --> 00:02:37.390
>> Right, it's about productive times.

51
00:02:37.390 --> 00:02:42.230
And we'll use time management to help us
to make the most of our productive time.

52
00:02:42.230 --> 00:02:48.630
But an ideal day in terms of a project
is the productive part of our day.

53
00:02:48.630 --> 00:02:53.540
So do you remember how much time
we said that we were actually

54
00:02:53.540 --> 00:02:54.270
productive?

55
00:02:54.270 --> 00:02:55.060
>> During a day?

56
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:55.700
>> Yeah.
>> An

57
00:02:55.700 --> 00:02:56.826
individual?
>> Mm-hm.

58
00:02:56.826 --> 00:02:57.859
>> 50%.

59
00:02:57.859 --> 00:02:59.809
>> Right, only about half of a working

60
00:02:59.809 --> 00:03:02.090
day we're actually really productive.

61
00:03:02.090 --> 00:03:05.110
The rest of the time, we're distracted.

62
00:03:05.110 --> 00:03:08.880
We're distracted by meetings maybe,
even our stand up meeting,

63
00:03:08.880 --> 00:03:10.440
which we're going to have
a look at in a moment.

64
00:03:10.440 --> 00:03:12.028
Even our stand up meeting,

65
00:03:12.028 --> 00:03:15.628
that's a part of a day where
we're not actually productive.

66
00:03:15.628 --> 00:03:22.480
Even though it's part of the project, it's
something that happens where we are not.

67
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:26.407
It's only 15 minutes, but that's 15
minutes that we're not actually developing

68
00:03:26.407 --> 00:03:29.480
anything, that we're not
working on the project itself.

69
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:34.620
So everything that we do takes,
just chips away,

70
00:03:34.620 --> 00:03:38.110
just takes a little bit away
from our eight hours per day.

71
00:03:38.110 --> 00:03:45.010
And communication is a real important
time waster, as is social media as well,

72
00:03:45.010 --> 00:03:48.670
and all of the other distractions
that we know that we also come to.

73
00:03:48.670 --> 00:03:52.995
But at the end of the day, we've got
to make sure that we are productive.

74
00:03:52.995 --> 00:03:56.944
And that means that if we can minimize
the amount of time that we spend

75
00:03:56.944 --> 00:04:01.173
either communicating with, or
reading and receiving communication,

76
00:04:01.173 --> 00:04:05.340
then that's only going to work
to the benefit of the project.

77
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:07.690
And if it works to
the benefit of the project,

78
00:04:07.690 --> 00:04:10.710
then it's going to deliver
value to our customer.

79
00:04:10.710 --> 00:04:14.567
So plan your communication and
basic time management as well.

80
00:04:14.567 --> 00:04:16.331
Plan when you're going to read or

81
00:04:16.331 --> 00:04:19.485
when you're going to perform
your communication as well.

82
00:04:19.485 --> 00:04:25.290
So don't just plan when you're going to
send it or how often you're going to send.

83
00:04:25.290 --> 00:04:28.750
So we're going to send communication
out to our users once a week,

84
00:04:28.750 --> 00:04:33.040
you should also plan when you're going
to compile that communication too.

85
00:04:33.040 --> 00:04:36.782
So everything should be planned,
that allows us to be more productive.

86
00:04:36.782 --> 00:04:42.069
So our project managers, or if we're
in a SCRUM project, then our SCRUM

87
00:04:42.069 --> 00:04:46.940
masters have got to communicate
on a regular and continual basis.

88
00:04:48.010 --> 00:04:49.980
We've also got that role
of product owner as well.

89
00:04:49.980 --> 00:04:54.391
And the product owner is responsible for
what?

90
00:04:54.391 --> 00:04:55.657
>> The product.

91
00:04:55.657 --> 00:04:56.179
>> Right, sorry,

92
00:04:56.179 --> 00:04:57.990
I like putting her on the spot.
>> [LAUGH]

93
00:04:57.990 --> 00:04:58.766
>> [LAUGH] I wanna see if

94
00:04:58.766 --> 00:05:00.460
she's been paying attention.

95
00:05:00.460 --> 00:05:04.860
But the product owner is responsible for
the functionality

96
00:05:04.860 --> 00:05:09.560
of the actual product itself,
of what it is that we are developing.

97
00:05:09.560 --> 00:05:12.760
So do you think he communicates?
>> Of course.

98
00:05:12.760 --> 00:05:13.880
>> Right, in fact,

99
00:05:13.880 --> 00:05:19.036
in a previous episode we looked at sort of
estimating, and we looked at estimating

100
00:05:19.036 --> 00:05:24.140
our stories, and estimating how long it's
going to take us to complete a story.

101
00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:26.309

00:18:21.930 --> 00:18:27.140
per iteration, or as iterations progress.
>> Right, so the plan is that

331
00:18:27.140 --> 00:18:33.430
we should be hovering around the 300 mark.
>> But a project in reality doesn't often

332
00:18:33.430 --> 00:18:38.780
start with 300 stories, because what we do
at the beginning of a project, remember,

333
00:18:38.780 --> 00:18:41.540
iteration zero in a previous episode?
>> The planning.

334
00:18:41.540 --> 00:18:44.210
>> That's when we do all of our planning.

335
00:18:44.210 --> 00:18:48.180
And with each iteration,
we will then look and

336
00:18:48.180 --> 00:18:53.250
we visit the problem statement again, and
we look at the stories that we've got

337
00:18:53.250 --> 00:18:56.760
still outstanding that we haven't
completed, and also new stories.

338
00:18:56.760 --> 00:18:59.790
Remember, an agile project
is adaptive to change.

339
00:18:59.790 --> 00:19:03.680
So we add in new requirements,
we add in new requests.

340
00:19:04.690 --> 00:19:09.930
So we expect our backlog to grow
in this particular instance.

341
00:19:11.550 --> 00:19:12.700
>> Seems pretty accurate.

342
00:19:12.700 --> 00:19:14.545
>> Right, yeah, you're grinning there,

343
00:19:14.545 --> 00:19:15.130
I like that!

344
00:19:15.130 --> 00:19:19.162
[LAUGH] Yeah,
that's exactly what we should be doing,

345
00:19:19.162 --> 00:19:24.230
is that we should be planning accurately,
we should be expecting.

346
00:19:24.230 --> 00:19:29.490
If we think that this is a project where
expectations are going to change or

347
00:19:29.490 --> 00:19:32.550
requirements are going to change,
then we should be planning for that.

348
00:19:32.550 --> 00:19:36.940
We should be acknowledging that that's
going to happen rather than say, right,

349
00:19:36.940 --> 00:19:40.070
okay, this is all we want to
deliberate at the very start.

350
00:19:40.070 --> 00:19:42.220
And then cast it in stone and
leave it at that.

351
00:19:42.220 --> 00:19:44.260
That's the traditional waterfall approach.

352
00:19:45.760 --> 00:19:51.280
So we have to take responsibility for
effective and efficient communication.

353
00:19:51.280 --> 00:19:55.900
So we wanna focus on sort of
targeted communications, but

354
00:19:55.900 --> 00:19:58.390
we wanna focus on clear, concise and

355
00:19:58.390 --> 00:20:03.470
unambiguous communications that answer
those questions, what's in it for me?

356
00:20:03.470 --> 00:20:05.300
If you're gonna bring me to a meeting,

357
00:20:05.300 --> 00:20:09.090
you're gonna invite me to a meeting,
I need to be there for a reason.

358
00:20:09.090 --> 00:20:14.590
If I'm there just to sort of sit in
the corner and twiddle my thumbs,

359
00:20:14.590 --> 00:20:16.640
then that's not a productive
use of my time.

360
00:20:17.890 --> 00:20:21.390
So all forms of communication,
even those emails,

361
00:20:21.390 --> 00:20:23.700
have got to answer what's in it for me.

362
00:20:23.700 --> 00:20:27.440
And I know I've asked you this before, but
how many emails, what percentage of emails

363
00:20:27.440 --> 00:20:31.020
do you delete without even opening?
>> Quite a bit.

364
00:20:31.020 --> 00:20:32.330
I know you said you were at 90.

365
00:20:32.330 --> 00:20:36.350
I don't think I'm, maybe for
that particular email account, but for

366
00:20:36.350 --> 00:20:40.040
work emails it's going to be less,
but it's still rather high.

367
00:20:40.040 --> 00:20:41.614
>> Right, and so I find, and

368
00:20:41.614 --> 00:20:46.410
this is just me personally, and it's a
recommendation that we do make with a lot

369
00:20:46.410 --> 00:20:50.152
of sort of organizations that
deal with external customers.

370
00:20:50.152 --> 00:20:54.920
We'll have two different email addresses,
one that's an internal email address.

371
00:20:54.920 --> 00:20:59.484
It's for all of our work and our internal
communications, and more specifically,

372
00:20:59.484 --> 00:21:04.570
sort of for the project communication or
any internal work issues.

373
00:21:04.570 --> 00:21:08.500
And you can do this by just having
two mailboxes within one account, for

374
00:21:08.500 --> 00:21:09.490
instance, and

375
00:21:09.490 --> 00:21:14.260
having rules in place so that we can
filter certain emails that come in.

376
00:21:14.260 --> 00:21:15.400
In our internal emails,

377
00:21:15.400 --> 00:21:19.370
we probably only delete about
5% of them without reading them.

378
00:21:19.370 --> 00:21:23.059
But external emails,
which tend to be marketing type emails or

379
00:21:23.059 --> 00:21:26.965
any other type email, then-
>> Maybe it gets past the spam filter.

380
00:21:26.965 --> 00:21:29.574
>> Right, there's a good chance that a lot

381
00:21:29.574 --> 00:21:34.870
of that of it's not caught by a spam
filter that you still delete lot of that.

382
00:21:34.870 --> 00:21:40.769
So how effective is that communication?
>> A lot of time is wasted,

383
00:21:40.769 --> 00:21:43.489
Muda, on-
>> [LAUGH] Right, yeah,

384
00:21:43.489 --> 00:21:49.050
a lot of time is Muda as we saw
in Kanban and in Lean as well.

385
00:21:49.050 --> 00:21:51.180
It's time wasted.

386
00:21:51.180 --> 00:21:53.110
But it's not really,
because we don't open them.

387
00:21:53.110 --> 00:21:56.070
So it's time wasted on behalf of those

388
00:21:56.070 --> 00:21:59.530
other organizations that
have tried to market us.

389
00:21:59.530 --> 00:22:01.951
What it does do, though,

390
00:22:01.951 --> 00:22:05.909
is it does irritate us.
>> It also affects network performance

391
00:22:05.909 --> 00:22:08.250
too, it can.
>> It affects network performance.

392
00:22:08.250 --> 00:22:11.560
It does affect our performance a little
bit but it does also as I say,

393
00:22:11.560 --> 00:22:12.770
it irritates us.

394
00:22:12.770 --> 00:22:15.669
And if we're feeling irritated,
how productive are we?

395
00:22:15.669 --> 00:22:16.615
>> [LAUGH]

396
00:22:16.615 --> 00:22:17.635
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]

397
00:22:17.635 --> 00:22:20.983
>> What if I'm irritated right now, Jo,

398
00:22:20.983 --> 00:22:23.980
how do you know?
>> I could tell, I could tell, yeah.

399
00:22:23.980 --> 00:22:26.118
[LAUGH] But yeah-
>> It's true.

400
00:22:26.118 --> 00:22:27.869
>> Yeah, if we're irritated by something,

401
00:22:27.869 --> 00:22:29.531
we're not generally very productive.

402
00:22:29.531 --> 00:22:31.480
In fact-
>> You gotta get your mind right.

403
00:22:31.480 --> 00:22:32.380
>> Yeah, you're

404
00:22:32.380 --> 00:22:33.820
more likely to decide, you know what?

405
00:22:33.820 --> 00:22:36.500
I'm gonna go and get a coffee
rather than deal with anything.

406
00:22:36.500 --> 00:22:40.599
And that's even more unproductive
time out of your day.

407
00:22:40.599 --> 00:22:47.180
So communication, if it's ineffective,
then we shouldn't do it.

408
00:22:47.180 --> 00:22:48.640
Think about Lean principles.

409
00:22:49.680 --> 00:22:52.150
Think about direct conversations as well.

410
00:22:52.150 --> 00:22:55.730
It's much easier to achieve
a resolution with a conversation.

411
00:22:55.730 --> 00:22:58.430
Now that doesn't mean that
we don't write it down.

412
00:22:58.430 --> 00:23:02.810
Because even though we'll say that
we'll value collaboration over

413
00:23:02.810 --> 00:23:06.880
things like contract negotiation,
we still need to have things written down.

414
00:23:06.880 --> 00:23:08.850
This is what we agreed.

415
00:23:08.850 --> 00:23:12.362
So we should still write things, but
nevertheless we achieve more with

416
00:23:12.362 --> 00:23:15.660
face-to-face communication
with just a simple discussion.

417
00:23:15.660 --> 00:23:21.710
So communicate regularly and frequently,
but communicate only what is needed.

418
00:23:22.720 --> 00:23:25.845
Now of course, something that's very
close to our heart is the daily

419
00:23:25.845 --> 00:23:26.830
stand-up meeting.

420
00:23:26.830 --> 00:23:32.790
And that daily stand-up is literally
where we discuss exactly what we're

421
00:23:32.790 --> 00:23:37.500
all going to be doing in that day and what
we achieved in the previous day as well.

422
00:23:38.960 --> 00:23:41.120
So it involves the core team.

423
00:23:41.120 --> 00:23:42.900
It involves the project team.

424
00:23:42.900 --> 00:23:48.980
It doesn't necessarily include the product
owner, so who should chair that and

425
00:23:48.980 --> 00:23:52.522
make sure that it runs on time?
>> Share the daily stand-up?

426
00:23:52.522 --> 00:23:53.532
>> No, chair it.

427
00:23:53.532 --> 00:23:54.762
>> Chair it, okay.

428
00:23:54.762 --> 00:23:59.664
So that should be the,
hold on, the one on the top,

429
00:23:59.664 --> 00:24:00.565
the-
>> [LAUGH]

430
00:24:00.565 --> 00:24:02.237
>> I'm drawing a blank right now.

431
00:24:02.237 --> 00:24:03.532
Not the project manager.

432
00:24:03.532 --> 00:24:08.355
But the, one second, it's there, hold on,

433
00:24:08.355 --> 00:24:12.230
scrum master.
>> I'd fallen asleep,

434
00:24:12.230 --> 00:24:13.232
sorry, what did she say?

435
00:24:13.232 --> 00:24:15.092
[LAUGH]
>> Wow, that was painful to get that out.

436
00:24:15.092 --> 00:24:17.177
>> It was, it was very painful from this

437
00:24:17.177 --> 00:24:18.749
side as well.
>> Sorry.

438
00:24:18.749 --> 00:24:20.765
>> Yeah, it's the scrum master because

439
00:24:20.765 --> 00:24:23.160
the scrum master has
that responsibility for

440
00:24:23.160 --> 00:24:25.650
facilitating the team efficiency.
>> Right.

441
00:24:25.650 --> 00:24:27.450
>> So it is the scrum master.

442
00:24:27.450 --> 00:24:31.185
It doesn't necessarily have
to include the product owner.

443
00:24:31.185 --> 00:24:36.130
I'd like to

444
00:24:36.130 --> 00:24:41.850
say that only on rare occasions should
we really not include the product owner.

445
00:24:41.850 --> 00:24:47.060
The product owner needs to be as
productive as anybody else, fair enough.

446
00:24:47.060 --> 00:24:50.230
But it's only for 15 minutes,
and if there are any conflicts or

447
00:24:50.230 --> 00:24:54.750
any issues amongst the team
that require his intervention,

448
00:24:54.750 --> 00:24:57.880
it's much easier to intervene
at that point in time.

449
00:24:57.880 --> 00:25:02.895
It should literally just be a 15 minute
meeting and we should be standing up.

450
00:25:02.895 --> 00:25:06.875
And the reason for that is then because if
we're sitting down we're more comfortable

451
00:25:06.875 --> 00:25:11.175
and then we're more likely to
sort of go over the 15 minutes.

452
00:25:11.175 --> 00:25:13.530
So, it should be 15 minutes,

453
00:25:13.530 --> 00:25:17.040
no more than that, stood up where
we just simply go around the team.

454
00:25:17.040 --> 00:25:19.690
We discussed what we
accomplished yesterday, and

455
00:25:19.690 --> 00:25:21.960
then what we plan on doing today.

456
00:25:21.960 --> 00:25:27.230
And then if there are any issues or if
there are any problems that we can see or

457
00:25:27.230 --> 00:25:32.020
any conflicts, you give somebody else the
opportunity to interrupt and to say, hey,

458
00:25:32.020 --> 00:25:33.320
look, I can help you with that.

459
00:25:34.490 --> 00:25:38.947
So, that's what our daily stand up is, and
it should just be very short and sweet.

460
00:25:38.947 --> 00:25:44.152
So, in large organizations, and
we see this as well ourselves,

461
00:25:44.152 --> 00:25:48.317
in large organizations
information radiators, or

462
00:25:48.317 --> 00:25:51.850
those boards, the big visible charts.

463
00:25:51.850 --> 00:25:54.690
You might not be able
to scale them because

464
00:25:54.690 --> 00:25:57.290
it's okay while we're
only on one location.

465
00:25:57.290 --> 00:26:00.370
But when we're not only on one location,
like with 4,000 miles apart,

466
00:26:00.370 --> 00:26:05.120
like our office in England, the it's
really difficult then to scale that.

467
00:26:05.120 --> 00:26:09.220
So we have to think of other communication
channels then traditional ones,

468
00:26:09.220 --> 00:26:12.200
like,, the ones we mentioned so
far, email,

469
00:26:12.200 --> 00:26:17.180
instant messaging and just simple
presentations or even something like this.

470
00:26:17.180 --> 00:26:17.960
You know, nowadays,

471
00:26:17.960 --> 00:26:23.020
a lot of organizations will go in for
webinars or brown bag sessions.

472
00:26:23.020 --> 00:26:26.060
They'll also go in for
what we call town hall meetings.

473
00:26:26.060 --> 00:26:29.900
And a lot of organizations will
actually communicate in this way.

474
00:26:29.900 --> 00:26:33.510
Where if I've got something that I
want to communicate to everybody and

475
00:26:33.510 --> 00:26:36.680
everybody is all over the world,

476
00:26:36.680 --> 00:26:42.210
then what I will do is I'll communicate to
the core team here what I haven't videod.

477
00:26:42.210 --> 00:26:45.450
So then that video is then
shown to all the teams around

478
00:26:45.450 --> 00:26:46.810
the world.
>> Right.

479
00:26:46.810 --> 00:26:48.930
>> And that makes most efficient use of my

480
00:26:48.930 --> 00:26:52.590
time, as well as making most efficient
use of everybody else's time.

481
00:26:53.710 --> 00:26:55.870
So there's no right or wrong way.

482
00:26:55.870 --> 00:27:00.470
You just have to find the way that's
appropriate for your organization.

483
00:27:00.470 --> 00:27:01.710
What you've also gotta do and

484
00:27:01.710 --> 00:27:07.370
talk about planning communication,
I know that on a Monday morning

485
00:27:07.370 --> 00:27:12.080
when I open up my email I'm going to get
an email from one particular person.

486
00:27:12.080 --> 00:27:14.080
And I'm gonna get an email
from somebody else and

487
00:27:14.080 --> 00:27:19.000
I'm gonna get an email from Cherokee,
and that's planned and I expect that.

488
00:27:19.000 --> 00:27:22.720
So I know that I'm gonna get that email so
I'm waiting for it and

489
00:27:22.720 --> 00:27:23.420
I'm going to open it.

490
00:27:24.710 --> 00:27:27.360
It's a planned communication method.

491
00:27:27.360 --> 00:27:32.260
If you start off by communicating
with the team in a certain way,

492
00:27:32.260 --> 00:27:37.960
that becomes expected.
>> So, like just going in and like

493
00:27:37.960 --> 00:27:43.060
randomly switching communication channels,
is not necessarily the right thing to do?

494
00:27:43.060 --> 00:27:44.155
Might be fun.

495
00:27:44.155 --> 00:27:46.550
[LAUGH]
>> No, with a previous, and

496
00:27:46.550 --> 00:27:48.270
I mean it might be fun.
>> I'm just,

497
00:27:48.270 --> 00:27:50.790
just to see people get yeah, crazy.

498
00:27:50.790 --> 00:27:54.360
Cuz that's what will happen.
>> Yeah, cuz that's really, really gonna

499
00:27:54.360 --> 00:27:57.180
help the efficiency of the project, right?
>> Yeah.

500
00:27:57.180 --> 00:28:00.150
>> If you switch up your communication

501
00:28:00.150 --> 00:28:03.130
methods, and you don't tell
everybody you're doing that, then

502
00:28:03.130 --> 00:28:06.830
if all of a sudden I started receiving
a text from you instead of an email,

503
00:28:06.830 --> 00:28:10.180
I might think to myself,
that's not important, it's just a text.

504
00:28:11.640 --> 00:28:13.650
You can't just switch
communication methods.

505
00:28:13.650 --> 00:28:15.590
>> Right, that was sarcasm.

506
00:28:15.590 --> 00:28:19.580
I don't know if I conveyed that
in my communication very well.

507
00:28:19.580 --> 00:28:20.490
>> No, no,

508
00:28:20.490 --> 00:28:24.740
what it was was unproductiveness and
we don't like that in a project.

509
00:28:24.740 --> 00:28:25.740
>> Distractions.

510
00:28:25.740 --> 00:28:27.330
>> Right, it was a distraction.

511
00:28:28.380 --> 00:28:33.120
So yeah, we wanna be productive, don't
switch up your communication methods.

512
00:28:33.120 --> 00:28:37.230
Think about who you're communicating to,
what language it should be in, but also

513
00:28:37.230 --> 00:28:43.700
what medium is more important for and more
relevant for that particular audience.

514
00:28:43.700 --> 00:28:45.500
Some people like emails.

515
00:28:45.500 --> 00:28:47.700
Other people like instant messaging.

516
00:28:47.700 --> 00:28:50.780
Some people are worried about,
say, audit trails for instance,

517
00:28:50.780 --> 00:28:54.250
so they actually want more
than just instant messaging.

518
00:28:54.250 --> 00:28:56.870
But some people are quite
happy with the conversation.

519
00:28:56.870 --> 00:29:01.741
Think about the medium and
think about the message you're conveying.

520
00:29:01.741 --> 00:29:06.022
You do not want to be notified of,
say, a reduction in your hours or

521
00:29:06.022 --> 00:29:09.470
maybe a reduction in your
salary by text message.

522
00:29:09.470 --> 00:29:10.900
>> That'd be awful.

523
00:29:10.900 --> 00:29:11.800
>> Right, okay.

524
00:29:11.800 --> 00:29:16.100
So think about the medium of
the communication because it really is

525
00:29:16.100 --> 00:29:18.790
important to the message that
you're trying to convey.

526
00:29:18.790 --> 00:29:23.210
If you use a more informal communication
method then it's considered to be a less

527
00:29:23.210 --> 00:29:25.190
important message that
you're communicating.

528
00:29:28.040 --> 00:29:32.538
So make sure, and really just to wrap
this session up on communication,

529
00:29:32.538 --> 00:29:35.940
make sure that you understand
who your audience is.

530
00:29:35.940 --> 00:29:39.160
How often they want to receive
their communication, and

531
00:29:39.160 --> 00:29:41.240
how you're gonna communicate.

532
00:29:41.240 --> 00:29:44.480
And think about what is actually
going to be the most efficient and

533
00:29:44.480 --> 00:29:48.000
most effective for
the delivery of that increment.

534
00:29:48.000 --> 00:29:48.750
And, overall, for

535
00:29:48.750 --> 00:29:51.020
the delivery of the project.
>> All right, and great,

536
00:29:51.020 --> 00:29:53.740
thank you so much, and Jo, and
thank you guys for joining us as well,

537
00:29:53.740 --> 00:29:55.530
but we're gonna sign out.

538
00:29:55.530 --> 00:29:58.206
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

539
00:29:58.206 --> 00:30:02.909
>> See you here next time at ITPRO.TV.

540
00:30:02.909 --> 00:30:06.680
[MUSIC]

541
00:30:06.680 --> 00:30:12.758
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In episode 16 we planned our suite of iterations to be included in the project and in this episode we work at iteration level. We look at the details needed to plan the contents and activities of each specific iteration.
episodes.title: Planning Iteration Capacity
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.390 --> 00:00:01.295
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.295 --> 00:00:03.514
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.514 --> 00:00:06.385
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.385 --> 00:00:08.440
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.440 --> 00:00:12.100
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:12.100 --> 00:00:15.420
Welcome everyone to your
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

7
00:00:15.420 --> 00:00:17.430
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.430 --> 00:00:21.750
In this episode we'll be taking a look
at how to plan our iteration capacity.

9
00:00:21.750 --> 00:00:24.720
And with us today back in
the studios we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:24.720 --> 00:00:25.770
Thanks for stopping by Jo.

11
00:00:25.770 --> 00:00:27.010
How are you?
>> I'm fine thank you.

12
00:00:27.010 --> 00:00:28.900
How are you Cherokee?
>> I'm doing well.

13
00:00:28.900 --> 00:00:31.940
We've spoken quite a bit about
iterations but right, and

14
00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:34.970
now on this show we're gonna be
looking at them individually, correct?

15
00:00:34.970 --> 00:00:36.120
>> Yes, that's right.

16
00:00:36.120 --> 00:00:39.080
We're gonna be looking at
individual iterations.

17
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:43.020
Before, on previous episodes,
we looked at working out and

18
00:00:43.020 --> 00:00:48.680
estimating the amount of effort needed for
individual user stories.

19
00:00:48.680 --> 00:00:51.150
And now we have that estimation in place.

248
00:14:12.590 --> 00:14:14.200
What's the most important?

249
00:14:14.200 --> 00:14:20.210
There may be, there may be an instance
when we don't complete all of our tasks

250
00:14:20.210 --> 00:14:23.730
and which ones should we work on first.
>> Right, and I also see, then, right

251
00:14:23.730 --> 00:14:28.280
after you said that, I'm thinking, okay,
well, then why are high importance at

252
00:14:28.280 --> 00:14:32.390
the top of the list, but I see that those
being denoted as dependencies, so that's

253
00:14:32.390 --> 00:14:34.190
another thing that we should think about.
>> Yeah, and

254
00:14:34.190 --> 00:14:36.900
we've gotta think about dependencies, too.

255
00:14:36.900 --> 00:14:43.650
The highest task that I have might
be dependent on your highest task.

256
00:14:43.650 --> 00:14:46.280
And your highest task
might not be completed for

257
00:14:46.280 --> 00:14:49.440
three days which means that
I can't start on mine.

258
00:14:49.440 --> 00:14:52.020
It's a highest priority but
I can't do anything about it.

259
00:14:52.020 --> 00:14:54.160
So I'm gonna work on that medium one.
>> Right,

260
00:14:54.160 --> 00:14:58.420
cuz you're not just gonna-
>> If I'm the person on the left, if mine

261
00:14:58.420 --> 00:15:05.210
is the task list on the left, then you see
I've got two Hs that are depending on you.

262
00:15:05.210 --> 00:15:08.881
If you have the middle, then absolutely
because you're a super duper person.

263
00:15:08.881 --> 00:15:09.414
>> I was gonna say,

264
00:15:09.414 --> 00:15:11.063
why are you giving me all
the high priority things?

265
00:15:11.063 --> 00:15:14.993
>> Cuz you're a super duper person,

266
00:15:14.993 --> 00:15:18.570
your scales are fantastic.

267
00:15:18.570 --> 00:15:20.300
So you've got all of the Hs and

268
00:15:20.300 --> 00:15:23.980
you've prioritized them in that
way along with the product owner.

269
00:15:23.980 --> 00:15:24.990
He's helped you to do that.

270
00:15:24.990 --> 00:15:27.670
You've prioritized them in that way so

271
00:15:27.670 --> 00:15:32.500
I know that I can't do my two
highs until you've finished yours.

272
00:15:32.500 --> 00:15:35.784
So I'm gonna start working on
to the next one down which for

273
00:15:35.784 --> 00:15:37.976
me is going to be a medium.
>> Okay.

274
00:15:37.976 --> 00:15:38.518
>> Yeah.

275
00:15:38.518 --> 00:15:41.468
And so I'm gonna work on those
until you've finished those

276
00:15:41.468 --> 00:15:44.388
two particular highs and then
>> The pressure is unreal here.

277
00:15:44.388 --> 00:15:46.444
>> Right, well, that's what you get for

having all of these skills.

00:15:47.970 --> 00:15:48.850
What can I say?

280
00:15:51.230 --> 00:15:53.005
So that's how we progress through.

281
00:15:53.005 --> 00:15:57.542
And with every, think about as well and
we've got in our boards,

282
00:15:57.542 --> 00:16:01.750
we have got You know, we're gonna to
be moving those sticky notes around and

283
00:16:01.750 --> 00:16:04.598
we're going to right,
that's one's finished.

284
00:16:04.598 --> 00:16:06.986
This one's in progress or
this one's completed.

285
00:16:06.986 --> 00:16:10.623
So we want to use those
boards as visibility so

00:16:10.623 --> 00:16:13.974
that we can see what's been completed and

00:16:13.974 --> 00:16:19.890
we can actually monitor progress

288
00:16:19.890 --> 00:16:23.280
And if we go to our previous

00:16:23.280 --> 00:16:27.650
episode where we looked at monitoring
progress and we looked at visibility and

290
00:16:27.650 --> 00:16:32.750
communication then we can put
those onto our burn down charts.

291
00:16:32.750 --> 00:16:36.510
This is exactly how far
we've got to go and

292
00:16:36.510 --> 00:16:42.105
our burn up charts which is this
is exactly how far we've got.

293
00:16:42.105 --> 00:16:46.934
Not forgetting that for
every single task that we complete,

294
00:16:46.934 --> 00:16:49.688
we have to make sure that it works.

295
00:16:49.688 --> 00:16:54.138
So we have to test all of our tasks,
we have to test each iteration.

296
00:16:54.138 --> 00:16:58.840
Now you might test your tasks individually
but that might not be efficient.

297
00:16:58.840 --> 00:17:03.410
And we wouldn't necessarily recommend
that you test each and every task.

298
00:17:03.410 --> 00:17:07.640
Because especially where there's
dependencies if I go back to that board.

299
00:17:07.640 --> 00:17:10.410
So the two that I'm working on
are dependant on the two that you're

300
00:17:10.410 --> 00:17:10.930
working on.

301
00:17:10.930 --> 00:17:14.830
But you may not be able to test
the two that you're working on until

302
00:17:14.830 --> 00:17:17.030
I finish mine.
>> Okay

303
00:17:17.030 --> 00:17:18.350
>> You know, let's go back

304
00:17:18.350 --> 00:17:19.750
to that finger print thing again.

305
00:17:19.750 --> 00:17:23.570
If wer're talking about finger
print sort of capability,

306
00:17:23.570 --> 00:17:27.420
I can't test that the functionality
of my software works until you

307
00:17:27.420 --> 00:17:29.190
finish the hardware.
>> Right.

308
00:17:29.190 --> 00:17:31.052
>> But you can't test that the hardware

309
00:17:31.052 --> 00:17:31.968
works
>> [LAUGH]

310
00:17:31.968 --> 00:17:33.325
>> Until I finish the software.

311
00:17:33.325 --> 00:17:36.604
All right, so
there may be interdependencies there, so

312
00:17:36.604 --> 00:17:41.248
we might not necessarily want to test each
particular task in any great debt, but

313
00:17:41.248 --> 00:17:45.343
we still need to check that we have
done exactly what we set out to do, and

314
00:17:45.343 --> 00:17:47.698
that we've done it within time as well.

315
00:17:47.698 --> 00:17:52.594
And also, on that I like the making
everybody aware of responsibilities that I

316
00:17:52.594 --> 00:17:58.518
know exactly what you're working on, and
you know exactly what I'm working on.

317
00:17:58.518 --> 00:18:03.140
Again, our standup meeting's gonna help
us with that, so we've got no overlap

318
00:18:03.140 --> 00:18:07.500
in any activities at all,
because we're thinking about efficiency.

319
00:18:08.690 --> 00:18:13.290
So we have testing types and the next two
slides just simply look at the various

320
00:18:13.290 --> 00:18:18.490
testing types that we have within Agile,
but within IT in general.

321
00:18:19.780 --> 00:18:22.280
It's up to you what type
of test you want to use.

322
00:18:22.280 --> 00:18:26.110
And so
this list is not particularly exhaustive.

323
00:18:26.110 --> 00:18:29.150
It's not a definitive
list of types of tests.

324
00:18:30.830 --> 00:18:35.215
We're just saying that the sooner you find
something wrong then the easier it is

325
00:18:35.215 --> 00:18:37.535
to fix, or
certainly the less costly it is.

326
00:18:37.535 --> 00:18:40.125
So that's more efficiency for us and

327
00:18:40.125 --> 00:18:42.325
we're in an agile environment,
that's what we want.

328
00:18:42.325 --> 00:18:45.595
And we're gonna do
testing together as well.

329
00:18:45.595 --> 00:18:48.395
Then you have to think about user
testing and you have to think about

330
00:18:48.395 --> 00:18:52.715
customer testing and then you also have
to think about functionality testing.

331
00:18:52.715 --> 00:18:53.995
Does it actually fail?

332
00:18:53.995 --> 00:18:55.900
Does it give an error message?

333
00:18:55.900 --> 00:18:58.480
As well as does it deliver
what the customer wants it to

334
00:18:58.480 --> 00:19:01.760
deliver?
>> As well as is it protecting

335
00:19:01.760 --> 00:19:02.280
them in a way?

336
00:19:02.280 --> 00:19:05.377
Like any kind of red team, blue team
with the security side of things,

337
00:19:05.377 --> 00:19:06.507
pen testing.
>> Right, yeah, so

338
00:19:06.507 --> 00:19:09.400
there are various tests.
>> Right.

339
00:19:09.400 --> 00:19:10.740
>> And we've gotta,

340
00:19:10.740 --> 00:19:15.270
it's part of the plan in the iteration,
you've gotta plan to test as well.

341
00:19:15.270 --> 00:19:19.453
And so you've gotta plan all of the
aspects of the testing that you want to

342
00:19:19.453 --> 00:19:23.089
include, including the security,
the user, the customer,

343
00:19:23.089 --> 00:19:27.638
including the actual functionality and
does it actually, physically work?

344
00:19:27.638 --> 00:19:28.996
You know
>> [LAUGH] Right?

345
00:19:28.996 --> 00:19:29.747
>> Without any errors.

346
00:19:29.747 --> 00:19:30.687
Right?

347
00:19:30.687 --> 00:19:31.728
So that's key.

348
00:19:31.728 --> 00:19:34.923
And so when you think about
how we split up the tasks,

349
00:19:34.923 --> 00:19:39.090
then we should expect our
testing to be collaborative.

350
00:19:39.090 --> 00:19:42.350
Cuz we should expect everybody
to be involved in testing.

351
00:19:42.350 --> 00:19:46.360
Now, I've just got one question for you
really, and, you know, a straight yes or

352
00:19:46.360 --> 00:19:47.000
no will do.

353
00:19:47.000 --> 00:19:48.908
Not that that's a hint.

354
00:19:48.908 --> 00:19:53.991
[LAUGH] Should I test my own programming.
>> I say no.

355
00:19:53.991 --> 00:19:56.320
>> You're right, we don't.

356
00:19:56.320 --> 00:19:59.600
We'll ask, we talked about in XP in that

357
00:19:59.600 --> 00:20:03.380
particular episode where we looked at
that methodology, we do pair programming.

358
00:20:03.380 --> 00:20:06.050
But you don't test your own code.
>> You're right.

359
00:20:06.050 --> 00:20:08.743
>> It just makes sense because if you test

360
00:20:08.743 --> 00:20:12.263
your own code, I know how my code works.
>> Right.

361
00:20:12.263 --> 00:20:13.300
[LAUGH]
>> But

362
00:20:13.300 --> 00:20:17.620
I have to make sure that you're able to
use and somebody else is able to use it.

363
00:20:17.620 --> 00:20:19.560
>> And you also have like a unique bias.

364
00:20:19.560 --> 00:20:22.607
Like of course it's creative,
of course it worked, but..

365
00:20:22.607 --> 00:20:25.640
And I'm going to be trying to prove
that it's going to work as well.

366
00:20:25.640 --> 00:20:26.420
>> So yeah.

367
00:20:26.420 --> 00:20:28.210
We don't test our own code.

368
00:20:29.270 --> 00:20:31.950
And our test should be replaceable, and

369
00:20:31.950 --> 00:20:38.140
this is not just from an efficiency
perspective, which, yes it is efficiency.

370
00:20:38.140 --> 00:20:41.860
If I can use that test somewhere else
that same test somewhere else then that's

371
00:20:41.860 --> 00:20:43.260
gonna be very efficient.

372
00:20:43.260 --> 00:20:48.050
But I also need to prove functionality,
which means that I

00:20:48.050 --> 00:20:51.030
don't just test once and then go,
yeah, that's it, it's working.

374
00:20:51.030 --> 00:20:54.070
I'm going to test a number of times so

375
00:20:54.070 --> 00:20:56.710
that I can demonstrate that it's working,
okay?

376
00:20:56.710 --> 00:20:59.870
And so, as we've already said,
testing should be independent.

377
00:20:59.870 --> 00:21:02.640
It shouldn't be done by
the person that's coded it.

378
00:21:03.830 --> 00:21:08.210
In the same way that we prioritize
our tasks, we prioritize our testing.

379
00:21:08.210 --> 00:21:13.429
Which functionality is
more important to tests?

380
00:21:13.429 --> 00:21:17.501
What do we do if a test fails?
>> You rework.

381
00:21:17.501 --> 00:21:20.605
I don't know what the technical term is,
but

382
00:21:20.605 --> 00:21:23.301
you gotta go back to the drawing board,

383
00:21:23.301 --> 00:21:27.880
some how maybe added to the next story.
>> Yes.

384
00:21:27.880 --> 00:21:31.460
See, she is thinking along
the Agile frame of mind now, yeah.

385
00:21:31.460 --> 00:21:32.120
Okay, yeah.

386
00:21:32.120 --> 00:21:35.950
We noted in a traditional word
full of approach here, so

387
00:21:35.950 --> 00:21:39.053
if something fails,
then we have to decide.

388
00:21:39.053 --> 00:21:42.230
And we decide whether we're
going to add it to the backlog.

389
00:21:42.230 --> 00:21:47.080
In other words, we're going to add
it into the next user story or

390
00:21:47.080 --> 00:21:50.825
the next iteration or
decide whether we're just going to and

391
00:21:50.825 --> 00:21:56.340
that's going to be a you know,
whatever you want to call it and what

392
00:21:57.410 --> 00:22:02.810
we don't do is we don't go back and
reinvent the wheel.

393
00:22:04.280 --> 00:22:06.260
We're on a very strict timeline here.

394
00:22:07.640 --> 00:22:11.940
So if we get as far as developing
all of the coding, and

395
00:22:11.940 --> 00:22:15.420
then we do the testing and
we find that there's something wrong.

396
00:22:15.420 --> 00:22:19.860
If that's the only story that we're
delivering in that iteration,

397
00:22:19.860 --> 00:22:24.120
then we failed in that iteration.
>> That sounds so

398
00:22:24.120 --> 00:22:26.512
tragic.
>> I know right.

399
00:22:26.512 --> 00:22:30.381
[LAUGH] Now, be careful cuz I know
Cherokees likely to cry at the drop of

00:22:30.381 --> 00:22:32.999
a hat, so
I don't wat to make it sound too bad.

401
00:22:32.999 --> 00:22:38.042
[LAUGH] But, yeah, we have to acknowledge
that's okay, that's where we are right

402
00:22:38.042 --> 00:22:42.340
now, so let's look at our next iteration.
>> Okay.

403
00:22:42.340 --> 00:22:46.061
So think about,
we wanna make sure that we get it right,

404
00:22:46.061 --> 00:22:50.674
first of all, then we don't have to
go back and do everything again.

405
00:22:50.674 --> 00:22:54.391
But at the end of the day, though we know
that sometimes the whole idea of testing

406
00:22:54.391 --> 00:22:56.612
is that sometimes tests fails.
>> Right.

407
00:22:56.612 --> 00:22:58.482
>> Sometimes we get error messages, and so

408
00:22:58.482 --> 00:23:01.860

we're going to do about it.

409
00:23:01.860 --> 00:23:07.530
And our tests should be specified before
we even start to do any development work.

410
00:23:08.540 --> 00:23:12.520
And of course, all of our requirements,
all of our functionality,

411
00:23:12.520 --> 00:23:16.080
should be tested for risk, for
the probability, the likelihood,

412
00:23:16.080 --> 00:23:20.530
that vulnerability that
the likelihood of any failure.

413
00:23:20.530 --> 00:23:25.263
And the greatest risks, well, they should
be tested first because then we can add

414
00:23:25.263 --> 00:23:27.607
in, potentially, resilience, etc.

415
00:23:27.607 --> 00:23:31.303
And actually that question that
I just asked you is really

416
00:23:31.303 --> 00:23:33.310
about backlog grooming.

417
00:23:33.310 --> 00:23:39.293
And that just goes back to, once we

418
00:23:39.293 --> 00:23:44.020
then we go back and we look at

419
00:23:44.020 --> 00:23:48.183
to be delivered and
we may not want to work, [LAUGH].

420
00:23:48.183 --> 00:23:53.014
We may need to add to those stories
because we might have failed in some

421
00:23:53.014 --> 00:23:55.168

>> But priorities also could have shifted,

422
00:23:55.168 --> 00:23:56.792

>> Right, and we also want to,

423
00:23:56.792 --> 00:24:00.662
that's why we call it grooming because we
also want to reevaluate those stories that

424
00:24:00.662 --> 00:24:02.120
are still there.

425
00:24:02.120 --> 00:24:04.100
Because what we may have done,

426
00:24:04.100 --> 00:24:07.990
inadvertantly, is we may have
programmed one thing and

427
00:24:07.990 --> 00:24:10.880
then the user has turned around and said
well actually I'm really happy with that.

428
00:24:10.880 --> 00:24:11.770
And I don't need this.

429
00:24:12.900 --> 00:24:17.120
So our user stories may have changed or
something else in the outside world,

430
00:24:17.120 --> 00:24:20.590
some other external influence might
have changed as well, maybe there's been

431
00:24:20.590 --> 00:24:26.360
a security patch released that now means
that a particular story is obsolete.

432
00:24:26.360 --> 00:24:29.870
So again, we go back and
will at the end of each iteration,

433
00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:34.630
then we will review and
we will perform our back log grooming and

434
00:24:34.630 --> 00:24:39.350
make sure that what's in our back log Is
actually still relevant to that project.

435
00:24:40.870 --> 00:24:45.480
So now what we've done is we've taken
a look at planning an iteration.

436
00:24:45.480 --> 00:24:50.440
And in our next episode, when we come
back we're going to be looking at after

437
00:24:50.440 --> 00:24:53.013

>> Yeah.

>> [LAUGH] Anyway.

00:25:10.583 --> 00:25:11.707

445

Yeah, sorry.
>> Well, [LAUGH] it's 5:00 somewhere.

446
00:25:17.270 --> 00:25:17.820
Right?

447
00:25:17.820 --> 00:25:18.790
Just kidding.

448
00:25:18.790 --> 00:25:22.705
No, we are out of time, so
we'll go ahead and sign out for this show.

expect them to know anything about IT.
