00:13:33.973 --> 00:13:39.420
And I don't expect the business
to understand any terminology.

248
00:13:39.420 --> 00:13:43.230
I don't need them to know any terminology,
and they don't need to either.

249
00:13:43.230 --> 00:13:45.208
It's not efficient for them to do that.

250
00:13:45.208 --> 00:13:48.695
>> Right, you said something to
me in a previous series that we

251
00:13:48.695 --> 00:13:52.576
have shot together that was really
powerful and it stuck with me.

252
00:13:52.576 --> 00:13:56.220
>> But just with that business
relationship management, you should be

253
00:13:56.220 --> 00:14:00.140
able to identify those needs before
they even know that there's an issue or

254
00:14:00.140 --> 00:14:02.330
that there's a void in their life there.

255
00:14:02.330 --> 00:14:06.490
Right, a business relationship role,
however you wanna call it,

256
00:14:06.490 --> 00:14:09.780
whether you wanna call it a BRM, or
whether you want to call it a lead

257
00:14:09.780 --> 00:14:13.190
business representative,
it doesn't matter what you call them.

258
00:14:13.190 --> 00:14:16.910
The business relationship role,
that person

259
00:14:16.910 --> 00:14:21.890
should know the business inside out and
should be able to identify what is needed.

260
00:14:21.890 --> 00:14:25.990
And when it comes to identifying
user stories, they're key for this.

261
00:14:25.990 --> 00:14:30.410
And because what that BRM role will
do is they will observe the business.

262
00:14:30.410 --> 00:14:32.420
They will see how the business work.

263
00:14:32.420 --> 00:14:35.280
They will understand what it is they need.

264
00:14:35.280 --> 00:14:38.500
And they will see that maybe, just maybe,

265
00:14:38.500 --> 00:14:43.530
there life would be a little easier
if they had some form of biometric

266
00:14:43.530 --> 00:14:47.505
recognition, which meant that they didn't
have to keep remembering a password.

267
00:14:47.505 --> 00:14:50.805
Because when their password
changed every single month, and

268
00:14:50.805 --> 00:14:54.925
you have to have a different one for
a two-year period, and

269
00:14:54.925 --> 00:15:00.200
you can't have the same one with just one,
two, three, four, and five after.

270
00:15:00.200 --> 00:15:04.213
Right, [LAUGH] a password history, they're
like nope, you used that three months ago.

271
00:15:04.213 --> 00:15:07.537
>> [LAUGH] Right, exactly, and so the BRM
should be able to recognize that look,

272
00:15:07.537 --> 00:15:11.066
this clearly isn't working cuz what we've
got are loads of notes that are stuck on

273
00:15:11.066 --> 00:15:12.824
the keyboards and stuck on the screens.

274
00:15:12.824 --> 00:15:14.477
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we've got so

275
00:15:14.477 --> 00:15:16.740
secure that we've become insecure.

276
00:15:16.740 --> 00:15:18.680
>> Yeah,
defeating the purpose at that point.

277
00:15:18.680 --> 00:15:23.090
>> Exactly, so the BRM is
the person that recognizes this.

278
00:15:23.090 --> 00:15:28.190
But the BRM, I always look at them as
a translator because what they should do,

279
00:15:28.190 --> 00:15:32.280
and the way that the interactions should
be right at the very start of the project

280
00:15:32.280 --> 00:15:35.020
is Cherokee,
you've forgotten your password.

281
00:15:35.020 --> 00:15:38.674
You've had to have it reset,
I've noticed, 15 times in the last year.

282
00:15:38.674 --> 00:15:41.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is partly getting ridiculous.

283
00:15:41.050 --> 00:15:44.030
Do you think I could
replace your laptop and

284
00:15:44.030 --> 00:15:46.720
give you something that would
recognize your fingerprint?

285
00:15:46.720 --> 00:15:48.971
>> And
then we wouldn't have to go any further.

286
00:15:48.971 --> 00:15:50.590
>> That'd be great, Jo!

287
00:15:50.590 --> 00:15:51.641
>> Right, now you see,

288
00:15:51.641 --> 00:15:55.265
the thing is that I have had this
interaction with Cherokee right now, but

289
00:15:55.265 --> 00:15:59.142
what she doesn't realize is I've already
been back to the development team.

290
00:15:59.142 --> 00:16:01.767
And I've already said to the Do
you reckon we could do this?

291
00:16:01.767 --> 00:16:05.645
Do you reckon we could add
some fingerprint security,

292
00:16:05.645 --> 00:16:09.279
some fingerprint recognition
into our services?

293
00:16:09.279 --> 00:16:12.840
And I've already had the discussion
to see whether it's possible.

294
00:16:12.840 --> 00:16:16.452
That's when I've gone to Cherokee and
said, you've got an issue, clearly.

295
00:16:16.452 --> 00:16:18.170
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

296
00:16:18.170 --> 00:16:19.310
>> How about I do this?

297
00:16:19.310 --> 00:16:21.100
We could do this for you.

298
00:16:21.100 --> 00:16:24.645
And it's at that point in time when
I come back then to development,

299
00:16:24.645 --> 00:16:27.455
and I say to development,
right, we need to do this.

300
00:16:27.455 --> 00:16:29.600
This is the way they work.

301
00:16:29.600 --> 00:16:31.010
This is the way the business work.

302
00:16:31.010 --> 00:16:33.890
We need to do this, and
we need to develop this for them.

303
00:16:33.890 --> 00:16:34.940
So it means hard work.

304
00:16:34.940 --> 00:16:37.260
It also means some software as well.

305
00:16:37.260 --> 00:16:42.610
And that's when we start with the problem
statement then exploring the vision for

306
00:16:42.610 --> 00:16:46.780
our project and then looking at
our individual user's story.

307
00:16:46.780 --> 00:16:48.380
That's when that happens.

308
00:16:48.380 --> 00:16:51.350
And then here we are at
the end of an iteration.

309
00:16:51.350 --> 00:16:56.082
And now I'm the person as the business
relationship manager in that business

310
00:16:56.082 --> 00:16:59.230
relationship role where I
am going to look at this.

311
00:16:59.230 --> 00:17:02.530
And I'm going to say, right,
okay, the developers did well.

312
00:17:03.570 --> 00:17:05.000
It works, okay?

313
00:17:05.000 --> 00:17:06.960
I'm testing it, and it works.

314
00:17:06.960 --> 00:17:12.380
And it's at that point in time that we
say, yes, okay, that is good to go.

315
00:17:12.380 --> 00:17:16.430
And that acceptance is
completely dependent on that

316
00:17:16.430 --> 00:17:19.100
successful review of the solution.

317
00:17:19.100 --> 00:17:20.270
So it's me.

318
00:17:20.270 --> 00:17:23.440
I sign off that
the functionality is fit for

319
00:17:23.440 --> 00:17:27.900
use, because the solution meets
all of the acceptance criteria.

320
00:17:27.900 --> 00:17:31.970
Cherokee is only going to
accept it if it works.

321
00:17:31.970 --> 00:17:33.710
If it doesn't work,

322
00:17:33.710 --> 00:17:37.135
what do you gonna think of me if I give
you something then that just doesn't work?

323
00:17:39.621 --> 00:17:40.350
>> Jo?

324
00:17:40.350 --> 00:17:41.861
>> It's the first time she's been loss for
words.

325
00:17:41.861 --> 00:17:42.364
Go on.

326
00:17:42.364 --> 00:17:43.990
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Well,

327
00:17:43.990 --> 00:17:47.400
I'm probably just gonna have
that same kind of reaction.

328
00:17:47.400 --> 00:17:50.719
If I go to log in, and
I'm like, okay, now what?

329
00:17:50.719 --> 00:17:53.260
At least I could use my
password reset before, but

330
00:17:53.260 --> 00:17:55.920
now I can't even get into this system,
right?

331
00:17:55.920 --> 00:18:01.760
>> Right, and that's exactly what's going
to happen is that the credibility of IT

332
00:18:01.760 --> 00:18:07.770
and, also, my only personal reputation,
as well, is simply just gonna plummet.

333
00:18:07.770 --> 00:18:11.203
And so we've got to make sure that
what we deliver is working software.

334
00:18:11.203 --> 00:18:15.399
If we don't deliver working software,
if we don't deliver value to Cherokee,

335
00:18:15.399 --> 00:18:18.487
then Cherokee's start looking
elsewhere for solutions,

336
00:18:18.487 --> 00:18:21.716
because she knows that there's
something better out there.

337
00:18:21.716 --> 00:18:25.900
And so it's up to us then
to provide that for her.

338
00:18:25.900 --> 00:18:31.730
So the business acceptance is obtained
here within this particular iteration.

339
00:18:31.730 --> 00:18:34.450
We don't wait until the end
of the entire project,

340
00:18:34.450 --> 00:18:39.260
because there are definitely going to
be other iterations in the project.

341
00:18:39.260 --> 00:18:42.716
And we don't wait until the entire
project, because, of course,

342
00:18:42.716 --> 00:18:46.850
we're releasing, and we're releasing
maybe one or two iterations together.

343
00:18:48.220 --> 00:18:51.680
Well, when we release something,
it's got to work.

344
00:18:51.680 --> 00:18:55.470
So that means that, yes,
we've got to sign off with each iteration.

345
00:18:55.470 --> 00:18:57.280
Of course, we have to.

346
00:18:57.280 --> 00:18:59.710
So we review the iteration, and

347
00:18:59.710 --> 00:19:03.970
we review to make sure that we've
achieved what we set out to achieve.

348
00:19:03.970 --> 00:19:05.470
We're going to include Cherokee.

349
00:19:05.470 --> 00:19:08.352
Once I have verified that,
yes, it's definitely working.

350
00:19:08.352 --> 00:19:12.050
I'm gonna present it to her, and
I'm going to say, is this okay?

351
00:19:12.050 --> 00:19:16.540
Now, the purpose of this review is not
to get that formal business sign off.

352
00:19:16.540 --> 00:19:20.000
It's just for Cherokee to have
an influence over that and

353
00:19:20.000 --> 00:19:22.610
to identify anything that
she may want to have.

354
00:19:22.610 --> 00:19:25.870
Because she might turn around to me and
say, well, that looks fine, but

355
00:19:25.870 --> 00:19:28.420
can we have like facial recognition now?

356
00:19:28.420 --> 00:19:31.810
Cuz I hear that there were a lot of
other gadgets out there that do that, so

357
00:19:31.810 --> 00:19:32.990
can I have that instead?

358
00:19:34.180 --> 00:19:40.450
So it gives Cherokee as the customer
the opportunity to bring in,

359
00:19:40.450 --> 00:19:46.320
maybe, new functionality, or maybe to
identify an improvement that she sees.

360
00:19:46.320 --> 00:19:49.370
And it really is also to
assess how effective and

361
00:19:49.370 --> 00:19:51.220
how efficient that iteration went.

362
00:19:51.220 --> 00:19:52.310
Now, of course,

363
00:19:52.310 --> 00:19:56.050
that's something that's internal
to us within the development team.

364
00:19:56.050 --> 00:19:58.690
It's not something that Cherokee
needs to be aware of at all,

365
00:19:58.690 --> 00:20:01.730
because, as far as Cherokee's concerned,
we've just done our job.

366
00:20:03.690 --> 00:20:06.000
And then we have a retrospective, and

367
00:20:06.000 --> 00:20:10.200
the retrospective happens at
the end of every iteration as well.

368
00:20:10.200 --> 00:20:15.842
And the retrospective just simply
looks at how well we worked together.

369
00:20:15.842 --> 00:20:16.420
How well we worked.

370
00:20:16.420 --> 00:20:18.610
How well we collaborated.

371
00:20:18.610 --> 00:20:22.210
How efficient and
effective we are at our estimation.

372
00:20:22.210 --> 00:20:25.229
How many changes came as
a result of that estimation.

373
00:20:25.229 --> 00:20:29.203
Because if there are too many changes that
come as a result of maybe the estimation

374
00:20:29.203 --> 00:20:30.781
or as a result of the iteration,

375
00:20:30.781 --> 00:20:34.070
then maybe we didn't plan the iteration
in the first place right.

376
00:20:35.220 --> 00:20:39.910
So after every single iteration, we're
going to be conducting the retrospective,

377
00:20:39.910 --> 00:20:44.580
which is really gonna allow us to
evaluate efficiency and effectiveness.

378
00:20:44.580 --> 00:20:47.010
Who's going to be involved
in that do you think?

379
00:20:48.080 --> 00:20:52.230
>> Well, I think that the scrum master is,
because you're also talking about how

380
00:20:52.230 --> 00:20:55.840
we worked together, and that's going
to be those interpersonal skills.

381
00:20:55.840 --> 00:20:58.439
>> If we look at the elements
that are on the right hand side,

382
00:20:58.439 --> 00:21:00.227
here, when we talk about practices and

383
00:21:00.227 --> 00:21:03.823
collaboration then, yes, that's
definitely going to be the scrum master.

384
00:21:03.823 --> 00:21:08.835
Now, in terms of estimation, I'd expect
the product managers to also have, sorry,

385
00:21:08.835 --> 00:21:12.310
the product owner to have
some involvement in that too.

386
00:21:12.310 --> 00:21:16.840
So, yes, it's going to be both of them
that are involved in the retrospective,

387
00:21:16.840 --> 00:21:20.670
but the retrospective is
internal to the project team.

388
00:21:20.670 --> 00:21:23.710
It's got absolutely nothing to
do with the customer at all.

389
00:21:23.710 --> 00:21:27.010
It's just where we look back and
we conduct our lessons learned.

390
00:21:27.010 --> 00:21:29.280
And we identify opportunities for

391
00:21:29.280 --> 00:21:32.310
improvement out of that,
as well as out of the review.

392
00:21:32.310 --> 00:21:35.990
And the review is really based on
the actual functionality itself.

393
00:21:38.190 --> 00:21:43.530
And then, lastly, the thing that we want
to do when we've completed any improvement

394
00:21:43.530 --> 00:21:47.260
is to, well, use our lessons learned.

395
00:21:47.260 --> 00:21:50.690
If we've learned some lessons then,
what are we gonna do about it?

396
00:21:50.690 --> 00:21:56.010
And that's how we're using that review and
that retrospective and

397
00:21:56.010 --> 00:22:01.590
the opportunities that have been
highlighted in those two activities.

398
00:22:01.590 --> 00:22:07.220
And we're going to document
those improvement opportunities.

399
00:22:07.220 --> 00:22:10.110
Those improvement opportunities
can come in two ways.

400
00:22:10.110 --> 00:22:12.160
It can either be additional
functionality or

401
00:22:12.160 --> 00:22:17.270
maybe changes to the functionality
that we have just coded.

402
00:22:17.270 --> 00:22:20.960
Or it could be improvements in
the way we're working as well.

403
00:22:20.960 --> 00:22:22.900
But whatever improvement that we make,

404
00:22:22.900 --> 00:22:26.580
certainly when it comes to
improving the way that we work and

405
00:22:26.580 --> 00:22:31.240
improving that collaboration, that
improvement has to have team consensus.

406
00:22:31.240 --> 00:22:34.250
We've all got to agree
that this is a good idea.

407
00:22:34.250 --> 00:22:36.895
If it's just one person's idea and
nobody else agrees,

408
00:22:36.895 --> 00:22:39.994
then we're going back to that
dictatorship thing again, right?

409
00:22:39.994 --> 00:22:40.643
>> Right.

410
00:22:40.643 --> 00:22:43.660
>> So we've all gotta agree
that that's a good idea.

411
00:22:43.660 --> 00:22:48.690
And the improvement, we don't wait to
implement that type of improvement.

412
00:22:48.690 --> 00:22:50.600
If we're gonna change
the way that we've worked,

413
00:22:50.600 --> 00:22:53.063
we do that with the next iteration.

414
00:22:53.063 --> 00:22:56.820
Remember the values, the Agile values,

415
00:22:56.820 --> 00:23:02.380
we're not too focused on the process and
on the documentation.

416
00:23:02.380 --> 00:23:05.610
We want to be working, and
we want to be efficient, but

417
00:23:05.610 --> 00:23:10.690
the comprehensive documentation
that's not such a focus for us.

418
00:23:10.690 --> 00:23:14.350
We still need to have documentation,
and, yes, we still need to have

419
00:23:14.350 --> 00:23:19.350
a process to implement improvements and
to identify improvements.

420
00:23:19.350 --> 00:23:20.100
But we've got that.

421
00:23:20.100 --> 00:23:21.490
We've got it right in front of us.

422
00:23:21.490 --> 00:23:24.110
That's what our review and
our retrospective is.

423
00:23:24.110 --> 00:23:27.050
So we document that, and
then we implement them.

424
00:23:27.050 --> 00:23:30.700
We don't wait for six months to evaluate
them, because then that's not efficient.

425
00:23:32.290 --> 00:23:35.490
So now what we've done,
in this particular episode,

426
00:23:35.490 --> 00:23:40.950
is we've looked at the conclusion,
the end of the iteration.

427
00:23:40.950 --> 00:23:43.740
And so
when we come back in our next episode,

428
00:23:43.740 --> 00:23:46.380
we're still going to be carrying
on with our Agile journey.

429
00:23:46.380 --> 00:23:49.160
Don't worry, things haven't finished yet.

430
00:23:49.160 --> 00:23:50.670
We've just finished one iteration.

431
00:23:50.670 --> 00:23:52.216
We haven't released anything right now.

432
00:23:52.216 --> 00:23:55.720
>> Yeah, and we're about to talk about
ways we can improve on the next show.

433
00:23:55.720 --> 00:24:00.250
But also, this will give us a good chance
to maybe look at things that we've done

434
00:24:00.250 --> 00:24:02.780
well that we can carry on
to the next show also.

435
00:24:02.780 --> 00:24:04.550
So we'll have to-
>> That's about an improvement, yeah.

436
00:24:04.550 --> 00:24:09.680
I mean, improvement doesn't just mean,
kind of, looking at what went wrong.

437
00:24:09.680 --> 00:24:13.070
But we also look at what went right,
and then we can apply that across

438
00:24:13.070 --> 00:24:16.830
the board to other iterations and
also to other teams as well.

439
00:24:16.830 --> 00:24:19.329
>> Learning from life lessons, Jo.

440
00:24:19.329 --> 00:24:20.967
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH] Well, thank you for

441
00:24:20.967 --> 00:24:23.240
being here to provide those life lessons.

442
00:24:23.240 --> 00:24:25.750
And thank you for being here with
us as well, but let's go ahead and

443
00:24:25.750 --> 00:24:27.090
sign out of this show.

444
00:24:27.090 --> 00:24:29.620
I've been our host Cherokee Boose
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

445
00:24:29.620 --> 00:24:32.044
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

446
00:24:32.044 --> 00:24:38.170
[MUSIC]

447
00:24:38.170 --> 00:24:41.034
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: The modifications discussed in the previous episode will need to be included in the iteration plan and therefore these changes will need to be managed. Impediments also need to be identified and removed and this episode identifies impediment types found in every project and how these may be overcome.

>> Lovely.

changes that we might

what we've looked at

00:02:24.360 --> 00:02:29.510

Waterfall approach and an Agile approach.

00:02:29.510 --> 00:02:32.880
Now, if you 've been with us right all
the way through from the beginning of

00:02:32.880 --> 00:02:37.040

59
00:02:49.750 --> 00:02:54.570
However, there is a huge difference
between the traditional waterfall approach

60
00:02:54.570 --> 00:02:56.520
and the Agile approach.

61
00:02:56.520 --> 00:02:59.561
Because the traditional waterfall
approach, Cherokee is right.

62
00:02:59.561 --> 00:03:01.610
In a traditional waterfall approach,

63
00:03:01.610 --> 00:03:06.760
we will agree on what we're
doing right up front.

64
00:03:06.760 --> 00:03:10.850
And thats not subject to change or at
least in a traditional waterfall approach,

65
00:03:10.850 --> 00:03:13.180
it shouldnt be subject to change.

66
00:03:13.180 --> 00:03:16.830
Thats whats agreed up front,
thats what were going to produce, and

67
00:03:16.830 --> 00:03:19.000
thats what we work towards producing.

68
00:03:19.000 --> 00:03:22.160
Whereas in an Agile environment,
were producing in increments.

69
00:03:22.160 --> 00:03:23.650
Were producing iterations.

70
00:03:23.650 --> 00:03:25.920
And so because were developing and

71
00:03:25.920 --> 00:03:30.200

then there's going to be change.

72
00:03:30.200 --> 00:03:34.400
It allows us to make changes because
once one iteration is finished,

73
00:03:34.400 --> 00:03:37.610
we can review that iteration and
we can make changes.

74
00:03:37.610 --> 00:03:39.940
We can add in new user stories, or

75
00:03:39.940 --> 00:03:44.480
we can amend the way that our
current functionality is.

76
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:46.610
So maybe we've changed something,
we don't like it.

77
00:03:47.620 --> 00:03:50.890
So we can amend it and
we can do that in future iteration.

78
00:03:50.890 --> 00:03:57.750
So we actually actively embrace change and
more importantly, we can adopt the change.

79
00:03:57.750 --> 00:04:02.220
Because the whole way that we

80
00:04:02.220 --> 00:04:06.890

81
00:04:06.890 --> 00:04:11.250

00:04:20.732 --> 00:04:25.151

85
00:04:25.151 --> 00:04:29.647

00:04:29.647 --> 00:04:33.370

00:04:33.370 --> 00:04:39.820

00:04:39.820 --> 00:04:44.620

So it's generally the business

>> Yeah.

building on what you just said there, is
we don't actually make changes midstream

176
00:09:52.542 --> 00:09:54.624
in an increment.
>> That's right.

177
00:09:54.624 --> 00:09:55.600
>> We wait until

00:09:55.600 --> 00:09:56.469
the-

00:09:56.469 --> 00:10:01.600
[LAUGH]
>> We can fail,

00:10:01.600 --> 00:10:03.060
that's all right, it's not a problem.

00:10:03.060 --> 00:10:05.430
But you don't want to
make changes midstream.

182
00:10:05.430 --> 00:10:07.570
What we'll do is we'll wait

183
00:10:07.570 --> 00:10:12.330
and that's when we implement

00:10:12.330 --> 00:10:15.370
We don't want to make changes midstream.

00:10:15.370 --> 00:10:16.760
If it's an active iteration,

00:10:16.760 --> 00:10:20.440
as we call it, then we definitely

187
00:10:20.440 --> 00:10:26.480
So how do we then, well that next slide
mentions effecting a change process.

00:10:26.480 --> 00:10:28.780
But here's a simplified change process,
and

189
00:10:28.780 --> 00:10:31.230
this is how we actually
implement a change.

190
00:10:31.230 --> 00:10:37.040
We simply write the new and changed story,
then we estimate that change, and

191
00:10:37.040 --> 00:10:42.408
then we prioritize it, and we update
our iteration and our release plan.

192
00:10:42.408 --> 00:10:46.395
Sounds simple [LAUGH].

193
00:10:46.395 --> 00:10:48.910
Nothing is ever as simple as it sounds,
let's face it.

194
00:10:48.910 --> 00:10:50.820
Did you notice the evil laugh there?

195
00:10:50.820 --> 00:10:53.643
[LAUGH] It sounds simple, but

196
00:10:53.643 --> 00:10:58.710
you see a change can impact
something else as well.

197
00:10:59.810 --> 00:11:01.470
So, Yes.

198
00:11:01.470 --> 00:11:07.680
When we make a change, we want to
document it and then we will re-estimate.

199
00:11:07.680 --> 00:11:11.970
If we're changing an existing story
we then have to re-estimate and

200
00:11:11.970 --> 00:11:15.658
potentially we prioritize that story.

201
00:11:15.658 --> 00:11:21.657
But if we bring a new story in,
well not only do we have to estimate and

202
00:11:21.657 --> 00:11:29.045
prioritize that new story, but you might
have an adverse effect on other stories.

203
00:11:29.045 --> 00:11:34.424
And you see this is why right at
the very start of this particular

204
00:11:34.424 --> 00:11:40.212
series when we looked at the theories
of agile project management,

205
00:11:40.212 --> 00:11:46.706
one of the, I guess, the pillars that we
looked at were the fact that we do not

206
00:11:46.706 --> 00:11:51.710
plan too far ahead in great
detail because things change.

207
00:11:53.140 --> 00:11:56.020
So we will prioritize and

208
00:11:56.020 --> 00:12:01.800
we will estimate at a high level for
the whole project.

209
00:12:02.830 --> 00:12:05.830
But then at the start of each iteration,

210
00:12:05.830 --> 00:12:10.840
that's when we do our definitive plan and
we will then allocate,

211
00:12:10.840 --> 00:12:17.480
we will convert those ideal days
into real days for each iteration.

212
00:12:17.480 --> 00:12:23.350
And we don't waste time planning in great
detail the long term because of this,

213
00:12:23.350 --> 00:12:26.990
Because of what's in front of you
right now, Because things change.

214
00:12:26.990 --> 00:12:31.580
And so if I've brought something in,
there is a good chance that it's going to

215
00:12:31.580 --> 00:12:35.600
have an impact on what
I've already planned.

216
00:12:35.600 --> 00:12:39.780
So if I've got five years of stories
planned for my next iteration,

217
00:12:39.780 --> 00:12:44.790
which is iteration two, and then I've got
six years of stories planned for iteration

218
00:12:44.790 --> 00:12:49.715
three, and now I've just written an extra
two and I've realized that they're urgent

219
00:12:49.715 --> 00:12:54.930
then I have got to move my user stories
from iteration to an iterational play.

220
00:12:54.930 --> 00:12:58.840
I have got to reprioritize,
I have got to move them around.

221
00:12:58.840 --> 00:13:04.254
This is why we don't plan too far ahead
in any great detail because of change,

222
00:13:04.254 --> 00:13:07.016
because we accept that things change.

223
00:13:07.016 --> 00:13:12.520
In the traditional waterfell approach
we will try and plan as much as we can.

224
00:13:13.720 --> 00:13:18.110
But then that leaves us fairly
inflexible when it comes to change, and

225
00:13:18.110 --> 00:13:22.370
this is how we end up with our awful term,
I hate it, scope creep.

226
00:13:23.800 --> 00:13:28.430
And scope creep is really about
accepting that something's changed,

227
00:13:28.430 --> 00:13:32.490
maybe the schedule's changed,
maybe our backlog's changed, our task,

228
00:13:32.490 --> 00:13:36.160
we haven't got through our task
as quickly as we anticipated.

229
00:13:36.160 --> 00:13:40.320
And so we end up with scope creep for
whatever reason.

230
00:13:40.320 --> 00:13:44.310
Here, in an Agile environment, we accept
that there's going to be change, so

231
00:13:44.310 --> 00:13:45.580
we allow for change.

232
00:13:45.580 --> 00:13:48.150
And what we'll say is, well okay then,

233
00:13:48.150 --> 00:13:53.150
we're only gonna plan at a very high
level overall, over the entire project.

234
00:13:53.150 --> 00:13:57.693
And then, for each iteration,
once we've planned each iteration,

235
00:13:57.693 --> 00:14:02.313
which is only for the next four weeks
maximum, that bit's cast in stone

236
00:14:02.313 --> 00:14:06.861
because we have to know what we're
going to do for the next four weeks.

237
00:14:06.861 --> 00:14:09.247
You can't bungalow along
from week to week.

238
00:14:09.247 --> 00:14:10.341
>> Roll the dice, and say,

239
00:14:10.341 --> 00:14:12.100
what are we doing today.
>> Exactly.

240
00:14:12.100 --> 00:14:13.120
That's not efficient.

241
00:14:13.120 --> 00:14:16.160
It really is not going to be
an efficient way of doing anything, and

242
00:14:16.160 --> 00:14:17.850
it's definitely not going to be effective.

243
00:14:17.850 --> 00:14:21.980
It is not going to deliver anything that
is going to be useful because, every day,

244
00:14:21.980 --> 00:14:23.170
we could something different.

245
00:14:23.170 --> 00:14:23.970
I mean, why not?

246
00:14:23.970 --> 00:14:27.120
I got bored yesterday, so
I want to do something else today.

247
00:14:27.120 --> 00:14:30.120
All right, no,
we don't wanna do that, okay.

248
00:14:30.120 --> 00:14:32.460
So we've got to accommodate change.

249
00:14:32.460 --> 00:14:34.940
But we still have to have a process for

250
00:14:34.940 --> 00:14:38.140
And although we don't have
comprehensive documentation,

251
00:14:38.140 --> 00:14:40.350
you still gotta manage change.

252
00:14:40.350 --> 00:14:44.340
And that process that you've got in
front of you right now is so simple.

253
00:14:44.340 --> 00:14:47.120
It belongs to that so
to keep it simple approach.

254
00:14:47.120 --> 00:14:51.310
It's so simple but
we still have to manage it.

255
00:14:51.310 --> 00:14:53.438
It doesn't just happen in a night or.

256
00:14:53.438 --> 00:14:55.180

However

00:15:31.155 --> 00:15:34.070
An impediment is anything
that blocks progress.

00:15:34.070 --> 00:15:38.561
It's anything that either prohibits
us from going any further, or

00:15:38.561 --> 00:15:43.207

that we have to try to get round or

00:15:43.207 --> 00:15:45.831

00:15:45.831 --> 00:15:50.163
And impediments can be, they can be
something to completely stops us as I've

00:15:50.163 --> 00:15:53.910

00:15:53.910 --> 00:15:57.859
So including things like dependencies and

And even though we agree

Seasonal, trying to put deposits or

That means you can't

that particular story at

00:18:12.280 --> 00:18:14.920
Cuz you've only got four

00:18:14.920 --> 00:18:18.790
So that means that we gotta be realistic
about some of the tasks that we do

320
00:18:18.790 --> 00:18:20.630

00:18:20.630 --> 00:18:23.240
And we have to understand

with a lead time of 8 weeks or 12 weeks,

00:18:30.010 --> 00:18:32.240
We've got to do something about that.

00:18:32.240 --> 00:18:36.710
You can't just ignore it,

00:18:40.900 --> 00:18:43.210
You can't just do that at

are causing the impediment,

489
00:27:15.550 --> 00:27:17.428
then I'm gonna say that as well.
>> [LAUGH]

490
00:27:17.428 --> 00:27:18.189
>> [LAUGH] But

491
00:27:18.189 --> 00:27:22.099
it really depends on what
the impediment is too.

492
00:27:22.099 --> 00:27:24.660
Because it'll tell you there
that the project manager or

493
00:27:24.660 --> 00:27:27.890
that scrum master is responsible for
removing the impediment.

494
00:27:27.890 --> 00:27:32.850
If the impediment happens to be something
technical, if it's something to

495
00:27:32.850 --> 00:27:37.650
do with functionality, would,
and this is a question for

496
00:27:37.650 --> 00:27:40.020
you, would the product owner be involved?
>> Yes.

497
00:27:41.870 --> 00:27:43.550
>> Right, well, it depends.

498
00:27:43.550 --> 00:27:46.812
Cuz the product owner is responsible for
the product.

499
00:27:46.812 --> 00:27:52.570
If there's likely to be some impediment,
technically speaking

500
00:27:52.570 --> 00:27:59.100
that impediment, it's not going to be
an impediment to the coding, is it?

501
00:27:59.100 --> 00:28:02.130
It's actually gonna be an impediment
to caused by the operating system or

502
00:28:02.130 --> 00:28:08.560
caused by the fact that maybe we can't get
the hardware in on time, for instance.

503
00:28:08.560 --> 00:28:10.000
So not always.

504
00:28:10.000 --> 00:28:14.710
The product owner's only gonna be
involved in that if it actually affects

505
00:28:14.710 --> 00:28:19.670
the product that's being released,
i.e., if the impediment is caused by

506
00:28:19.670 --> 00:28:23.850
the product that's being released.
>> Yeah.

507
00:28:23.850 --> 00:28:24.671
>> There's a thought.

508
00:28:24.671 --> 00:28:29.530
[LAUGH] Impediments have gotta be
visible across the whole team,

509
00:28:29.530 --> 00:28:34.070
bearing in mind that our
team could consist of, well,

510
00:28:34.070 --> 00:28:37.330
it should consist of everybody
that's involved on the project.

511
00:28:37.330 --> 00:28:40.810
And so our stand-ups would consist of
everybody that's involved on the project.

512
00:28:40.810 --> 00:28:45.455
So we should all be aware of them
because one of us might have a solution.

513
00:28:45.455 --> 00:28:52.580
[LAUGH] If you and I aren't getting
on together, and I happen to mention,

514
00:28:52.580 --> 00:28:57.900
I've gotta work with Cherokee today in our
stand-up meeting, then it might well be

515
00:28:57.900 --> 00:29:02.380
that Ronnie sorta jumps in and says, I'll
tell you what, I'll work with you, Jo.

516
00:29:02.380 --> 00:29:06.860
Because then that sort of
removes you from harm's way.

517
00:29:06.860 --> 00:29:07.680
>> Is this a clue?

518
00:29:07.680 --> 00:29:09.610
If you guys see Ronnie in the next show,

519
00:29:09.610 --> 00:29:13.164
then you'll understand.
>> Right, yeah, exactly.

520
00:29:13.164 --> 00:29:19.150
[LAUGH] I might just do that
just deliberately, but yeah.

521
00:29:19.150 --> 00:29:23.383
So that's stand-up allows
us to communicate that.

522
00:29:23.383 --> 00:29:25.261
We've gotta employ tact, all right?

523
00:29:25.261 --> 00:29:27.710
[LAUGH] And we've gotta make sure
we are all part of the team.

524
00:29:27.710 --> 00:29:29.640
We do have to be objective.

525
00:29:29.640 --> 00:29:32.450
Ultimately, what we should all
be aiming for, and whether we're

526
00:29:32.450 --> 00:29:35.880
bringing in a new change all whether we're
actually trying to remove an impediment,

527
00:29:35.880 --> 00:29:40.630
what we're aiming for
is the delivery of value to the customer.

528
00:29:40.630 --> 00:29:45.080
And we're aiming for
the addition of change.

529
00:29:45.080 --> 00:29:48.990
We're aiming to bring change in and
at the same time remove impediments.

530
00:29:48.990 --> 00:29:51.690
But ultimately,
what we've gotta do is deliver value for

531
00:29:51.690 --> 00:29:55.983
our customer.
>> That's key, because they're ones with

532
00:29:55.983 --> 00:29:58.779
that perceived value, so.
>> Excellent, yeah, and

533
00:29:58.779 --> 00:29:59.808
on that note-
>> Yay.

534
00:29:59.808 --> 00:30:03.290
[LAUGH]
>> I will stop right there.

535
00:30:03.290 --> 00:30:03.890
Let's go ahead and sign out.

536
00:30:05.340 --> 00:30:08.050
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

537
00:30:08.050 --> 00:30:10.940
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

538
00:30:10.940 --> 00:30:16.931
[MUSIC]

539
00:30:16.931 --> 00:30:20.066
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: All projects must interface with teams and methodologies outside of the project environment, including those of 3rd party suppliers. This episode looks at managing these interfaces in more detail.
episodes.title: 3rd Party Interfaces
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:05.384
Welcome to IT ProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:05.384 --> 00:00:06.180
[CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:06.180 --> 00:00:12.462
>> You're watching IT ProTV.
>> Welcome

4
00:00:12.462 --> 00:00:15.610
everyone to
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

5
00:00:15.610 --> 00:00:17.710
I am your host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.710 --> 00:00:21.650
In this episode we'll be taking
a look at third party interfaces.

7
00:00:21.650 --> 00:00:24.510
And back with us in studios
today we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

8
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:26.230
thank you so much for joining us Jo.

9
00:00:26.230 --> 00:00:28.110
How are you?
>> I'm great thank you Cherokee.

10
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:29.760
How are you?
>> I'm doing well.

11
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:30.940
Thanks for asking.

12
00:00:30.940 --> 00:00:33.430
So Jo what will be looking at

13
00:00:33.430 --> 00:00:36.330
in this episode?
>> What we're going to be looking at is

14
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:41.090
none of the technical details, and
I know that's what makes you excited, but

15
00:00:41.090 --> 00:00:44.320
unfortunately not today.
>> I know you say the term interface and

16
00:00:44.320 --> 00:00:48.630
my mind starts to go like components and
router configuration,

17
00:00:48.630 --> 00:00:51.060
but none of that, right?
>> Well, we're not actually

18
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:55.570
building anything right here, what we're
doing is we're managing the project.

19
00:00:55.570 --> 00:00:57.650
And so, in this particular episode,

20
00:00:57.650 --> 00:01:00.560
what we're going to look at
are the interfaces that we have to manage,

21
00:01:00.560 --> 00:01:02.810
not the ones that we have to build.
>> Okay.

22
00:01:02.810 --> 00:01:04.529
>> So what we're gonna be doing is we're

23
00:01:04.529 --> 00:01:07.960
gonna be looking at interfaces or, rather,
you might want to call them relationships

24
00:01:07.960 --> 00:01:12.190
for instance, and that's relationships
with maybe other vendors,

25
00:01:12.190 --> 00:01:16.700
or third parties, suppliers, that
are using different methodologies to you.

26
00:01:16.700 --> 00:01:20.910
Or maybe even different projects within
your own sort of organization and

27
00:01:20.910 --> 00:01:25.230
with your own development teams that
are using different approaches to you,

28
00:01:25.230 --> 00:01:27.820
how do you actually
interact with these people?

29
00:01:27.820 --> 00:01:31.090
So that's what's on the agenda for
this particular episode.

30
00:01:31.090 --> 00:01:33.520
Is just looking at
relationship management,

31
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:34.720
that's really what we're doing.

32
00:01:35.950 --> 00:01:38.595
So lets take a look at our first slide
then that we have in front of us.

33
00:01:38.595 --> 00:01:43.860
There's no guarantee that the way that
you work is gonna be exactly the same

34
00:01:43.860 --> 00:01:48.950
as the way that your suppliers, your third
parties, or even your customers work.

35
00:01:48.950 --> 00:01:51.310
They might work in
a slightly different way.

36
00:01:51.310 --> 00:01:55.400
And whilst what we're trying to
do here in agile is we are trying

37
00:01:55.400 --> 00:01:59.330
to deliver value to our customers, and
I say trying, but we should be doing

38
00:01:59.330 --> 00:02:02.160
a little bit more than just trying,
because we should be delivering value.

39
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:05.430
If we're not, then we shouldn't
be doing anything, let's face it.

40
00:02:05.430 --> 00:02:10.000
So we wanna deliver value to the
customers, but if well, if our customers

41
00:02:10.000 --> 00:02:14.840
work at a slightly different way, or
if our suppliers work a slightly different

42
00:02:14.840 --> 00:02:18.960
way, then that's going to cause
problems for us, potentially.

43
00:02:18.960 --> 00:02:23.840
Let's just imagine this and, well, I could
say let's get a little bit technical,

44
00:02:23.840 --> 00:02:27.110
but I know that you're going to
out techie me, anyway, Cherokee.

45
00:02:27.110 --> 00:02:30.160
So maybe let's not get too technical.

46
00:02:30.160 --> 00:02:34.270
But let's just say that we are,
I know that in previous episodes

47
00:02:34.270 --> 00:02:37.700
we've been looking to at the concept
of maybe adding in some biometrics and

48
00:02:37.700 --> 00:02:42.800
fingerprint scanning, right maybe,
into our sign-on services.

49
00:02:42.800 --> 00:02:45.530
And so let's just say that
we're trying to do this.

50
00:02:45.530 --> 00:02:49.708
We've already explored in previous
episodes the fact that we've

51
00:02:49.708 --> 00:02:54.345
got user stories and we've got two
user stories, part of one epic story.

52
00:02:54.345 --> 00:02:58.520
One epic story is to,
can you remember what it is?

53
00:02:58.520 --> 00:03:02.790
[LAUGH]
>> It was to use fingerprint

54
00:03:02.790 --> 00:03:07.770
recognition to utilize single sign-ons for
all of our applications and

55
00:03:07.770 --> 00:03:09.220
environment.
>> Right,

56
00:03:09.220 --> 00:03:13.295
perfect, that was actually the vision.
>> Okay, something like that.

57
00:03:13.295 --> 00:03:14.170
>> [LAUGH] But no,

58
00:03:14.170 --> 00:03:18.940
no, the epic story was actually two
utilize the fingerprint scan in.

59
00:03:18.940 --> 00:03:24.770
So in other words to, not necessarily
the single sign-on but to actually,

60
00:03:24.770 --> 00:03:30.130
the first story, the epic story,
was to bring in fingerprint scanning.

61
00:03:30.130 --> 00:03:32.630
The single sign on bit
was kind of our vision.

62
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:35.900
Because that's what the project's
going to do as a whole.

63
00:03:35.900 --> 00:03:37.330
But we've got to think in iteration.

64
00:03:37.330 --> 00:03:39.100
So we've got to break it down.

65
00:03:39.100 --> 00:03:43.980
So the first story really which is
actually turns out to be an epic story.

66
00:03:43.980 --> 00:03:49.130
But that first story was about having
fingerprint recognition on our hardware.

67
00:03:50.610 --> 00:03:53.975
And that consisted then of two stories.

68
00:03:53.975 --> 00:03:58.250
Cuz we had to break that down, and
the two stories were the software,

69
00:03:58.250 --> 00:04:00.920
we've gotta get the software and
we've gotta get the hardware.

70
00:04:02.390 --> 00:04:07.010
Now for the most part we
are developers I would expect us

71
00:04:07.010 --> 00:04:10.310
as developers to be developing
the software and that's what we do.

72
00:04:11.640 --> 00:04:14.620
But then the other story is for-
>> The hardware.

73
00:04:14.620 --> 00:04:16.610
>> The hardware, right.

74
00:04:16.610 --> 00:04:18.660
When was the last time you
built your own hardware?

75
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:19.965
I know you're gonna say yesterday.

76
00:04:19.965 --> 00:04:23.710
[LAUGH] When was the last time you
built your own hardware, Cherokee?

77
00:04:23.710 --> 00:04:25.988
>> Actually, it has been a while.

78
00:04:25.988 --> 00:04:27.960
>> Right, [LAUGH] so

79
00:04:27.960 --> 00:04:32.880
we don't tend to do that,
unless we're sort of part of the big

80
00:04:32.880 --> 00:04:36.530
corporations ourselves, then we really
don't tend to build our own hardware.

81
00:04:36.530 --> 00:04:41.000
And even then, If you were part
of a big organization, like HP or

82
00:04:41.000 --> 00:04:44.830
Dell, then actually, the group that
develops the software is completely

83
00:04:44.830 --> 00:04:47.996
separate business from the group.
>> Yeah, I was about to say they usually

84
00:04:47.996 --> 00:04:50.584
have different divisions for that.
>> Right, so

85
00:04:50.584 --> 00:04:55.430
you're reliant on completely what you
might consider to be a third party.

86
00:04:55.430 --> 00:04:58.920
They may be somewhere in the same
organization, but they're still going to

87
00:04:58.920 --> 00:05:02.500
be a third party because they're
gonna be developing the hardware.

88
00:05:02.500 --> 00:05:07.100
And that epic story, which is the
combination of both of those user stories,

89
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:09.770
that epic story is not
going to be complete, or

90
00:05:09.770 --> 00:05:13.960
it's not gonna be considered done until
the functionality's been provided.

91
00:05:13.960 --> 00:05:17.540
And the functionality consists
of those two stories.

92
00:05:17.540 --> 00:05:20.210
Okay, so we laid the ground work for
that, right?

93
00:05:20.210 --> 00:05:25.907
We've set our scene, now we're in
a position where we're working in one way

94
00:05:25.907 --> 00:05:32.414
we're working in to an agile methodology
in our particular development environment.

95
00:05:32.414 --> 00:05:36.350
But the other division the one that
is working on a hardware isn't.

96
00:05:36.350 --> 00:05:40.420
They are working to a traditional
waterfall approach.

97
00:05:40.420 --> 00:05:43.050
Because it was hard to manufacture then

98
00:05:43.050 --> 00:05:45.830
generally you can't build
a laptop piece by piece, right?

99
00:05:45.830 --> 00:05:47.500
You gotta build the whole thing.

100
00:05:47.500 --> 00:05:51.140
So maybe it would make sense for them to
actually work to a waterfall approach.

101
00:05:51.140 --> 00:05:52.280
So how do we integrate?

102
00:05:53.550 --> 00:05:55.555
And no, that wasn't the question,
don't worry.

103
00:05:55.555 --> 00:05:58.400
[LAUGH] Cuz that wasn't the big challenge.

104
00:05:58.400 --> 00:06:01.080
But there is no right or wrong way.

105
00:06:01.080 --> 00:06:02.050
And you might say,

106
00:06:02.050 --> 00:06:06.550
well that took a long time to get to the
fact that there's no right or wrong way.

107
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:11.160
Well we've gotta make sure that
our interactions are still agile

108
00:06:11.160 --> 00:06:15.330
because working with somebody that's
not on the same methodology as us,

109
00:06:15.330 --> 00:06:17.250
well that brings in risk.

110
00:06:17.250 --> 00:06:21.740
It certainly brings in complications,
but it's most definitely brings in risk.

111
00:06:21.740 --> 00:06:26.473
So we will, I was gonna say tackle,
but I don't like use the word tackle.

112
00:06:26.473 --> 00:06:27.056
>> [LAUGH]

113
00:06:27.056 --> 00:06:29.140
>> [LAUGH] It kinda sounds a bit severe.

114
00:06:29.140 --> 00:06:33.730
But we'll approach that risk in
the same way that we approach any risk.

115
00:06:33.730 --> 00:06:38.280
And as part of our agile
project we do risk management.

116
00:06:38.280 --> 00:06:42.070
And so we have to think
about the risks that we have

117
00:06:42.070 --> 00:06:45.030
in dealing with that particular vendor.

118
00:06:45.030 --> 00:06:48.550
And the risks that we have, or
rather the constraints that we have.

119
00:06:48.550 --> 00:06:50.280
Take a look along the bottom there.

120
00:06:50.280 --> 00:06:51.630
We've got a defined budget.

121
00:06:51.630 --> 00:06:53.380
We've got a schedule.

122
00:06:53.380 --> 00:06:55.805
Or a schedule, as Cherokee might say.

123
00:06:55.805 --> 00:06:59.910
[LAUGH] We've gotta be able
to keep our end goal, right,

124
00:06:59.910 --> 00:07:01.980
that iteration, that epic story.

125
00:07:01.980 --> 00:07:03.990
We've gotta be able to keep that in mind.

126
00:07:03.990 --> 00:07:06.150
But we've also got, probably,

127
00:07:06.150 --> 00:07:11.090
contractual obligations as well
with that particular third-party.

128
00:07:11.090 --> 00:07:15.350
And then we've got the risk of the,
these are all constraints, but

129
00:07:15.350 --> 00:07:18.350
these are all risks as well,
that we need to analyze.

130
00:07:18.350 --> 00:07:21.660
Because you see, it's really, really easy,
if you're dealing with a third party,

131
00:07:21.660 --> 00:07:24.140
it's really easy for
them to go over the budget.

132
00:07:24.140 --> 00:07:27.920
It's really easy for them to stretch
out their schedule, or schedule.

133
00:07:27.920 --> 00:07:33.300
[LAUGH] And it not have any effect, or
it have a major effect on our project.

134
00:07:34.590 --> 00:07:38.280
It doesn't have any effect on their
project, but it will have a major effect

135
00:07:38.280 --> 00:07:41.980
to on ours, and it will have
a major effect on that epic story.

136
00:07:41.980 --> 00:07:43.870
So we have to manage that risk.

137
00:07:45.460 --> 00:07:49.834
Managing the risk that means
identifying the risk and

138
00:07:49.834 --> 00:07:53.633
then working out what we
can do with that risk.

139
00:07:53.633 --> 00:07:58.998
And I'm but in this sort of real high
level here working out what we can do and

140
00:07:58.998 --> 00:08:01.739
then decided what we're going to do.

141
00:08:01.739 --> 00:08:05.310
But what do you do if you don't
have any influence over that?

142
00:08:05.310 --> 00:08:06.360
Can you just accept it?

143
00:08:07.970 --> 00:08:10.720
Or are there other things that you can do?

144
00:08:10.720 --> 00:08:14.010
What about one of the things that we do
with risk management, is share the risk.

145
00:08:15.040 --> 00:08:17.939
Let's think about how we could
have applied that to our project,

146
00:08:17.939 --> 00:08:19.800
actually really easy.

147
00:08:19.800 --> 00:08:22.360
Because we are responsible for
the software, but

148
00:08:22.360 --> 00:08:27.320
the only user story is being built by,
well, somebody else.

149
00:08:27.320 --> 00:08:30.780
So maybe instead of giving it to just
one vendor, maybe we give it two.

150
00:08:30.780 --> 00:08:35.580
And maybe we say to Dell,
okay, can you go away, and

151
00:08:35.580 --> 00:08:37.240
develop the hardware that will do this?

152
00:08:37.240 --> 00:08:40.320
And then, we might say to HP or
to Apple, can you go away, and

153
00:08:40.320 --> 00:08:42.370
develop hardware that can do this?

154
00:08:42.370 --> 00:08:45.460
Which means that we're
actually sharing the risk.

155
00:08:45.460 --> 00:08:48.820
We have transferred, well,
we still own that risk,

156
00:08:48.820 --> 00:08:54.040
even though the actual performing
of these activities, well,

157
00:08:54.040 --> 00:08:56.230
we've transferred to somebody else,
but we've shared it.

158
00:08:56.230 --> 00:08:57.700
And we've shared it across vendors.

159
00:08:59.540 --> 00:09:03.570
What we have to do is make sure
that we manage our project within

160
00:09:03.570 --> 00:09:05.160
our defined constraints.

161
00:09:05.160 --> 00:09:10.020
And if we think that our vendors or our
third parties are going to influence that

162
00:09:10.020 --> 00:09:15.510
because of the way that they work,
then we have got to manage that.

163
00:09:15.510 --> 00:09:18.220
They're our constraints, and
they're our deliverables.

164
00:09:18.220 --> 00:09:20.477
So we've gotta manage as best as we can.

165
00:09:20.477 --> 00:09:24.399
A Waterfall approach to
a project is very likely, and

166
00:09:24.399 --> 00:09:29.279
I'm not gonna say 100% of the time,
but it's really likely to

167
00:09:29.279 --> 00:09:33.744
suffer from Cherokee's favorite two words,
scope creep.

168
00:09:33.744 --> 00:09:39.210
[LAUGH] Right, it's really likely
to go over in its schedule.

169
00:09:39.210 --> 00:09:42.022
It's really likely to go over in budget,
and

170
00:09:42.022 --> 00:09:46.170
that $500 laptop that they promised you
that they were going to get to you,

171
00:09:46.170 --> 00:09:50.090
is now been released, and
it's going to cost $1,000 instead.

172
00:09:50.090 --> 00:09:52.930
That's going to effect
our project severely.

173

really well, right?

399
00:22:57.630 --> 00:22:59.885
When does it ever work out just like that,
right?

400
00:22:59.885 --> 00:23:05.399
[LAUGH] Yeah, it's just exactly
the same as that plan, right?

401
00:23:05.399 --> 00:23:09.761
Don't bury your head in the sand, and
think that everything's gonna be okay.

402
00:23:09.761 --> 00:23:12.811
The use of penalties, and incentives,

403
00:23:12.811 --> 00:23:17.940
I can't tell you not to do it
because I know you're gonna do it.

404
00:23:17.940 --> 00:23:21.540
And as much as I'd like to tell you,
don't use penalties, and incentives.

405
00:23:21.540 --> 00:23:26.160
Because if you frighten people, if you're
using sort of a big stick to beat people

406
00:23:26.160 --> 00:23:28.960
up with, then you're not gonna
get the best out of them.

407
00:23:28.960 --> 00:23:30.300
So be flexible.

408
00:23:30.300 --> 00:23:32.130
Flexibility's really important.

409
00:23:32.130 --> 00:23:37.560
Flexibility is something that we mentioned
way back in one of the first episodes that

410
00:23:37.560 --> 00:23:42.910
we filmed in Agile, where we looked at
sort of Agile being a flexible approach.

411
00:23:42.910 --> 00:23:47.500
And we have to have a flexible
approach to dealing with our vendors.

412
00:23:47.500 --> 00:23:50.380
Understand, there's some
things that they can't change.

413
00:23:52.000 --> 00:23:55.871
They cant change the fact that theyre
going to release that laptop all in one

414
00:23:55.871 --> 00:23:56.522
go, right?

415
00:23:56.522 --> 00:23:59.807
Theyre not gonna give you one bit, and
then, another bit, and then, another bit,

416
00:23:59.807 --> 00:24:01.337
because that would be like a DIY laptop,

417
00:24:01.337 --> 00:24:01.972
right?
>> [LAUGH]

418
00:24:01.972 --> 00:24:03.453
>> Thats not going to happen.

419
00:24:03.453 --> 00:24:07.846
So understand that they can be
flexible with some things, but

420
00:24:07.846 --> 00:24:10.860
then we have to reach that compromise.

421
00:24:10.860 --> 00:24:12.680
And if you don't have
the relationship with them,

422
00:24:12.680 --> 00:24:15.240
then you're not gonna
reach that compromise.

423
00:24:15.240 --> 00:24:16.470
And then communicate with them.

424
00:24:17.900 --> 00:24:21.960
So set those expectations and understand
where there are flexibilities, but

425
00:24:21.960 --> 00:24:24.780
then communicate with
them on a regular basis.

426
00:24:24.780 --> 00:24:27.925
We did an episode on
communication planning, and

427
00:24:27.925 --> 00:24:30.830
that's really important,
plan your communication.

428
00:24:30.830 --> 00:24:34.817
And the minute you see something not
going the way that you need it to go,

429
00:24:34.817 --> 00:24:39.580
whether it's on your side or
whether it's on their side, communicate.

430
00:24:39.580 --> 00:24:42.970
Tell them that something is not
working out the way it should.

431
00:24:42.970 --> 00:24:47.220
And then work out a plan together,
and all of these

432
00:24:47.220 --> 00:24:52.510
activities should be activities that
are in your backlog, definitely so.

433
00:24:52.510 --> 00:24:55.370
Everything that we do,
I mean all of our communication plan and

434
00:24:55.370 --> 00:24:59.480
etc., there are activities
that we need to document.

435
00:24:59.480 --> 00:25:02.960
But more importantly, if they're defined,

436
00:25:02.960 --> 00:25:07.350
then you will undertake
them in a structured way.

437
00:25:07.350 --> 00:25:11.400
And it will keep it on your radar as well,
and then, of course,

438
00:25:11.400 --> 00:25:14.140
bring our vendors into testing as well.

439
00:25:14.140 --> 00:25:19.430
I mean, when we're testing the solution,
when we're testing the epic story,

440
00:25:19.430 --> 00:25:20.580
we bring them into testing.

441
00:25:20.580 --> 00:25:22.500
You think that that's fairly obvious, but

442
00:25:22.500 --> 00:25:24.610
what about when you're
testing the software?

443
00:25:25.740 --> 00:25:28.630
Because you've gotta have
something to test the software on.

444
00:25:29.940 --> 00:25:34.290
So it's at that point in time, even if
you've finished your first user story, and

445
00:25:34.290 --> 00:25:38.380
you've got your software ready, you're
not gonna be able to test it until you've

446
00:25:38.380 --> 00:25:44.040
got at least a beta test of
that piece of hardware itself.

447
00:25:44.040 --> 00:25:47.200
And so you've gotta work with your
supplier and your vendor, and

448
00:25:47.200 --> 00:25:50.870
you've gotta say, okay,
I think I've got the software ready.

449
00:25:50.870 --> 00:25:53.246
What have you got that I could test it on?
>> Yeah, how are you doing?

450
00:25:53.246 --> 00:25:55.738
>> Yeah, yeah, can I test it on something,

451
00:25:55.738 --> 00:25:56.318
please?

452
00:25:56.318 --> 00:25:58.898
Because then at least that
way I know whether it's okay,

453
00:25:58.898 --> 00:26:01.240
whether I'm headed in the right direction.

454
00:26:01.240 --> 00:26:05.210
Or whether, maybe,
I need to adjust my user stories and

455
00:26:05.210 --> 00:26:07.270
add something else into the backlog.

456
00:26:08.320 --> 00:26:09.670
Work with your vendor.

457
00:26:09.670 --> 00:26:10.820
Treat your vendor and

458
00:26:10.820 --> 00:26:14.520
your supplier as just another
member of the development team.

459
00:26:14.520 --> 00:26:18.525
If you wanna invite them to stand ups,
then invite them to stand ups.

460
00:26:18.525 --> 00:26:22.470
And they might not wanna come every time,
but you never know, invite them.

461
00:26:22.470 --> 00:26:25.500
Give them an input into what
it is that youre doing.

462
00:26:25.500 --> 00:26:27.210
Obviously, be wary of security,

463
00:26:27.210 --> 00:26:30.320
and there might be certain things that
you don't wanna discuss with them.

464
00:26:30.320 --> 00:26:33.560
But invite them,
have them in as part of your project.

465
00:26:33.560 --> 00:26:35.870
Ultimately, it's your relationship,

466
00:26:35.870 --> 00:26:40.600
it's that way of working that we have,
that is collaborative.

467
00:26:40.600 --> 00:26:45.630
It's that relationship that will
determine, especially in this instance,

468
00:26:45.630 --> 00:26:49.670
whether you're going to
actually achieve dumbness.

469
00:26:49.670 --> 00:26:53.630
You're not, if you don't have that
relationship in place with your vendor.

470
00:26:53.630 --> 00:26:54.620
>> Thank you, so much, Jo, for

471
00:26:54.620 --> 00:26:56.100
your time today, and thank you for

472
00:26:56.100 --> 00:26:58.890
explaining how we're gonna be
integrating with those third parties.

473
00:26:58.890 --> 00:27:01.740
And thank you for your time as well, but
we're gonna go head and sign out for

474
00:27:01.740 --> 00:27:02.640
this show.

475
00:27:02.640 --> 00:27:05.200
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

476
00:27:05.200 --> 00:27:07.692
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

477
00:27:07.692 --> 00:27:13.459
[MUSIC]

478
00:27:13.459 --> 00:27:16.780
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: The modifications discussed in the previous episode will need to be included in the iteration plan and therefore these changes will need to be managed. Impediments also need to be identified and removed and this episode identifies impediment types found in every project and how these may be overcome.
episodes.title: Delivering the Release
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:03.476
Welcome to IT ProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.476 --> 00:00:08.290
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.290 --> 00:00:11.944
>> You're watching IT ProTV.

4
00:00:11.944 --> 00:00:15.605
>> Welcome everyone to your
Agile Project Management Concepts series.

5
00:00:15.605 --> 00:00:17.615
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.615 --> 00:00:20.935
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at how we can actually be

7
00:00:20.935 --> 00:00:26.045
delivering the release, if I can say that,
deliver this information to you.

8
00:00:26.045 --> 00:00:30.475
And of course, you know it, we have Mrs.
Jo Peacock back in studios with us today.

9
00:00:30.475 --> 00:00:31.615
How's it going today, Jo?

10
00:00:31.615 --> 00:00:33.225
>> Absolutely great, thank you, Cherokee.

11
00:00:33.225 --> 00:00:33.805
How are you?

12
00:00:33.805 --> 00:00:36.090
>> I'm doing well, thank you for asking.

13
00:00:36.090 --> 00:00:37.900
So we've been at this for quite a while.

14
00:00:37.900 --> 00:00:42.430
We've been talking about
different iterations, and concepts

15
00:00:42.430 --> 00:00:47.180
that are bringing us to this culmination,
this delivery so to speak, right?

16
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:48.760
>> Well, I know what you're thinking.

17
00:00:48.760 --> 00:00:50.590
You're thinking about that margarita.

18
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:53.560
You know that initial
project vision that we have.

19
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:55.730
Right on one of our previous episodes,
right?

20
00:00:55.730 --> 00:00:57.326
>> Right.
[LAUGH] >> That's what she's thinking.

21
00:00:57.326 --> 00:01:00.610
She thinks I don't know this right.

22
00:01:00.610 --> 00:01:03.640
But yes we are,
we're on our penultimate episode.

23
00:01:03.640 --> 00:01:09.040
We are just about to finish
with our Agile concepts show.

24
00:01:09.040 --> 00:01:12.429
And we are sort of just
tying up the loose ends now,

25
00:01:12.429 --> 00:01:17.435
ready to deliver that project in its
entirety, to complete the project,

26
00:01:17.435 --> 00:01:21.713
to achieve doneness, as it were,
and to prepare ourselves for

27
00:01:21.713 --> 00:01:26.400
the Agile foundation test,
if that's what you want to do.

28
00:01:26.400 --> 00:01:30.370
Of course, if your ambition has been just
to gain a little bit more understanding

29
00:01:30.370 --> 00:01:34.370
about Agile, and Agile concepts,
then I hope that we have achieved that for

30
00:01:34.370 --> 00:01:36.010
you throughout our episodes.

31
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:40.720
And don't forget to download all of
the material that's available to you,

32
00:01:40.720 --> 00:01:43.200
that accompany all of
our episodes as well.

33
00:01:43.200 --> 00:01:45.110
So as Cherokee's already said,

34
00:01:45.110 --> 00:01:50.850
we are going to be looking at
planning a release in its entirety.

35
00:01:50.850 --> 00:01:56.060
So, so far in all of our previous episodes
we started right the way at the beginning,

36
00:01:56.060 --> 00:01:57.920
and we looked to the concepts of Agile.

37
00:01:57.920 --> 00:02:02.630
We looked at what Agile stand for,
the principles of Agile, and

38
00:02:02.630 --> 00:02:07.940
also, our values, and
we've looked at the pillars of Agile.

39
00:02:07.940 --> 00:02:10.800
So and the manifesto itself our values.

40
00:02:10.800 --> 00:02:15.320
So we looked at the iterative
approach to a project through Agile.

41
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:18.978
And that's where we get this term
iterations that Cherokee just mentioned.

42
00:02:18.978 --> 00:02:23.060
So we release

43
00:02:23.060 --> 00:02:28.390
in an iterative manner in the same way
that we develop in an iterative manner.

44
00:02:28.390 --> 00:02:31.310
But if you remember from
our previous episodes,

45
00:02:31.310 --> 00:02:36.840
we can actually join many iterations
together to form one release.

46
00:02:36.840 --> 00:02:37.880
>> Epic release.

47
00:02:37.880 --> 00:02:39.150
>> Sorry.
>> Epic release.

48
00:02:39.150 --> 00:02:40.180
>> An epic release, right.

49
00:02:40.180 --> 00:02:41.341
>> I've been paying attention Jo.

50
00:02:41.341 --> 00:02:43.362
[LAUGH]
>> That was an epic story,

51
00:02:43.362 --> 00:02:46.342
you weren't paying that much attention,
were you?

52
00:02:46.342 --> 00:02:47.968
>> Okay, half way there.

53
00:02:47.968 --> 00:02:49.578
[LAUGH]
>> It's all right,

54
00:02:49.578 --> 00:02:51.150
we'll let her off this time.

55
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:56.630
[LAUGH] So yeah, what we're doing
is we're going to, perhaps,

56
00:02:56.630 --> 00:03:01.550
join two or three iterations together,
and then, release them as one release.

57
00:03:01.550 --> 00:03:06.050
We might release individual
iteration itself,

58
00:03:07.740 --> 00:03:10.230
but that's probably not the most
efficient way of approaching this.

59
00:03:10.230 --> 00:03:14.080
Why do you think we wouldn't do that?

60
00:03:14.080 --> 00:03:16.930
>> Why wouldn't we release
on a per iteration basis?

61
00:03:18.990 --> 00:03:21.540
That's a good question Jo.

62
00:03:21.540 --> 00:03:25.920
From a software perspective because as you
mentioned earlier in the previous show

63
00:03:25.920 --> 00:03:30.750
about hardware, you probably would want
to have some kind of product unveiling.

64
00:03:30.750 --> 00:03:34.863
But from a software perspective,
okay, I remember,

65
00:03:34.863 --> 00:03:41.760
I think this is going to be not as a big
of a disturbance to an environment.

66
00:03:41.760 --> 00:03:44.240
>> Right, that's exactly the reason why.

67
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:46.930
It's not really about a disturbance to us.

68
00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:48.920
It's about delivering
value to the customer, and

69
00:03:48.920 --> 00:03:53.220
that's what we want to achieve is
to deliver value to the business.

70
00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:55.940
If you're being disturbed every
single week, you know for

71
00:03:55.940 --> 00:03:59.550
a fact that you're gonna get really
fed up with it really quick.

72
00:03:59.550 --> 00:04:01.110
It's gonna get old very, very quickly.

73
00:04:01.110 --> 00:04:03.690
So it's really about disturbance.

74
00:04:03.690 --> 00:04:08.590
And we've talked about in previous
episodes about ensuring that the number of

75
00:04:08.590 --> 00:04:10.180
increments that we have or

76
00:04:10.180 --> 00:04:13.990
rather the length of the increments
that we have is fairly consistent.

77
00:04:13.990 --> 00:04:16.240
So we don't want an increment of one week,
and then,

78
00:04:16.240 --> 00:04:19.710
an increment the last four weeks, and
then, an increment the last one week.

79
00:04:19.710 --> 00:04:23.450
We'd rather have sort of three episodes or
three, so

80
00:04:23.450 --> 00:04:27.510
three iterations of two weeks in length,
for instance.

81
00:04:27.510 --> 00:04:28.170
>> It's okay, Jo.

82
00:04:28.170 --> 00:04:31.805
I've been thinking about our episodes
as little mini iterations here.

83
00:04:31.805 --> 00:04:34.470
>> [LAUGH] Well,
that's exactly what they are.

84
00:04:34.470 --> 00:04:36.320
So you might not want to do that.

85
00:04:36.320 --> 00:04:40.390
Because if you're releasing every two
weeks, well, I don't know about you,

86
00:04:40.390 --> 00:04:42.390
but as a user I'm gonna
get pretty fed up with it.

87
00:04:43.510 --> 00:04:46.750
So what we might want to do,
and what would make sense,

88
00:04:46.750 --> 00:04:51.730
is work out what our users really need,
and we do that by prioritizing, and

89
00:04:51.730 --> 00:04:53.880
we do that right at the very
start of the project.

90
00:04:53.880 --> 00:04:58.440
But of course, we work out the detail
priorities at the start of each increment,

91
00:04:58.440 --> 00:05:03.320
but we might want to work out
what the priorities are in our

92
00:05:03.320 --> 00:05:07.170
user stories, and then,
we might want to bundle them together.

93
00:05:07.170 --> 00:05:08.130
So for instance,

94
00:05:08.130 --> 00:05:11.858
in previous episodes we looked at
the dependencies between stories.

95
00:05:11.858 --> 00:05:17.260
And we also looked at in previous episodes
the fact that we are implementing,

96
00:05:17.260 --> 00:05:18.230
didn't you know?

97
00:05:18.230 --> 00:05:21.580
We're actually implementing
new functionality.

98
00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:24.280
We're implementing the think
print recognition, aren't we?

99
00:05:24.280 --> 00:05:27.570
>> That's right.
>> Right, and so one depends on the other.

100
00:05:27.570 --> 00:05:31.520
And the fact is that the software depends
entirely on the hardware, but of course,

101
00:05:31.520 --> 00:05:34.040
being able to demonstrate that
the hardware works also depends on

102
00:05:34.040 --> 00:05:35.600
the software too.

103
00:05:35.600 --> 00:05:39.200
Now, they may be in different iterations,
they probably will be.

104
00:05:39.200 --> 00:05:41.880
We're probably going to get
the software finished before we have

105
00:05:41.880 --> 00:05:43.800
the hardware available to us.

106
00:05:43.800 --> 00:05:46.970
So if they're in different iterations,
we're going to bundle those iterations,

107
00:05:46.970 --> 00:05:49.210
and release them together.

108
00:05:49.210 --> 00:05:51.170
We're certainly not going
to release them separately,

109
00:05:51.170 --> 00:05:52.950
what would be the point of that?

110
00:05:52.950 --> 00:05:54.120
You can't use it.

111
00:05:54.120 --> 00:05:58.950
And then it goes against Agile principles
of only delivering what you need, and

112
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:02.220
not delivering additional
functionality that you don't need.

113
00:06:02.220 --> 00:06:04.641
So you don't deliver
something that can't be used.

114
00:06:04.641 --> 00:06:05.750
There's no sense in that.

115
00:06:06.920 --> 00:06:11.120
So we've got to make sure that
when we plan our iterations,

116
00:06:11.120 --> 00:06:13.350
we also plan our releases as well.

117
00:06:13.350 --> 00:06:17.570
So we understand what we're going
to release where, and when, and

118
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:20.940
what's it going to be
included in that release.

119
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:22.700
So what's included in that release?

120
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:27.870
Our iterations, and so, with each
individual iteration, the team and

121
00:06:27.870 --> 00:06:32.345
the product owner, the product owner
because they're responsible for the?

122
00:06:32.345 --> 00:06:33.866
>> Product.

123
00:06:33.866 --> 00:06:39.790
>> Right, they're responsible for the
functionality of the working product, yes.

124
00:06:39.790 --> 00:06:44.450
So the team, and the product owner will
actually review the functionality that's

125
00:06:44.450 --> 00:06:47.990
required to be delivered at
the end of that iteration.

126
00:06:49.900 --> 00:06:53.300
And then, as it already says there,
not every iteration ends with a release.

127
00:06:53.300 --> 00:06:56.170
And in fact,
in this particular diagram here,

128
00:06:56.170 --> 00:07:01.470
you've got three iterations there or
three increments, and they're released.

129
00:07:01.470 --> 00:07:03.270
They're bundled together,
and released together.

130
00:07:04.410 --> 00:07:07.850
So bearing in mind,
we're thinking about efficiency.

131
00:07:07.850 --> 00:07:11.235
And I keep putting Cherokee on the spot,
I know.

132
00:07:11.235 --> 00:07:11.833
>> [LAUGH]
>> Keep in mind

133
00:07:11.833 --> 00:07:15.740
that we're thinking about efficiency here,
when do you think we're going to test?

134
00:07:17.000 --> 00:07:17.880
>> Prior to release.

135
00:07:19.180 --> 00:07:22.710
>> Well, that's kind of just a catchall,
isn't it?

136
00:07:22.710 --> 00:07:23.910
>> Like more specifically?

137
00:07:23.910 --> 00:07:24.410
>> Yeah.

138
00:07:26.650 --> 00:07:31.560
>> Well shoot, since we're on such
a short timeline, I would say with

139
00:07:31.560 --> 00:07:35.810
enough time to give yourself for rework.

140
00:07:35.810 --> 00:07:39.030
But we don't wanna be really doing that
here in our iterations cuz we have

141
00:07:39.030 --> 00:07:40.600
the option to fail.

142
00:07:40.600 --> 00:07:44.460
So in a small window there,
I would assume.

143
00:07:45.970 --> 00:07:47.660
>> I hope you've been paying attention.

144
00:07:47.660 --> 00:07:51.908
This is all I'm saying, I hope you've been
paying attention to our previous episodes

145
00:07:51.908 --> 00:07:54.306
cuz it's quite obvious
that somebody hasn't.

146
00:07:54.306 --> 00:07:56.887
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm just going to leave that one there.

147
00:07:56.887 --> 00:07:59.360
We want to fail fast.

148
00:07:59.360 --> 00:08:05.591
Yep, failing fast, failing early means
that we can rectify any situation early,

149
00:08:05.591 --> 00:08:09.431
which means that we actually
test each increment.

150
