Having bad surgery,
we need that fixed in right now.

382
00:21:12.337 --> 00:21:15.559
If you have a bad haircut, quite often
you just gotta sort of look at it.

383
00:21:15.559 --> 00:21:16.081
>> Deal with it.

384
00:21:16.081 --> 00:21:16.596
[LAUGH]
>> Look at it.

385
00:21:16.596 --> 00:21:18.259
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, look at himself for

386
00:21:18.259 --> 00:21:20.416
a few weeks and go, no,
did that really happen?

387
00:21:20.416 --> 00:21:23.215
But at the end of the day,
it's not life-threatening,

388
00:21:23.215 --> 00:21:25.792
whereas a defect in surgery
is life-threatening.

389
00:21:25.792 --> 00:21:29.719
If somebody makes a mistake there,
yeah, that's an issue, all right?

390
00:21:29.719 --> 00:21:30.694
[LAUGH]
>> So yes,

391
00:21:30.694 --> 00:21:35.269
your defects, we'll prioritize them in
the same way that we prioritize all of our

392
00:21:35.269 --> 00:21:39.465
other stories because our defects,
quite simply, need to be dealt with.

393
00:21:39.465 --> 00:21:42.507
You can't just sort of brush
them under the carpet and

394
00:21:42.507 --> 00:21:45.288
hope that they never get
seen because they will.

395
00:21:45.288 --> 00:21:47.366
So we have to be honest about them.

396
00:21:47.366 --> 00:21:48.578
We have to document them.

397
00:21:48.578 --> 00:21:52.800
And then we deal with them in the same way
that we deal with all of the other stories

398
00:21:52.800 --> 00:21:55.149
that we have, our customer requirements.

399
00:21:55.149 --> 00:21:58.631
But what we have to understand is that,
as we get a defect,

400
00:21:58.631 --> 00:22:03.056
then that will mean prioritizing or
reprioritizing other user stories.

401
00:22:03.056 --> 00:22:07.035
And I'm not even gonna say that may
mean reprioritizing other stories.

402
00:22:07.035 --> 00:22:10.313
It's not a may,
we will have to do that task.

403
00:22:10.313 --> 00:22:13.913
So when we highlight a defect,
it has to be documented,

404
00:22:13.913 --> 00:22:18.293
and then we have to go back and
revisit all of our priorities, okay?

405
00:22:18.293 --> 00:22:21.502
So as far as our agile
project is concerned,

406
00:22:21.502 --> 00:22:24.817
we're pretty much at
the end of our project.

407
00:22:24.817 --> 00:22:27.119
Now we are planning our release.

408
00:22:27.119 --> 00:22:32.084
And we're ready to release all of our
software, or release the iterations that

409
00:22:32.084 --> 00:22:36.767
we've decided we're going to release
in this particular moment in time.

410
00:22:36.767 --> 00:22:40.512
What's next really is just for
us to close out our project.

411
00:22:40.512 --> 00:22:43.118
And that we're gonna look
at in the next episode.

412
00:22:43.118 --> 00:22:45.800
Right, Jo, what was the word that you
used at the beginning of this show?

413
00:22:45.800 --> 00:22:50.310
It's definitely a British thing
because our British mate from across

414
00:22:50.310 --> 00:22:54.140
the pond there, Pete,
said it also, not paramount, no?

415
00:22:54.140 --> 00:22:54.886
>> Penultimate.

416
00:22:54.886 --> 00:22:56.793
>> Penultimate, I like that.

417
00:22:56.793 --> 00:22:57.366
That's a good word.

418
00:22:57.366 --> 00:22:58.463
>> [LAUGH] It means the one before last.

419
00:22:58.463 --> 00:22:59.148
>> The one before the last.

420
00:22:59.148 --> 00:23:00.166
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

421
00:23:00.166 --> 00:23:00.981
>> I knew the definition, but

422
00:23:00.981 --> 00:23:02.334
I just couldn't remember
what the term was.

423
00:23:02.334 --> 00:23:04.432
So yes, thank you for that, Jo.

424
00:23:04.432 --> 00:23:05.506
Everything has been great so far.

425
00:23:05.506 --> 00:23:07.185
And I look forward to our last show and

426
00:23:07.185 --> 00:23:09.469
not just because we're
gonna get rid of you, Jo.

427
00:23:09.469 --> 00:23:10.432
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I'm looking

428
00:23:10.432 --> 00:23:13.976
forward to some more great information
that you're ready to bring.

429
00:23:13.976 --> 00:23:16.511
Hopefully, you'll be able to stay with us,
and we can go ahead and

430
00:23:16.511 --> 00:23:17.522
sign out of this show now.

431
00:23:17.522 --> 00:23:18.954
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

432
00:23:18.954 --> 00:23:19.983
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

433
00:23:19.983 --> 00:23:22.658
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

434
00:23:22.658 --> 00:23:28.483
[MUSIC]

435
00:23:28.483 --> 00:23:31.721
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: The modifications discussed in the previous episode will need to be included in the iteration plan and therefore these changes will need to be managed. Impediments also need to be identified and removed and this episode identifies impediment types found in every project and how these may be overcome.
episodes.title: Project Close-out
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:06.192
I am your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.192 --> 00:00:08.270
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.270 --> 00:00:11.974
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.

5
00:00:11.974 --> 00:00:16.493
>> Welcome everyone to your Agile Project
Management Concept Series I'm your host,

6
00:00:16.493 --> 00:00:18.080
Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.080 --> 00:00:21.670
In this episode we'll take a look at
what it really requires to go ahead and

8
00:00:21.670 --> 00:00:22.720
close out a project.

9
00:00:22.720 --> 00:00:26.100
And of course with us today in
studios we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:26.100 --> 00:00:27.660
Thank you so much for
joining us today, Jo.

11
00:00:27.660 --> 00:00:28.890
How's it going?

12
00:00:28.890 --> 00:00:29.920
>> Absolutely great.

13
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:31.450
Thank you Cherokee, how are you?

14
00:00:31.450 --> 00:00:32.000
>> Wonderful.

15
00:00:32.000 --> 00:00:33.400
Do you ever have a bad day?

16
00:00:34.930 --> 00:00:37.228
Sometimes, but
I'm not telling you about that.

17
00:00:37.228 --> 00:00:39.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> But speaking-

18
00:00:39.470 --> 00:00:40.400
>> No, of course I don't.

19
00:00:40.400 --> 00:00:41.572
That is absolutely nominal.

20
00:00:41.572 --> 00:00:43.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know.

21
00:00:43.130 --> 00:00:44.230
I'm just messing with you.

22
00:00:44.230 --> 00:00:48.120
And speaking of closing out
we're getting close to a project

23
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:49.550
close out ourselves, correct?

24
00:00:49.550 --> 00:00:51.540
>> Were we speaking of closing out.

25
00:00:51.540 --> 00:00:52.340
>> I was.

26
00:00:52.340 --> 00:00:55.210
>> Okay then, fair enough [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:00:55.210 --> 00:00:56.350
>> Then yeah, we are.

28
00:00:56.350 --> 00:01:00.750
In this episode we are actually looking
at all of our close out activities

29
00:01:00.750 --> 00:01:02.840
because in all of our previous episodes.

30
00:01:02.840 --> 00:01:06.420
We have looked at the startup
of an Agile project.

31
00:01:06.420 --> 00:01:09.860
We've looked at the delivery
of our iterations and

32
00:01:09.860 --> 00:01:11.944
the delivery of our releases.

33
00:01:11.944 --> 00:01:14.183
We've looked at what to do
when there are defects,

34
00:01:14.183 --> 00:01:17.735
how to work with people that aren't quite
working on the same methodology as us.

35
00:01:17.735 --> 00:01:19.090
And now, guess what?

36
00:01:19.090 --> 00:01:20.720
We've delivered everything.

37
00:01:20.720 --> 00:01:24.730
Which if I remember rightly,
according to one of our previous episodes,

38
00:01:24.730 --> 00:01:28.520
that means that you just about to get
a margarita in your hand, is that right?

39
00:01:28.520 --> 00:01:30.740
>> I think I earned that, right?

40
00:01:30.740 --> 00:01:32.780
>> What, for working with me,
is that what you're saying?

41
00:01:32.780 --> 00:01:35.270
>> Actually, I have a confession, Jo.

42
00:01:36.710 --> 00:01:39.472
I don't even drink,
I don't even drink margaritas.

43
00:01:39.472 --> 00:01:40.770
>> You don't drink margaritas.

44
00:01:40.770 --> 00:01:44.490
Well, I've got a confession too,
I don't like them either.

45
00:01:44.490 --> 00:01:49.150
>> I'll take the beach part though still,
if you're still good with that.

46
00:01:49.150 --> 00:01:50.340
>> Okay we can head to beach.

47
00:01:50.340 --> 00:01:51.860
>> Okay.
>> That sounds good, yeah,

48
00:01:51.860 --> 00:01:55.570
as long as it's not raining out there,
we can head to the beach.

49
00:01:55.570 --> 00:01:58.332
Even if it's raining as long as it's
a decent temperature we're okay.

50
00:01:58.332 --> 00:01:58.969
>> Okay.

51
00:01:58.969 --> 00:02:03.600
>> [LAUGH] So yeah let's wrap
this project up then shall we?

52
00:02:03.600 --> 00:02:06.450
Don't forget though this
isn't our final episode.

53
00:02:06.450 --> 00:02:11.650
What you do have after this episode is
you do have the opportunity to review

54
00:02:11.650 --> 00:02:13.320
our additional materials.

55
00:02:13.320 --> 00:02:15.520
The supplementary information
that you can download.

56
00:02:15.520 --> 00:02:19.760
And also take the sample test paper,
which will give you preparation for

57
00:02:19.760 --> 00:02:23.790
your VCS Agile Foundation certification.

58
00:02:25.180 --> 00:02:28.380
So let's take a look then at what
we do at the end of our project.

59
00:02:28.380 --> 00:02:32.767
Well, you can't just kind of tick
a box and then just walk away, right?

60
00:02:32.767 --> 00:02:39.740
Now different to our waterfall project,
this is where we release.

61
00:02:39.740 --> 00:02:42.880
We release,
we check that everything is working okay,

62
00:02:42.880 --> 00:02:47.800
we have that early life support period
where we do the hand holding with our

63
00:02:47.800 --> 00:02:51.540
support teams, and
then we kind of walk away.

64
00:02:51.540 --> 00:02:54.530
Well, here, we don't really do that,

65
00:02:54.530 --> 00:02:57.520
because you see,
we've already done the releases.

66
00:02:57.520 --> 00:03:00.380
We've been doing those
releases iteratively.

67
00:03:00.380 --> 00:03:04.970
And even though we don't really say
every time we have an iteration,

68
00:03:04.970 --> 00:03:10.150
every time we complete an iteration,
we still do iterative releases.

69
00:03:10.150 --> 00:03:13.845
So it's slightly different to
the waterfall approach, but,

70
00:03:13.845 --> 00:03:18.027
and here where the similarities start,
is we've still got to be able to

71
00:03:18.027 --> 00:03:22.439
demonstrate that we have achieved what
we have supposed to have achieved.

72
00:03:22.439 --> 00:03:26.230
And that we have also
achieved value delivery.

73
00:03:26.230 --> 00:03:29.166
Value delivery's quite often
expressed in customer terms.

74
00:03:29.166 --> 00:03:33.300
Well, that is, money, yeah?

75
00:03:33.300 --> 00:03:35.720
It's a return on investment.

76
00:03:35.720 --> 00:03:39.720
Now we know that returns on
investment are not always financial.

77
00:03:39.720 --> 00:03:44.450
And so
you could also have statements for VOI,

78
00:03:44.450 --> 00:03:49.910
as well as ROI,
VOI meaning a value on investment return.

79
00:03:49.910 --> 00:03:55.520
When a value on investment return is
a return that is not financially related.

80
00:03:55.520 --> 00:03:58.930
So it could be adherence to regulations,
for instance.

81
00:03:58.930 --> 00:04:00.950
That would be a value return.

82
00:04:00.950 --> 00:04:04.850
Or maybe just getting to market first,
that would be a value return as well.

83
00:04:04.850 --> 00:04:06.280
>> Would time fall into that category?

84
00:04:06.280 --> 00:04:09.330
If I were investing time
into this training series?

85
00:04:10.370 --> 00:04:12.830
>> Right yeah,
that would be a value return.

86
00:04:12.830 --> 00:04:16.890
Lets think about it if you were investing
time into this particular series

87
00:04:16.890 --> 00:04:19.530
then you might achieve an accreditation.

88
00:04:19.530 --> 00:04:20.790
Hopefully you will.

89
00:04:20.790 --> 00:04:26.510
But you will definitely have achieved new
knowledge, new skills, which hopefully

90
00:04:26.510 --> 00:04:31.100
will then translate into you being more
productive in your work environment.

91
00:04:31.100 --> 00:04:35.990
But also you being more salable, and
you having more skills on your resume.

92
00:04:35.990 --> 00:04:38.860
Now hopefully eventually
the value on investment

93
00:04:38.860 --> 00:04:42.000
will also deliver a financial
return on that investment.

94
00:04:42.000 --> 00:04:43.212
>> You know, that's the goal, Jo.

95
00:04:43.212 --> 00:04:46.902
>> [CROSSTALK] Cuz you need
to get a raise out of it.

96
00:04:46.902 --> 00:04:48.690
But no, that wasn't a guarantee.

97
00:04:48.690 --> 00:04:50.130
Okay, don't take that the wrong way.

98
00:04:50.130 --> 00:04:52.140
Nobody's getting raise today.

99
00:04:53.910 --> 00:04:57.410
But you know if you build
up your skills then

100
00:04:57.410 --> 00:05:01.360
there's a really good chance that
you will become more marketable and

101
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:05.490
therefore you will become more
valuable to your organization.

102
00:05:05.490 --> 00:05:09.510
And yeah you might actually get
something out of it in financial terms.

103
00:05:10.640 --> 00:05:12.110
Everything that we do is to improve.

104
00:05:12.110 --> 00:05:17.480
And so even when we take a training class,
or when we're delivering a new project,

105
00:05:17.480 --> 00:05:20.040
we're delivering new features,
we do it to improve.

106
00:05:20.040 --> 00:05:23.060
But we have to be able to
demonstrate that improvement.

107
00:05:23.060 --> 00:05:27.580
We have to demonstrate that we have
achieved what we set out to achieve.

108
00:05:27.580 --> 00:05:30.980
And so in Agile terms, what that means is,

109
00:05:30.980 --> 00:05:35.419
we've got to verify that we
have met all of our stories,

110
00:05:35.419 --> 00:05:40.912
we've delivered our stories, and
we satisfied our done criteria.

111
00:05:40.912 --> 00:05:43.340
Do you remember what MosCoW stood for?

112
00:05:43.340 --> 00:05:48.980
>> Must haves, should haves, could haves,
look, I'm missing a few in there,

113
00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:52.935
but along those lines-
>> There's only so many letters, right?

114
00:05:52.935 --> 00:05:55.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> Must have,

115
00:05:55.070 --> 00:05:57.500
that's our must have features.

116
00:05:57.500 --> 00:06:03.000
Should have, what it should have,
but we won't cry if it doesn't.

117
00:06:03.000 --> 00:06:05.180
What it could have, which is kind of like,

118
00:06:05.180 --> 00:06:08.480
how nice to have them,
we're okay with that.

119
00:06:08.480 --> 00:06:12.880
And then won't have right now or
would like in the future.

120
00:06:12.880 --> 00:06:17.160
I've seen it written both ways and
they both mean pretty much the same thing.

121
00:06:17.160 --> 00:06:19.970
Now, let's think about lean principles.

122
00:06:21.400 --> 00:06:23.000
So there's a danger.

123
00:06:24.840 --> 00:06:29.929
And the danger is that when
we are first establishing our

124
00:06:29.929 --> 00:06:37.950
MosCoW list then we categorize trying to
categorize everything as a must have.

125
00:06:39.000 --> 00:06:45.420
Because you see, as far as a lean is
concerned, we only deliver what's needed.

126
00:06:45.420 --> 00:06:48.200
We don't deliver excess functionality.

127
00:06:48.200 --> 00:06:52.110
So as far as lean is concerned, you might
even think to yourself, well, that means

128
00:06:52.110 --> 00:06:57.240
we exclude the should-haves and the
could-haves, and the won't-have right now.

129
00:06:57.240 --> 00:07:02.240
And so because people think like that,
and because people will

130
00:07:02.240 --> 00:07:05.650
automatically think that this is
what happens in an Agile project.

131
00:07:05.650 --> 00:07:12.320
Then all of the wants, they then tend to
categorize that [CROSSTALK] must haves.

132
00:07:12.320 --> 00:07:13.063
Right.

133
00:07:13.063 --> 00:07:18.424
So we've got to be really careful, and
that's something that when it comes

134
00:07:18.424 --> 00:07:23.410
to quantifying whether we're done,
and quantifying the doneness.

135
00:07:23.410 --> 00:07:26.250
Obviously, right at
the start of the project.

136
00:07:26.250 --> 00:07:29.350
Right at the start of the project,
not at the start of each iteration, but

137
00:07:29.350 --> 00:07:33.640
right at the start of the project,
we verified our problem statements, and

138
00:07:33.640 --> 00:07:38.320
we also looked at our user stories,
sure, we added on to those user stories.

139
00:07:38.320 --> 00:07:40.390
And possibly because of defects as well.

140
00:07:41.832 --> 00:07:45.290
But nevertheless, we've got to be
really careful in our categorization.

141
00:07:45.290 --> 00:07:47.000
And we have got to be realistic.

142
00:07:48.000 --> 00:07:54.740
And what you see left in that backlog
section there on that particular screen.

143
00:07:54.740 --> 00:07:58.524
They could be those items
that have fallen into our,

144
00:07:58.524 --> 00:08:03.170
you should could haves or
should haves or want to have right now.

145
00:08:03.170 --> 00:08:05.719
But you've got to decide,
at the end of a project,

146
00:08:05.719 --> 00:08:08.700
what you're going to do with
anything that's remaining.

147
00:08:08.700 --> 00:08:12.390
I guarantee that there will be
stories that are remaining.

148
00:08:12.390 --> 00:08:15.580
There will be stories that
haven't quite finished.

149
00:08:15.580 --> 00:08:17.250
So what do you do about it?

150
00:08:17.250 --> 00:08:19.630
You haven't delivered those stories.

151
00:08:19.630 --> 00:08:20.760
What are you going to do?

152
00:08:22.170 --> 00:08:24.310
And it all comes down to
the correct categorization.

153
00:08:24.310 --> 00:08:27.590
And you've got to remember right at
the beginning that not everything

154
00:08:27.590 --> 00:08:28.290
is a must have.

155
00:08:29.900 --> 00:08:33.770
Some things we can transfer to operations,
especially if there

156
00:08:33.770 --> 00:08:36.990
are things like technical issues
that just need addressing.

157
00:08:36.990 --> 00:08:39.510
Maybe we'll hand those off to operations.

158
00:08:39.510 --> 00:08:42.405
But by the way, we're not just
gonna throw them over the fence.

159
00:08:42.405 --> 00:08:45.740
We don't just turn to our operations and
say, all right, that's it,

160
00:08:45.740 --> 00:08:49.500
then we're done with that,
that's it, over to you.

161
00:08:49.500 --> 00:08:51.910
No, no,
that's never gonna be best practice.

162
00:08:53.190 --> 00:08:54.380
We have to make a decision, and

163
00:08:54.380 --> 00:08:58.450
it has to be a decision in line
with what the customer values.

164
00:08:58.450 --> 00:09:01.930
And sometimes, we might not actually
sign off on our project, or

165
00:09:01.930 --> 00:09:06.310
close out of our project until we've
delivered yet another iteration.

166
00:09:06.310 --> 00:09:10.720
But some of these stories, we might not
actually be able to deliver on anyway,

167
00:09:10.720 --> 00:09:14.390
because think about our dependencies and
our third-party providers.

168
00:09:14.390 --> 00:09:16.829
We might be completely dependent on them,
and

169
00:09:16.829 --> 00:09:19.215
we might not be able to
deliver on that story.

170
00:09:19.215 --> 00:09:23.030
>> From a personal note, I'm just
like sitting over here thinking, man,

171
00:09:23.030 --> 00:09:25.736
I'm going through this
home renovation process.

172
00:09:25.736 --> 00:09:30.330
You should see my backlog
of want to haves, Jo.

173
00:09:30.330 --> 00:09:32.705
>> [LAUGH]
>> And the reason I can't deliver is

174
00:09:32.705 --> 00:09:34.950
a budget constraint.

175
00:09:34.950 --> 00:09:36.340
So I totally get it there.

176
00:09:36.340 --> 00:09:40.852

404
00:22:21.846 --> 00:22:25.970
>> So finding some kind of metric or
PKI that works for your organization.

405
00:22:25.970 --> 00:22:27.856
>> KPI even, yeah.

406
00:22:27.856 --> 00:22:31.134
>> I did that in between talking in shows,
public key infrastructure.

407
00:22:31.134 --> 00:22:33.342
Yeah, they're like why is
she talking about that?

408
00:22:33.342 --> 00:22:36.478
>> [LAUGH]
>> KPI, Key Performance Indicator.

409
00:22:36.478 --> 00:22:39.506
Listen, too many acronyms and IT guys.

410
00:22:39.506 --> 00:22:42.785
We already know this
>> And not enough margaritas, perhaps.

411
00:22:42.785 --> 00:22:45.947
>> [LAUGH] Any who, Jo do you have any
final thoughts or anything else that

412
00:22:45.947 --> 00:22:49.320
you'd like to convey before we go
ahead and close out this episode?

413
00:22:49.320 --> 00:22:50.351
>> Yeah, I do.

414
00:22:50.351 --> 00:22:53.217
I've always got some
final nuggets of wisdom.

415
00:22:53.217 --> 00:22:55.264
>> [LAUGH] Great tid bits, yeah.

416
00:22:55.264 --> 00:22:59.762
>> Yeah, at this point in time,
in your next very, very small episode,

417
00:22:59.762 --> 00:23:04.571
you are going to be invited to download
all of the material that accompanies

418
00:23:04.571 --> 00:23:06.279
this particular series.

419
00:23:06.279 --> 00:23:10.699
And then undertake the exercises that
there are at the end of every single

420
00:23:10.699 --> 00:23:11.650
episode.

421
00:23:11.650 --> 00:23:13.820
So please feel free to do that.

422
00:23:13.820 --> 00:23:17.540
And if you do have any questions,
then come back to us.

423
00:23:17.540 --> 00:23:20.585
We're here, we're on the forum,
you can chat with us, and

424
00:23:20.585 --> 00:23:24.052
we'll certainly answer any
queries that you might have.

425
00:23:24.052 --> 00:23:27.673
>> All right Jo, should I be like
stretching and getting ready for

426
00:23:27.673 --> 00:23:29.529
all these exercises over here?

427
00:23:29.529 --> 00:23:32.110
>> Well I think so because I think
you might find them a challenge.

428
00:23:32.110 --> 00:23:34.662
>> [LAUGH] No but in all seriousness,
thank you so much for

429
00:23:34.662 --> 00:23:37.971
everything you've brought to
the table here, we appreciate that.

430
00:23:37.971 --> 00:23:41.720
I appreciate you guys hanging with us but
now's the time for us to sign out.

431
00:23:41.720 --> 00:23:43.153
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

432
00:23:43.153 --> 00:23:43.922
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

433
00:23:43.922 --> 00:23:46.040
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

434
00:23:46.040 --> 00:23:52.686
[MUSIC]

435
00:23:52.686 --> 00:23:55.417
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: A review over the BCS Agile Foundation sample exam paper.
episodes.title: Test Prep
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.050 --> 00:00:06.698
[SOUND] Hi and welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:06.698 --> 00:00:09.889
I'm Jo Peacock and congratulations,

3
00:00:09.889 --> 00:00:15.930
you have completed the series on
Agile Project Management Concepts.

4
00:00:15.930 --> 00:00:17.820
And now what I'm gonna do
is just talk to you very,

5
00:00:17.820 --> 00:00:23.850
very briefly about the Agile Foundation
certification and exam.

6
00:00:23.850 --> 00:00:27.120
So now that you've completed this series,
what's available for

7
00:00:27.120 --> 00:00:31.440
you are all of the course materials
that go along with the series.

8
00:00:31.440 --> 00:00:33.310
You can download those.

9
00:00:33.310 --> 00:00:36.190
Download those from our
website at itpro.tv and

10
00:00:36.190 --> 00:00:40.030
you'll find that at the end of every
episode, there are a series of

11
00:00:40.030 --> 00:00:45.140
exercise on those slides decks and
I'd like you just to undertake those.

12
00:00:45.140 --> 00:00:46.100
Do the exercises.

13
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:50.730
Give yourself a quick refresher on all
of the subjects that we've covered.

14
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:54.390
Once you've done that and you're
comfortable with what you already know and

15
00:00:54.390 --> 00:00:59.610
you've done a quick recap of the episodes,
then download the sample paper.

16
00:00:59.610 --> 00:01:02.700
The sample paper is 20 questions long.

17
00:01:02.700 --> 00:01:07.283
In real life, when you do your real test,
it will be 40 questions long.

18
00:01:07.283 --> 00:01:10.578
But this sample paper
is 20 questions long,

19
00:01:10.578 --> 00:01:15.486
just to give you a taste as to what
the foundation test is like, okay?

20
00:01:15.486 --> 00:01:20.370
And what I'd like you to do, download
that, take that test, and the come back

21
00:01:20.370 --> 00:01:25.280
and join us on our next episode,
when we'll go over that test for you.

22
00:01:25.280 --> 00:01:28.120
And then after you've done that,
once we've gone over the test,

23
00:01:28.120 --> 00:01:33.537
then you're ready to log onto the website
that's on that slide there, bcs.org and

24
00:01:33.537 --> 00:01:38.477
register for
your Agile Foundation certification.

25
00:01:38.477 --> 00:01:40.202
I'll see you later.

26
00:01:40.202 --> 00:01:43.488
[SOUND]

episodes.description: A review over the BCS Agile Foundation sample exam paper.
episodes.title: Sample Paper Review agile foundation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.050 --> 00:00:04.941
[SOUND] Hi, I'm Jo Peacock and

2
00:00:04.941 --> 00:00:08.859
welcome to ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:08.859 --> 00:00:13.120
And, right now, what we're doing
in this particular episode,

4
00:00:13.120 --> 00:00:17.950
this is our final episode for
our Agile Project Management Concept show.

5
00:00:17.950 --> 00:00:22.300
And in this particular episode, what we're
going to do is we're going to overview

6
00:00:22.300 --> 00:00:27.020
the Agile foundation certification,
a sample paper.

7
00:00:27.020 --> 00:00:31.940
That's the one that you downloaded from
the website with your course materials.

8
00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:35.145
And, hopefully, the one that you
had a chance to take a look at.

9
00:00:35.145 --> 00:00:39.311
And you've gone through, and
then I'm gonna go through it with you and

10
00:00:39.311 --> 00:00:42.446
see if we can iron out any
questions that you may have.

11
00:00:42.446 --> 00:00:48.112
Now, don't forget, the questions that you
have in the sample paper are based on both

12
00:00:48.112 --> 00:00:53.565
our episodes and also the supplementary
material that you have downloaded.

13
00:00:53.565 --> 00:00:54.965
So all of those course notes,

14
00:00:54.965 --> 00:00:58.280
the additional material that
you have in front of you.

15
00:00:58.280 --> 00:00:59.690
Now, hopefully,

16
00:00:59.690 --> 00:01:05.250
we should be in a position where you'd be
able to pass the exam with flying colors.

17
00:01:05.250 --> 00:01:10.420
Your real exam when you come to take it,
you will need to take,

18
00:01:10.420 --> 00:01:14.710
or you'll need to achieve,
sorry, 28 out of 40,

19
00:01:14.710 --> 00:01:18.400
40 questions,
in order to be able to pass the exam.

20
00:01:18.400 --> 00:01:20.140
It's a multiple choice exam.

21
00:01:20.140 --> 00:01:23.465
It's simple multiple choice
only one right answer, and

22
00:01:23.465 --> 00:01:26.600
you'll need to get 28
out 40 in order to pass.

23
00:01:26.600 --> 00:01:31.620
Now this sample paper that you have, well,
the sample paper's only 20 questions.

24
00:01:31.620 --> 00:01:36.310
And so you only need to get 14 out of
those 20 in order to be able to pass.

25
00:01:36.310 --> 00:01:38.100
So let's see how you did, shall we?

26
00:01:39.700 --> 00:01:40.990
So here we have it then.

27
00:01:40.990 --> 00:01:44.600
As if by magic in front of you,
we've got a sample paper A,

28
00:01:44.600 --> 00:01:46.910
which is the one that you
should have downloaded.

29
00:01:46.910 --> 00:01:50.010
And you will see that it tells you
that it's a specimen paper only.

30
00:01:50.010 --> 00:01:56.570
And it's 20 questions, and the pass mark
is 14 out of 20, as I've already said.

31
00:01:56.570 --> 00:01:58.761
So let's take a look at
these questions then.

32
00:02:00.537 --> 00:02:04.370
So lets start with question number 1.

33
00:02:04.370 --> 00:02:09.360
Why is 7 plus or
minus 2 an optional size of an Agile team?

34
00:02:09.360 --> 00:02:14.090
Well, we know that Agile
teams need to be kept small.

35
00:02:14.090 --> 00:02:18.580
And we know that Agile teams,
if they get too large, well, the stand up

36
00:02:18.580 --> 00:02:22.643
can be quite cumbersome, and could
potentially take longer than 15 minutes.

37
00:02:22.643 --> 00:02:26.880
And we also know that there's
going to be less collaboration

38
00:02:26.880 --> 00:02:28.710
if you've got a larger team.

39
00:02:28.710 --> 00:02:35.160
So the reason why we do that is to ensure
effective communication and collaboration.

40
00:02:35.160 --> 00:02:38.320
It's not about fitting
everybody in to an entire room.

41
00:02:38.320 --> 00:02:43.020
Although, we do like to have people in
the same room where possible.We also

42
00:02:43.020 --> 00:02:48.530
accept that you know common practices,
nowadays, such as remote working and using

43
00:02:48.530 --> 00:02:54.370
tools like Skype and FaceTime, well, they
can help achieve exactly the same results.

44
00:02:54.370 --> 00:02:55.890
And it's not about control.

45
00:02:55.890 --> 00:02:59.555
Because don't forget,
as far as Agile is concerned,

46
00:02:59.555 --> 00:03:02.354
we're really not controlling the team.

47
00:03:02.354 --> 00:03:04.980
The team are empowered
to act on themselves.

48
00:03:06.300 --> 00:03:10.980
So it really is to ensure effective
communication and collaboration.

49
00:03:10.980 --> 00:03:12.360
It's not a hard or fast rule.

50
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:14.360
It's just the case of
that's what we prefer,

51
00:03:14.360 --> 00:03:16.160
and that's why we use the word optimal.

52
00:03:17.200 --> 00:03:21.366
So now on question 2, we're actually
taking a look at the values,

53
00:03:21.366 --> 00:03:22.762
the Agile manifesto.

54
00:03:22.762 --> 00:03:26.031
And one of those values
are producing work and

55
00:03:26.031 --> 00:03:29.940
software over comprehensive documentation.

56
00:03:29.940 --> 00:03:35.560
And the answer to that, you'll find,
way back in one of our opening episodes,

57
00:03:35.560 --> 00:03:39.560
in this particular series, where we
looked at the Agile manifesto, and

58
00:03:39.560 --> 00:03:42.850
we looked at the principles
of Agile as well.

59
00:03:44.370 --> 00:03:50.737
So the Agile manifesto, well, we know that
Agile is a framework, it's a methodology.

60
00:03:50.737 --> 00:03:55.697
And, well, it consists of many
methodologies, including Lean and

61
00:03:55.697 --> 00:04:00.580
Scrum and Kanban and XP, and
we know that we welcome change.

62
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:04.610
Unlike the traditional waterfall approach,
where change is not particularly welcome,

63
00:04:04.610 --> 00:04:08.228
we know that in an Agile approach,
we want to welcome change.

64
00:04:08.228 --> 00:04:12.580
So what does the Agile manifesto say that
we should do with changing requirements?

65
00:04:12.580 --> 00:04:13.950
Well, welcome them.

66
00:04:13.950 --> 00:04:19.530
So it's going to be A or B, but then the
top one says, except in late development.

67
00:04:19.530 --> 00:04:24.600
Well, bearing that some change actually
occurs as a result of testing or

68
00:04:24.600 --> 00:04:29.920
maybe fail-testing,
then that wouldn't make A appropriate.

69
00:04:29.920 --> 00:04:33.620
And when we talk about late development
in Agile iteration, it's between one and

70
00:04:33.620 --> 00:04:34.720
four weeks.

71
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:38.530
So late development really kind
of means that last week, but

72
00:04:38.530 --> 00:04:40.560
we welcome change any time.

73
00:04:40.560 --> 00:04:47.561
So B is the answer to this one, welcoming
changes even in late development.

74
00:04:47.561 --> 00:04:52.560
Our next question, question number 4,
is the role of a ScrumMaster.

75
00:04:52.560 --> 00:04:57.110
Now, we have two roles that
we have identified, well,

76
00:04:57.110 --> 00:04:59.680
I guess three if you count
the Agile team itself, but

77
00:04:59.680 --> 00:05:04.390
we've got two main roles that
we've identified in an Agile team.

78
00:05:04.390 --> 00:05:07.538
And that is the role of the product owner.

79
00:05:07.538 --> 00:05:11.900
And the product owner takes ownership and
accountability for

80
00:05:11.900 --> 00:05:15.630
the functionality and for
the product itself, for the software.

81
00:05:15.630 --> 00:05:17.710
And we also have the role
of the ScrumMaster.

82
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:21.880
And the ScrumMaster's job is
to take accountability for

83
00:05:21.880 --> 00:05:23.960
the smooth running of the team, for

84
00:05:23.960 --> 00:05:28.200
all of those interpersonal issues and
all of the scheduling issues, etc.

85
00:05:28.200 --> 00:05:31.130
So as we said,
the smooth running of the team.

86
00:05:31.130 --> 00:05:37.520
Now I know that my co-host, Cherokee,
in some of our previous episodes,

87
00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:40.940
if you've looked back on those episodes
before you've done this review,

88
00:05:40.940 --> 00:05:46.100
she struggles sometimes with the
responsibilities of the product owner and

89
00:05:46.100 --> 00:05:47.340
the ScrumMaster.

90
00:05:47.340 --> 00:05:50.020
And don't worry, because everybody does.

91
00:05:50.020 --> 00:05:51.820
It can be a very, very fine line.

92
00:05:51.820 --> 00:05:54.760
And you've really go to get your
head around it before you can fully

93
00:05:54.760 --> 00:05:55.850
understand it.

94
00:05:55.850 --> 00:05:57.490
And that might take some doing.

95
00:05:57.490 --> 00:06:00.610
So if you do have any
questions about that then

96
00:06:00.610 --> 00:06:03.920
feel free to drop us
a message in our forum.

97
00:06:03.920 --> 00:06:07.207
And I'll be happy to help you with
any queries that you might have.

98
00:06:07.207 --> 00:06:12.675
So the role of the ScrumMaster
is to remove impediments.

99
00:06:12.675 --> 00:06:14.781
It's not to hold the vision.

100
00:06:14.781 --> 00:06:17.463
The vision is for the entire project, and

101
00:06:17.463 --> 00:06:22.490
the ScrumMaster is the relevant
ScrumMaster for that iteration.

102
00:06:22.490 --> 00:06:25.810
And determining who does the work,
well, that's done by skills, and

103
00:06:25.810 --> 00:06:28.330
that's actually done by the team itself.

104
00:06:28.330 --> 00:06:32.913
And in terms of the skils where the
product owner will help with the skills.

105
00:06:32.913 --> 00:06:37.885
And signing off the work is done, well,
the dumbness, as we call it of work,

106
00:06:37.885 --> 00:06:42.860
would be signed off by the business
relationship manager or the lead business

107
00:06:42.860 --> 00:06:48.316
representative, because, after all,
we're delivering value to the customer.

108
00:06:48.316 --> 00:06:50.733
So let's take a look at number 5, then.

109
00:06:50.733 --> 00:06:53.150
What do you remember
about question number 5?

110
00:06:53.150 --> 00:07:00.136
Again, our three pillars were found in
one of our opening episodes to Agile.

111
00:07:00.136 --> 00:07:04.609
And that was the episode where we
looked at the Agile principles, and

112
00:07:04.609 --> 00:07:07.232
where we looked at the Agile manifesto,

113
00:07:07.232 --> 00:07:11.430
and where we also looked at
the three pillars of Agile.

114
00:07:11.430 --> 00:07:17.838
And those three pillars were inspection,
transparency and adaptation.

115
00:07:17.838 --> 00:07:20.860
So it's all about being transparent
in everything that we do.

116
00:07:20.860 --> 00:07:23.840
So that we can inspect
everything that we do,

117
00:07:23.840 --> 00:07:28.090
and then we can adapt whatever
is not quite working.

118
00:07:28.090 --> 00:07:33.590
And then we're transparent in monitoring
that, and, well, it's a cycle.

119
00:07:33.590 --> 00:07:38.400
Yeah, we're transparent in monitoring
that, and then we inspect and we adapt.

120
00:07:39.450 --> 00:07:42.160
And these are our three pillars of Agile.

121
00:07:42.160 --> 00:07:45.610
Control is not a pillar of Agile,
because, of course,

122
00:07:45.610 --> 00:07:48.620
we let the team control themselves.

123
00:07:48.620 --> 00:07:51.547
Their aim is to deliver
value to the customer.

124
00:07:51.547 --> 00:07:56.553
And so we empower them to be able
to deliver that value in a way

125
00:07:56.553 --> 00:08:02.576
that they deem to be the most efficient,
as well as the most effective.

126
00:08:02.576 --> 00:08:04.235
So let's take a look at number six then.

127
00:08:04.235 --> 00:08:09.064
The number six, well, now that is
a phrase that you'd expect to find

128
00:08:09.064 --> 00:08:13.510
elsewhere in IT methodologies and
frameworks, such as ITIL.

129
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:16.370
We talked about recourse analysis.

130
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:18.240
Well we know in ITIL world,

131
00:08:18.240 --> 00:08:22.550
recourse analysis is something that is
associated with problem management.

132
00:08:22.550 --> 00:08:26.680
Trying to find out why something happened.

133
00:08:26.680 --> 00:08:29.940
Not necessarily just fixing it,
but finding out why it happened.

134
00:08:29.940 --> 00:08:31.742
When would we want to do that?

135
00:08:31.742 --> 00:08:36.480
Well you're going to find the answer to
this actually laid out in the additional

136
00:08:36.480 --> 00:08:41.582
information that you've downloaded
from your series material.

137
00:08:41.582 --> 00:08:44.520
But you're also gonna find
this out with common sense.

138
00:08:44.520 --> 00:08:48.050
When would you try and
find out why something went wrong?

139
00:08:48.050 --> 00:08:52.070
Well, you try and
find out during a retrospective session,

140
00:08:52.070 --> 00:08:54.860
to identify why something went wrong.

141
00:08:54.860 --> 00:08:56.990
You're not going to use it
during a planning stage,

142
00:08:56.990 --> 00:09:01.050
because root cause analysis is about
finding out why something went wrong.

143
00:09:01.050 --> 00:09:04.200
Something shouldn't be going
wrong in a planning stage.

144
00:09:04.200 --> 00:09:07.260
To say it's never used in agile
environments is not true.

145
00:09:07.260 --> 00:09:11.520
And one of the myths that we've really
got to overcome when it comes to

146
00:09:11.520 --> 00:09:16.220
methodologies, is that there is a
disconnect between project management and

147
00:09:16.220 --> 00:09:18.400
service management, because there isn't.

148
00:09:18.400 --> 00:09:22.510
And the two should be working together,
there should be synergy between them.

149
00:09:22.510 --> 00:09:27.030
This is where the term DevOps
originally comes from, it's the synergy

150
00:09:27.030 --> 00:09:32.410
between project management and
our service management environment.

151
00:09:32.410 --> 00:09:37.108
So to say that we would never ever
cross any of these methodologies,

152
00:09:37.108 --> 00:09:39.770
that's completely wrong.

153
00:09:39.770 --> 00:09:42.018
So, where do we use root cause analysis?

154
00:09:42.018 --> 00:09:46.935
What do we try to find out what went wrong
during a demonstration to end users.

155
00:09:46.935 --> 00:09:51.638
Absolutely not, and if you were in that
position where that's what you were doing,

156
00:09:51.638 --> 00:09:55.427
I would really say you're in the wrong
position at that point in time.

157
00:09:55.427 --> 00:09:59.287
And at that point in time, you probably
need to be ending the demonstration.

158
00:09:59.287 --> 00:10:01.467
So yeah,
we don't do it in front of the users.

159
00:10:01.467 --> 00:10:05.867
This is where we look at how things went,
doing the retrospective, and

160
00:10:05.867 --> 00:10:07.577
then we'll do our recourse analysis.

161
00:10:08.967 --> 00:10:13.230
So the three Cs of the user story,
if you remember,

162
00:10:13.230 --> 00:10:19.650
a user story is all about
finding out what the user wants.

163
00:10:19.650 --> 00:10:23.740
And we do that through conversation,
we do that through talking to the users.

164
00:10:23.740 --> 00:10:27.690
And then of course, if you remember,
we write it down on cards.

165
00:10:27.690 --> 00:10:32.630
And of course we confirm with our
users that, well, this is their story,

166
00:10:32.630 --> 00:10:35.130
this is exactly what they want.

167
00:10:35.130 --> 00:10:38.280
Control is not part of the user's story.

168
00:10:38.280 --> 00:10:40.320
We're not trying to control the users.

169
00:10:40.320 --> 00:10:42.680
We're trying to document what they need.

170
00:10:42.680 --> 00:10:46.160
So the question asked of you is, which
one of these is not part of the three Cs.

171
00:10:46.160 --> 00:10:48.670
Well, B is the right answer to that.

172
00:10:50.370 --> 00:10:51.980
So what about refactoring?

173
00:10:51.980 --> 00:10:53.840
What does refactoring do?

174
00:10:55.800 --> 00:10:59.070
Refactoring is just about making
something more efficient.

175
00:10:59.070 --> 00:11:01.800
Making something more effective.

176
00:11:01.800 --> 00:11:06.700
So it really is, it's not about removing
any defect, it's just about making it

177
00:11:06.700 --> 00:11:11.820
work better, which is big,
it's just improving the quality.

178
00:11:11.820 --> 00:11:15.350
We're not gonna alter the behavior,
we're not gonna alter the result.

179
00:11:15.350 --> 00:11:17.740
We're actually just improving the quality.

180
00:11:19.380 --> 00:11:21.650
Now, the next one, number nine.

181
00:11:21.650 --> 00:11:26.540
Number nine looks at this Cone of
Uncertainty that again is found in your

182
00:11:26.540 --> 00:11:30.020
supplementary material,
the material that you've downloaded.

183
00:11:30.020 --> 00:11:34.705
And of course the Cone of Uncertainty You
will see the diagram in there, and

184
00:11:34.705 --> 00:11:39.985
it simply refers to the fact that,
the farther in the distance you are from

185
00:11:39.985 --> 00:11:45.163
your end result, then the more
ambiguous that result should be.

186
00:11:45.163 --> 00:11:49.380
So, the further away
you are from delivery,

187
00:11:49.380 --> 00:11:52.020
the less detailed your plan should be.

188
00:11:52.020 --> 00:11:56.480
And we've talked about this right
the way throughout all of our episodes,

189
00:11:56.480 --> 00:11:59.780
about the fact that we don't
plan the long term in detail.

190
00:12:00.870 --> 00:12:06.030
So the closer that you get to
your specific goal, then the more

191
00:12:06.030 --> 00:12:11.090
detailed your plan should be, and
the more detailed your design should be.

192
00:12:11.090 --> 00:12:17.200
So the further away you are,
then the more ambiguous those designs are,

193
00:12:17.200 --> 00:12:20.890
which is why we call it a cone, because
that's basically what it looks like.

194
00:12:20.890 --> 00:12:25.990
Is that we become more specific
the closer to our end goal.

195
00:12:25.990 --> 00:12:28.070
Which is why A is your right answer.

196
00:12:28.070 --> 00:12:33.250
Your high level, your epic stories, the
big picture, contains limited knowledge.

197
00:12:34.770 --> 00:12:40.580
So we cannot predict
accurately at that high level,

198
00:12:40.580 --> 00:12:43.790
exactly what effort is going to be needed.

199
00:12:43.790 --> 00:12:48.520
But as we get closer to our end goal,
then the closer we get,

200
00:12:48.520 --> 00:12:51.570
the more detailed our
requirements should be.

201
00:12:53.540 --> 00:12:58.040
So number 10,
then Which of these describe Scrum?

202
00:12:58.040 --> 00:13:01.390
Well we know that Scrum is a methodology.

203
00:13:01.390 --> 00:13:05.810
Again we mentioned this right at the very
beginning at one of our earlier episodes.

204
00:13:05.810 --> 00:13:08.130
Scrum is one of
the methodologies of Agile,

205
00:13:08.130 --> 00:13:13.220
and Scrum also gives us
the Scrum master as well.

206
00:13:13.220 --> 00:13:17.000
So it is an Agile framework for
project management.

207
00:13:17.000 --> 00:13:23.800
It is not just about product development,
it's about managing a project.

208
00:13:23.800 --> 00:13:26.810
Some projects don't actually develop,

209
00:13:26.810 --> 00:13:32.320
some projects don't do anything new,
they change what's already there.

210
00:13:33.350 --> 00:13:36.460
So just remember,
this is about project management,

211
00:13:36.460 --> 00:13:38.600
it's an approach to project management.

212
00:13:38.600 --> 00:13:41.630
And it's not just about
product development.

213
00:13:41.630 --> 00:13:46.960
And in fact, we even looked at this in,
it was probably about our fourth episode

214
00:13:46.960 --> 00:13:50.580
in this particular series, where we looked
at the fact that actually the Agile

215
00:13:50.580 --> 00:13:55.000
principle, of doing one thing at a time,
one step at a time.

216
00:13:55.000 --> 00:13:59.710
Can be applied to anything,
not just product development.

217
00:13:59.710 --> 00:14:01.540
So it's about managing
any type of project.

218
00:14:03.530 --> 00:14:07.630
So the MoSCoW prioritization,
if you remember MoSCoW stood for,

219
00:14:07.630 --> 00:14:11.450
must have, should have,
could have, and would like.

220
00:14:11.450 --> 00:14:16.970
And that was something that we utilized
when assessing user priorities.

221
00:14:16.970 --> 00:14:19.490
What is it that the users must have?

222
00:14:19.490 --> 00:14:21.090
What's a typical problem with this?

223
00:14:21.090 --> 00:14:23.265
Well of course,
it's that they want everything, right?

224
00:14:23.265 --> 00:14:27.210
[LAUGH] That they put everything
into the must have category.

225
00:14:27.210 --> 00:14:31.040
And nothing's in the should have, or the
could have, or the won't have right now,

226
00:14:31.040 --> 00:14:34.910
or would like in the future,
everything appears in must have.

227
00:14:34.910 --> 00:14:37.400
And yeah,
that's just one of the typical problems.

228
00:14:37.400 --> 00:14:42.150
And we've gotta balance that out,
as project managers, as scrum masters, or

229
00:14:42.150 --> 00:14:46.940
as even product owners, we've got to
balance that out and ensure that,

230
00:14:46.940 --> 00:14:51.180
the things that appear in the must have
are those things that we must have, and

231
00:14:51.180 --> 00:14:54.780
not the nice to have, which should
appear maybe in the should have, or

232
00:14:54.780 --> 00:14:55.750
even in the could have.

233
00:14:57.240 --> 00:15:00.160
So what about a general benefit of Agile,
then.

234
00:15:00.160 --> 00:15:05.360
Well a general benefit of Agile is that
regular interaction with a customer.

235
00:15:05.360 --> 00:15:09.780
Which means that we should have increased
customer satisfaction, because not only

236
00:15:09.780 --> 00:15:14.880
do they have regular interaction but
they also see regular results.

237
00:15:14.880 --> 00:15:18.760
These are results that
are released on a regular basis,

238
00:15:18.760 --> 00:15:23.240
on an iterative basis,
at the most, every four weeks.

239
00:15:23.240 --> 00:15:28.330
So a benefit is A,
increase customer satisfaction.

240
00:15:28.330 --> 00:15:33.150
It's not about fewer developers,
because we may even need more developers

241
00:15:33.150 --> 00:15:37.900
if we're doing a lot of work,
in that four week period for instance.

242
00:15:37.900 --> 00:15:42.230
Agile won't give you benefit, and with any
framework and it doesn't matter whether

243
00:15:42.230 --> 00:15:45.050
it's an Agile framework or
whether it's a waterfall framework.

244
00:15:45.050 --> 00:15:49.050
If it's managed badly and
if the team don't know their part and

245
00:15:49.050 --> 00:15:53.420
don't understand their responsibilities,
it's not gonna give any benefit at all.

246
00:15:53.420 --> 00:15:56.589
So Agile's not going to
give instant benefit,

247
00:15:56.589 --> 00:15:59.293
it is not something that's automatic.

248
00:15:59.293 --> 00:16:02.943
And whilst we don't like comprehensive
documentation, and we don't like

249
00:16:02.943 --> 00:16:07.610
comprehensive, and elaborate processes,
that doesn't mean that we don't have them.

250
00:16:07.610 --> 00:16:11.370
So to say that we don't do any planning
would be a huge big mistake as well.

251
00:16:11.370 --> 00:16:14.090
Because if you don't plan anything,
then what are you going to get?

252
00:16:14.090 --> 00:16:14.590
Chaos.

253
00:16:16.210 --> 00:16:20.910
So Kanban, we know that Kanban was another

254
00:16:20.910 --> 00:16:24.500
Agile methodology that
looked at the story boards.

255
00:16:24.500 --> 00:16:27.530
And in fact, Kanban means visual board.

256
00:16:27.530 --> 00:16:30.852
So which of these are prescribed
by the Kanban method?

257
00:16:30.852 --> 00:16:36.550
Well, the product owner,
that comes from the Scrum methodology.

258
00:16:36.550 --> 00:16:40.557
The development team,
that's just something that is accepted

259
00:16:40.557 --> 00:16:44.290
within waterfall projects that
we have a development team.

260
00:16:44.290 --> 00:16:47.520
So actually,
neither of those are part of Kanban,

261
00:16:47.520 --> 00:16:52.150
neither of those are specified in Kanban,
remember?

262
00:16:52.150 --> 00:16:53.540
Read the full question.

263
00:16:53.540 --> 00:16:57.530
A lot of that acronym by the way,
have you heard it, RTFQ?

264
00:16:57.530 --> 00:17:01.490
Read the full question, don't you go
adding your own letters into that.

265
00:17:01.490 --> 00:17:06.430
Read the full question,
only answer what's being asked of you.

266
00:17:06.430 --> 00:17:11.320
Don't answer what you think you've read,
answer what you've really read.

267
00:17:11.320 --> 00:17:15.760
Be careful cuz Kanban doesn't exclude

268
00:17:15.760 --> 00:17:20.440
those particular roles, but
Kanban doesn't prescribe those roles.

269
00:17:22.180 --> 00:17:24.980
So number 14 then, daily stand-up.

270
00:17:24.980 --> 00:17:27.252
We know that we should
do that every morning.

271
00:17:27.252 --> 00:17:30.202
The scrum team realizes they
can't complete the stories,

272
00:17:30.202 --> 00:17:32.160
what should they do next?

273
00:17:32.160 --> 00:17:36.700
They simply negotiate with the product
owner cuz he's responsible for

274
00:17:36.700 --> 00:17:39.430
the functionality, and try, and

275
00:17:39.430 --> 00:17:43.520
negotiate the scope of some of
the lowest priority stories.

276
00:17:43.520 --> 00:17:46.660
Can we move them to another iteration?

277
00:17:47.960 --> 00:17:49.370
Simple as that.

278
00:17:49.370 --> 00:17:52.890
If we don't think that we can do it,
we shouldn't be trying it, and

279
00:17:52.890 --> 00:17:54.888
then only delivering half of product.

280
00:17:54.888 --> 00:17:57.870
We should move those,
move them into the backlog, and

281
00:17:57.870 --> 00:17:59.690
move them into another iteration.

282
00:17:59.690 --> 00:18:02.778
And it's the product owner
that takes accountability for

283
00:18:02.778 --> 00:18:04.611
delivering that functionality.

284
00:18:06.147 --> 00:18:10.310
So what advantage does Agile
have over Waterfall projects?

285
00:18:10.310 --> 00:18:14.450
Well, change, we welcome change,
simple as that.

286
00:18:14.450 --> 00:18:18.350
So to say that it doesn't use any
planning, we've already talked about that.

287
00:18:18.350 --> 00:18:22.970
And to say that it can cope with chaos,
no, we still got to have planning.

288
00:18:22.970 --> 00:18:27.699
And about the documentation, no,
we still gotta have some documentation,

289
00:18:27.699 --> 00:18:30.257
just not comprehensive documentation.

290
00:18:30.257 --> 00:18:33.734
So the answer here is, B.

291
00:18:33.734 --> 00:18:38.562
CSI that's in number 16,
is actually a term that

292
00:18:38.562 --> 00:18:43.180
comes from the Agile methodology or
framework.

293
00:18:43.180 --> 00:18:48.500
And in Agile, we refer to CSI as
continual service improvement.

294
00:18:48.500 --> 00:18:51.120
It's the term for ongoing improvement.

295
00:18:53.190 --> 00:18:55.490
So number 17 then,

296
00:18:55.490 --> 00:18:59.820
which of these is not a stage of
Tuckmans model of group development?

297
00:18:59.820 --> 00:19:04.191
Well, this is one that Cherokee mentioned
in one of our previous episodes.

298
00:19:04.191 --> 00:19:09.640
In one of our previous episodes even,
and this is starting,

299
00:19:09.640 --> 00:19:14.790
we have forming, storming, performing,
but we don't have starting.

300
00:19:14.790 --> 00:19:16.840
That's not one of those.

301
00:19:16.840 --> 00:19:19.220
So the answer here is B.

302
00:19:19.220 --> 00:19:22.120
So let's get on to number 18 then.

303
00:19:22.120 --> 00:19:25.670
Number 18, what would be
the response to a Test Manager

304
00:19:25.670 --> 00:19:29.500
who insists that it's gonna take too
much time to test continuously, and

305
00:19:29.500 --> 00:19:32.120
it'll be better to test at
the end of the project?

306
00:19:32.120 --> 00:19:34.520
What advice would you give?

307
00:19:34.520 --> 00:19:37.010
No, you're not going to take
the baseball bat out at him, all right?

308
00:19:37.010 --> 00:19:38.345
That's not an option.

309
00:19:38.345 --> 00:19:40.960
[LAUGH] Yeah,
I know that it might be tempting, and

310
00:19:40.960 --> 00:19:44.920
it might also be tempting to stand there,
and look at him, and go, seriously?

311
00:19:44.920 --> 00:19:47.835
[LAUGH]
>> But that's not the answer either.

312
00:19:47.835 --> 00:19:50.465
For the start off,
we're not going to accept it, are we?

313
00:19:50.465 --> 00:19:51.725
We can't accept it.

314
00:19:51.725 --> 00:19:55.989
It goes against all of our Agile
principles, but it's true,

315
00:19:55.989 --> 00:19:59.106
if you tested the answer,
sorry, B is true.

316
00:19:59.106 --> 00:20:03.554
If you test at the end of the project,
you might have to go back, and

317
00:20:03.554 --> 00:20:06.532
do absolutely everything again.

318
00:20:06.532 --> 00:20:08.780
So we're not gonna test at
the end of the project.

319
00:20:08.780 --> 00:20:12.690
And testing just those important features,
but

320
00:20:12.690 --> 00:20:16.540
it might be one of the small features
that might actually cause that

321
00:20:16.540 --> 00:20:21.040
particular retaliation to fail, and might
actually cause the entire project to fail.

322
00:20:21.040 --> 00:20:24.770
It could set the project back by months,
potentially.

323
00:20:24.770 --> 00:20:27.100
So we're not gonna do that.

324
00:20:27.100 --> 00:20:29.850
As I've said, it goes against
everything that Agile stands for.

325
00:20:29.850 --> 00:20:30.890
We're not gonna do that.

326
00:20:30.890 --> 00:20:34.600
So we're gonna explain to them,
not with the baseball bat mind, but

327
00:20:34.600 --> 00:20:38.350
we're gonna explain to them that
the cost of finding defects is huge.

328
00:20:38.350 --> 00:20:45.470
So we're gonna do the testing on
a continual basis with each iteration.

329
00:20:45.470 --> 00:20:47.580
So let's take a look at number 19 then.

330
00:20:47.580 --> 00:20:54.240
Which of these would not be one of
the Lean Muda, or as we know them, wastes?

331
00:20:54.240 --> 00:20:56.530
We know that Muda is the Japanese word for
waste.

332
00:20:56.530 --> 00:20:58.653
We also mention it Kanban too.

333
00:20:58.653 --> 00:21:02.670
Well, we know that partially
done work is a waste.

334
00:21:02.670 --> 00:21:03.920
Yeah, we know that.

335
00:21:03.920 --> 00:21:06.700
Why did you do it if you can't
be bothered to finish it or

336
00:21:06.700 --> 00:21:09.130
if there's not enough time to finish it?

337
00:21:09.130 --> 00:21:13.130
We know that extra features, features
that are never ever going to be used,

338
00:21:13.130 --> 00:21:14.545
why on Earth are you doing them?

339
00:21:14.545 --> 00:21:17.270
Okay, that is just a waste.

340
00:21:17.270 --> 00:21:22.240
And then relearning or doing something
again, that's just duplication, isn't it?

341
00:21:22.240 --> 00:21:24.170
So that's a waste, of course it is.

342
00:21:24.170 --> 00:21:26.240
So then that brings us to
exploratory testing, and

343
00:21:26.240 --> 00:21:30.340
we know that we've got to test, and
there's never ever a wastage in testing.

344
00:21:30.340 --> 00:21:34.060
So we always want to test, that's never
going to be a waste of your time.

345
00:21:34.060 --> 00:21:37.807
So the answer there has got to be D.

346
00:21:37.807 --> 00:21:41.358
So now, let's go one to number 20,
our last question of this

347
00:21:41.358 --> 00:21:44.310
particular sample paper
>> So what

348
00:21:44.310 --> 00:21:48.880
would be a concern if business users are
not actively engaged with the developers?

349
00:21:48.880 --> 00:21:52.750
Well, if there's no communication there,
then there's a huge concern.

350
00:21:52.750 --> 00:21:55.530
Cuz the developers could
develop what they want, and

351
00:21:55.530 --> 00:21:58.630
the customers are probably not
likely to get what they want.

352
00:21:58.630 --> 00:22:03.740
Remember, we're here to
deliver value to the business,

353
00:22:03.740 --> 00:22:06.530
and to deliver value to the customers.

354
00:22:06.530 --> 00:22:09.190
We're not here to deliver what we want or
do what we wanna do.

355
00:22:09.190 --> 00:22:12.180
We're here to do what's right for
the business.

356
00:22:12.180 --> 00:22:14.900
So what would be a concern?

357
00:22:14.900 --> 00:22:17.450
Well, it could be that we
developed the wrong products.

358
00:22:17.450 --> 00:22:20.520
It could be that the products don't
meet any of the requirements that

359
00:22:20.520 --> 00:22:21.600
the customers have.

360
00:22:21.600 --> 00:22:27.460
And it's certainly going to nurture or
foster an environment of mistrust.

361
00:22:27.460 --> 00:22:31.630
So all of the above is the only
answer that it really could be for

362
00:22:31.630 --> 00:22:33.010
this particular question.

363
00:22:34.550 --> 00:22:35.560
So that's it.

364
00:22:35.560 --> 00:22:38.130
You have completed your sample paper.

365
00:22:38.130 --> 00:22:39.575
How did you do?

366

Did you get 20 out of 20?

367
00:22:41.500 --> 00:22:43.800
Okay, don't worry if you didn't.

368
00:22:43.800 --> 00:22:44.746
It's not a problem.

369
00:22:44.746 --> 00:22:49.705
At this point in time, I'd expect you
to get around about the pass mark.

And if you wanna improve your score,
then go back,

And they're gonna give you
